sentence:
A pair (A,B) of subsets of G is a called a
  separation of order k in G if k = A ∩ B and
  there is no edge of G between A ∖ B and B ∖ A.

sentence:
Let r>2 be an integer. The double wheel of order r (denoted r) is a cycle of length r whose each vertex is adjacent to two different extra vertices, in other words it is the graph of the form
   
   
    G =    {o_1, o_2, w_1,…, w_r}
    G =    {w_1,w_2, w_2,w_3, …, w_r-1, w_r,
         w_r, w_1}
       ∪o_1,w_1, …,
           o_1,w_r
       ∪o_2,w_1, …,
         o_2,w_r

   (see Figure <ref> for an example)

sentence:
[path decomposition, pathwidth]
  A path decomposition of a graph G is a tree
  decomposition T of G such that T is a
  path. Its width is the width of the tree decomposition T
  and the pathwidth of G, written (G), is the minimum
  width of any of its path decompositions.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[minor model]
  A minor model (sometimes abbreviated model ) of a graph
  H in a graph G is a pair ( M,φ) 
  where M is a collection of disjoint subsets
of G such that ∀ X ∈ M, GX
is connected and φH→ M is a
bijection that satisfies ∀{u,v}∈H, ∃ u'
∈φ(u), ∃ v' ∈φ(v), {u',v'}∈G. We say that a graph H is a minor of a graph G
(H  G) if there is a minor model of H in G. Notice that
H is a minor of G if H can be obtained by a subgraph of G
after contracting edges.

sentence:
[linked sets]
Let G be a graph and S ⊆G. The set S is said to be
linked in G if for every two subsets X_1, X_2 of S (not
necessarily disjoint) such that X_1 = X_2, there is
a set Q of X_1 (vertex-)disjoint paths between X_1 and X_2 in G whose
length is not one (but can be null) and whose endpoints only are in S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[left-contains, <cit.>]
  Let H be a graph on r vertices, G a graph and (A,B) a
  separation of order r in G. We say that (A,B)
  left-contains H if GA contains a minor model M of H
  such that ∀ M ∈ M, M ∩ (A ∩ B) = 1

sentence:
[Trees and cycles]
Given a tree T we denote by T the set of its leaves,  vertices of degree 1
and by (T) its diameter, that is the maximum length (in number of edges) of a path
in T.

For every two vertices u,v ∈T,
there is exactly one path in T between u and v, that we denote
by uTv. Also, given that uTv has at least 2
vertices, we denote by uTv
(resp. uTv) the path uTv without vertex
u (resp. v).

Let C be a cycle on which we fixed some orientation.
Then, there is exactly one path following this orientation between any two
vertices u,v ∈C. Similarly, we denote this path by
uCv and we define uCv and
uCv as we did for the tree.

In a rooted tree T 
of root r, the least common ancestor of two vertices u and
v, written T(u,v) is the first common vertex of the paths
uTr and vTr. We refer to the root of T
by the notation (T).

For every integer h>0, we denote by B_h the complete binary tree
of height h.

sentence:
[nice path decompostion, <cit.>]
 A path decomposition p_1 p_2 … p_k, {X_p_i}_i ∈1k of a graph G is said to be nice if
 X_p_1 = 1 and

    ∀ i ∈2k, (X_p_i∖ X_p_i-1) ∪
    (X_p_i-1∖ X_p_i) = 1

It is known <cit.> that every graph have an optimal
path decomposition which is nice and that in such decomposition, every
node X_i is either an introduce node ( either i = 1 or X_i
  ∖ X_i-1 = 1) or a forget node ( X_i-1∖ X_i = 1).

sentence:
[yurt graph of order r]
  Let r>0 be an integer. In this paper, we call yurt graph of order r the graph Y_r of the form
  
    Y_r    = x_1, …, x_r, y_1, …, y_r, o
    Y_r    = (x_i,y_i)_i ∈1r∪(y_i,o)_i ∈1r

(see Figure <ref> for an example.)

sentence: Let t be a positive integer. A permutation π∈ S_n is called t-stack sortable if s^t(π)=123⋯ n. A permutation that  is 1-stack sortable is simply called sortable . Let W_t(n) denote the number of t-stack sortable permutations of length n. Let W_t(n,k) denote the number of t-stack sortable permutations of length n with exactly k descents.

sentence:
Let π∈ S_n. We say that an m-tuple ℋ=(H_1,H_2,…,H_m) is a valid hook configuration of π if H_1,H_2,…,H_m are hooks in the diagram of π that satisfy the following properties. 


  * If _eH_ℓ=(i_ℓ,π_i_ℓ) for each ℓ∈[m], then i_1<i_2<⋯<i_m. 

  * If i is a descent of π, then (i,π_i)=_eH_ℓ for some ℓ∈[m]. 

  * If (j,π_j)=H_ℓ^e for some ℓ∈[m], then there exist ℓ',ℓ”∈[m] such that the x-coordinate of _eH_ℓ' is a descent of π, (j-1,π_j-1)=_eH_ℓ”, and H_ℓ'^e=H_ℓ”^e=(j,π_j). 

  * If ℓ,ℓ'∈ [m], _eH_ℓ=(i,π_i), H_ℓ^e=(j,π_j), _eH_ℓ'=(i',π_i'), H_ℓ'^e=(j',π_j'), π_j≤π_j', and |[i,j]∩[i',j']|>1, then [i,j]⊆[i',j']. 

Let SW(ℋ)={_eH_1,_eH_2,…,_eH_m} and NE(ℋ)={H_1^e,H_2^e,…,H_m^e}. Let ℋ(π) denote the set of valid hook configurations of π.

sentence: For π∈ S_n, let ℋ_{0,2}(π) be the set of valid hook configurations ℋ∈ℋ(π) in which each point in NE(ℋ) is the northeast endpoint of exactly two hooks.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: Let V(π)=φ(ℋ_{0,2}(π)). We say that a composition in V(π) is a valid composition of π .

sentence:
For every integer 1≤ k< n, the characteristic polynomial of ^(k,n) is

    χ(^(k,n),q)=q(q-n)^n-1 .

sentence:
[Cf. <cit.>]
Let =(V,A) be a (finite) directed connected multigraph without loops, where V=[n] for some n∈.
A function [n]→_0 is a -parking function if for every non-empty subset I⊆[n] there exists a vertex i∈ I such that the number of elements j∉ I such that (i,j)∈ A, counted with multiplicity, is greater than or equal to (i).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝕊_1=(𝔽_p^n, +, *) and 𝕊_2=(𝔽_p^n, +, ⋆) be two presemifields. If there exist three bijective linear mapping L, M, N:𝔽_p^n→𝔽_p^n such that
    
    M(x)⋆ N(y)=L(x*y)

    for any x,y∈𝔽_p^n, then 𝕊_1 and 𝕊_2 are called isotopic , and the triple (M,N,L) is an isotopism  between 𝕊_1 and 𝕊_2. Furthermore, if there exists an isotopism of the form (N, N, L) between 𝕊_1 and 𝕊_2, then 𝕊_1 and 𝕊_2 are strongly isotopic .

sentence: Let p be an odd prime. A function f: 𝔽_p^n→𝔽_p^n is called a planar function , or perfect nonlinear (PN) , if for each a∈𝔽_p^n^*, f(x+a)-f(x) is a bijection on 𝔽_p^n.

sentence: A -graph is a graph which at each vertex has a bijection from the outgoing half-edges to the vertices of a cycle graph. Half-edges which are mapped to adjacent vertices are (formally) adjacent . Half-edges are said to be opposite if they are mapped to vertices of maximal distance in the cycle graph.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An angle in a -graph is a pair of adjacent half-edges at a vertex.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A checkerboard embedding of a  -graph Γ into S is an embedding such that the cells of S ∖Γ admit a 2-coloring under which any cells with a common edge have different colors.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A -atom is a closed 2-surface S into which a connected graph Γ (the skeleton of the -atom) is embedded in such a way that it divides S into black and white cells so that cells sharing an edge have different colors.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An Euler circuit C of a -graph Γ is a surjective mapping S^1 →Γ which is one-to-one except at the vertices, and such that every vertex of degree d has d/2 preimages.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given an Euler circuit C of a -graph Γ, a 4-vertex v ∈Γ is rotating with respect to C if for every a ∈ C^-1({v}), C(a+ϵ) and C(a-ϵ) are on adjacent half-edges around v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given an Euler circuit C of a -graph Γ, a 6-vertex v ∈Γ is rotating with respect to C if for every a ∈ C^-1({v}), C(a+ϵ) and C(a-ϵ) are on adjacent half-edges around v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given an Euler circuit C of a -graph Γ, a 6-vertex v ∈Γ is splitting with respect to C if for some a ∈ C^-1({v}), C(a+ϵ) and C(a-ϵ) are on opposite half-edges around v, and for the other two points b, c ∈ C^-1({v}), C(b+ϵ) and C(b-ϵ) are on adjacent half-edges, and C(c+ϵ) and C(c-ϵ) are on adjacent half-edges.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A rotating-splitting circuit is a circuit with respect to which every vertex is rotating or splitting.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A rotating-splitting circuit induces an orientation on the half-edges around a rotating 6-vertex. If the order of the edges containing C(a+ϵ) and C(a-ϵ) agrees with this orientation, then the angle is said be untwisted ; otherwise it is twisted . See Figures <ref>, <ref>, <ref>, <ref>.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: A chord diagram is a cubic graph D with a distinguished Hamiltonian cycle; i.e. an embedding S^1 → D which covers all the vertices of D.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A signed chord diagram is a chord diagram in which each edge not in the distinguished cycle is assigned a positive or negative sign.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A signed -chord diagram is a -chord diagram in which each edge not in the distinguished cycle is assigned a positive or negative sign.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An arc of a -chord diagram Γ is an edge in the distinguished cycle of Γ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A chord of a -chord diagram Γ is an edge not in the distinguished cycle of Γ, connecting two vertices of degree 3 which are in the cycle.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A triad of a -chord diagram Γ is a vertex v not in the distinguished cycle of Γ, together with the three edges incident to v. The vertex v is called a triad point .
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A double chord of a -chord diagram Γ is a pair of edges not in the distinguished cycle of Γ, which are incident to a shared vertex v. The vertex v is called the principal vertex of the double chord.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
An expansion of as signed -chord diagram D_Γ, C a signed chord diagram D'_Γ, C such that


  * For every chord in D,Γ,C containing vertices a and b, there is a chord of the same sign in D'_Γ,C of the same sign connecting vertices a and b.

  * For every triad e in D_Γ,C containing at least one edge with positive sign, for some labeling a,b,c of the vertices of e such that the edge connecting a to the triad point is positive, D'_Γ,C contains a chord connecting a ±ϵ to b and a chord connecting a ∓ϵ to c, with ±ϵ chosen in such a way that the chords are not linked. Furthermore, the chords connecting a to b and a to c in D'_Γ,C have the same signs as the edges connecting the triad point of e to b and c in D_Γ,C, respectively.

  * For every triad e in D_Γ,C in which all edges have negative sign, for some labeling a,b,c of the vertices of e, D'_Γ,C contains a chord connecting a ±ϵ to b and a chord connecting a ∓ϵ to c, with ±ϵ chosen in such a way that the chords are linked. Furthermore, the chords connecting a to b and a to c in D'_Γ,C have signs opposite to the edges connecting the triad point of e to b and c in D_Γ,C, respectively.

  * For every double chord e in D_Γ,C with principal vertex a, for some labeling b, c of the nonprincipal vertices of e, there is a chord in D'_Γ,C connecting a - ϵ to b and a chord in D'_Γ,C connecting a + ϵ to c. These chords are not linked.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A permissible separation of a signed chord diagram D'_Γ, C arising as an expansion of a signed -chord diagram D_Γ, C is a pair of signed chord diagrams D_W and D_B such that


  * Every chord in D'_Γ, C is in exactly one of D_W and D_B.

  * Two chords in D'_Γ, C which come from the same triad in D_Γ, C are both in D_W, or both in D_B.

  * Of any two chords in D'_Γ, C which come from the same double chord in D_Γ, C, one chord is in D_W and the other is in D_B.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a chord diagram D, surgery of D is the following process: For each chord e connecting points a,b, delete a neighborhood of e and connect the obtained endpoints a+ϵ to b-ϵ and a-ϵ to b+ϵ if e is positive, and a+ϵ to b+ϵ and a-ϵ to b-ϵ if e is negative. This produces a family of circles; these are called the result of surgery of D.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: To form the intersection matrix of a signed chord diagram D with n chords, first enumerate the chords 1,…,n. Then the intersection matrix M(D) is an n × n matrix over ℤ_2, such that M_ii=1 if and only if the chord i is negative, and M_ij=M_ji=1 for i ≠ j if and only if the chords i and j are linked.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A permissible partition of the indices of M(D'_Γ, C) is a partition of the indices of M(D'_Γ, C) (which are just the chords of D'_Γ, C) into two parts, in such a way that chords arising from the same triad in D_Γ, C are in the same part, and chords arising from the same double chord in D_Γ, C are in different parts.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that an instance of a combinatorial optimization problem has the 
constant objective value property (COVP) if every feasible solution has 
the same objective value.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(ℓ-Forcing Fort).

A set of vertices T ⊂ V in the graph G is an (ℓ-forcing) fort (or just fort, if the context is clear), if there are subsets of vertices S, L ⊂ V such that when S is initially colored and the vertices L have leaks, the set of uncolored vertices after iteratively applying the color-change rule as much as possible is precisely T.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A partition σ of n contains a partition τ of k if there exists a subpartition σ' of σ that has the same relative order as τ.  Otherwise, σ avoids τ.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A layered partition is a partition whose blocks consist of sets of consecutive integers.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A complete partite undirected graph on n vertices is a graph whose complement is the union of vertex-disjoint complete graphs.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A directed acyclic complete partite graph (DACP) is a directed acyclic graph whose underlying undirected graph is a complete partite graph.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a set partition τ of [n], let the permeability pm(τ) be the minimum k such that [n] can be partitioned into k+1 intervals (i.e. sets of consecutive integers) and each of these intervals has at most one element from each block of τ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let A={A_1,A_2,…,A_m} be a bimodal collection of disjoint subsets of an abelian group G.  Suppose that A_i is a coset of H_i for some i.  Let A_i^1,A_i^2, …, A_i^r be disjoint subsets partitioning A_i, having internal difference groups H_i^1,H_i^2, …, H_i^r respectively, and which possess the property that for j=1,2,…, r the set A_i^j is a coset of H_i^j.  Then the collection A^'={A_1,A_2,…,A_i-1,A_i^1,A_i^2,…,A_i^r ,A_i+1,…,A_m} satisfies the bimodal property.  We shall refer to A^' as a subdivision of A.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: Let G be a finite group.  If G has subgroups S_1,S_2,…, S_m with the property that S_1^*,S_2^*,… , S_m^* partition G^*, then the collection of subgroups S_1,S_2,…, S_m is called a group partition of G.  A group partition is called trivial if m=1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: A bimodal collection A={A_1,A_2,…,A_m} of disjoint subsets of an abelian group G with r__ A≥ 2 will be said to be in canonical position if it has been shifted so that D__ A is  a subgroup of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A bimodal collection A={A_1,A_2,…,A_m} of disjoint subsets of an abelian group G with r__ A=1 will be said to be in canonical position if it has been shifted so that A_1 ⊆ H_1 and the subgroup D=H_2+H_3+…+H_m is contained in H_1 ∖ A_1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(Tadao Oda <cit.>)
Every smooth fan in dimension three, with at most eight rays, can, up to isomorphism, be created by finitely many successive equivariant blowing-ups of one of the 19 fans with labels 3^4, (3^24^3)', (3^24^3)”, 4^6, 3^24^36^2, 3^14^35^3, 4^55^2, 4^66^2, 3^24^47^2, 3^34^15^16^3, 3^24^25^26^2, 3^14^45^16^2, 3^24^15^46^1, (3^14^35^36^1)', (3^14^35^36^1)”, (3^25^6)', (3^25^6)”, (4^45^4)' and (4^45^4)” and weights as given in Convex Bodies and Algebraic Geometry .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[A'Campo <cit.>]

A divide is the image of an immersion of a finite number of intervals and circles into D such that: 
(i) there is no triple point, 
(ii) there is no self-tangency, 
(iii) all intersections are transverse, 
(iv) both endpoints of every immersed segment lie on ∂ D and the endpoints of all segments are distinct, 
(v) immersed circles do not intersect ∂ D. 

We denote by  the family of all isotopy classes of connected divides.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(See Figure <ref>.) Assume that P is a divide whose complement in D is colored in black and white. 
Then the fiber surface Σ(P) is the surface that consists of those vectors in  that are based at points of P 
and are directed into a black region or are tangent to P, plus all vectors based at all double points of P. 

We denote by  the family of all isotopy classes of fiber surfaces of connected divides.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that (the isotopy class of) a surface Σ embedded in ^3 is a surface minor of (the isotopy class of ) 
another surface Σ' if Σ is isotopic to an incompressible subsurface of Σ'. 
We then write ΣΣ'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that a connected divide P' is a subdivide of P, if P' can be obtained from P by several desingularizations and isotopies. 
We then write P' P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A discal graph is a graph embedded into D such that the edges intersect ∂ D in vertices only, and whose vertices are 
colored as follows: 
the vertices lying in the interior of D are black, those lying on ∂ D are white. 
If there is exactly one vertex on ∂ D, we can also draw a star instead of coloring in white. 

We denote by  the family of all isotopy classes of discal graphs.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Assume that P is a connected divide. 
Then the code of P is the discal graph G(P) obtained by taking one vertex in every black region of D∖ P 
and by putting at every double point of P an edge that connects the two vertices 
associated with the two adjacent black regions.  
If P does not intersect ∂ D at all, and if the region of D∖ P touching ∂ D is black, 
then we put only one vertex on ∂ D, and color it with a star.
For p a double point of P, the corresponding edge is denoted by e(p).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For G, G' two discal graphs, we say that G is a discal minor of G' if G can be obtained from G' by  repeatedly choosing one edge e and replacing G by G-e or by G/e, if allowed. We then write G G'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Assume that G and H are embedded colored graphs and that  is an ordered set. 
We say that H is a planar minor of G, written H_ G, 
if H can be obtained from G by repeatedly applying the following operations:

(i) decreasing the color of a vertex,

(ii) deleting an edge, 

(iii) contracting an edge whose ends have the same color,

(iv) deleting an isolated vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(See Figure <ref>.) 
Let G be an embedded colored graph. 
A Tutte-Mazoit tree for G is an abstract binary tree T_G, such that every node v is labelled with (a) a disc D(v) in the plane whose boundary ∂ D(v) intersects G in some vertices only, and (b) the planar decoration G(v)^* of the restriction G(v) of G to D(v), and such that

(i) for every leaf v of T_G, the graph G(v) is 3-connected,

(ii) for every internal node v with sons v_1, v_2, the disc D(v) is the union of D(v_1) and D(v_2),

(iii) denoting by r(T_G) the root of T_G, the graph G(r(T_G)) equals the whole graph G (or, equivalently, the disc D(r(T_G)) contains all of G).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For Σ an oriented surface in ^3, the signature of Σ is the signature of any symmetrized Seifert matrix S+^tS.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Orthogonality equation, radius equation(s), characteristic equation(s), weight]
Consider the matrix S= (s_ij) comprising  the variables x_1, x_2, ⋯ x_τ.

The matrix orthogonality equation 

    S^⊤S = SS^⊤ = ω I_n
 
yields two types of equations: the n equations which arise from taking the inner product of each row/column with itself (which leads to the diagonal elements of ω I_n being ω) are called radius equation(s) , g(x_1, x_2, ⋯ x_τ)=ω, and the n^2 -n equations, f(x_1, x_2, ⋯ x_τ)=0, which arise from taking inner products of distinct rows of S (which leads to the zero off diagonal elements of ω I_n  are called characteristic equation(s) . Cretan matrices must satisfy the three equations: the orthogonality equation (<ref>), the radius equation and the characteristic equation(s).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G, G_1, and G_2 be graphs.  Let k ≥ 1 be a positive integer.  The graph G is a k-edge sum of G_1 and G_2 if the following holds.  There exist vertices v_i ∈ V(G_i) such that (v_i) = k for i = 1, 2 and a bijection π: δ(v_1) →δ(v_2) such that G is obtained from (G_1 - v_1) ∪ (G_2 - v_2) by adding an edge from x ∈ V(G_1) - v_1 to y∈ V(G_2) - v_2 for every pair e_1, e_2 of edges such that e_1 ∈δ(v_1), e_2=π(e_1), the ends of e_1 are x and v_1, and the ends of e_2 are y and v_2.

We will also refer to a k-edge sum as an edge sum of order k.  The edge sum is grounded if  there exist vertices v_1' and v_2' in G_1 and G_2, respectively, such that for i = 1, 2, v_i' ≠ v_i and there exist k edge-disjoint paths linking v_i and v_i'.  If G can be obtained by a k-edge sum of G_1 and G_2, we write G = G_1 ⊕̂_k G_2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A tree-cut decomposition of a graph G is a pair (T, ) such that T is a tree and = {X_t ⊆ V(G): t ∈ V(T)} is a near-partition of the vertices of G indexed by the vertices of T.  For each edge e = uv in T, T-uv has exactly two components, namely T_v and T_u containing v and u respectively.  The adhesion of the decomposition is 

    max_uv ∈ E(T) | δ ( ⋃_t ∈ V(T_v) X_t ) |

when T has at least one edge, and 0 otherwise.  
The sets {X_t: t ∈ V(T)} are called the bags of the decomposition.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: A sum-`n+2' transform always results in a better sequence.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A sum-`n+1' transform always results in a better sequence.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
For a sequence C⃗={c_k,1≤ k≤ n},  if the following two conditions do not hold,
         
          
  * c_k<c_n+2-k , for all 2≤ k≤ u ;
          
          
  * c_k>c_n+2-k , for all 2≤ k≤ u .
        then do (k,n+2-k)-interchange for each  k  satisfying  c_k<c_n+2-k,2≤ k≤ u  until all  c_k>c_n+2-k,2≤ k≤ u. This is called the  sum-`n+2' transform of  C⃗.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: For sequence  C⃗={c_k,1≤ k≤ n}, do  (k,n+1-k)-interchange for each  k  satisfying  c_k>c_n+1-k, 2≤ k≤ u^'  until all  c_k<c_n+1-k,2≤ k≤ u^'. where  u^'=⌊ n/2⌋, ⌊ ⌋  denotes the floor function. This is called the  sum-`n+1' transform of  C⃗.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
[Compare <cit.>] A finitary semimatroid is a
  triple =(S,,) consisting of a (possibly infinite) set
  S, a non-empty finite dimensional simplicial complex  on S and a bounded function :→ satisfying the following conditions.

  
  (R1) If X∈, then 0≤(X)≤ |X|.
  
  (R2) If X,Y∈ and X Y, then (X)≤(Y).
  
  (R3) If X,Y∈ and X∪ Y∈, then (X)+(Y)≥(X∪ Y)+(X∩ Y).
  
  (CR1) If X,Y∈ and (X)=(X∩ Y), then X∪ Y∈.
  
  (CR2) If X,Y∈ and (X)<(Y), then X∪ y∈ for some y∈ Y-X.


If only (R1), (R2), (R3) are known to hold, we call  a locally ranked triple. 

A finite semimatroid is a finitary semimatroid with a finite ground set. Finiteness of locally ranked triples is defined accordingly.

Here, and in the following, we often write  instead of  and omit braces when representing singleton sets, thus writing (x) for ({x}) and X∪ x for X∪{x}, when no confusion can occur.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A finitary semimatroid =(S,,) is simple if 
(x)=1 for all x∈ S and  (x,y)=2 for all {x,y}∈ with x≠ y.


A loop of a locally ranked triple =(S,,) is any s∈
S with (s)=0. Two elements s,t∈ S that are not loops are called parallel if {s,t}∈ and ({s,t})= 1. The triple  is called simple if it has no loops and no parallel elements.
 An isthmus of  is any s∈ S such that, for every  X∈, X∪ s ∈ and (X∪ s)=(X)+1.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[See Theorem 2.1 in <cit.>]
 
 A (chain-finite) ranked meet-semilattice  
 
 is called a finitary geometric semilattice if it satisfies the following conditions.


  
  (G3) There is N∈ℕ such that every (maximal) interval in ℒ is a (finite) geometric lattice with at most N atoms.
  
  (G4) For every independent set A of atoms of  and every x∈ such that (x)<(∨ A), there is a∈ A with a≰ x and such that x∨ a exists.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.>
Let A be an quiver algebra with acyclic quiver T_A.
The algebra A ≅T̨_A/I is called gentle
if the bound quiver (T_A, I) has the following properties:

  * Each point of T_A is the source and the target of at most two arrows.

  * For each arrow α∈ (T_A)_1,
    there is at most one arrow β and one arrow γ
    such that αβ∉I and γα∉I.

  * For each arrow α∈ (T_A)_1,
    there is at most one arrow ξ and one arrow ζ
    such that αξ∈I and ζα∈I.

  * The ideal I is generated by the paths in 3^∘.
If T_A is a tree,
the gentle algebra A ≅T̨_A/I is called
a gentle tree algebra
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM

sentence:
A gentle tree is a quiver T with a 2-coloring,
such that each vertex has at most one arrow of each color incoming or outgoing.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A graded gentle tree G
is a gentle tree with a positive grading for each arrow.
The associated quiver G of G,
is a graded quiver with the same vertex set and
an arrow a:i → j for each unicolored path p:i → j in G,
with the grading of p.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a graded gentle tree G,
let V be a vertex with neighborhood

    @C=1.5pc@R=1.5pcR_1 [dr]^γ_1      B_2 @< [dl]_δ_2
        V    
    B_1 @ [ur]^δ_1      R_2 @<-[ul]_γ_2

where B_i, R_i are the sub trees
and γ_i, δ_i are degrees, i=1,2.
The straight line represent one color
and the curly line represent the other color.
Define the forward mutation μ_V at vertex V (on G) as follows:


  * if δ_1 ≥ 1,
    μ_V on the lower part of of the quiver is:
        
    @C=1.8pc@R=1.8pc    V    
    B_1 @ >[ur]^δ_1      R_2 @<-[ul]_γ_2
    @C=0.8pc@R=0.8pc         
    @=>@/^1pc/[rrr]^μ_i         @C=1.8pc@R=1.8pc    V    
    B_1 @ >[ur]^δ_1-1      R_2 @<-[ul]_γ_2+1


  * if δ_1 = 1, denote
    
    @C=0.8pc@R=1.5pc
    B_1    @=[r]       @C=1.5pc@R=1.5pcE_1 [dr]^θ_1      
        W    
    L_1 @ >[ur]^β_1      E_2 @<-[ul]_θ_2

    and μ_V on the lower part of of the quiver is:
    
    @C=1.5pc@R=1.5pcE_1 [dr]^θ_1        V @< [dl]_1 [dr]^γ_2   
        W       R_2 
    L_1 @ >[ur]^β      E_2 @<-[ul]_θ_2
    @C=0.8pc@R=0.8pc      
    @=>@/^.7pc/[rr]^μ_i      @C=1.5pc@R=1.5pc    V @< [dl]_β[dr]^1       E_2^×@< [dl]_θ_2
    L_1        W    
       E_1^×@ >[ur]^θ_1      R_2 @<-[ul]_γ_2

    where X^× is the operation of swapping colors
    on a graded gentle trees X.

  * μ_V on the upper part follows the mirror rule of the lower part. 


Dually, define the backward mutation μ_V^-1 to be the reverse of μ_V
(which follows a similar rule).

sentence:
Let C be a permutation class, and let π be an element of C. We say that
π is unavoidable in C , if C has no irredundant splitting that
contains (π) as a part. We let C denote the set of all
the unavoidable permutations in C.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let π be a permutation of order n. The envelope of π is a
directed lattice path P_π with these properties (see
Fig. <ref>):

 
  * P_π connects the point (0,n) to the point (n,0),

  * every step of P_π is either a down-step connecting a point
(i,j) to a point (i,j-1), or a right-step connecting (i,j) with
(i+1,j), and

  * for every i∈ [n], the path P_π contains the right step
(i-1,j)→(i,j) where j=min{π(1),…,π(i)}-1.

sentence:
Let M be a matching with n arcs, and let I be an open interval on the
real line. The tangling of M in I is an operation which produces
a matching N with n+1 arcs, defined as follows. First, we reorder the
endpoints of M belonging I in such a way that all the left endpoints
in I appear to the left of all the right endpoints, while the relative
position of the left endpoints as well as the relative position of the right
endpoints remains the same. Next, we create a new short arc α 
whose endpoints belong to I, and which is nested below all the other arcs
that have at least one endpoint in I. Let N
be the resulting matching.

sentence:
A Schröder-type path from p to q, for points p,q∈×, is a
  sequence P=(p_0,p_1,…,p_k) with k∈, p_i∈× for
  0≤ i≤ k, p_0=p, p_k=q, and
  p_i+1-p_i∈{0+1,-1+1,-10} for 0≤ i<k. The
  support of P is (P)={p_0,p_1,…,p_k}.

sentence:
If π∈_n is a permutation of [n]={0,1,…,n-1}, then we
  shall call “π-family” any n-tuple (P_0,P_1,…,P_n-1) where
  P_i is a Schröder-type path form i0 to 0π_i for
  i∈[n]. If π is the identity permutation of [n] we shall call a
  π-family simply an “n-family”. A π-family is called
  disjoint if (P_0), (P_1), … and (P_n-1)
  are all disjoint.

sentence: An edge xy∈ E(G) is called tight if w(xy)=r-1.  A complete subgraph in G, all of whose edges are tight, is called a tight clique , and a maximal tight clique is called a cluster .

sentence:
For G ∈(m,r) with a cluster T and e(B) ≥ e(R), we define a new graph G_T ∈(m,r) by converting T∪ S_T into a complete subgraph (of size r+1) and deleting all the edges in B_T. In other words, we define the folding of G at T by
	
    G_T = G + S_T2 - E(B_T).

	A graph G is a bipartite threshold graph if and only if G is bipartite and the neighborhoods of vertices in one of the partite sets are linearly ordered by inclusion.

sentence: Let A_S be an exterior structure on a network N with stem base u and stem tip v. Then C(N,A_S) is the network constructed by removing A_S from N, and then inserting a placeholder leaf a_S along a new edge {u,a_S}. This is the cut procedure .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let A_S be an exterior structure with stem tip v. Let l be a leaf on network N and u the vertex of N adjacent to l. Then I(N, l, A_S) is constructed by removing l, adding A_S, and replacing the edge {u,l} with the edge {u,v}. This is the insertion procedure .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let N be a network with at least one exterior structure, and let A_1, …, A_k be an ordered list of subgraphs of exterior structures with stem tips v_1, …, v_k. Then C(N | A_1, …, A_k) is a cut sequence defined by recursively cutting the exterior structures. Let Z_0=N Z_i=C(Z_i-1,v_i) for 1 ≤ i ≤ k. Then the resulting network Z_k is C(N | A_1, …, A_k) which does not have any A_i as a subgraph.

sentence:
Sequential Voting Procedure

For a network N, let x be the leaf to be attached by a single leaf attachment. Let 𝒬(x) be the set of quartets whose support includes x. An attachment M is allowed on N by q, if the network constructed by that attachment displays q. The optimal attachment is the attachment that is allowed by all q∈𝒬(x).

sentence: Let A_1, …, A_k be exterior structures with stem tips v_1, …, v_k, and let Z be a network with at least 4 leaves. Then I(Z | A_1, …, A_k) is an insertion sequence defined by recursively inserting the exterior structures. We let N_0=Z, and N_i=I(N_i-1,v_i,A_i) for 1 ≤ i ≤ k. The resulting network N_k is I(Z | A_1, …, A_k).

sentence: For a network N with leaf set X, let H(𝒬(N)) be the incompatibility graph with vertex set V=X. Define an edge between leaves a and b if there exists single or double reticulation quarnet q∈𝒬(N) such that {a,b}⊂ supp(q) and there is a non-trivial cut edge on the path between a and b on q (see Figure <ref>).

sentence:
For g∈ F[t] and h∈ R,
  
    f = g ∘ h = g(h) ∈ R

  is their composition .  If g ≥ 2 and h ≥
  1, then (g,h) is a decomposition of f. A polynomial f
  ∈ R is decomposable if there exist such g and h.
  Otherwise f is indecomposable . The decomposition (g,h) is
  normal if h is monic and original. It is superlinear if h
≥ 2.

sentence:
Let us recall that the outer face of a
plane graph G  is the unique unbounded face;
all other faces of G are called internal . 
We  denote the set of internal faces of G by (G).

If f is a face of  a 2-connected plane graph G, then we let |f| denote the length of the cycle bounding f.
Likewise, if C is a cycle in G, then we denote its length by |C|.
If G' is a subgraph of G and  f∈(G'), then
 we denote by G[f] the subgraph of G consisting of all vertices and edges
drawn in the closure of f.
If G is a 2-connected plane graph with outer cycle C, then we define

    def(G):=|C|-3 - ∑_f∈(G) (|f|-3).

sentence:
Let E be a binary code of length n. We will  define

    (E) = __2{ d(E), ℓ(1^n) }
 to be the code
generated by d(E) and ℓ(1^n). We call the binary code (E) of length 2n the
extended doubling (or simply the doubling ) of E.

sentence:
(<cit.>)
A simple VOA V is said to be framed if there exists a set {e^1,
…,e^n} of mutually orthogonal Ising vectors of V such that their sum
e^1+ +e^n is equal to the conformal element of V.   The subVOA  T_n
generated by e^1,…,e^n is thus isomorphic to
  L(,0)^⊗ n and  is called
  a Virasoro frame or simply  a frame of V.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
A simplicial complex Δ on vertex set V
is called vertex decomposable if


  * Δ is a simplex, or

  * there is some vertex v ∈ V such that Δ∖ v and 
link_Δ(v) are vertex 
decomposable and do not share any facets; such a vertex v is called a 
shedding vertex of Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex on the vertex set V
 with facets F_1, …, F_t.  An s-coloring of Δ  is a
partition of the vertices  V = V_1∪…∪ V_s
(where the sets V_i are allowed to be empty) such that  |F_i ∩ V_j| ≤ 1
for all
1 ≤ i ≤ t, 1 ≤ j ≤ s.
We will sometimes write that χ is an s-coloring of Δ
to mean χ is a specific partition of V that gives an s-coloring of Δ.
If there exists an s-coloring of Δ, we say that
Δ is s-colorable .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex on the vertex set
V and let W ⊆ V.  The restriction of Δ to W
(or equivalently, the induced subcomplex over W ) is the
subcomplex

    Δ |_W = {σ∈Δ | σ⊆ W}.

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex on the vertex set V and let
W ⊆ V.  If χ is an s-coloring of the restriction Δ|_W,
then we call χ a partial coloring of Δ.  We call the vertices
in W the colored vertices of Δ and those in W = V∖ W the
non-colored vertices .

sentence:
Two permutations p and q of {1, 2, …, n  } have the same form if for each i = 0, 1, …, n-1, p_i < p_i+1 if and only if q_i < q_i+1.  For a binary word u of length n-1, say that p has form u if 

    p_i<p_i+1⟺ u_i = 0

for each i = 0, 1, …, n-2.

sentence: Let p = π[a,a+n] be a subpermutation of the infinite permutation π.  The left restriction of p, denoted by L(p), is the subpermutation of p so that L(p) = π[a, a+n-1].  The right restriction of p, denoted by R(p), is the subpermutation of p so that R(p) = π[a+1, a+n].  The middle restriction of p, denoted by M(p), is the subpermutation of p so that M(p) = R(L(p)) = L(R(p)) = π[a+1, a+n-1].

sentence:
A subpermutation p = π_T[a,a+n] is of type k, for k ≥ 1, if p can be decomposed as

    p = [α_1 ⋯α_k λ_1 ⋯λ_l β_1 ⋯β_k]

where α_i = β_i + ε for each i = 1, 2, …, k and an ε∈{ -1, 1 }.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that the subpermutation p = π_T[a,a+n] is of type k so that for ε∈{-1, 1 }, α_i = β_i + ε for each i = 1, 2, …, k.  If there exists a subpermutation q = π_T[b,b+n] of type k so that p and q can be decomposed as:

    p    = π_T[a,a+n] = [α_1 ⋯α_k λ_1 ⋯λ_l β_1 ⋯β_k] 
     
    q    = π_T[b,b+n] = [β_1 ⋯β_k λ_1 ⋯λ_l α_1 ⋯α_k]

then p and q are said to be a complementary pair of type k.  If p and q are a complementary pair of type k ≤ 0 then p = q.

Let E be a linearly ordered set. Let G=(V,E) be a graph with set of edges E.

We call filtration of G (or of E) a 
sequence (F'_, …, F'_0, F_c , F_0, …, F_) of subsets of E such that:

  * ∅= F'_⊂...⊂ F'_0=F_c=F_0⊂...⊂ F_= E;

  * the sequence min(F_k∖ F_k-1), 1≤ k≤  is increasing with k;

  * the sequence  min(F'_k-1∖ F'_k), 1≤ k≤, is increasing with k.

sentence:
A filtration (F'_, …, F'_0, F_c , F_0, …, F_) of G is called connected if, in addition:















=0mm


  * for every 1≤ k≤, the minor G(F_k)/F_k-1 is either loopless and 2-connected with at least two edges, or a single isthmus; 


  * for every 1≤ k≤, the minor G(F'_k-1)/F'_k is either  loopless and 2-connected  with at least two edges, or a single loop.

sentence:
Let =(V,E) be a directed graph, on a linearly ordered set of edges, 
which is bipolar 
with respect to the minimal element p of E. The fully optimal spanning tree α() of  is the unique spanning tree T of G such that:



for all b∈ T∖{p}, the directions (or the signs) of b and min(C^*(T;b)) are opposite in C^*(T;b);




for all e∈ E T, the directions (or the signs) of e and min(C(T;e)) are opposite in C(T;e).

sentence:
Let  be a directed graph on a linearly ordered set of edges.
The active spanning tree α() is defined by extending the definition of α from (cyclic-)bipolar (Definitions <ref> to <ref>) to general ordered digraphs by the two following characteristic properties:


(1) α()=α(/ F) ⊎ α((F))
where F is the union of all directed cycles of  whose smallest element is the greatest active element of .  


(2) α()=α(/ F) ⊎ α((F))
where F is the complementary of the union of all directed cocycles of  whose smallest element is the greatest dual-active element of .

sentence:
Let G be a 
graph on a linearly ordered set of edges E.
Let T be a spanning tree of G.

The 

active filtration of T in G
is the unique connected filtration of G associated to T in the decomposition given by Theorem <ref>. 
It is thus the unique filtration  ∅= F'_⊂...⊂ F'_0=F_c=F_0⊂...⊂ F_= E of G such that:



=0mm =0mm =0mm =0mm

  * for  1≤ k≤, T∩ (F_k F_k-1) is an internal  uniactive spanning tree of G(F_k)/F_k-1,

  * for  1≤ k≤, T∩ (F'_k-1 F_k) is an external  uniactive spanning tree of G(F'_k-1)/F'_k

(such a filtration is necessarily connected, otherwise one of the induced minors has no spanning tree with the required property, see Lemma <ref>).

The active partition of T in G is the partition of E formed by successive differences of subsets in the active filtration 

(yielding parts whose smallest elements are the internally/externally active elements of T).

sentence: An arc diagram is decomposable if  a vertical line swept from the first vertex of the diagram to the last encounters at least once no intersection with any arc   strictly  between the first and the last vertices.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Given a positive integer r, define an r-coloured partition of [n] to be a pair (P, ϕ) consisting of a set partition P of [n] and a map ϕ : (P) → [r] where (P) is the set of arcs of P in the arc annotated diagram.

 Let Λ be an r-coloured partition of [n]; define (Λ) = { (i,j,t) : (i,j) ∈(P), t= ϕ (i,j)}. Note that a P can have many different Λ's, and this set, with n, uniquely determines Λ.

Let F be a relevant collection. F is said to be a Konig Egervary collection (KE collection in short), if the following equality
 holds: 
    |⋃ F|+|⋂ F|=2α.

sentence:
An hereditary Konig Egervary collection (hke collection in short) is a collection of sets, F, such that for some positive integer, α, the equality

    |⋃Γ|+|⋂Γ|=2α
 holds for every non-empty sub-collection, Γ, of F. We call this α, α(F). We may omit F, where it is clear from the context.

sentence:
Assume that F is a connected k-nilpotent Lie group with filtration 𝒱 and Γ is a co-compact subgroup of F. Assume that M is the left coset space of Γ in F. Then a map h:ℤ^d→ℂ is called a d-dimensional polynomial nilsequence (corresponding to M) if there is a polynomial map ϕ:ℤ^d→ F of degree k and a continuous Lipschitz function g:M→ℂ such that h is the composition of ϕ, the projection F→ M and g. 
The complexity of such a nilsequence is measured by the maximum of c and the complexity of M.

For any polynomial P ∈[x_-1, x_0, x_1, x_2, …], the upshift of P is the polynomial 
    Q = P|_x_i ← x_i+1 ∀ i∈[x_0, x_1, x_2, …].

If P does not depend on x_-1, then the downshift is defined analogously: 
    R = P|_x_i ← x_i-1 ∀ i∈[x_0, x_1, …].

  * The map μ is such that for every e∈^-

  *   if e'∈μ(e), then every cycle containing e' contains t(e),

  *  if e≠ e', then μ(e)∩μ(e')=∅. 

 

We say   a P-graph if there is an edge partition (,μ) such that  for every e∈^-,

sentence:
Let  be a 3-uniform hypergraph. 
A function h V() × E() → [0,1] is called a fractional ()-tiling of  if


  * h(v,e) ≠ 0 ⇒ v ∈ e,

  *  h(v) = ∑_e ∈ E()h(v,e) ≤ 1,

  *  for every e ∈ E() there exists a labeling of the vertices of e = uvw such that 
    h(u,e) = h(v,e) ≥ h(w,e) ≥2/3 h(u,e)


By h_min we denote the smallest non-zero value of h(v,e) (and we set h_min=∞ if h≡ 0) and
 the sum over all values is the weight w(h) of h
  
    w(h) = ∑_(v,e) ∈ V() × E() h(v,e) .

sentence:
Let G be an abelian group, let n≥ 1, let X⊆ G be a finite, nonempty subset, let L≤𝖧(X), let S∈(G) be a sequence, and let S'| S be a subsequence with 𝗁(ϕ_L(S'))≤ n≤ |S'|. Suppose |S'|≤ 2n. Then one of the following holds: 

  1. n=2, |S'|=|S|=|(ϕ_L(S))|, (ϕ_L(S))=α+K/L for some K≤ G and α∈ G with L≤ K and  K/L≅ (/2)^2,   X∖ (β+L) is K-periodic (or empty) for some β∈ X,  and  X+Σ_n(S)=X+(K∖ L)+2α with |X+Σ_n(S)|=|X|+2|L|=(|S|-n)|L|+|X|.
    
  2. There exists an equitable setpartition 𝒜=A_1… A_n  with 𝖲(𝒜)| S,  |𝖲(𝒜)|=|S'|, |ϕ_L(A_i)|=|A_i| for all i∈ [1,n], and |X+Σ_n(S)|≥ |X+i=1nA_i|≥ (|S'|-n)|L|+|X|.

  3. There exists an equitable setpartition 𝒜=A_1… A_n  with 𝖲(𝒜)| S,  |𝖲(𝒜)|=|S'| and |ϕ_L(A_i)|=|A_i| for all i∈ [1,n], a subgroup K≤ H=𝖧(X+Σ_n(S)) with L<K proper, and α∈ G such that 

  (a) X+Σ_n(S)=X+i=1nA_i,

  (b)  (𝖲(𝒜)^[-1] S)⊆α+K=⋂_i=1^n(A_i+K) and  |A_i∖ (α+K)|≤ 1 for all i,

  (c) |X+Σ_n(S)|≥ |X+H|+|S_G∖ (α+H)|·|H| and
 |X+Σ_n(S)|≥ |X+K|+|S_G∖ (α+K)|·|K|,

  (d) L+i∈ I_KA_i=α |I_K|+K, where I_K⊆ [1,n] is the nonempty subset of all i∈ [1,n] with A_i⊆α+K.

f) and (Y, g), denoted by

f(x)- g(h(x)) where h varies in the set
H(X,Y) of all the homeomorphisms between X and Y, if X and
Y are homeomorphic;

  (ii) +∞, if X and Y are
not homeomorphic.

sentence:
Bottleneck (or matching ) distance .

 Let 𝒟_k and 𝒟'_k be two persistence diagrams with a finite number of cornerpoints, the bottleneck distance d(𝒟_k,𝒟'_k) is defined as

    d(𝒟_k,𝒟'_k)=min_σmax_P∈𝒟_kd̂(P,σ(P))

where σ varies among all the bijections between 𝒟_k and 𝒟'_k and

    d̂((u,v),(u',v'))=min{max{|u-u'|,|v-v'|},max{v-u/2,v'-u'/2}}

given (u,v)∈𝒟_k and (u',v')∈𝒟'_k.

sentence:
A tropical plane curve of degree d is a piecewise linear,
weighted graph Γ in ^2 satisfying:


  * 
all edges e of Γ have weights (e) ∈_≥ 1,

  * 
all edges have rational slopes,

  * 
the total weight of the edges of Γ in each of the
  directions -10, 0-1, and 11
  equals d, and Γ has no other unbounded edges,

  * 
 all vertices v of Γ are balanced , i.e.,



    ∑_edges e
    
    v ∈ e
    
    (e) ·(e, v) = 0,




where (e, v) is the primitive vector of the edge
e at the vertex v, i.e., the shortest non-zero integral vector in
the ray spanned by e.

  v.

sentence:
Given an index set J, a k-complex H with vertex set X partitioned into {X_j}_j∈ J and a k-graph  with vertex set V partitioned into {V_j}_j∈ J, the standard construction is as follows. 
Let ' be an X-partite k-graph with vertex sets {V'_x}_x∈ X where for each x∈ X, the set V'_x is a copy of the set V_j such that x∈ X_j, and where for each set f⊂ V(H) and each edge e∈ V'_f we define
 
    g'(e):= 1    if f∉H ,
     g(e')    if f∈ H ,

 where e' is the natural projection of e to V().

sentence:
[Typically hereditary counting (THC)]
 Given k≥ 1, a vertex set J endowed with a linear order, and a density k-graph  on J, we say the J-partite k-graph  is an (η,c^*)-THC graph if the following two properties hold.
 
  
  *  For each J-partite k-complex R with at most 4 vertices in each part and at most c^* vertices in total, we have
   
    (R)=(1± v(R)η)(∅)p(∅)(R) .

  
  *  If |J|≥ 2 and x is the first vertex of J, there is a set V_x'⊂ V_x with V_x'≥(1-η)V_x such that for each v∈ V_x' the graph _v is an (η,c^*)-THC graph on J∖{x} with density graph _x.

sentence:
[Regularity of hypergraphs]
Given k≥ 1 and nonnegative real numbers , d, let  and  be k-partite hypergraphs on the same vertex parts. Suppose that for each e with |e|<k we have g(e)=(e), and suppose that for each e with |e|=k we have g(e)≤(e). Then we say that  is (,d)-regular with respect to  if

    (k1⃗^k)   =(d±)(k1⃗^k)    and      (k2⃗^k)   ≤(d^2^k+)(k2⃗^k) .

We say that  is -regular with respect to  to mean that the corresponding (, d)-regularity statement holds with d= (k1⃗^k)/(k1⃗^k).

sentence:
[Stack of candidate graphs, update rule]
 Let k≥ 2, and suppose that a k-complex H, a partial embedding ϕ of H, and disjoint vertex sets V_x for each x∈ V(F) which is unembedded (that is, x∉ϕ) are given. Suppose that for each 0≤ℓ≤ k and each e⊂ V(H)∖ϕ we are given a subgraph ^(ℓ)(e) of V_e. We write ^(ℓ) for the union of the ^(ℓ)(e); that is, the graph with parts {V_x}_x∈ V(H)∖ϕ whose weight function is equal to that of ^(ℓ)(e) on V_e for each e⊂ V(H)∖ϕ. If ^(0)≥^(1)≥…≥^(k) then we call the collection of k+1 graphs a stack of candidate graphs , and ^(ℓ) is the level ℓ candidate graph .
 
 Given x∈ V(H)∖ϕ and v∈ V_x, we form a stack of candidate graphs corresponding to the partial embedding ϕ∪{x↦ v} according to the following update rule . For each 0≤ℓ≤ k, we let ^(ℓ)_x↦ v:=^(ℓ)_v be the link graph of v in ^(ℓ). Note that trivially since ^(ℓ)≤^(ℓ-1) we have ^(ℓ)_x↦ v≤^(ℓ-1)_x↦ v for each 1≤ℓ≤ k, so that this indeed gives a stack of candidate graphs.

plain_text_term: stack of candidate graphs;level ℓ candidate graph;update rule

sentence:
[Ensemble of parameters, valid ensemble]
 Given integers k, c^*, h^*, and Δ, an ensemble of parameters is a collection δ_1,…,δ_k of minimum relative densities , η_0,…,η_k of counting accuracy parameters , and (_ℓ,r,h)_ℓ,r∈[k], h∈{0,…,h^*} of regularity parameters . For each ℓ∈[k] we define the best-case regularity _ℓ:=min_r∈[k],h∈{0,…,h^*}_ℓ,r,h and the worst-case regularity '_ℓ:=max_r∈[k],h∈{0,…,h^*}_ℓ,r,h.
 
 An ensemble of parameters is valid if the following statements all hold for each 1≤ℓ≤ k.
 
  
  * 
  η_0≪δ_1,…,δ_ℓ, η_ℓ, k, c^* and for all ℓ'∈[ℓ] we have '_ℓ'≪δ_ℓ',…,δ_ℓ, η_ℓ,  k, c^*, Δ such that the following hold: 
  
    η_0    ≤η_ℓ/72(k+1)c^*∏_0<ℓ”≤ℓδ_ℓ”^c^* ,
      
    
    _ℓ''    ≤η_ℓδ_ℓ'/72k(k+1)Δ^2∏_ℓ'<ℓ”≤ℓδ_ℓ”^c^* .

  
  *  For each r∈[k] and 0≤ h≤ h^*-1, we have _ℓ,r,h≪_ℓ,r,h+1, δ_ℓ small enough for Lemma <ref> (inheritance and link regularity) with input δ_ℓ and _ℓ,r,h+1. In particular _ℓ,r,h increases with h.
  
  *  For each r∈[k-1] we have _ℓ,r+1,h^*≤_ℓ,r,0.
  
  *  The counting accuracy (4k+1)η_ℓ-1 is good enough for each application of Lemma <ref> as above. 
  That is, with inputs δ_ℓ and _ℓ,r,h for 1≤ h≤ h^* we have (4k+1)η_ℓ-1 small enough to apply Lemma <ref>.

sentence:
[Good partial embedding]
 Given k≥ 2, a k-complex H of maximum degree Δ, integers c^*, h^*, and for each 0≤ℓ≤ k a density k-graph  on V(H), let δ_1,…,δ_k, η_0,…,η_k, and (_ℓ,r,h)_ℓ,r∈[k],h∈[h^*] be a valid ensemble of parameters. 
 Given 1≤ℓ≤ k, we say that a partial embedding ϕ of H together with a stack of candidate graphs ^(0),…,^(ℓ) is an ℓ-good partial embedding (ℓ-GPE) if
 
  
  * 
   The graph  is an (η_0,c^*)-THC graph with density graph _ϕ.
  
  * 
  For each 1≤ℓ'≤ℓ and ∅≠ e⊂ V(H)∖ϕ, the graph ^(ℓ')(e) is (,d)-regular with respect to ^(ℓ'-1)(e), where
  
    =_ℓ',|e|,π_ϕ(e)   and    d=d^(ℓ')_ϕ(e)=∏_f⊂ V(H),
    e⊂ f, f∖ e⊂ϕd^(ℓ')(f) .

  
  * 
  The parameters δ_1,…,δ_ℓ are `global' lower bounds on the relative density terms in the sense that for each 1≤ℓ'≤ℓ and ∅≠ e⊂ V(H)∖ϕ, we have
  
    δ_ℓ'≤∏_f⊂ V(H),
     e⊂ fd(f) .

 
 When we have a k-good partial embedding, we will usually simply say good partial embedding (GPE).

sentence:
Let  be a k-partite k-graph and η≥0. Then we say that  is η-minimal if, for every i∈ [k] and for every a⃗,b⃗,c⃗∈{0,1,2}^k which satisfy a⃗_j=b⃗_j=c⃗_j for all j∈ [k]∖{i} and a⃗_i=0, b⃗_i=1, c⃗_i=2, we have

    (kc⃗) ≤ 
    (1+η)(kb⃗)^2/(k-1a⃗) .

sentence: Let T be a maximal m-rigid object of _m (A_n) and  be the corresponding graph in _n,m. We say that T is connected if the full subgraph of  with set of vertices given by the non-isolated vertices in  is connected.

sentence:
A word w is rich if it has exactly |w| + 1 distinct palindromic factors. An infinite word is rich if its
    every factor is rich.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let w be a finite or infinite word. The privileged complexity function which counts the number of distinct
    privileged factors of length n in w is defined as
    
    _n(w) = |_n(w)|

    for all n ≥ 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An infinite word w is Sturmian if _n(w) = n+1 for all n ≥ 0.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Q-property of words is defined to satisfy the following conditions:
    
      
  - Q(ε) and Q(a) hold for all letters a ∈ A,
      
  - for every position i in every word there exists a factor with property Q ending at position i,
      
  - every position in every word introduces at most one factor with property Q.
    
    Factors with property Q are called Q-factors .
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The Q-complexity function of a word w is defined as
    
    ^Q_n(w) = |{u ∈_n(w) : Q(u) }|.

    For a finite word w we define ^Q(w) = |{u ∈(w) : Q(u)}|.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If ^Q_n(w) = 0 for some integer n, then we say that n is a vanishing index of w .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
An infinite word w over alphabet A (|A| ≥ 2) is episturmian if w has the property _n(w) and has
    at most one right special factor of length n for all n ≥ 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Episturmian word w is A-strict if for each n ≥ 0 there exists a unique right special factor u of
    length n and ua ∈(w) for all a ∈ A.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An even-tempered game is an integer or a pair {G^L|G^R} where {G^L} and {G^R} are finite nonempty sets
of odd-tempered games.[We are using the standard notational abbreviations of combinatorial game theory, where
G^L and G^R are variables ranging over the left and right options of a game G.  We will use this kind of abbreviation later
in Definitions <ref> and <ref> to save space.]  An odd-tempered game is a pair {G^L|G^R} where {G^L} and {G^R} are finite nonempty
sets of even-tempered games.  A well-tempered game is an even-tempered game or an odd-tempered game.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The left outcome and right outcome of G, denoted (G) and (G), respectively, are recursively defined as follows:

    (G) = 
    G     if G is an integer
    max_G^L(G^L)  otherwise


    (G) = 
    G     if G is an integer
    min_G^R(G^R)  otherwise

Here max_G^L(G^L) denotes the maximum value of (G^L) as G^L ranges over the left options of G, and similarly
min_G^R(G^R) is the minimum as G^R ranges over the right options of G.

We define the outcome of G to be the pair ((G),(G)).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
The left final outcome of G, denoted (G), is (G) when G is odd and (G) when G is even.  Similarly,
the right final outcome of G, denoted (G), is (G) when G is odd and (G) when G is even.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a well-tempered scoring game.  A subgame of G is G or a subgame of an option of G.
If S is a set of numbers, we say that G takes values in S or is S-valued if every subgame of G
that is an integer is an element of S.  We denote the class of S-valued well-tempered scoring games 𝒲_S.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: subgame of G;takes values in S;S-valued

sentence:
Let S_1, S_2 ⊆ f, and let f : S_1 × S_2 →ℤ be a function.  Then let the extension of f to games be the
function f̃ : 𝒲_S_1×𝒲_S_2→𝒲_ℤ defined recursively by

    f̃(G_1,G_2) =
    
    f(G_1,G_2)     if G_1 and G_2 are integers
    {f̃(G_1^L,G_2),f̃(G_1,G_2^L) | f̃(G_1^R,G_2), f̃(G_1,G_2^R)}    otherwise
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: the extension of f to games

sentence:
Let f : S_1 ×⋯× S_n →ℤ be a function.  Then we say that f is order-preserving if

    f(x_1',…,x_n') ≥ f(x_1,…,x_n)

whenever x_i' ≥ x_i for all i.
If f is order-preserving, we call the extension to games f̃ a generalized disjunctive operation .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let G be a well-tempered game.  For i = 0,1, let _i(G) be the supremum
of (H) - (H) as H ranges over the subgames of G with π(H) = i.
We call _0(G) the even gap of G and _1(G) the odd gap of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
If G is a game and t is an integer, then ∫^t G ( G heated by t ) is the game defined inductively by

    ∫^t G = 
    G     if  G ∈ℤ
    {t + ∫^t G^L | -t + ∫^t G^R }    otherwise
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G, H be games.  We say that G and H are equivalent , denoted G ≈ H, if (G + X) = (H + X)
and (G + X) = (H + X) for every game X.  Similarly, we say that G ≳ H if (G + X) ≥(H + X)
and (G + X) ≥(H + X) for every game X.  We define G ≲ H  H ≳ G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If G, H are games, we let G ≈_+ H if π(G) = π(H) and (G + X) = (H + X) for every X.  Similarly,
we let G ≳_+ H if π(G) = π(H) and (G + X) ≥(H + X) for every H.  Define G ≲_+ H if H ≳_+ G.

Define ≈_-, ≲_-, and ≳_- analogously, using (G + X) and (H +X) instead of (G + X) and (H + X).
We call ≈_+ and ≈_- left-equivalence and right-equivalence , respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
If G is a well-tempered game, we let G^+ and G^- be the games of the previous theorem.  These are defined only up to equivalence.
We call G^+ the upside of G and G^- the downside of G, by analogy with the theory of loopy games.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a game.  The even projection of G , denoted (G), is G if G is even-tempered, and G + * otherwise.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a well-tempered scoring game.  Then we say that a left option G^L is reversible if there is some right option G^LR
of G^L with G^LR≲ G.  We say that a right option G^R is reversible if there is some left option G^RL of G^R
with G^RL≳ G.  We say that a left option G^L is dominated if some other left option G^L' satisfies
G^L'≳ G^L, and we say that a right option G^R is dominated if some other right option G^R' satisfies
G^R'≲ G^R.  If G ∈ℐ, we say that G is canonical if it has no reversible or dominated options, and the
same is true for all subgames.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a Boolean-valued well-tempered game.  Then we define u^+(G) and u^-(G) to be the unique elements of S such that

    ψ^±(G) = ∫_1^1/2 u^±(G)

if G is even, and

    ψ^±(G) = * + ∫_1^1/2 u^±(G)

if G is odd.
If u^+(G) = u^-(G), we denote the common value by u(G).  We call u^+(G) and u^-(G) the u-values of the game G .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: the u-values of the game G

sentence:
Cauchy-Schwarz inequality(from <cit.>, Theorem 3.14)Let f,g∈ℱ^σ, then

    f^2_σ· g^2_σ≥ fg_σ^2.

In particular (g=1_σ),

    f^2_σ·σ≥ f_σ^2,

which in turn implies

    f^2_σ≥ 0.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A finite, connected, biregular, bipartite
graph with valencies q_1+1 and q_2+1 is called Ramanujan bigraph if

    |λ^2-q_1-q_2| ≤ 2 √(q_1q_2),
 for every λ∈{±λ_2,±λ_3,…,±λ_n_1}, where the notation is as in (<ref>).
In particular, this means λ_n_1>0.

 We call X a weak Ramanujan bigraph if λ_n_1>0, in other words if (X) has the eigenvalue 0 with multiplicity exactly n_2-n_1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Zeta function of a finite, connected, biregular,
bipartite graph X with valencies q_1+1 and q_2+1 is said to satisfy the
Riemann Hypothesis if the  non-trivial zeros   of Z_X(u)^-1 satisfy the following property: 
 
    if (s)∈ (0,1) and Z_X((q_1q_2)^-s)^-1=0,  then
    (s)=1/2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[characterization of m-error-correcting  P-codes] 
An (n,2^n-m) code 𝒞 is an m-error-correcting P-code
if and only if the following two conditions hold:

a) ℐ_P^m contains exactly one ideal I;

b) there is a function f:2^P\ I→ 2^I
such that 𝒞={Y∪ f(Y) | Y∈ 2^P\ I}, i. e.,
the code 𝒞 is systematical with
information symbols P\ I and
check symbols I.

Every m-error-correcting P-code is an m-perfect P-code.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: An element w∈ W is cyclically fully commutative  if every cyclic shift of any expression in R(w) is a reduced expression for a fully commutative element (which can be different from w).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let c be an r-coloring of [ℕ]^2 ([n]^2). A
  path decomposition for c is a collection of r paths
  P_0, P_1,…, P_r-1 such that P_j is a path of color j and
  every integer (less than n) appears on exactly one path.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A collection 𝒰 of subsets of ℕ is an
  ultrafilter (on ℕ) if and only if
  ∅∉𝒰, 𝒰 is closed under
  superset, 𝒰 is closed under intersection, and, for all
  X ⊆ℕ, either X ∈𝒰 or its
  complement X∈𝒰. An ultrafilter is
  non-principal if and only if, for all a ∈ℕ,
  {a}∉𝒰.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An infinite set C is cohesive with respect to the
    sequence of sets {X_n}_n∈ℕ if and only if for
    every n either C ⊆^* X_n or
    C⊆^* X_n.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose P̃_b is a BLUE path and P̃_r a RED path.
  Then the pair (P̃_b, P̃_r) is a one-step path
    extension of (P_b,P_r) if exactly one of the following holds:
  
  
  * P̃_b is P_b with one additional element at the end
    and P̃_r = P_r, or
  
  * P̃_r is P_r with one additional element at the end
    and P̃_b = P_b, or
  
  * P̃_b is the path P_b with the last element x_b
    removed and P̃_r is P_r with x_b and some integer x
    added in that order at the end, (in this case x_b
    switches to RED), or
  
  * P̃_r is the path P_r with the last element x_r
    removed and P̃_b is P_b with x_r and some integer x
    added in that order at the end, (in this case x_r
    switches to BLUE).
  
 
  
  
  
  
  (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a path extension of
  (P_b, P_r) if it can be obtained from (P_b,P_r) by a sequence of
  one-step path extensions.  Also, if (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a
  path extension of (P_b, P_r), P̃_r=P_r, and x is
  the last element of P̃_b, then we say that
  (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a BLUE path extension of
    (P_b, P_r) to x .  We similarly define a RED path
    extension of (P_b, P_r) to x .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a one-step path extension of
  (P_b,P_r) obtained by Case (3) (i.e. x_b switches to RED and is
  followed by x on P̃_r.)  We say that x_b strongly
    switches to RED if there is no BLUE path extension to x.  We
  similarly define what it means for x_r to strongly switch
  to BLUE.
  
  We say (P̃_b,P̃_r) forms a strong one-step
    path extension of (P_b,P_r) if the pair
  (P̃_b,P̃_r) is a one-step path extension of
  (P_b, P_r) via either Cases (1) or (2), or via Cases (3) or (4)
  with a strong switch.
  
  We say that (P̃_b,P̃_r) forms a strong path
    extension of (P_b,P_r) if it can be obtained from (P_b,P_r)
  by a sequence of strong one-step path extensions.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a coloring c, we will say that we can always strongly
    RED switch if for every pair (P_b, P_r) of disjoint finite BLUE
  and RED paths, there is a strong path extension
  (P̃_b, P̃_r) of (P_b, P_r) such that there was
  a strong RED switch at some point during the path extension between
  (P_b, P_r) and (P̃_b, P̃_r).

  We define being able to always strongly BLUE switch
  similarly.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Consider a AWT (r,ℓ,ω) with ω is the minimum member in set W_i, we call r be subject into leaf ℓ, denoted by r⇀ℓ and, we call weight ω Minimal Vassal Cost , abbr. MVC . Meanwhile we also denote MVC by ω_r⋉ℓ, on the other hand we use the term ω_r^⋉ to represent a pure quantity of MVC not to shoot any specific leaf.

sentence: Following the definition(<ref>), consider ∃ω_r⋉ℓ∈ W_r and ∃ω_ℓ⋉ r∈ W_ℓ on instance, we denote them by r⇌ℓ or ℓ⇌ r. And say such abreast relation refers to a beam structure .

sentence:
[<cit.>] 
Let ||=3. Then (c,d) has a solution if and only if the cut
condition cut_cond holds and
  
  
    Δ_c,d(m):=c(m)-d(m)≥ 0

  
holds for all (2,3)-metrics m on V (the (2,3)-metric condition ).
Furthermore, if (c,d) is Eulerian and the problem (c,d) has a
solution, then it has an integer solution.

sentence: Let S be a set of polynomials in the polynomial ring ℚ[α_1,…α_r] and let σ be a permutation of {α_1,…, α_r}. Then S is simply reducible with respect to σ if for all i ∈{1,…,r-1}, all polynomials in S_(σ(1),…,σ(i)) are linear in σ(i+1). If there exists a permutation σ of {α_1,…,α_r} such that S is simply reducible with respect to σ, then we say that S is simply reducible. If for some graph G, the set S ⊆{ψ_G, ϕ_G} is simply reducible, then we will say G is simply reducible with respect to S .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: simply reducible with respect to σ

sentence: Let S be a set of polynomials in the polynomial ring ℚ[α_1,…,α_r].  Let σ be a permutation of {α_1,…,α_r}. We say S is compatibility graph reducible with respect to σ if for all 1 ≤ i ≤ r-1, all polynomials in the set S_[σ(1),…,σ(i)] are linear in σ(i+1). If there exists a permutation σ such that S is compatibility graph reducible with respect to σ, we say that S is compatibility graph reducible . Given a graph G, and S ⊆{ψ_G,ϕ_G}, if S is compatibility graph reducible, then we say G is compatibility graph reducible with respect to S.

sentence:
Let G be a graph with associated external momenta, masses, and Schwinger parameters. Let 𝒯 be the set of spanning trees of G. Then the first Symanzik polynomial of G is 
 
 
    ψ_G = ∑_T ∈𝒯∏_e ∉E(T)α_e.

sentence:
Let G be a graph with associated external momenta, masses, and Schwinger parameters.  Let 𝒯 be the set of spanning 2-forests of G. Then the second Symanzik polynomial is 
 
 
    ϕ_G = ∑_(T_1,T_2) ∈𝒯 (ρ^T_1)^2∏_e ∉T_1∪ T_2α_e + ψ_G∑_i =1^|E(G)|α_im_i^2.

sentence: Let G be a graph let v ∈ V(G). The momentum ρ_v is on-shell if ρ_v^2 =m^2, where m is the mass of the external edge corresponding to ρ_v. For the purposes of this thesis, we will always assume m^2=0, so a momentum vector ρ_v is on-shell if ρ_v^2=0.

sentence: Let S be a set of polynomials in the polynomial ring ℚ[α_1,…α_r] and let σ be a permutation of {α_1,…, α_r}. Then S is simply reducible with respect to σ if for all i ∈{1,…,r-1}, all polynomials in S_(σ(1),…,σ(i)) are linear in σ(i+1). If there exists a permutation σ of {α_1,…,α_r} such that S is simply reducible with respect to σ, then we say that S is simply reducible. sentence: Let S be a set of polynomials in the polynomial ring ℚ[α_1,…,α_r].  Let σ be a permutation of {α_1,…,α_r}. sentence: Let G be a graph with m edges. The width of an ordering e_1, e_2,…, e_m of E(G) is the maximum order of a separation of the form ({e_1,…,e_l},{e_l+1,...,e_m}) for l ∈{1,…,m}. To be consistent with the given definition of separation, here we are viewing {e_1, …,e_l} as a set of vertices induced by the edges e_1,…, e_l. The vertex width of G is the minimum width among all edge orders of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let S be a set of polynomials in ℚ[α_1,…,α_n]. Let C be the complete graph on |S| vertices. If there exists a permutation σ of {α_1,…,α_n} such that (S_(σ(1),…,σ(i)),C_(σ(1),…,σ(i))) exist and are linear in σ(i+1) for all i ∈{1,…,n-1}, then we will say S is reducible with respect to Panzer's method .

sentence: Let G be a graph and e_1,…,e_|E(G)| an ordering of the edges of G. This ordering induces a sequence of graphs of G, ∅⊊ G_1⊊ G_2⊊…⊊ G_|E(G)| = G such that G_i differs from G_i+1 by edge e_i+1. Similarly, the ordering induces a sequence of graphs of G, G = G^1⊋ G^2⊋…⊋∅ where G^i differs from G^i+1 by exactly one edge for all i ∈{1,…,|E(G)|-1}. Define A_i = V(G_i) ∩ V(G^i+1). The graph G is k-constructable if for all A_i, we have that |A_i| = k.

 ℚ[α_1,…,α_r]. We will denote the set of reducible orders , O_S, to be the permutations σ of {α_1,…,α_r} such that S is reducible with respect to σ.

sentence: Let G be a 2-connected graph and X = {a,b,c,d}⊆ V(G). Let n be any positive integer. Let ((A_1,B_1), …,(A_n,B_n)) be a 2-dissection. If A_i∩  B_i∩  A_i+1∩ B_i+1≠∅  for all i ∈{1,…, n-1}, then we will say the 2-dissection is a 2-chain. Let ((A_1,B_1),…,(A_n,B_n)) be a 2-chain. Suppose both A_1∩ B_1 and A_n∩ B_n contain at least one vertex of X, and there is exactly one vertex of X in A_1∖ (A_1∩ B_1), and exactly one vertex of X in B_n∖ (A_n∩ B_n). Then we say ((A_1,B_1),…, (A_n,B_n)) is a terminal separating 2-chain .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let G be a 2-connected graph and X = {a,b,c,d}⊆ V(G). Suppose there are three distinct 2-separations (A_1,B_1),(A_2,B_2),(A_3,B_3). We say these separations form a triangle if A_1∩ B_1 = {x,y}, A_2∩ B_2 = {x,v} and A_3∩ B_3 = {v,y} for distinct vertices x,y,v ∈ V(G). For notational convenience, we will enforce that in a triangle, (A_i∖ (A_i∩ B_i)) ∩ (A_j∖ (A_j∩ B_j)) = ∅ for any i,j ∈{1,2,3}, i ≠ j.  We say a triangle (A_1,B_1),(A_2,B_2),(A_3,B_3), is terminal separating if exactly two vertices of X are contained in A_1, exactly one vertex of X is contained in A_2∖ (A_2∩ B_2) and exactly one vertex of X is contained in A_3∖ (A_3∩ B_3). Two triangles  ((A^1_1,B^1_1), (A^1_2,B^1_2), (A^1_3,B^1_3)), ((A^2_1,B^2_1),(A^2_2,B^2_2),(A^2_3,B^2_3)), are distinct if there exists an i ∈{1,2,3}, such that for A^2_i, A^1_j∩ B^1_j⊆ A^2_i for all j ∈{1,2,3} and there exists an i ∈{1,2,3} such that for  A^1_i, A^2_j∩ B^2_j⊆ A^1_i for all j ∈{1,2,3}.
