sentence:
[Metsch <cit.>]
Let μ, λ^(1), λ^(2) and m be positive integers. Assume that X is a connected graph with the following properties.


  * Every pair of adjacent vertices has at least λ^(1) and at most λ^(2) common neighbors.

  * Every pair of non-adjacent vertices has at most μ common neighbors.

  *   2λ^(1)-λ^(2)>(2m-1)(μ-1)-1.

  * Every vertex has fewer than (m+1)(λ^(1)+1)-1/2m(m+1)(μ-1) neighbors.


Define a line to be a maximal clique C satisfying |C|≥λ^(1)+2-(m-1)(μ-1). Then every vertex is on at most m lines, and every pair of adjacent vertices lies in a unique line.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Babai <cit.>]
A pair of vertices u and v is distinguished by a vertex x in a graph X if the distances (x,u) and (x,v) in X are distinct.

sentence:
In any graph define D(u,v) to be the number of vertices that distinguish u and v. Define the minimal distinguishing number D_min(X) of the graph X to be 

    D_min(X) = min_u≠ v∈ V D(u, v).

sentence: A distance-regular graph X of diameter d is called primitive if for each i∈ [d] the distance-i graph X_i of X is connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let d≥ 2 and Ω be a set of m≥ 2d+1 points. The Johnson graph J(m,d) is a graph on a set V(J(m,d)) = Ωd of n = md vertices, for which two vertices are adjacent if and only if the corresponding subsets U_1, U_2⊆Ω differ by exactly one element, i.e., |U_1∖ U_2| = |U_2∖ U_1| = 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Ω be a set of m≥ 2 points. The Hamming graph H(d, m) is a graph on a set V(H(d, m)) = Ω^d of n = m^d vertices, for which a pair of vertices is adjacent if and only if the corresponding d-tuples v_1, v_2 differ in precisely one position. In other words, if the Hamming distance d_H(v_1, v_2) for the corresponding tuples equals 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A distance-regular graph X is called geometric if there exists a collection 𝒞 of Delsarte cliques such that every edge of X lies in precisely one clique from 𝒞.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that a graph X contains a clique geometry , if there exists a collection 𝒞_0 of maximal cliques, such that every edge is contained in precisely one clique from 𝒞_0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A distance-regular graph X of diameter d is called antipodal if being at distance d in X is an equivalence relation, namely if X_d is a disjoint union of cliques.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph X is called a cocktail-party graph if it is obtained from a regular complete bipartite graph by deleting one perfect matching.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given G∈[x,y]\ and K∈[s,t]\,
a polynomial F∈[x,y,s,t] is (G,K)-Cartesian if it can be written as


    F(x,y,s,t) = G(x,y)H(x,y,s,t)+ K(s,t)L(x,y,s,t),

with H,L∈[x,y,s,t];
F is Cartesian if there are non-constant G,K such that F is (G,K)-Cartesian.

Let X be a variety in ^4 and let I(X) be its defining ideal.
Then X is Cartesian if there are G∈[x,y]\, K∈[s,t]\ such that every F∈ I(X) is (G,K)-Cartesian.
Note that a reducible variety is Cartesian if  one of its components is Cartesian, since the ideal of a union of varieties is the intersection of the ideals of the components.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph F is r-critical if χ(F) = r+1 but F contains an edge e such that χ(F-e) = r.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F be an r-critical graph.
We say that F is pair-free if there do not exist
two  (different, but not necessarily disjoint)
edges u_1v_1, u_2v_2 and  
a proper r-coloring χ of F-u_1v_1-u_2v_2
such that χ(u_1)=χ(u_2)=χ(v_1)=χ(v_2).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be a poset with ground set {x_1,…,x_n}. The
Kimble split of P is the poset on the ground set
{x_1',x_1”,…,x_n',x_n”} with x_i'≤ x_j” if and only
if x_i≤ x_j in P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For non-empty subsets L,R of a group G, we define the two-sided 
Cayley graph sc(G;L,R) as the (directed) graph with vertex
set G with an arc from x to y if and only if y=ℓ^-1xr for 
some ℓ∈ L and r∈ R. The connection set of sc(G;L,R) 
is defined as the set Ŝ(L,R)={λ_ℓ,r: (ℓ,r)∈ L× R}.

sentence:
Let Δ>1 be an integer. A set 𝒞 of points in
   is called weakly Δ-divisible if there exists
  u∈ℤ with
  (𝒞∩ H)≡ uΔ for each hyperplane
  H of . If u≡𝒞Δ, we
  call 𝒞 (strongly) Δ-divisible .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let X be a subspace of _q^v and t≥ 2 an integer.  A
  t-sunflower in _q^v with center X is a set
  {Y_1,…,Y_t} of subspaces of _q^v satisfying Y_i≠ X
  and Y_i∩ Y_j=X for i≠ j. The point sets Y_i∖ X_i
  are called petals of the sunflower.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Let X, Y be complementary subspaces of _q^v
  with (X)=s, (Y)=t (hence v=s+t)
  and ℬ a set of points in (Y). The cone with
  vertex X and 
  base ℬ is the point set
  𝒞=⋃_P∈ℬ(X+P).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
In a forest T on n vertices, a vertex v is called 

 
  * an (ϵ,2)-split vertex if T ∖{v} = T_1⊎ T_2 such that |T_1|, |T_2| ≤ (1/2 + ϵ)n, and
 
  * an (ϵ,3)-split vertex if T ∖{v} = T_1⊎ T_2⊎ T_3 such that |T_1|, |T_2|, |T_3| ≤ (1/2 - ϵ)n,
    
where T_1, T_2 and T_3 are subgraphs of T.

sentence: We call an l-encoding ϕ _G of a graph G, a well-begun l-encoding if the first coordinate of ϕ_G is from {0, …, χ(G)-1}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Definition 1, <cit.>]
A tree decomposition of G is a pair ({X_i : i ∈ I },T ), where I is an index set, {X_i : i ∈ I } is a collection of subsets of V(G) and T is a tree whose node set is I, such that the following conditions are satisfied:


 
  * ∪_i ∈ I X_i=V(G).
 
  * ∀{u,v}∈ E(G), ∃ i ∈ I such that u,v ∈ X_i.
 
  * ∀ i,j,k ∈ I : if j is on a path in T from i to k, then X_i∩ X_k⊂ X_j.


The width of a tree decomposition ({ X_i : i ∈ I },T) is max{|X_i| : i ∈ I} -1. The treewidth of G, tw(G) , is the minimum width over all tree decompositions of G.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: tree decomposition;width of a tree decomposition;treewidth;tw(G)

sentence:
[Definition 2, <cit.>]
A normalized tree decomposition of a graph G is a triple ({X_i : i ∈ I },r ∈ I,T ) where ({X_i : i ∈ I },T ) is a tree decomposition of G that additionally satisfies the following two properties:


 
  * It is a rooted tree where the subset X_r that corresponds to the root node r contains exactly one vertex.
 
  * For any node i, if i^' is the child of i, then |X_i^' - X_i|=1 where, X_i^' - X_i denoted the symmetric difference of X_i^' and X_i.

sentence:
A pure (relative) simplicial complex Δ with facets F_1,…,F_n is called partitionable if there exists a partitioning of Δ into pairwise disjoint Boolean intervals

    Δ=_i=1^n[R_i,F_i],

where [R_i,F_i]={G∈Δ : R_i⊆ G⊆ F_i}.

sentence:
An inversion (i,j)∈ π is admissible if either π(j)<π(j+1) or π(j)>π(k) for some i<k<j. Let π be the set of admissible inversions of π, and let

    π=| π|,      π= π+ π.

sentence: A string w=w_1w_2… w_r (r≥ 2), over a totally ordered alphabet is a hook if w_1>w_2≤ w_3…≤ w_r. Every string π over ℕ (and hence any permutation π) can be decomposed uniquely <cit.> as π=π_0π_1…π_k (k≥ 0), where π_0 is an nondecreasing string and each of π_i, 1≤ i≤ k, is a hook. Then π_0π_1…π_k is called the hook factorization of π.

sentence:
Let G = (V, E) be a graph.
The
domination polynomial D(G, x) is 
given by 

    D(G,x)=∑_i=0^|V| d_i(G) x^i ,

where d_i(G) is the number of dominating sets of size i in G.

sentence: A blocking set β is a subset of points of Π such that every line of Π contains at least one point in β.  A minimal blocking set is a blocking set in which removing any of its points never yields a blocking set.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A unital in Π is a set U of q^3+1 points of Π such that every line of Π intersects U in exactly 1 or q+1 points. Lines of Π will be called tangent or secant to U depending on whether they intersect U in 1 or q+1 points, respectively.

sentence: Let U_α, β be an orthogonal-Buekenhout-Metz unital and P a point not in U_α, β. Each of the q+1 points of U_α, β that are on a tangent line to U_α, β through P is said to be a foot of P. We will denote the set of feet of P by τ_P(U_α, β) and we will call it the pedal of P.

sentence:
If L is a lattice, we say that an interval [a,b] is up-projective to [x,y], written [a,b]↗ [x,y], if and only if b∧ x=a and b∨ x=y. Equivalently we can write [x,y]↘ [a,b].

If [a,b] and [c,d] are two intervals and there is [x,y] such that 
[a,b]↗ [x,y]↘ [c,d], we say that [a,b] is up-and-down projective to [c,d] and write [a,b][c,d],
see Figure <ref>.

sentence: Let C be a simplicial d-complex, and let D be a subcomplex. Any shelling sequence (C_i) for C induces a sequence of subcomplexes of D, defined by D_i:=(C_i,|D|). Clearly D_i+1⊂ D_i. If all the D_i are pure, then the shelling (C_i) of C is called D-conforming . If C is a simplicial complex in ^k (resp. S^k), and A is a subset of ^k (resp. S^k), then a shelling of C is called A-conforming if it is (C,A) conforming.

sentence:
Let Δ be a (d-1)-simplex. Let P = Δ× I. A stacked subdivision of P is any subdivision that has no (d-2)-faces in the interior of P, and that does not subdivide the two bases  Δ×{0} and  Δ×{1} of the prism. 
Such a subdivision is combinatorially a path of d-simplices, so it shells to any of its d-faces (exactly like its dual graph, which is a path, can be shelled to any of its vertices, by recursively deleting leaves).

sentence: A (d-dimensional) pseudosimplex Δ in S^d is the intersection of d+1 or less hemispheres whose centers lie in convex position. The boundary ∂Δ has a natural decompositon into pseudosimplices, which we will call faces . In the special case when Δ is defined by one hemisphere, we call ∂Δ an equator . If p is a point, we denote by L_p the hemisphere with center p, and by E_p the equator ∂ L_p.

sentence:
Let C be a refinement of some pseudosimplex Δ in S^d or of a simplex in ^d. We call C strongly shellable if, for every (d-1)-boundary complex M in ∂Δ that is p-spanning (with respect to some p), there is a shelling of C that is M-conforming.
Let C be a refinement of some pseudosimplex P in S^d (resp. of a simplex in ^d). We call C strongly k-split-shellable if C is k-split-shellable, and the shelling of definition <ref> can be chosen to be (^k C,|D|)-conforming, for any p-spanning subcomplex D of ∂ P, where p is the center of the hemisphere H (resp. where p is the exterior normal to ∂ H).

sentence: Let v be a vertex of a simplicial complex T in ^d, and let y be a generic vector in ^d. The lower link of T at v with respect to y , denoted by Lowlink^y (v,T), is the subcomplex of (v,T) induced by vertices w of T with ⟨ y, w ⟩   <  ⟨ y, v ⟩.

sentence:
[cf. <cit.>]
A triangulation C of a d-manifold with non-empty (resp. empty) boundary is called endo-collapsible if C minus a d-face collapses onto ∂ C (resp. onto a vertex).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let C be a polytopal complex in ^d, and let τ be any face of C. Let C' denote the polytopal complex that is obtained from C by 
[(1)]

  * embedding C into ^d×{0}⊂^d+1,

  * deleting τ from C,

  * attaching the complex ∂ ((τ,C))× [0,1] to C, and finally

  * attaching (τ,C)×{1}.

This C' has a combinatorially equivalent realization as a subdivision (τ,C) of C. We say that (τ,C) is obtained from C by tubing the face τ .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[Tubular, tubecentric subdivision]
A tubular subdivision of a complex C is any subdivision E of C for which there exists a sequence of complexes C = C_0, C_1, …, C_m = E, so that each C_i+1 is obtained from C_i by tubing some face τ.

A tubecentric subdivision is a subdivision of a d-complex C obtained by tubing first all d-faces of C, then all (d-1)-faces of C, then all (d-2)-faces, and so on.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Shelling sequences]  Let C be a simplicial d-complex with N facets. Assume that d (N-1) > 0. A shelling step is the removal from a pure simplicial d-complex C of a single d-face whose intersection with the remaining complex is pure (d-1)-dimensional and shellable. Given two pure simplicial d-complexes C and D, we say that “C shells to D”, and write C ↘_ D, if there is a sequence of shelling steps which leads from C to D. The intermediate complexes between C and D form a sequence of subcomplexes (C_i), which we call shelling sequence . By definition, C_i+1 is a subcomplex of C_i obtainable from C_i via a single shelling step.
Clearly, a complex C is shellable if and only if C shells to some facet Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

Clearly D_i+1⊂ D_i. If all the D_i are pure, then the shelling (C_i) of C is called D-conforming . If C is a simplicial complex in ^k (resp. S^k), and A is a subset of ^k (resp. S^k), then a shelling of C is called A-conforming if it is (C,A) conforming.

sentence:
[Stacked] 
Let Δ be a (d-1)-simplex. Let P = Δ× I. A stacked subdivision of P is any subdivision that has no (d-2)-faces in the interior of P, and that does not subdivide the two bases  Δ×{0} and  Δ×{1} of the prism. 
Such a subdivision is combinatorially a path of d-simplices, so it shells to any of its d-faces (exactly like its dual graph, which is a path, can be shelled to any of its vertices, by recursively deleting leaves).

sentence:
[Pseudosimplex]
A (d-dimensional) pseudosimplex Δ in S^d is the intersection of d+1 or less hemispheres whose centers lie in convex position. The boundary ∂Δ has a natural decompositon into pseudosimplices, which we will call faces . In the special case when Δ is defined by one hemisphere, we call ∂Δ an equator . If p is a point, we denote by L_p the hemisphere with center p, and by E_p the equator ∂ L_p.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[p-spanning boundary complexes]
Let P be a pseudosimplex in S^d (resp. a simplex in ^d). Let M be a pure subcomplex of ∂ P, either empty or (d-1)-dimensional. Let p be a point in S^d (resp. a vector in ^d). We say that M is p-spanning if the hemisphere centered at p contains the intersection of all facets of M or does not intersect the hemisphere at all (resp. if the unique local minimum of the scalar product ⟨ p, - ⟩ on M is contained in the intersection of all facets of M).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[General position, k-split-shellable]
Let C be a simplicial complex in the sphere S^d, that is convex with respect to the standard intrinsic metric on S^d (resp. ^d). (This means that for any two points of C, a shortest arc between them is completely contained in |C|.)
A hemisphere (resp. a halfspace) H of S^d (resp. ^d) intersecting C is in general position with respect to C if no vertex of C lies in ∂ H. If k is a positive integer, we say that C is k-split-shellable if for every hemisphere (resp. any halfspace) H in general position with respect to C, the shelling of ^k C can be chosen so that ^k C shells to ^k-1N^1((C,H),C), which then shells to some facet.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: in general position with respect to C;k-split-shellable

sentence:
[E-splitting subdivisions] 
Let P be a polytopal complex in S^d. Let E be an equator of S^d. The E-splitting subdivision of P is the (realization of a) derived subdivision where vertices are chosen so that:
[–]

  * they coincide with the barycenters of those faces whose relative interior does not intersect E;

  * they lie at the barycenter of the intersection E∩τ, for any face τ of P whose relative interior intersects the equator E.

sentence:
We say Σ(C,V) is a minimal skeleton of C^ if
  V is minimal.

sentence:
Consider a skeleton Σ(C,V) of C^ and
  a finite subgraph Γ on it.  We say a closed embedding
  C↪ (K^*)^n faithfully represents Γ if
   maps Γ homeomorphically and isometrically onto its
  image in ^n.

sentence:
We say that C^→(C)
  is faithful if it faithfully represents a skeleton of
  C.

sentence:
Let (g) be a tropicalization of the plane curve defined by
  g, and v a vertex of (g).  We say that v is
  locally reducible if the star of v in (g) is a
  reducible 1-dimensional complex that is balanced at v, i.e. if
  it can be written as the union of two non-zero complexes with
  multiplicities that are balanced v.  In particular, if
  _(g)(v) is the union of s edges e_1,…, e_s
  adjacent to v with multiplicities m_1,…, m_s, we can find
  m̃_1,…, m̃_s with 0≤m̃_i≤ m_i
  for all i such that the resulting complex with multiplicities is
  balanced at v, contains an edge of positive multiplicity and it
  does not agree with _(g)(v) as complexes with
  multiplicities.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If Σ(g)∖ D_g→(g)
  contracts a fixed bounded edge but Σ(I_g,f)∖ D_I_g,f→(I_g,f) does not, we say that the linear
  re-embedding decontracts this edge.  

  Assume next that a segment in a bounded edge e of (g) is
  obtained by overlapping the images of several edges of
  Σ(g)∖ D_g in more than one
  point. Refine the structure of (g) and let e be this
  segment. If π^-1_XY(e) is the union of images of finitely
  many edges from Σ(I_g,f)∖
  D_I_g,f that pairwise intersect in at most one point, we say
  that the linear re-embedding unfolds the edge e.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Assume the tropical plane elliptic cubic (g) contains a cycle
  and a locally reducible vertex v with vanishing discriminant, and
  let L be a straight line in _(g)(v). If L is
  vertical (resp., horizontal) with equation {X=l} (resp., {Y=l}), we say that
  the cycle of (g) is on the visible side of L if it
  lies on the halfspace L^+:={X≥ l} (resp., L^+:={Y≥ l}).

sentence: An irreducible _n-character is called primary to the cuspidal U if χ does occur as an irreducible constituent of some product U^n/s=U  U ⋯ U, where (U)=s.

sentence:
A padded decomposition of G is a probability measure μ
on 𝒯 that satisfies the following two conditions:
 
  * For every P∈(μ) and every C ∈ P
we have (C) ≤  O(log n).

  * For every x∈ V we have
_P ∼μ[N(x) ⊆ P(x)] ≥ 1/2.

sentence:
A permutation σ on n bits is a unicyclic strong permutation if it satisfies the following 3 properties:


  𝔓1. the algebraic degree of φ_j is n-1 for all 0≤ j ≤ n-1;

  𝔓2. σ has one cycle of length 2^n; and

  𝔓3. the number of terms in the expressions φ_j is at least 2^n-1 for all j.

sentence:
Let ϕ be a formula with reversal over alphabet Σ.  A variable x∈Σ is called 


  * two-way in ϕ if both x and x appear in ϕ;

  * one-way in ϕ if either x or x appears in ϕ (but not both); and

  * absent from ϕ if neither x nor x appears in ϕ.

sentence:
For nonnegative integers m and n, define the Zimin formula with reversal Z_m,n by

    Z_m,0=x_1^♯… x_m^♯

and

    Z_m,n=Z_m,n-1y_nZ_m,n-1.

sentence:
Let p be a pattern with reversal over Σ.  The flattening of p, denoted p^♭, is the image of p under the morphism defined by x↦ x and x↦ x for all x∈Σ.  We say that p flattens to p^♭.

The flattening of a formula with reversal ϕ, denoted ϕ^♭, is the set of flattenings of all fragments of ϕ, i.e. ϕ^♭={p^♭ p∈ϕ}.  Again, we say that ϕ flattens to ϕ^♭.

sentence:
<cit.>
Let C_r be a perfect code of Q_r. Let f be a function from C_r to ℤ_2  and π be the parity function.
Then the set C_2r+1= {x||π(x)+f(c)||x+c;x∈𝔹_r,c∈ C_r} is a perfect code of Q_2r+1
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For the # product,  is free on either ^α or  _α 
where α runs over non-secable permutations ,
that is, permutations of size n≥2 such that any prefix
α_1…α_k of size 2≤ k<n is not, up to order, the union of
an interval with maximal value σ_k and another interval either empty or
with maximal value n.

sentence: Let X be a finite, non-empty set. A phylogenetic network is a connected graph (V,E) with X ⊆ V and no degree 2 vertices, such that the set of degree 1 vertices (referred to as leaves ) is precisely X. A phylogenetic tree is a phylogenetic network that is also a tree.

sentence: Let N be a network with some edge e=(v,w). The operation in which we delete e, add a new vertex z, then add the edges (v,z) and (z,w) is termed subdividing e, and the new vertex z is referred to as an attachment point . The inverse operation of subdivision is termed suppressing a vertex, in which a degree 2 vertex z with edges (v,z) and (z,w) is deleted and then the edge (v,w) is added.

sentence: Let N be a network on edge set X. A cut-edge is an edge such that N-e is a disconnected graph. A pendant edge is a cut-edge where one of the connected components of N-e is trivial. We refer to N as simple if all cut-edges of N are pendant. A blob is a maximal connected subgraph of N with no cut-edges that is not a vertex.

sentence: Let N be a network and v a vertex of N. We say that v is a cut-vertex if deletion of v and all edges incident to v from N forms a disconnected graph. The connected components of this disconnected graph are referred to as the  cut-components of v in N.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
Let N be a network on leaf-set X. Then N is referred to as



  * loosely tree-based on X if there exists a spanning tree in N whose leaf-set is equal to X,

  * tree-based on X if there exists a spanning tree T of N such that T contains all edges between two vertices of degree 4 or more, and all degree 2 vertices of T were degree 3 in N, and

  * strictly tree-based on X if there exists a spanning tree T in N whose leaf-set is equal to X and T contains every edge incident to the vertices of degree at least 4.

sentence: Let N be a network on leaf-set X. Then N is strictfully, fully, or loosefully tree-based if every embedded tree with leaf-set X is a base tree in the (respectively) strict, usual or loose sense.

i=1,…,m there is an ordering of the vertices of f_i={x_i_1,…,x_i_k} with the property that for every 
h<i there is a set Q∈ such that

    {r x_i_r∈ f_h∩ f_i}⊆ Q .
  
Here the orderings of the vertices for every edge of F can be chosen independently and 
might not be compatible with each other.

sentence:
[<cit.>, <cit.>]
  Let P be a bounded poset.
  An edge-lexicographical labeling (or simply EL-labeling ) of P is an edge labeling such that in each closed interval [x,y] ⊆ P there is a unique increasing maximal chain, and this chain lexicographically precedes all other maximal chains of [x,y].
  The poset P is EL-shellable if it admits an EL-labeling.

sentence:
Consider an edge (x,y) ∈ = (_n(G,S)) with y ≠.
  
    
  * Suppose that (x,y) is of type “merge”, i.e. x = (β̃∪{Ã, B̃}, z) and y = (β̃∪{C̃}, z), where C = A ∪ B and c = a ∪ bg.
    We say that (x,y) is coherent if c(min A) = c(min B) and non-coherent otherwise.
    If (x,y) is non-coherent, define α(x,y) ∈ G ∖{e} as
    
    α(x,y) =
          
    	c(min B) · c(min A)^-1   if min A < min B
    
    	c(min A) · c(min B)^-1   otherwise.

    Notice that this definition only depends on the ∼-equivalence class of c.
    The definition of α is motivated as follows: if c is normalized by setting c(min C) = e, then { c(min A), c(min B) } = { e, α(x,y) }.
    
    
  * Suppose that (x,y) is of type “color”, i.e. x = (β̃∪{B̃}, z) and y = (β̃, z').
    Then we say that (x,y) is colored , and its color is z'(min B).

sentence:
An increasing ordered tree is a rooted tree, with nodes labeled by a finite subset L ⊂, such that:
  
    
  * each path from the root to any leaf has increasing labels (in particular, the root has label min L);
    
  * for each node, a total order of its children is specified.
  
  If L is not specified, it is assumed to be {0,1,…,n} for some integer n≥ 0.

sentence:
Let q,r≥ 0 be integers.
  A (q,r)-blooming tree is an increasing ordered tree with q extra indistinguishable unlabeled nodes appended to the root, and r extra indistinguishable unlabeled nodes appended to each labeled node other than the root.
  The extra unlabeled nodes are called blooms .
  The only thing that matters about blooms is their position in the total order of the children of a node.

To any bijectivization  /J, we associate the following equivalence relation:

sentence:
A partial D_0 graph of degree  n is a graph  on a vertex set W ⊆_n
with edges colored from the set  {2,3,…,n-1} such that
for each KR_i square X = vw,
exactly one of the following possibilities occurs:
(ctr)ctr  

  *   X ∩ W = ∅,

  *  X ∩ W is equal to {v   bac   w, v   bca   w} or  {v   acb   w, v   cab   w} and is an  i-edge,

  * X ∩ W is equal to {v   bac   w, v   acb   w} or  {v   bca   w, v   cab   w} and is an  i-edge,

  * X ⊆ W and {v   bac   w, v   bca   w} and {v   acb   w, v   cab   w} are  i-edges,

  *  X ⊆ W and {v   bac   w, v   acb   w} and {v   bca   w, v   cab   w} are  i-edges,

  * X ⊆ W and no edge has both ends in X.







If (vi) never occurs, then we say that   is a D_0 graph of degree  n .

Recall from Definition <ref> that an edge {x,y} of   is a Knuth edge (resp. rotation edge )
if {x,y} is as in (ii) and (iv) (resp. (iii) and (v)); we call this the type of the edge so that each edge has two kinds of labels—color and type;
we can then speak of the type of the i-edge at  x, the color of a Knuth edge at  x, the rotation j-edges of  , etc.;
a Knuth i-edge (resp. rotation  i-edge) is denoted  i (resp.  ĩ) in figures.
Note that the type and color of an edge  {x,y}
can be recovered from the vertex labels x,y, with one exception: if x = v ac w,  y = v ca w, then {x,y} has type Knuth and color either  |v|+1 or  |v|+2.

sentence:
Given a KR set W, the minimal partial  D_0 graph on  W is the partial  D_0 graph  H on the vertex set  W having
as many undetermined KR squares as possible.
Equivalently,  H is the graph on the vertex set  W such that  {v,w} is an i-edge if and only if
 {v,w} = X ∩ W for some KR_i square X.

    rotation   if {a,b,c} is a rotation triple.

We say that a triples D_0 graph is a union of connected components of such a graph.

sentence:
Fix a positive integer  ℓ.
A root ideal is an upper order ideal
of the poset  Δ^+_ℓ = Δ^+  := {(i,j) | 1 ≤ i < j ≤ℓ}
with partial order given by (a,b) ≤ (c,d) when a≥ c and b≤ d.
Given a root ideal Ψ⊂Δ^+_ℓ and γ∈ℤ^ℓ, the associated
Catalan function is

    H(Ψ;γ)(𝐱;t) := ∏_(i,j) ∈Ψ(1-tR_i j)^-1 s_γ(𝐱)  ∈ Λ,

where the raising operator R_i j acts on the subscripts of the s_γ by R_i j s_γ = s_γ + ϵ_i - ϵ_j
(a discussion of raising operators is given in <ref>).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The bounce graph of a root ideal  Ψ⊂Δ^+_ℓ is the graph on the vertex set [ℓ]
with edges (r, _Ψ(r)) for each r∈ [ℓ] such that _Ψ(r) is defined.
The bounce graph of  Ψ is a disjoint union of paths called bounce paths of  Ψ .



For each vertex r ∈ [ℓ],
distinguish _Ψ(r) (resp. _Ψ(r)) to be
the maximum (resp. minimum) element of the bounce path of  Ψ containing  r.



For  a,b ∈ [ℓ] in the same bounce path of  Ψ with  a≤ b, we define

    _Ψ(a,b) = (a, _Ψ(a), ^2_Ψ(a), …, b),

i.e., the list of indices in this path lying between  a and  b.
We also set  _Ψ(r) = (r, _Ψ(r))
and _Ψ(r) to be the reverse of (_Ψ(r),r) for any r ∈ [ℓ].

By a slight abuse of notation, we also write  _Ψ(a,b), _Ψ(r), and  _Ψ(r) for the corresponding sets of indices.
For b = _Ψ^m(a), the bounce from  a to  b is

    B_Ψ(a,b) := |_Ψ(a,b)|-1 = m.

sentence:
A root ideal Ψ is said to have

a wall in rows r,r+1 if rows r and r+1 of Ψ have the same length,

a ceiling in columns c,c+1 if columns c and c+1 of Ψ have the same length, and

a mirror in rows r,r+1 if Ψ has removable roots (r,c), (r+1,c+1) for some c > r+1.

sentence:
Let λ∈^k_ℓ and z ∈ [ℓ].
Set μ = λ - ϵ_z
and Ψ= Δ^k(μ).
Let  c = |_Ψ(z)|.

If z = ℓ or λ_z > λ_z+1 or ^c_Ψ(z+1) is undefined, then set  h=0;
otherwise, set y + 1 = ^c_Ψ(z+1) and
let h ∈ [ℓ-z] be as large as possible such that

    12.4cmμ is constant on each of the intervals [z+1, z+h], [_Ψ(z), _Ψ(z)+h], 
    [^2_Ψ(z), ^2_Ψ(z)+h], …, [_Ψ(z), _Ψ(z)+h], and  [y+1, y+h].

    λ + ϵ_[y+1,y+h] - ϵ_[z,z+h].

If y is undefined or, equivalently, h = 0 then _z(λ) = μ (we interpret [y+1,y+h] = ∅ in this case).

Let  S be a finite set. Let ={A_1,…, A_r} be a family
of subsets of S.    A system of distinct representatives (SDR) of  is a choice of an element a_i ∈ A_i for each i such that a_i ≠ a_j for i ≠ j. 
A transversal is a set which can be ordered to obtain an SDR.

sentence:

∙  
replacing e_ij∈ G with e_ji∈ G',

∙  replacing every other edge of the form e_ik in G with e_jk∈ G', and

∙ replacing the sink j ∈ B with the new sink i ∈ B'.

sentence: Let M=(E, ) be a matroid. Let K⊆ E and let B_K be a basis of K. The contraction of M by K , denoted M/K, is the matroid on E-K whose bases are the sets B' ⊆ E-K such that B' ∪ B_K is a basis of M.

sentence:
The Cauchy-Schwarz calculus  operates with statements of the form f ≥ 0 with f ∈ and has axioms


  A1:  f^2 ≥ 0 for every f;

  A2:  f_1^2_T  f_2^2_T -  f_1f_2_T^2 ≥ 0 for f_1,f_2 and T as in (<ref>).

The inference rules of the Cauchy-Schwarz calculus are


  R1:  
    f ≥ 0      g≥ 0/α f + β g ≥ 0  (α,β≥ 0),


  R2:  
    f ≥ 0      g≥ 0/fg ≥ 0,


  R3:  
    f ≥ 0/ f _T ≥ 0  (T ⊆ℕ),


for f,g ∈.
We say that f ∈ is CS-positive if the statement f ≥ 0 is provable in the Cauchy-Schwarz calculus.

sentence: A poset P is a unit interval order if there exists a bijective map i ↦ [q_i, q_i+1] from P to a set S = {[q_i, q_i + 1] | 1 ≤ i ≤ n,   q_i ∈ℝ} of closed unit intervals of the real line such that for i,j ∈ P, i <_P j if and only if q_i + 1 < q_j. We then say that S is an interval representation of P.

Let A,B be non-empty disjoint sets such that A∪
B=x_1,…,x_n.  Then A and B are I-independent
if I∩ A∩ B=∅.

sentence:
A planar directed graph D with no multiple edges embedded in a disk is an A_2-web if it satisfies the following conditions:

 
  * D is bipartite, with each edge of D is oriented from one of the negative vertices to one of the positive vertices, and
 
  * all the boundary vertices have degrees 1 while all internal vertices have degree 3.

If, in addition, D is non-elliptic , i.e.,

 
  (3) all internal faces of D have at least 6 sides,

then we say D is an irreducible A_2 web .

sentence: Define a twist region of D(K) to be a longest possible string of bigons in the projection graph of D(K). Denote the number of twist regions in D(K) by t(D) and call t(D) the twist number of D(K). Note that it is possible for a twist region to consist of a single crossing of D(K).
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If a given twist region contains two or more crossings, then the A-resolution of a left-handed twist region will be called a long resolution and the A-resolution of a right-handed twist region will be called a short resolution . See Fig. <ref> for depictions of these resolutions. We will call a twist region long if its A-resolution is long and short if its A-resolution is short.

sentence: A link diagram D(K) satisfies the two-edge loop condition (TELC) if, whenever two all-A circles share a pair of A-segments, these segments correspond to crossings from the same short twist region of D(K).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Call an alternating tangle in D(K) a special tangle if, up to planar isotopy, it consists of exactly one of the following:





  (1) a tangle sum of a vertical short twist region and a one-crossing twist region (with the crossing type of Fig. <ref>)

  (2) a tangle sum of two vertical short twist regions

  (3) a tangle sum of a horizontal long twist region and a vertical short twist region 





To look for such tangles in D(K) ⊆ S^2, we look for simple closed curves in the plane that intersect D(K) exactly four times and that contain a special tangle on one side of the curve. Equivalently, the special tangles of D(K) can be found in the all-A state H_A by looking for all-A circles that are incident to A-segments from a pair of twist regions from the tangle sums mentioned above. We call these all-A circles special circles (SCs) of H_A. See Fig. <ref> for depictions of special tangles and special circles. Let st(D) denote the number of special tangles in D(K) (or, equivalently, the number of special circles in H_A).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We call each (small) all-A circle in the interior of the long resolution a small inner circle (SIC) . The remaining all-A circles in the rest of H_A will simply be called other circles (OCs) .

sentence: Given a braid β in the even-stringed braid group B_2n, we can form the plat closure of β by connecting string position 2i-1 with string position 2i for each 1 ≤ i ≤ n by using trivial semicircular arcs at the top and bottom of these string positions. See Fig. <ref> for a schematic depiction of the type of plat closure, call it a special plat closure , that we will consider in this paper.

sentence: Let D(K) denote a special plat closure of a braid β∈ B_2n, where n ≥ 3, that contains 2k+1 rows of twist regions, where k ≥ 1. Then we call D(K) a strongly negative plat diagram if a_i,j≤ -3 in odd-numbered rows and a_i,j≤ -2 in even-numbered rows. Similarly, we call D(K) a mixed-sign plat diagram if a_i,j≤ -3 or a_i,j≥ 1 in odd-numbered rows and a_i,j≤ -2 in even-numbered rows. See the left side of Fig. <ref> for an example of a strongly negative plat diagram and see the left side of Fig. <ref> for an example of a mixed-sign plat diagram.

sentence:
A quiver Q is a directed graph; we will assume that Q has no 
loops or 2-cycles.
If there are i arrows from vertex λ to μ, then 
we will set b_λμ = i and b_μλ = -i.
Each vertex is designated either  mutable or frozen .
The skew-symmetric matrix B = (b_λμ) is called the exchange matrix of Q.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let λ be a mutable vertex of quiver Q.  The quiver mutation 
_λ transforms Q into a new quiver Q' = _λ(Q) via a sequence of three steps:


  * For each oriented two path μ→λ→ν, add a new arrow μ→ν
(unless μ and ν are both frozen, in which case do nothing).

  * Reverse the direction of all arrows incident to the vertex λ.

  * Repeatedly remove oriented 2-cycles until unable to do so.

	If B is the exchange matrix of Q, then we let _λ(B) denote the 
	exchange matrix of _λ(Q).

sentence: We say that a Laurent polynomial is positive if all of its coefficients are in _>0. An element h∈[] is called universally positive  (for the 𝒜-cluster structure) if for every 𝒜-cluster seed  Σ̌_G^𝒜 the expansion 𝐡^G of h in  is a positive Laurent polynomial. Similarly f∈[×^*] is called universally positive if its expansion 𝐟^G in the variables ∪{q} is given by a positive Laurent polynomial for every seed Σ̌_G^𝒜.

    0 ≤  f_1 × 1
    
    	   f_(n-k)× k≤  r  
    
    	   0  ≤  f_i × j - f_(i-1)× j
    
    	   0  ≤  f_i × j - f_i × (j-1),

where

rectangles i × j
contained in a

is called the Gelfand-Tsetlin polytope for the highest weight rω_n-k.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let G be a reduced plabic graph of type π_k,n, and choose
an ayclic perfect orientation Ø with source set I_Ø={1,…,n-k}.
Let A be the (n-k)× n matrix with rows indexed by I_Ø whose (i,j)-entry equals

    (-1)^|{i'∈ [n-k]: i < i' < j}|∑_p:i→ j(w),

where the sum is over all paths w in Ø from i to  j. Then the map Φ_G sending 
(x_μ)_μ∈𝒫_G∈ (^*)^𝒫_G to the element of 𝕏 represented by A 
is an injective map onto a dense open subset of .    The restriction of Φ_G to 
(_>0)^𝒫_G gives a parameterization of the totally positive Grassmannian
(_>0).  We call the map Φ_G a network chart for .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Two plabic graphs are called move-equivalent if they can be obtained
from each other by moves (M1)-(M3).  The move-equivalence class
of a given plabic graph G is the set of all plabic graphs which are move-equivalent
to G.
A leafless plabic graph without isolated components
is called reduced if there is no graph in its move-equivalence
class to which we can apply (R1).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a reduced plabic graph 
with boundary vertices 1,…, n.
The trip T_i from i is the path
obtained by starting from i and traveling along
edges of G according to the rule that each time we reach an internal black vertex we turn
(maximally) right, and each time we reach an internal white vertex we turn (maximally) left.
This trip ends at some boundary vertex π(i).
In this way we associate a trip permutation
π_G=(π(1),…,π(n)) to each reduced plabic graph G,
and we say that G has type π_G .
	(Because one can reverse each trip, it is clear that π_G is a permutation.)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

loops or 2-cycles.

we will set b_λμ = i and b_μλ = -i.
Each vertex is designated either  mutable or frozen .
The skew-symmetric matrix B = (b_λμ) is called the exchange matrix of Q.

sentence:
Let G be a reduced plabic graph.  We associate a quiver Q(G) as follows.  The vertices of 
Q(G) are labeled by the faces of G.  We say that a vertex of Q(G) is frozen
if the 
corresponding face is incident to the boundary of the disk, and is mutable otherwise.
For each edge e in G which separates two faces, at least one of which is mutable, 
we introduce an arrow connecting the faces;
 this arrow is oriented so that it “sees the white endpoint of e to the left and the 
black endpoint to the right” as it crosses over e.  We then remove oriented 2-cycles
from the resulting quiver, one by one, to get Q(G). See <ref>.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Strongly minimal, strongly maximal,
 and pointed]
We say that a Laurent monomial 
∏_μ x_μ^a_μ appearing
in a Laurent polynomial P is strongly minimal
(respectively, strongly maximal ) in P  if 
for every other Laurent monomial ∏_μ x_μ^b_μ occurring in P,
we have a_μ≤ b_μ (respectively, a_μ≥ b_μ) for all μ.  

If P has a strongly minimal Laurent
monomial with coefficient 1, then we say  P is pointed .
Consider 
a plabic graph G and perfect orientation with source set {1,…, n-k}. Recall that the flow polynomial 
P_J 
is a sum over  flows from {1,…, n-k} to J. 
We call a flow from {1,…, n-k} to J strongly minimal 
(respectively, strongly maximal )
if it has a  strongly minimal (respectively, strongly 
maximal) weight monomial in P_J.

sentence:
Let A denote an (n-k) × n matrix representing an element of 
.  Let A_i denote the ith column of A, with indices
taken cyclically; that is, A_i+n = A_i.  
Let ⟨ -,-⟩ denote the standard Euclidean inner product on ^n-k.

The left twist of A is the 
	(n-k) × n matrix (A) such that, for all i, the ith column
(A)_i satisfies 

    ⟨(A)_i  | A_i ⟩ = 1, and
 

    ⟨(A)_i  | A_j ⟩ = 0  if A_j
     is not in the span of {A_j+1, A_j+2,…, A_i-1, A_i}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let μ_i^□ be the Young diagram associated to 
the k-element subset of horizontal steps
J_i^+:=[i+1,i+k-1]∪{i+k+1}, where the index i is always interpreted modulo n.  
Then for i  n-k,  
the Young diagram μ_i^□ 
turns out to be the unique diagram in  obtained by adding a single  box to μ_i.
And for i=n-k, the Young diagram  μ_n-k^□ associated to 
J_n-k^+ is the rectangular (n-k-1) (k-1) Young diagram obtained from μ_n-k by removing a rim hook.


We define the superpotential dual to the Grassmannian  to be the regular function W:^* → given by

    W= ∑_i=1^nq^δ_i,n-kp_μ_i^□/p_μ_i,

where q is the coordinate on the ^* factor and δ_i,j is the  Kronecker delta function. 
	
For i=1,…, n we also define W_i∈[] by

    W_i:= p_μ_i^□/p_μ_i=p_J_i^+/p_J_i,

so that

	W= q W_n-k + ∑_i≠ n-k W_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Universally positive]
We say that a Laurent polynomial is positive if all of its coefficients are in _>0. An element h∈[] is called universally positive  (for the 𝒜-cluster structure) if for every 𝒜-cluster seed  Σ̌_G^𝒜 the expansion 𝐡^G of h in  is a positive Laurent polynomial. Similarly f∈[×^*] is called universally positive if its expansion 𝐟^G in the variables ∪{q} is given by a positive Laurent polynomial for every seed Σ̌_G^𝒜.

sentence:

    _G^r={v∈^𝒫_G|_G(W)(v,r)≥ 0}.

When r=1, we will also write _G := ^1_G.

sentence:
Choose r_1,…,r_n ∈.  
	We define the generalized superpotential polytope by 
	
    _G(r_1,…,r_n) = ⋂_i {v∈^𝒫_G | _G(W_i)(v) + r_i ≥ 0}.

In particular if r_n-k=r and r_i=0 for i ≠ n-k, then 
_G(r_1,…,r_n) = _G^r.

sentence:
We define a GT tableau to be a rectangular array of integers {V_i × j} in a grid
(where i × j ranges over the nonempty rectangles
contained in ), which satisfy the following properties:


  * Entries in the top row and leftmost column are at most 1.

  * V_i × j≤ V_(i-1) × (j-1) + 1.

  * V_1 × 1≥ 0. 

  * Entries weakly increase from left to right 
in the rows, and from top to bottom in the columns.  

  * If V_i × j > 0, then V_(i+1) × (j+1) = V_i × j+1. 

See the left hand side of Figure <ref> for an example.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given two partitions λ and μ in 𝒫_k,n,
we let μ∖λ denote the corresponding 
	skew diagram , i.e. the set of boxes
remaining if we justify both μ and λ at the top-left
of a (n-k) × k rectangle, then remove from μ any boxes
that are in λ.
We let (μ∖λ) denote the maximum
number of boxes in μ∖λ that lie along
any diagonal (with slope -1) of the rectangle.

sentence:
Let Q = (Q_0,Q_1) be an arbitrary quiver with no loops or 2-cycles,
where Q_0 denotes the set of vertices of Q and Q_1 the set of arrows.  
Given  v∈^Q_0 and mutable vertex ν, we define the quantity

    ∘v_ν := ∑_μ→ν v_μ - 
    	∑_v←μ' v_μ',

where the summands correspond to arrows in Q 
to and from the vertex ν, respectively. 
We say that ν is balanced with respect to the pair (v,Q)
if ∘v_ν = 0.

contained in a 
(n-k) × k rectangle.  This polytope 
is called the Gelfand-Tsetlin polytope for the highest weight rω_n-k.

sentence:
Let G be a graph and G' be an induced subgraph of G. If for
every maximal clique C of G', each nontrivial component of
G'-C contains a heavy vertex of G, then G' is a
clique-heavy (or in short, c-heavy ) subgraph of G.
For a given graph S, G is S-c-heavy if every induced
subgraph of G isomorphic to S is c-heavy.

sentence: <cit.> A star edge coloring   of  a graph G is a proper edge coloring of G such that  no path or cycle of length four in G is bi-colored.    The smallest integer k   that G admits a k-star edge coloring is called star chromatic index  of G and is denoted by  χ^'_s(G).

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex and let {i,j } be an edge of Δ.
The (stellar) edge subdivision of Δ with respect to {i,j} is the simplicial complex

    { F ∈Δ: F ⊅{i,j}}∪{ F∪{v}, F∪{i,v}, F ∪{j,v}: F ∈_Δ({i,j})},

where v is a new vertex.
The edge contraction of i to j in Δ
is the simplicial complex Δ' which is obtained
from Δ by identifying the vertices i and j,
in other words,

    Δ' =
    { F ∈Δ: i ∉F}∪{ (F ∖{i}) ∪{j}:
    i ∈ F ∈Δ}.

sentence: Let π∈ S_n and σ∈ S_n-1 such that _σ.π is well-defined.  We say that σ is valid with respect to π if _σ.π is proper.  If σ is valid with respect to π, we will say that σ acts validly on π.

plain_text_term: σ is valid with respect to π

sentence:
Let π∈ S_n.  An interval [s,t] in the edge diagram of π is said to satisfy the linked conditions if, for every σ∈ S_n-1 that is valid with respect to π, the following are true:


  * The image σ.[s,t] is an interval.

  * If we let i,j ∈ [n] be such that σ.[s,t]=[i,j], then the ordered tuple (σ(s),σ(s+1),σ(s+2),…,σ(t-1)) equals either (i,i+1,…,j-1) or (j-1,j-2,…,i).


Additionally, [s,t] is called an irreducible interval if it is a maximal interval that satisfies the linked conditions (i.e. for any interval [x,y] such that [s,t] ⊊ [x,y], [x,y] does not satisfy the linked conditions).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let π∈ S_n with k irreducible intervals, and let [a,b] be an interval in the edge diagram of π.  We say that [a,b] is cohesive in π if all of the following are true:


  * The interval [a,b] is a union of irreducible intervals;

  * for every e ∈_π, we have e ⊆ [a,b], [a,b] ⊆ e, or [a,b] ∩ e = ∅; and

  * for every μ∈ B_k that is valid with respect to π, μ. [a,b] is an interval.

sentence: A partition 𝒫={x_s=a_0,a_1,a_2, …, a_l=x_t }_< of a cohesive  interval [x_s,x_t] is called a cohesive partition if [a_i,a_i+1] is irreducible or cohesive for every 1≤ i<l.

sentence:
Given an integer d≥ 1 and a field , consider the Veronese embedding ν_d: ^2→^A given by:
    ν_d: [x, y, z]↦ [x^d,…, x^iy^jz^k,…, z^d]_i+j+k=d.


We identify a degree d curve in ^2 with the preimage of a hyperplane in ^A or a point in the dual space (^A)^*. We say a subset  of the space of degree d polynomials ⊂ S_d is parametrized by an algebraic variety M if it is the preimage of M⊂ (^A)^*, and we define the dimension of  to be M.

sentence:
Let 𝒞 be a chain decomposition of a graded poset P. 
For any chains C_i,C_j∈𝒞, if |C_i|≤ |C_j| implies 
{r(x)| x∈ C_i}⊆{r(x)| x∈ C_j}, then 𝒞 is called a 
nested chain decomposition of P. 
We say P is nested, or it has a nesting, if such a decomposition of P exists.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be a graded poset and L_i be a level of P. Then L is said to be a k-clone of L_i if L=L_i×{1,…,k} and the partial 
order relations of each (y,i) and others elements in L_i-1 (resp. L_i+1) is x<(y,i) (resp. (y,i)<z) if and only 
if there exist some x∈ L_i-1 and y∈ L_i (resp. y∈ L_j and z∈ L_i+1). See Figure <ref> as an illustration.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let P be a graded poset and L_i be a level of P. Suppose |L_i|=mℓ for some integers m and ℓ.
First partition L_1 into m arbitrary subsets A_1,…,A_m of equal size ℓ.
Then L is an m-bunch of L_i if L={A_1,…,A_m} and the partial 
order relations of each A_j and others elements in L_i-1 (resp. L_i+1) is x<A_j (resp. A_j<z)
if and only if there exist x∈ L_i-1 and y∈ A_j (resp. y∈ A_j and z∈ L_i+1). 
See Figure <ref> as an illustration.

sentence:
A pair (A,ζ) is a combinatorial coalgebra
if (A,Δ,ϵ) is a graded coalgebra 
and ζ : A → is a linear map with ζ(a) = ϵ(a) whenever a∈ A is homogeneous of degree zero.
A morphism of combinatorial coalgebras (A,ζ) → (A',ζ') is a graded coalgebra morphism Φ : A → A'
with ζ = ζ'∘Φ. 
A combinatorial coalgebra (A,ζ) in which A is a graded bialgebra and ζ is an algebra morphism
is a combinatorial bialgebra .
Morphisms of combinatorial bialgebras are morphisms of combinatorial coalgebras that are bialgebra morphisms.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If (B,ζ) is a combinatorial bialgebra and (M,ξ) is a combinatorial coalgebra
such that M is a graded right B-module coalgebra with ξ(mb) = ξ(m)ζ(b)
for all m ∈ M and b∈ B,
then we say that (M,ξ) is a combinatorial (B,ζ)-module coalgebra .
A morphism of combinatorial (B,ζ)-module coalgebras is a morphism of combinatorial coalgebras that is 
a B-module map.

  * If B∈, then there is some s∈ S (resp. s'∈ S) such
            that B is the minimum element of _s (resp. maximum element of
            _s').

sentence: Given n ≥ 1, k ≥ 0, and a partition λ containing a staircase δ_k-1 such that skew diagram λ / δ_k-1 is connected and k ≤λ_1 ≤ n+k, then we can create a skew diagram called a staircase with a bad foundation , denoted 𝒮(λ, k,n), by placing λ / δ_k-1 immediately below Δ_n such that the rows of the two diagrams overlap in precisely λ_1-k positions. We call the subdiagram λ / δ_k-1 the foundation of 𝒮(λ, k,n).

sentence: Let π be a permutation with permutation matrix M.  The Rothe diagram of π is the collection of cells (i,j) such that M_i',j = 0 for all i' ≤ i , and M_i,j' = 0 for all j' ≤ j.

sentence: The permutation π is dominant if the Rothe diagram of π is a Young diagram - that is, if the Rothe diagram of π is either empty or if it contains only one connected component of cells in the upper left hand corner of the permutation matrix.

sentence:
(1) Convex hull: C_d:=(f(𝒫^d_s))=_f(σ^d)(f(𝒫^d_s)) is a simplicial cone of dimension ⌊ d/2 ⌋.

(2) Density of rays: for any ϵ>0 and any x∈ C_d there exists a simplicial polytope P∈𝒫^d_s such that the angle between x-f(σ^d) and f(P)-f(σ^d) is less than ϵ.

(3) Density of points: for any x∈ C_d there exists a simplicial polytope P∈𝒫^d_s such that in the l_1-norm ||x-f(P)||_1=O(||x||_1^1-1/⌊ d/2⌋)=o(||x||_1). (The O(·) estimate is tight; d≥ 2.)

(4) Boundary polytopes: the only polytopes P∈𝒫^d_s with f(P) on the boundary of C_d are the k-stacked polytopes for some k≤d/2 -1; only the 1-stacked polytopes have f(P) on an extremal ray, all are on the same ray.

sentence:
Let Γ be a tropical curve of genus 1. 
A divisor in the linear system |Γ·Γ| is said to be internal if has at least two chips (see Section <ref>) on the cycle, or a single chip in the interior of an edge of the cycle. If Γ has genus 0 then every divisor is said to be internal.

sentence:
Let Γ'∈𝒮_Γ,η, and denote F=Ψ_Γ,η^-1 (Ψ_Γ,η(Γ')), the collection of curves Γ”∈ V_Γ,η for which Γ·Γ'=Γ·Γ”. 

 
 We say that a vertex v' of Γ' is η-pinned (or pinned when η is understood) if there is an open neighborhood U⊂ V_Γ,η∩ F of Γ' such that U is contained in a domain of linearity of Ψ_Γ,η, and φ_Γ”(v')=v' for all Γ”∈ U.

sentence:
A cell of  is said to be exposed if it parametrizes divisors of the form 

    ' = v' + v”+ p_3+… + p_d,

where v', v” are vertices of the cycle, and p_3,p_4,…, p_d are in the interiors of edges that are external to the cycle.

sentence:
A non-empty binary matrix M=(m_i,j) of size n× k, is a Dyck matrix if it satisfies the
following conditions.


  (M1) There exists 0<h≤ k such that m_1,j=1 if and only if j≤ h.

  (M2) For each 1 ≤ i < n, there exist 1≤ a_i≤ b_i<c_i≤ k such that a_i is
    the smallest index satisfying m_i,a_i=1 and m_i+1,a_i=0, b_i is the greatest index
    such that m_i,b_i=1, and
    c_i is the greatest index such that m_i+1,c_i=1. Moreover, the following hold: 

    (M2.1) m_i+1,j=m_i,j,  for j=1,…,a_i -1;

    (M2.2) m_i+1,j=0,  for j=a_i,…,b_i;

    (M2.3) m_i+1,j=1,  for j=b_i+1,…,c_i;

    (M2.4) m_i+1,j=0,  for j=c_i+1,…,k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A 3-link in H is a set of 3 hyperedges h_1, h_2, h_3 ∈ E(H) such that h_1 ∩ h_2  ≠∅, h_2 ∩ h_3 ≠∅ and h_1 ∩ h_3 = ∅. The hyperedges h_1 and h_3 are called terminal hyperedges of this 3-link. (Notice that a given 3-link defines four different Berge paths because each end vertex can be chosen in two ways. Also note that a 3-link is simply the set of hyperedges of a linear path of length three.)  

Given a hypergraph H and abc ∈ E(H), let p_abc(H) denote the number of 3-links in H in which abc is a terminal hyperedge and let p(H) denote the total number of 3-links in H. Notice 
    p(H) = 1/2∑_abc ∈ E(H) p_abc(H).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A unicellular map  of size n is a triple =(H,α,σ), where H is a set of cardinality 2n, α is an involution of H without fixed points, 
and σ is a permutation of H such that γ=ασ has only one cycle.
The elements of H are called the half-edges of . The cycles of α and σ are called the edges and the vertices of , respectively, and the permutation γ is called the face of .

sentence: We say that a half-edge h∈ H is an up-step if h<_σ(h), and that it is a down-step if σ(h)≤_ h. A down-step h is called a trisection if σ(h)≠min_ V(h), i.e. if σ(h) is not the minimum half-edge inside its vertex.

sentence: We say that a component C_j of the source curve C is a trivial bubble if it maps to a component T_j of the expanded target T as a degree d map, fully ramified over 0 and ∞ and unramified elsewhere, i.e. the map is of the form [z_0:z_1]↦ [z_0^d:z_1^d].

sentence: A relative map [f:C→^1] is said to be stable if f_1-contracted genus 0 components have at least 3 special points, and for i≠ 0, there exists a component C' of C mapping to T that is not a trivial bubble.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph G = (V,E) is a set V together with a set E of unordered pairs of distinct elements of V. The elements of V are called vertices of G, and the elements of E are called edges of G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Two vertices u and v in a graph G are called adjacent if there is an edge between them, that is if {u,v}∈ E. Given a vertex v∈ V of a graph G, the neighborhood of v is the set 
    {u∈ V : {u,v}∈ E}.
 That is, the neighborhood of v is the set of vertices adjacent to it in G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The complement of a graph G = (V,E) is the graph H = (V,E'), where for all u,v∈ V, {u,v}∈ E' {u,v}∉ E. That is, the complement of G is the graph in which all vertices that were not adjacent in G are now adjacent and all vertices that were adjacent in G are not adjacent. See Figure <ref>
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A path in a graph G is a sequence u_1,…,u_n of vertices of G so that {u_i,u_i+1}∈ E, i = 1,…, n-1. G is called connected if for any two vertices v and w of G there is a path u_1,…,u_n in G with v=u_1 and w=u_n. G is called disconnected if it is not connected. See Figures <ref> and <ref>.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A bicolored graph is a graph where each vertex is colored with one of two colors (say, red or blue) such that no two vertices of the same color are adjacent. A bipartite graph is a graph that admits a proper bicoloring—a graph whose vertices can be colored with red or blue to produce a bicolored graph. See Figures <ref> and <ref>.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The exponential generating series of a species of structures F is defined as:

    F(x) = ∑_n=0^∞ f_n x^n/n!

where f_n = |F[n]| = the number of F-structures on a set of n elements.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let T(F_n) be the quotient set, denoted F[n]/∼, of isomorphism classes of F-structures of order n. The type generating series of a species of structures F is the formal power series:

    F(x) = ∑_n=0^∞f_n x^n

where f_n = |T(F_n)| is the number of unlabeled F-structures of order n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The cycle index series of a species of structures F is the formal power series: 

    Z_F(p_1, p_2, p_3 ⋯) = ∑_n=0^∞1/n!∑_σ∈ S_n (F[σ]) p_σ


where S_n denotes the permutation group of [n], F[σ] = (F[σ])_1 is the number of F-structures on [n] fixed by F[σ], p_σ is the monomial term p_1^σ_1 p_2^σ_2 p_3^σ_3⋯ p_n^σ_n, and σ_i is the number of i-cycles of σ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A species isomorphism from F to G is a family of bijections α_U: F[U]→G[U] which satisifies the naturality condition: For any bijection σ: U → V and any F-structure s ∈F[U], we have G[σ] (α_U(s)) = α_V(F[σ](s)).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F and G be species. Then their sum F+G is the species where

    (F+G)[U] = F[U] ⊔G[U],

where A ⊔ B, the disjoint union of A and B, is the set of A-elements colored red and B-elements colored blue, and

    (F+G)[σ](s) = {[  F[σ](s)  s ∈F[U];  G[σ](s) s ∈G[U]. ].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F and G be species. Then their product F·G is the species such that:

    (F·G)[U]    = ⋃_S ⊆ UF[S] ×G[U ∖ S] 
       = {(s, t) :  S ⊆ U  s ∈F[S]  t ∈G[U ∖ S] },

and

    (F·G)[σ](s, t) = (F[σ_1](s), G[σ_2](t)),

where σ_1 and σ_2 are the restrictions of σ to the label sets of s and t respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F and G be species such that G[∅] = ∅. We will define a species F∘G, called the composition (or substitution ) of F and G. Its structure set (F∘G)[U] is given by:

    { (s, T) : }.

Let (s, T) ∈ (F∘G)[U]. For each t ∈ T, let σ_t be the restriction of σ to the label set of t. Let τ be a function from T defined by

    τ(t) = G[σ_t](t).

Then the transports of F∘G are:

    (F∘G)[σ](s) = F[τ](s).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a species F, define its derivative F' to be the species such that, if * ∉U, then

    F'[U] = F[U ∪{ * }]

and

    F'[σ](s) = F[σ^+](s),

where σ^+(*) = * and σ^+(x) = σ(x) if x ∈ U.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F and G be species. Then we define the virtual species F-G as the element (F,G) in {(A,B) : A and B are species }/∼, where ∼ is the equivalence relation 
    (A,B)∼ (C,D) A+D≡B+C.
 The additive inverse of F, denoted -F, is given as -F = 0 - F.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Γ be a group. Then a Γ-species F is a combinatorial species F equipped with a group action of Γ on F-structures that respects isomorphisms between F-structures.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The composition for two Γ-species F and G is the Γ-species F∘G defined as

    (F∘G) [A] = ∏_π∈ P(A)(F[π]×∏_B∈πG[B]),
 where P(A) is the set of partitions of A and where γ∈Γ acts on an (F∘G)-structure by acting on the F-structure and the G-structures independently.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The plethysm of two Γ–cycle indices f and g, f∘ g, is 
    (f∘ g) (γ) = f(γ)(g(γ)(p_1, p_2, p_3, ...), g(γ^2)(p_2, p_4, p_6, ...), ...),
 a Γ–cycle index.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let F be a Γ-species with a group action given. We define F/Γ, the quotient species of F under the group action of Γ, to be the species of Γ-orbits on F-structures.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a graph G, recall that the neighborhood of a vertex v∈ V(G) is the set of vertices to which v is connected by an edge. A point-determining graph is a graph where no two vertices share a neighborhood.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: If Φ is a subspecies of the graph species G, then we will say that Φ is a graph subspecies ; a Φ-graph is a graph belonging to the species Φ (that is, a Φ-structure).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a graph G and a vertex v, the neighborhood of v is the set of vertices of G that are adjacent to v. A graph is point-determining if no two distinct vertices have the same neighborhoods. The species of point-determining graphs is called P; if Φ is a graph subspecies, then the species of point-determining Φ-graphs is called Φ_P.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a graph and let v and w be distinct vertices of G. Then v and w are duplicates if they have the same neighborhoods.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph with vertices v_1, v_2, …, v_n; let H_1, H_2, …, H_n be pairwise disjoint graphs, and for each k let V_k be the vertex set of H_k. Then the superimposition of G on the graphs H_1, …, H_n is the graph with vertex set V_1 ∪ V_2 ∪⋯∪ V_n where vertices u ∈ V(H_i) and v ∈ V(H_j) are adjacent if either


  * v_i and v_j are adjacent in G or

  * i = j and u and v are adjacent in H_i.

If Φ and Ψ are two graph subspecies, then Φ♢Ψ denotes the species consisting of superimpositions of a Φ-graph on a set of Ψ-graphs.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Φ be a graph subspecies. We say that Φ is closed under creating and deleting duplicates of vertices if, for every graph G and any distinct vertices v and w that are duplicates of each other, the following condition holds:

plain_text_term: closed under creating and deleting duplicates of vertices

sentence: Given a general graph G, a vertex v of G is an endpoint of G if and only if d(v)=1 (where d(v) is defined as the degree of vertex v).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph G is a graph without endpoints if, for every vertex v of G, d(v)≠ 1. The species of graphs without endpoints is called M; if Φ is a graph subspecies, then the species of Φ-graphs without endpoints is called Φ_M.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a connected graph G, the induced subgraph C⊆ G is a core of G if and only if C is a maximal subgraph without endpoints.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let Φ be a graph subspecies. We say that Φ is closed under creating and deleting endpoints if, for every graph G and any endpoint v of G, the following condition holds:
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: closed under creating and deleting endpoints

sentence:
Let C⊆ be a category.
   
     
  
  *   Equivalently to saying C is case H, we also call C hy­per­oc­ta­he­dral .
  
  *  Hence, if instead C is case O, B or S, we say that C is non-hy­per­oc­ta­he­dral .
    
  *  The set of all non-hyperoctahedral categories is denoted by .

sentence:
We define the parameter domain 𝖫 as the six-fold Cartesian product of 𝔓(): 
    𝖫𝔓()×𝔓()×𝔓()×𝔓()×𝔓()×𝔓().
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Define the analyzer  Z:  𝔓()→𝖫 by
        
    Z (  F,  V, ,   L,   K,   X )

where, for all S⊆,


  * F( S){  |B| | p∈ S,  B block of  p} is the set of block sizes,

  * V( S){ σ_p(B)| p∈ S,  B block of p} is the set of block color sums,

  * ( S){ (p)| p∈ S} is the set of total color sums,

  * [t]
                L( S){ δ_p(α_1,α_2)|     p∈ S,   B block of p, α_1,α_2∈ B, α_1≠α_2,
     ]α_1,α_2[_p∩ B=∅, σ_p({α_1,α_2})≠ 0} 

is the set of color distances between any two subsequent legs of the same block having the same normalized color,

  * [t]
    K( S){ δ_p(α_1,α_2)|     p∈ S,   B block of p, α_1,α_2∈ B, α_1≠α_2,
     ]α_1,α_2[_p∩ B=∅, σ_p({α_1,α_2})= 0}

is the set of color distances between any two subsequent legs of the same block having different normalized colors and

  * [t]
    X( S){ δ_p(α_1,α_2) |     p∈ S,  B_1,B_2 blocks of p,   B_1 crosses  B_2,
    α_1∈ B_1, α_2∈ B_2} 

is the set of color distances between any two legs belonging to two crossing blocks.

sentence:
Define the parametrization as the mapping
        
    R: 𝖫→𝔓(),  L ↦ R_L{p∈| Z({p})≤ L}.

sentence:
Define the parameter range 𝖰 as the subset of 𝖫 comprising exactly all tuples
    
    (f,v,s,l,k,x)

    listed below, where  u∈{0}∪, m∈, D⊆{0}∪⌊m/2⌋, where E⊆{0}∪ and where N is a subsemigroup of (,+):
    f   v   s   l   k    x  
    
    {2}   ±{0, 2}    2um    m    m   
    {2}   ±{0, 2}    2um    m+2m    2m   
    {2}   ±{0, 2}    2um    m+2m    2m   \ m
    {2}   {0}   {0}   ∅    m   
    {2}   ±{0, 2}   {0}   {0}   {0}   \ N_0 
    {2}   {0}   {0}   ∅   {0}   \ N_0 
    {2}   {0}   {0}   ∅   {0}   \ N_0' 
    {1,2}   ±{0, 1, 2}    um    m    m   \ D_m
    {1,2}   ±{0, 1, 2}    2um    m+2m    2m   \ D_m
    {1,2}   ±{0, 1}    um   ∅    m   \ D_m 
    {1,2}   ±{0, 1, 2}   {0}   {0}   {0}   \ E_0 
    {1,2}   ±{0,  1}   {0}   ∅   {0}   \ E_0
           um    m    m   \ D_m
          {0}   {0}   {0}   \ E_0
