sentence:
There is a natural cyclic order on [n]. In this section it is convenient to “break” this order into a linear order, as follows:

    1<2<…<n.

We refer to this total ordering as the broken order . (See Section <ref> for more on this symmetry-breaking.)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a tabloid T, define the inversion number (T) to be the number of pairs (i, j) such that 1⩽i < j⩽n in the broken order and i appears strictly below j in T. Given a shape λ and a weight ρ∈^ℓ(λ), define the inversion number _λ(ρ) to be the sum of the entries of ρ that correspond to rows of λ of odd length. The inversion number (λ) of a partition continues to have the same meaning as above.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Suppose that T is a tabloid and T is a corresponding tableau such that, for some column indices c_1, c_2 and some nonnegative integers i, k, l, column c_1 of T is filled (in order from top to bottom) with the elements i+1, i+2, …, i+k+l and column c_2 is filled with the elements i+k+l+1, i+k+l+2, …, i+k+2l.  Then the forward column rebase of type (i, k, l) of T is the sequence of tableaux (T = T_0, T_1, …, T_(k + l) · l), where T_j is formed from T_j - 1 by switching the elements in positions ((k + l)m - j + 1, c_1) and (m, c_2), where m = ⌈ j/(k + l)⌉ is the unique integer such that

    (k + l) · (m - 1) + 1 ≤ j ≤ (k + l) · m.
 
We say that the reversed sequence is the backward column rebase of T' := T_(k + l) · l.  The forward column rebase of T is the sequence of tabloids that we get by forgetting the row orders in every tableau in the forward column rebase of T, and similarly for the backward column rebase of the tabloid T' associated to T'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: forward column rebase;type;backward column rebase;forward column rebase;backward column rebase

sentence:
[Quantitative Arratia–Pittel–Tavare Principle]
Suppose for each i=1,2,…, g_i(k) is a perturbed log-concave sequence in k, and define the distributions of Z_1, Z_2, … via Equation (<ref>), with x chosen such that Z_i^2 < ∞ for all i=1,2,…. 
Fix any constants 0<C_2, C_3 < ∞, and let 

    M : = { k ∈ℕ |  1/C_2≤| [k Z_k]/σ_max^2| ≤ C_2 [Z_k] ≥ C_3 };

and for any set B ⊂ [n], define M_B := M ∩ B, and  M_B^c := M ∩ B^c. 
Finally, define

    Ł(C_B) ≡Ł(C_B(m)) := Ł(Z_B | T_n=m),     .

Then 
  

  * If T_B satisfies a central limit theorem with rate O(r_B); or, more strongly, if σ_B,max/σ_B → 0 and σ_B e^-C  |M_B|→ 0, then for any m ∈(T_n), we have 

    d_TV(C_B, Z_B)     = d_TV(𝒩_B, 𝒩) + O(min(r_B,σ_B,max/σ_B + σ_B e^-C  |M_B|) + exp(- n-μ_B/σ_B) +  σ_B μ_err/ (σ_B^c)^2 + μ_err^2/(σ_B^c)^2 + 
           σ_max/σ + σ  e^-C_3 |M| + σ_B^c,max/σ_B^c + σ_B^c  e^-C_3 |M_B^c|).


  * If T_B is such that σ_1 → 1, then we have 

    d_TV(C_B, Z_B)     = O( (1- σ_1^2) +min(r_B,σ_B,max/σ_B + σ_B e^-C  |M_B|)+exp(- n-μ_B/σ_B) +  σ_B μ_err/ (σ_B^c)^2 + μ_err^2/(σ_B^c)^2 + 
           σ_max/σ + σ  e^-C_3 |M| + σ_B^c,max/σ_B^c + σ_B^c  e^-C_3 |M_B^c|).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>] 
Suppose U = {u_1, u_2, …} is given. 
Define A(u) for u>0 as the number of elements of U which are less than or equal to u. 
Assume 


  (i) s = lim_k→∞loglogu_k/logk exists;

  (ii) lim inf_k→∞logu_k/k > 0; 

  (iii) A(2k) = O(A(k)) as k →∞;

  (iv) (U) = 1;

  (v) lim suploglog u_k/logk < ∞.

When U satisfies condition (i) we say that U has exponential growth .  
Using the notation from <cit.>, let α denote the solution to 

    n = ∑_k u_k (e^α u_k-1)^-1,

and let

    A_2 = ∑_k u_k e^-α u_k/(1-e^-α u_k)^2.

Then for any integer m ≥ 2, we have

    p_U(n)     =  1/√(2π A_2)exp(∑_ν=0^∞[α u_k/e^α u_k-1 - log(1-e^-α u_k)]) ×
               (1 + ∑_ρ=1^m-2 D_ρ + O(f_U^1-(2m/3)(α)) ),

where expressions for D_ρ can be found in <cit.>, and the function f_U(x) = ∑_k e^-x u_k for x>0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A sequence a_1, a_2, … of real numbers is called log-concave if a_n^2 ≥ a_n+1 a_n-1 for all n ≥ 2.  
We say a discrete random variable X is log-concave if (X=k) is a log-concave sequence for k in the support of X.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say a random variable X is perturbed log-concave with constant C if there exists a random variable Y defined on the same support of X such that (Y=k) is log-concave in k for each k in the support of Y, and there is a positive constant C_1 such that

    1/C_1≤|  ℙ ( X_k=l )/ℙ( Y_k =l )| ≤ C_1;
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X_ℓ be one of the affine types listed
in Section <ref>
and let I be the
indexing set of its Dynkin nodes. A type X_ℓ path p of
length k, is a function p: {0, 1, …, k-1}→ I such
that there is a directed walk in the type X_ℓ crystal B^1,1
whose ith step corresponds to a p(i)-arrow.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a path p: {0,1, …, k-1}→ I we call the arrow corresponding to p(0) the tail of p, and the arrow corresponding to p(k-1) the head of p. An extension to the tail of p by a j-arrow is a path p':{0,1,…, k}→ I such that p'(t) = p(t-1) for 1 ≤ t ≤ k and p'(0) = j. An extension to the head of p by a j-arrow, is a path p”:{0,1, …, k}→ I such that p”(t) = p(t) for 0 ≤ t ≤ k-1 and p”(k) = j.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let p be a path of length k ≥ 1 in B^1,1. p is called a cyclotomic path of tail weight (Λ_i_1,Λ_i_2) if the following hold:
 

  * p(0) = i_2 and p(1) ≠ i_2. If p has length 1 then
p i_2 =, i.e. the head of p
cannot be extended by an i_2-arrow.  
  * p(0) and p(1) are not
a class  pair. If p has length 1 then there
is no i ∈ I such that the head of p can be extended by an
i-arrow and (p(0),i) is a class  pair.

  * p = {i_1}, i.e. p has a unique extension by an i_1-arrow to its tail.

  * (i_1(i_1 p)) =, i.e.
 p cannot have its tail extended twice by i_1-arrows.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We refer to 1 ∈ I in type D^(2)_3 and 2 ∈ I in types D^(1)_4 and B^(1)_3 as forbidden elements of I.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: A metric graph (G,d) is ε-densely k-chordal if for every cycle C with length L(C)≥ k, there exist strict shortcuts σ_1,...,σ_r  such that their associated shortcut vertices define an ε-dense subset in (C,d_C).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph (G,d) is ε-densely (k,m)-chordal if for every cycle C with length L(C)≥ k, there exist strict shortcuts σ_1,...,σ_r with L(σ_i)≤ m ∀  i and such that their associated shortcut vertices define an ε-dense subset in (C,d_C).
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A subset S⊂ V(G) is a separator if G∖ S has at least two connected components. Two vertices a and b are separated by S if they are in different connected components of G∖ S. If a and b are two vertices separated by S then S is said to be an ab-separator .
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: S is a minimal separator if no proper subset of S is a separator. Similarly, S is a minimal ab-separator if no proper subset of S separates a and b. Finally, S is a minimal vertex separator if it is a minimal separator for some pair of vertices.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A graph Γ is said to be μ-uniform if each vertex p of V has at most μ neighbors, i.e.,

    sup{|N(p)|  |    p∈ V(Γ)}≤μ.

If a graph Γ is μ-uniform for some constant μ we say that Γ is uniform .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: A geodesic metric space (X,d) satisfies Bottleneck Property (BP) if there exists some constant Δ>0 so that given any two distinct points x, y∈ X and a midpoint z such that d(x,z)=d(z,y)=1/2 d(x,y), then every xy-path intersects N_(z).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given r∈ℕ, two vertices a and b are r-separated by a subset S⊂ V(G) if considering the connected components of G∖ S, G_a and G_b containing a and b respectively, for every pair of vertices v∈ G_a and w∈ G_b, 
d(v,w)>r. If a and b are two vertices r-separated by S then S is said to be an  ab-r-separator .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: S is a minimal ab-r-separator if no proper subset of S r-separates a and b. Finally, S is a minimal vertex r-separator if it is a minimal r-separator for some pair of vertices.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A path  in a graph G is chordal if it has no 1-shortcuts in G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: In a geodesic metric space (X,d), we say that geodesics are stable if and only if there is a constant R≥ 0 such that given two points x,y∈ X and any geodesic [xy], then every geodesic  joining x to y satisfies that d_H(,[xy])≤ R.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: In a graph G, we say that geodesics between vertices are stable if and only if there is a constant R≥ 0 such that given two vertices a,b∈ G and any geodesic [ab], then every geodesic  joining a to b satisfies that d_H(,[ab])≤ R.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A dendriform bialgebra over  is a dendriform algebra (H, ≻ ,≺ ) equipped with a coassociative coproduct  Δ :H^+⟶ H^+⊗ H^+ and a counit ϵ : H^+⟶ satisfying the following conditions:


  * (ϵ⊗ Id)∘Δ (x)=1_⊗ x and (Id⊗ϵ)∘Δ (x)=x⊗ 1_,

  * Δ (x≻  y):=∑ (x_(1)*y_(1))⊗ (x_(2)≻  y_(2)), 

  * Δ (x≺  y):=∑ (x_(1)*y_(1))⊗ (x_(2)≺  y_(2)), 
for all x,y∈ H where *  = ≻ + ≺, Δ (x)=∑ x_(1)⊗ x_(2), and by convention:
 
  * (x*y)⊗ (1_≻ 1_):=(x≻  y)⊗ 1_,  
 
  * (x*y)⊗ (1_≺ 1_):=(x≺  y)⊗ 1_, for x,y∈ H.
A q-tridendriform bialgebra is a q-tridendriform algebra H with a coproduct Δ such that:
 

  * (H,≽ , ≺ ) is a dendriform bialgebra,

  * Δ (x·  y):=∑ (x_(1)*y_(1))⊗ (x_(2)·  y_(2)),

where (x*y)⊗ (1_· 1_):=(x·  y)⊗ 1_.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Narayana numbers are defined as
  
    N_n,k=1/nnk-1nk

for 1≤ n and  1≤ k≤ n, and N_0,0=1. All other indices give
N_n,k=0. Combinatorially, for n≥ 1 the Narayana number N_n,k corresponds to the number of
plane trees with n edges (i.e. n+1 nodes) and k leaves.
  The Narayana polynomials are defined as
  
    N_n(x)=∑_k=1^nN_n,kx^k-1

for n≥1 and N_0(x)=1, and the associated Narayana polynomials are defined
as

    Ñ_n(x) = x· N_n(x)

for n≥ 0. Note that

    N_n(1) = Ñ_n(1) = C_n = 1/n+12nn

is the nth Catalan number.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The Fibonacci polynomials are recursively defined by

    F_r(z)=F_r-1(z)+zF_r-2(z)

for r≥ 2 and F_0(z)=0, F_1(z)=1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A concrete LP-type problem is a triple (X,, ≼), where X is a set linearly ordered
by ≼,  is a finite multiset whose elements are subsets of X, and for any ⊆,
 if ∩≠∅, then ∩ has a unique minimum element with respect to ≼. 
We call this unique minimum element ω(G) (this is in relation to the more abstract notion below).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider a pair (, ω), where  is a finite 
set of constraints, 
and ω is a function 
ω:∈ 2^→Λ, where Λ is a linearly ordered set including
an element ∞.
We say h violates F when ω(F+h) > ω(F). 
The pair (,ω) is an LP-type problem if it satisfies:


Monotonicity:     ω(G + h) ≥ω(G) holds for all G⊆ and h ∈, and

Locality:     For all F ⊆ G ⊆, such that ω(F) = ω(G), 

     h violates F if and only if h violates G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Consider a pair (, ω), where  is a finite 
set of constraints, 
and ω is a function 
ω:∈ 2^→Λ, where Λ is a linearly ordered set including
an element ∞.
We say h violates F when ω(F+h) > ω(F). 
The pair (,ω) is an LP-type problem if it satisfies:


Monotonicity:     ω(G + h) ≥ω(G) holds for all G⊆ and h ∈, and

Locality:     For all F ⊆ G ⊆, such that ω(F) = ω(G), 

     h violates F if and only if h violates G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A basis 
B⊆ is a subset such that ω(B - h) < ω(B) holds for all h ∈ B. 
For G⊆, a basis of G  is a minimal subset B of G with ω(B)=ω(G).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The size of a largest basis of an LP-type problem is called its combinatorial dimension 
and denoted by δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
A parameterized LP-type problem is a concrete LP-type problem (X,,≼)
in which the ground set
X =  (λ', X'), the linear order ≼ = λ', and the level sets are nested.
That is, a level set h_λ =  {  x' :   (λ',x') ∈λ' = λ}
is contained in the level set h_μ for all μ≥λ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a graph Γ, and j,k ∈ℕ, let W = (v_0, v_1, ⋯, v_j = v_0) be a closed walk on Γ. Now for t = 0, …, j-1, assign to vertex v_t the label t  k, so that at the end of the walk, vertex v_t has a list of labels l_t, each belonging to {0, …, k-1}. If vertex v_t occurs r times in the list (v_0, …, v_j-1) then l_t is a list of r labels, which may or may not all be distinct. We refer to the list of labelled vertices

    W_k  def= ((v_0, l_0), (v_1,l_1), ⋯, )

as a k-labelled walk.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The resonance arrangement is a set of hyperplanes W_I,J intersecting the region

    R_m,n={(μ_1,…, μ_m,ν_1,…,ν_n)∈^m+n| μ_i,ν_j>0; ∑_i=1^nμ_i=∑_j=1^n ν_j }.


For I⊂ [m], J⊂ [n] proper subsets, the hyperplane, or wall, W_I,J is the set of μ,ν∈ R_m,n satisfying

    ∑_i∈ Iμ_I =∑_j∈ Jν_J.


A chamber 𝔠 of the resonance arrangement is a connected component of the complement of the W_I,J inside R_m,n.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The infinite wedge V is the span of vectors of the form

    V=⊕_ (i_k)i_1∧i_2∧⋯

where the sum is over all decreasing sequences of half integers i_k∈+1/2 such that

    i_k+k-1/2=c  for k sufficiently large.

Here, c is some constant known as the charge .  This terminology is borrowed from physics, and will be explain in Sections <ref> and <ref>
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The charge operator C is defined by

    C=∑_k∈+1/2 E_kk

The energy operator E is defined by

    E=∑_k∈+1/2 k E_kk
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
For |μ|=|ν| partitions with ordered parts, a commutation pattern P consists of four m+n-1-tuples of sets I^P_ℓ, J^P_ℓ, K^P_ℓ, L^P_ℓ,

    I^P_ℓ, K^P_ℓ⊂ [m], J^P_ℓ, L^P_ℓ⊂ [n], 1≤ℓ≤ n+m-1

such that the algorithm has a nonvanishing term where the kth commutator computed was [I^P_kJ^P_k, K^P_kL^P_k].

We denote the set of all possible commutation patterns P for a given μ,ν by CP(μ,ν).
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The φ-totally negative chamber is the chamber defined by the following inequalities, for all k>1:

    φ(k)>∑_ℓ⋧ kφ(ℓ).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The sequence of parking preferences s = (s_1,s_2,,s_n) is called a classical parking function of length n if the parking procedure results in all n drivers successfully parking.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: classical parking function of length n

sentence: A sequence s ∈ [n]^n is a parking function on T if the parking procedure allows all cars to park on T.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A parking distribution is a parking function (T,s) such that s is weakly increasing.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A parking function (T,s) is prime if, for every non-root vertex v ∈ [n], we have |T_v| < |{i : s_i ∈ T_v}|.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a parking function (T,s), we say that an edge e is used by s if there exists some driver who, after failing to park at her preferred spot, crosses e during her search for an unoccupied spot.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For an ordered tree 𝒯 with |𝒯|=n and sequence p ∈ [n]^n, we say the pair (𝒯,p) is a standardized restricted prime parking function if 


  * (𝒯,p) is a prime parking function when 𝒯 is considered an unordered tree.

  * For any pair of sibling vertices, {u,v}⊆ V(𝒯), the vertex v is ordered to the right of u if and only if the edge (v,w), where w is the parent vertex, is crossed by some driver before the edge (u,w) is crossed during the parking procedure.

  * 𝒯 is labeled via post-order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A coloring of the vertex set V of some graph G=(V,E) with m colors
is called perfect if (1) all colors are used, and (2) for all i,j 
the number of neighbors of colors j of any vertex v of color i is 
a constant a_ij. The matrix A=(a_ij)_1 ≤ i,j ≤ m is called the
color adjacency matrix of the perfect coloring.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
Δ=(x_1, … , x_n ) is an order of the derivatives of a tree T,
when x_1, … , x_n are different vertices of T (all different from the root) and
x_k is a neighbor of the root in x_k-1…x_1
T. In this case we write ∂_ΔT=x_n…x_1 T.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let x≠ r be a vertex of an oriented  tree T∈ and let
(x_0,…,x_n) be the shortest path connecting the root r=x_0 and x=x_n. 
Let 1≤ i≤ n-1 be the biggest index such that x_i-1≺ x_i ≻
x_i+1 or x_i-1≻ x_i ≺ x_i+1. If such an index exists we say
that x_i is the last bend of x. 
We say that vertices x,y ∈ T are in the same layer if one of the following conditions holds true:


  * x and y have the same last bend; 

  * x,y≺ r or x,y≻ r.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let τ I → J be a matching and C one of its open clusters.  
  Consider the list consisting of all numbers in I∪ J, sorted in ascending order.
  (If i_m = j_m' for some m and m',
  then include that number twice in the list.)
  Let the endpoint separation C of the cluster C
  be the number of entries in this sorted list lying strictly between
  the numbers labelling the two endpoints of C.
  For closed clusters C, we set C=0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Endpoint separation]
  Let τ I → J be a matching and C one of its open clusters.  
  Consider the list consisting of all numbers in I∪ J, sorted in ascending order.
  (If i_m = j_m' for some m and m',
  then include that number twice in the list.)
  Let the endpoint separation C of the cluster C
  be the number of entries in this sorted list lying strictly between
  the numbers labelling the two endpoints of C.
  For closed clusters C, we set C=0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a discrete set S ⊂^d, we define the k-quantitative Helly number _S(k) as the smallest number for which the following statement holds.  For any finite family  of convex sets in ^d such that for every subfamily ' of cardinality _S(k) or less we know that ∩' has at least k points of S, then ∩ contains at least k points of S.  If no such number exists, we consider _S(k) = ∞.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say f:_d →^+ ∪{∞} admits a Helly theorem if given 1>ε>0 there is an integer H(f,d,ε) such that for any finite family  and λ >0, if every subfamily ' of cardinality at most H(f,d,ε) satifies f(∩') ≥λ, then f(∩) ≥ (1-ε)λ.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say f:_d →^+∪{∞} can be approximated by inscribed polytopes if for every 1> ε > 0 there is a constant C(f,d,ε) such that for every ∞ > λ≥ 0 and every convex set K ⊂^d with f(K) ≥λ, there is a polytope P ⊂^d such that
	
		
  * P ⊂ K,
		
  * P has at most C(f,d,ε) vertices, and
		
  * f(P) ≥ (1-ε) λ.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: can be approximated by inscribed polytopes

sentence: We say f:_d →^+∪{∞} admits a fractional Helly theorem if, given 1>ε>0, there is an integer F=F(f,d,ε) such that for any α>0 there is a β = β (α, f, d, ε) >0 such that the following holds.  Given any finite family  of convex sets in ^d, if there are at least α||F subsets A ⊂ of cardinality F that satisfy f(∩ A) ≥ 1, there is a subset ' ⊂ of cardinality at least β || such that f(∩') ≥ 1-ε.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say f:_d →^+ ∪{∞} admits a Tverberg theorem if, given 1>ε>0, there is an integer T(f,d,ε) such that for any positive integer m and any real λ >0, given a family = {T_1, T_2, …, T_n} of n=(m-1)T(f,d,ε)+1 convex sets T_i ⊂^d such that f(T_i) ≥λ for all i, there is a partition of  into m parts A_1, A_2, …, A_m such that
	
    f( ⋂_j=1^m  (∪ A_j)) ≥λ (1-ε)
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let f:_d →^+ ∪{∞} be a monotone function that can be approximated by inscribed polytopes and let r(f,d,ε) = max{d · C(f,d,ε/2), d+1}.  We say f admits a selection theorem if for any 1>ε>0 there is a constant ρ(f,d,ε) such that for any λ >0 and any finite family  of convex sets in ^d, if f(T) ≥λ for all T ∈, there is a convex set T_0 with f(T_0) ≥λ (1-ε) contained in the convex hull of the union at least ρ||r(f,d,ε) subsets A ⊂ of cardinality r(f,d,ε).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given f:_d →^+ ∪{∞} and 1>ε' > 0, we say f admits bounded weak ε'-nets for convex sets if for every 1>ε >0 there is a constant m=m(f,d,ε, ε') such that for every λ >0 and every finite family  of convex sets in ^d with f(T) ≥λ for all T ∈, there is a family _0 of at most m convex sets in ^d with f(T_0) ≥ (1-ε)λ for all T_0 ∈_0 such that for every subset A ⊂ of cardinality at least ε' ||, there is at least one set of _0 contained in (∪ A).
	
	We say that _0 is a ε'-weak net for the pair (, ε) if it satisfies the conditions above.

sentence:
Given λ >0 and a finite family ⊂_d, we define the f-transversal number τ_(f,λ)() as the minimum ∑_C∈_d(f,λ)w(C) over all functions w:_d(f,λ) →{0,1} such that
	
    ∑_C: C ⊂ F, C ∈_d(f,λ) w(C) ≥ 1

	for all F ∈.

sentence:
Given λ >0 and a finite family ⊂_d, we define the fractional f-transversal number τ^*_(f,λ)() as the minimum ∑_C∈_d(f,λ)w(C) over all functions w:_d(f,λ) → [0,1] such that
	
    ∑_C: C ⊂ F, C ∈_d(f,λ) w(C) ≥ 1

	for all F ∈.

sentence:
Given λ >0 and a finite family ⊂_d, we define the fractional f-packing number ν^*_(f,λ)() as the maximum ∑_F ∈ w(F) over all functions w: → [0,1] such that
	
    ∑_F: C ⊂ F, F ∈ w(F) ≤ 1

	for all C ∈_d(f,λ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a monotone function f:_d →^+ ∪{∞}, we say that there is a floating body for f if for every 1 > ε > 0, there is a δ = δ(ε) > 0 such that any convex set K with f(K) < ∞, there is a convex set K(f,ε) such that 
	
		
  * f(K(f,ε)) ≥ (1- δ)f(K) and
		
  * for any convex set A, if f(A ∩ K) ≥ (1-ε)f(K), then K(f,ε) ⊂ A.
	
	Morevoer, we require that δ (ε) → 0 if ε→ 0.  Throughout the rest of this section we will assume that f and d are fixed.  Even though δ (ε) depends on them, it will be useful to denote it this way.

sentence: For a digraph D, the closure D̅ of D is the digraph with vertex set V(D̅) := V( D) and edge set E(D̅):=E( D) ∪{( a,b ) :( b ,a ) ∈ E( D)  is in a directed cycle of D}.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph G is a threshold graph if it can be constructed recursively from K_1 by successively adding either a dominating vertex or an isolated vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A graph with (perhaps) loops is loop-threshold if it can be obtained from K_1, or K_1 with a loop, by successively adding an unlooped isolated vertex, or a looped dominating vertex.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let W be a Coxeter group. We say that a conjugacy class C
  satisfies the cyclic version of Matsumoto's theorem if any two
  cyclically reduced expressions of elements in C differ by braid relations
  and cyclic shifts.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An element w∈ W is cyclically fully commutative (CFC) if
  every cyclic shift of every reduced expression for w is a reduced
  expression for an FC element.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let w∈(W) and say that (W',S') is the Coxeter system
  generated by (w). We say that w has an st-band if
  for some reduced expression  and distinct generators s,t∈
  S', exactly one of which is an odd endpoint of (W',S'), the
  following two conditions hold:
  
  
  * some cyclic shift of  is commutation equivalent to a
    reduced expression containing s,t_m(s,t)-1 as a subword;
  
  * neither s nor t appears elsewhere in .
  
  We analogously define an ts-band (i.e., some cyclic shift
  of  is commutation equivalent to a reduced expression containing
  t,s_m(s,t)-1 as a subword).  If we do not care to specify
  whether s or t comes first, then we will simply say that w has
  a band . An st-band is called small if m(s,t)=3,
  and large otherwise.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
The game v is inessential if
  v (S) = ∑ _ i ∈ S  v ( { i }) for all
  S ⊂ N. That is, each coalition obtains the same value
  working together as its individual members would obtain working
  separately.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let d:=||=|μ|=|ν|.
A Young hypergraph H of type (,μ,ν) is a hypergraph with d vertices such that


  * There are three layers of hyperedges corresponding to ν, μ, and ν, respectively.

  * Every vertex lies in exactly three hyperedges, one from each layer.

  * There is a bijection between the vertices of H and the boxes in  such that
two vertices lie in a common hyperedge in layer 1 iff the corresponding boxes in  lie in the same column.
Analogously for layer 2 and μ and for layer 3 and ν. ▪
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Suppose λ⊢ N and μ⊢ N. We say λ dominates μ if λ_1+…+λ_i≥μ_1+…+μ_i for all i and we write λμ (and λμ if λμ and λ≠μ).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A be a multiset of partitions and let λ be a partition. We define the (generalized) Littlewood-Richardson coefficients c_A^λ by

    s_A = ∑_λc_A^λ s_λ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O

sentence:
A∈𝒮𝒫_N^2 is nested if no pair of partitions {λ,μ} in A satisfies any one of the following conditions:


  *  λ=(λ_1≥λ_2>0), μ=(μ_1≥μ_2>0), with 
    λ_1>μ_1≥λ_2>μ_2 ;


  *  λ=(λ_1>λ_2>0), μ=(μ_1>0), with 
    λ_1≥μ_1≥λ_2 ;


  *  λ=(λ_1>0), μ=(μ_1>0).

A pair satisfying one of the above conditions is called a bad pair .
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If ϕ (A) = λ = (λ_1, …, λ_2 ℓ) ⊢ N with λ_1 ≥λ_2 ≥…≥λ_2ℓ > 0, we say A is completely separated if 
    A={(λ_1, λ_2), (λ_3, λ_4), …, (λ_2ℓ-1, λ_2ℓ)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If ϕ (A) = λ = (λ_1, …, λ_2 ℓ) ⊢ N with λ_1 ≥λ_2 ≥…≥λ_2ℓ > 0, we say A is completely nested if 
    A={(λ_1, λ_2ℓ), (λ_2, λ_2ℓ-1), …, (λ_ℓ, λ_ℓ+1)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: For A, B ∈𝒮𝒫_λ^2, we say A and B agree within ρ = (ρ_1,ρ_2) if whenever ρ_1>μ_1>μ_2>ρ_2, then μ∈ A if and only if μ∈ B.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A formal power series f∈ℝ[[x_1,x_2,…]] of bounded degree is a symmetric function if, for any permutation π : ℤ_>0→ℤ_>0, f(x_1,x_2,…) = f(x_π(1),x_π(2),…).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let λ be a partition. We define the monomial symmetric functions by

    m_λ = ∑_αx_1^α_1x_2^α_2…

where the sum runs over all rearrangements α = (α_1,α_2,…) of λ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let n≥ 0. We define the complete homogeneous symmetric functions by

    h_n = ∑_λ⊢ nm_λ.
 
    h_λ=∏_i≥ 1 h_λ_i
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence:
If λ is a partition of N, we define the Schur function by

    s_λ = ∑_SSYT T
    sh(T) = λx^T.

sentence:
A∈𝒮𝒫_N^2 is nested if no pair of partitions {λ,μ} in A satisfies any one of the following conditions:


  *  λ=(λ_1≥λ_2>0), μ=(μ_1≥μ_2>0), with 
    λ_1>μ_1≥λ_2>μ_2 ;


  *  λ=(λ_1>λ_2>0), μ=(μ_1>0), with 
    λ_1≥μ_1≥λ_2 ;


  *  λ=(λ_1>0), μ=(μ_1>0).

A pair satisfying one of the above conditions is called a bad pair .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Suppose ρ = (p,p) and k is a non-negative integer. We define the notation λ[ρ^k] recursively as follows: define λ[ρ^0] = λ. For k≥ 0, we say that λ[ρ^k+1] is undefined if λ[ρ^k] is undefined or if λ[ρ^k] has less than two p's. Otherwise, we define λ[ρ^k+1] = (λ[ρ^k])[ρ].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let g'=⟨ R_g' ,C_g' ,E_g'⟩ and g”=⟨ R_g” ,C_g” ,E_g”⟩ are two bipartite graphs.
We will say that the graphs g' and g” are isomorphic and we will write

    g'≅ g” ,

if |R_g' |=|R_g” |=n, |C_g' |=|C_g” |=m and there exist ρ∈𝒮_n and σ∈𝒮_m such that  ⟨ r,c⟩∈ E_g'⇔⟨ρ (r),σ (c)⟩∈ E_g”.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A,B∈𝔅_n× m. We will say that the matrices A and B are equivalent and we will write

    A∼B,

if there exist permutation matrices X∈𝒫_n and Y∈𝒫_m, such that

    A=XBY.


In other words A ∼ B if A is received from B after dislocation of some of the rows and the columns of B.
Obviously, the introduced relation is an equivalence relation.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A∈𝔅_n× m,
r(A)=⟨ x_1 ,x_2 ,… ,x_n⟩ and
c(A)=⟨ y_1 ,y_2 ,… ,y_m⟩.
We will call the matrix A semi-canonical , if

    x_1≤ x_2≤⋯≤ x_n

and

    y_1≤ y_2≤⋯≤ y_m .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We will call the matrix A∈𝔅_n× m canonical matrix , if r(A) is a minimal element about the lexicographic order in the set A= { r(B)  |  B ∼ A}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 0 ≠ξ∈. The additive energy of A and ξ A is defined in the following equivalent ways

    E_+(A, ξ A) 
        = ∑_x ∈ r_A ±ξ A^2(x) 
        = number of solutions to (a_1-a_2) = ξ (a_3-a_4) with the a_i ∈ A
        = |A|^2 + number of solutions to a_1-a_2/a_3-a_4 = ξ with the a_i ∈ A.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A unital associative algebra A over a field 𝕂 is a 𝕂-linear space endowed with two algebra homomorphisms: 
  
  
  * a product m :⊗→ satisfying the associativity condition:
    
    ∀Γ∈, m∘(m⊗𝕀)(Γ)=   m∘(𝕀⊗ m)(Γ),

  
  * a unit u :→ satisfying:
    
    ∀Γ∈, m∘(u⊗𝕀)(Γ)=   Γ=m∘(𝕀⊗ u)(Γ).
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A coalgebra  over a field  is a -linear space endowed with two algebra homomorphisms: 
  
  
  * a coproduct Δ :→⊗ satisfying the coassociativity condition:
    
    ∀Γ∈, (Δ⊗𝕀)∘Δ(Γ)=   (𝕀⊗Δ)∘Δ(Γ),

  
  * a counit :→ satisfying:
    
    ∀Γ∈, (⊗𝕀)∘Δ(Γ)=   Γ=(𝕀⊗)∘Δ(Γ).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A bialgebra  over a field  is a -linear space endowed with both an algebra and a coalgebra structure (see Definitions <ref> and <ref>) such that the coproduct and the counit are unital algebra homomorphisms (or equivalently the product and unit are coalgebra homomorphisms):
  
    
    
    Δ∘ m_=   m_⊗∘(Δ⊗Δ), Δ(1_)=1_⊗ 1_,
    ∘ m_=   m_∘(⊗), (1_)=1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A graded bialgebra is a bialgebra graded as a linear space: 
  
    =⊕_n=0^∞^(n)

  such that the grading is compatible with the algebra and coalgebra structures:
  
    ^(n)^(m)⊆^(n+m) and Δ^(n)⊆⊕_k=0^n^(k)⊗^(n-k) .
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Hopf algebra  over a field  is a bialgebra over  equipped with an antipode map S:→ obeying:
  
    m∘(S⊗𝕀)∘Δ=   u∘=m∘(𝕀⊗ S)∘Δ.

sentence: Let Γ∈, Γ^[1] its set of internal edges and Γ^[0] its vertices. A subgraph γ of Γ, written γ⊂Γ, consists in a subset γ^[1] of Γ^[1] and the vertices of Γ^[0] hooked to the edges in γ^[1].

sentence:
[Algebra]
  A unital associative algebra A over a field 𝕂 is a 𝕂-linear space endowed with two algebra homomorphisms: 
  
  
  * a product m :⊗→ satisfying the associativity condition:
    
    ∀Γ∈, m∘(m⊗𝕀)(Γ)=   m∘(𝕀⊗ m)(Γ),

  
  * a unit u :→ satisfying:
    
    ∀Γ∈, m∘(u⊗𝕀)(Γ)=   Γ=m∘(𝕀⊗ u)(Γ).

sentence:
[Coalgebra]
  A coalgebra  over a field  is a -linear space endowed with two algebra homomorphisms: 
  
  
  * a coproduct Δ :→⊗ satisfying the coassociativity condition:
    
    ∀Γ∈, (Δ⊗𝕀)∘Δ(Γ)=   (𝕀⊗Δ)∘Δ(Γ),

  
  * a counit :→ satisfying:
    
    ∀Γ∈, (⊗𝕀)∘Δ(Γ)=   Γ=(𝕀⊗)∘Δ(Γ).

and n ≥ C/^4 for a sufficiently large absolute constant C, then there exists a finite subgroup H of G of order at most C √(n) which contains at least (1-C^2) n of the A_i.

sentence:
A pure nondeterministic graph 3muG=(V,) is a
hierarchical cyclic graph if one of conditions
(i) or (ii) holds:



  (i) V=1 and 4.5mu=∅.


  (ii) There exist V_1, …, V_k, _1, …,
            _k, a_1, …, a_k, with k > 1, such that:

  


   
   2pt

    
  * V_1, …, V_k are nonempty pairwise disjoint subsets of
    4muV and V=⋃_i=1^kV_i.

    
  * _i consists of all actions in  whose sources
    and targets lie in V_i, for i=1, …, k.

    
  * (V_i,  _i) is a hierarchical cyclic graph, for i=1, …, k.

    
  * = {a_1, …, a_k} 4.5mu ⋃_i=1^k_i.

    
  * For i=1, …, k, (a_i) ∈ V_i and 4mu(a_i) ⊆ V_i+1
          
 (here indices wrap around, so V_k+1 again means V_1).
   



The decomposition above need not be unique.  We implicitly assume a
specific decomposition when stating that a graph is hierarchical
cyclic.  We refer to it as the tree decomposition of
G.




A graph of type (i) is a leaf and a graph of type (ii)
is a node.




When G is a node, we refer to the subgraphs (V_1, _1),
…, (V_k, _k) in .09emG's tree decomposition as
the .06emchildren of G.  Each subgraph
1mu(V_i, _i) is itself either a leaf or a node, with
.07emparent (V, ).  When (V_i, _i)
is a node, we may then speak of its children, and so forth.
Transitively, we may therefore speak of all the nodes
and leaves within G (that includes (V, )).  Finally,
we may speak of the root of the tree decomposition of
1.75muG, meaning the node or leaf (V, ), i.e., G
itself.




For a graph of type (ii), the actions a_1, …, a_k are the
(top-level) cycle actions of G.  Similarly, if N is
any node within G, the cycle actions of N are the
top-level cycle actions of N when N is viewed as a hierarchical
cyclic graph in its own right.

	for Motzkin trees as well.

sentence: Let G(V,E) be a graph and v∈ V(G). The clique substitution at v is the graph obtain from G by replacing v with a clique of size |N_G(v)| and matching vertices in N_G(v) with the vertices of that clique. The clique substitution of G is the graph obtained from G by performing clique substitutions at all vertices of G. We refer to a clique substituted for a vertex of G as a knot (of K(G)).

sentence:
Let a prime p be fixed.  By a linear datum , we mean a tuple Ψ = (V, (W_i)_i ∈ I, (ψ_i)_i∈ I), where I is some finite index set, and
  
    
  * V and W_i for i ∈ I are finite-dimensional vector spaces over _p;
    
  * ψ_i  V → W_i are surjective linear maps.
  

  Given a positive integer n, we abuse notation to write ψ_i  V^n → W_i^n for the map that applies ψ_i to each coordinate.  Now, for a collection of functions (f_i)_i ∈ I with f_i  W_i^n →, we define
  
    Λ_Ψ((f_i)_i ∈ I) = _v ∈ V^n∏_i ∈ I f_i(ψ_i(v))   .

sentence:
Suppose we have two linear data Ψ = (V, (W_i)_i ∈ I, (ψ_i)_i ∈ I) and Ψ' = (V', (W'_i)_i∈ I', (ψ'_i)_i ∈ I').  Suppose further that for some pair j ∈ I, j' ∈ I' the subspaces W'_j' = W_j are identified.  Finally, let c > 0 be a positive real number.

  We say Ψ' dominates Ψ respecting (j,j') with exponent c if the following holds: for n ≥ 1 and any collection of functions (f_i)_i ∈ I, f_i  W_i^n → with f_i_∞≤ 1, there exist functions (g_i)_i ∈ I', g_i W'_i^n →, g_i_∞≤ 1, such that g_j' = f_j, and
  
    | Λ_Ψ((f_i)_i ∈ I) | ≤| Λ_Ψ'((g_i)_i ∈ I') |^c .

sentence:
Let ϕ_1,…,ϕ_6  V →_p be non-zero linear forms, with [ϕ_1],…,[ϕ_4] in general position, and let ℓ be a subspace of dimension 2 in V^∗ containing ϕ_5, ϕ_6 but none of ϕ_1,…,ϕ_4.  An augmented datum representing (ϕ_1,…,ϕ_6;ℓ) is a linear datum Ψ = (V ⊕_p, (W_i)_i∈ I, (ψ_i)_i∈ I) where I =[6], W_i = _p for each 1 ≤ i ≤ 4 and W_5 = W_6 = _p^2, and ψ_i  V ⊕_p → W_i satisfy:
  
    
  * for 1 ≤ i ≤ 4 and any (v,t) ∈ V ⊕_p we have ψ_i(v, t) = ϕ_i(v);
    
  * for i = 5, 6 and any (v, t) ∈ V ⊕_p we have ψ_i(v, t) = (ϕ_i(v), t + χ_i(v)) for some χ_i ∈ℓ.
  

  Also, the standard datum representing (ϕ_1,…,ϕ_6) is just Ψ' = (V, (W'_i)_i ∈ I, (ϕ_i)_i ∈ I) where I = [6] and W'_i = _p for each i, as in Lemma <ref>.

sentence:
A graph G is called a plane semi-partial 3-tree if 
G is obtained from a plane 3-tree H by erasing some of the tilted edges of H.

sentence:
Let F be a connected plane partial 3-tree with maximum degree Δ, and 
let k be an integer. We say that a 3-tree H correctly covers F up 
to level k , if the following conditions are satisfied:


  * F is a spanning subgraph of H.

  * Let V^≤ k denote the set of vertices that have level at most k in 
H. For every vertex v∈ V^≤ k there are at most 36Δ balanced 
edges of H that are incident to v.
                        
Furthermore, we say that H correctly covers F at all levels if, 
for any k, H correctly covers F up to level k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: correctly covers F at all levels

sentence:
Let B be a nontrivial bubble in a tripod T. The unique internal face of 
B adjacent to its root edge will be called the root face of B. The 
dual of a bubble B is the rooted binary tree  whose nodes 
correspond bijectively to the internal faces of B, and two nodes are 
adjacent if and only if the corresponding faces of B share an edge. The 
root of the tree  is the node that represents the root face of B. 

When dealing with the internal faces of B, we will employ the usual 
terminology of rooted trees; for instance, we say that a face Φ is the 
parent (or child) of a face Ψ if the node representing Φ in 
 is the parent (or child) of the node representing Ψ. For 
every internal face Φ of B, the three edges that form the boundary of Φ 
will be called the top edge , the left edge and the right 
edge , where the top edge is the edge that Φ shares with its parent face 
(or the root edge, if Φ is the root face), while left and right edges are 
defined in such a way that the top, left, and right edge form a 
counterclockwise sequence on the boundary of Φ. With this convention, we 
may speak of a left child face or right child face of Φ without any 
ambiguity. Our terminology is motivated by the usual convention of embedding 
rooted binary trees with their root on the top, and the parent, the left child 
and the right child appearing in counterclockwise order around every node of 
the tree. Furthermore, for a given face Φ, the bottom vertex of 
Φ is the common vertex of the left edge and right edge of Φ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: the root face;dual;the top edge;the left edge;bottom vertex

sentence:
An adder A is a bubble with a root edge h and another edge t≠ 
h, such that the dual tree of A is a path, and the edge t is an external 
edge adjacent to the single leaf face of A. See Figure <ref>. The 
edges h and t are called head and tail of the adder. It is 
easy to see that every adder contains a unique path Z whose first edge is 
h, its last edge is t and no other edge of Z belongs to the outer face 
of A. The path Z will be called the zigzag path of the adder A. 
The length of the adder is defined to be the number of edges of its 
zigzag path. By definition, each adder has length at least 2. An adder of 
length 2 will be called degenerate .

sentence:
[Arnoux-Rauzy words]   
Let 𝒜 = {1,2,…,d}. 
An infinite word ω∈𝒜^ℕ is an Arnoux-Rauzy word if all its factors occur infinitely often, and if for all n it has (d-1)n+1 factors of length n, with exactly one left special and one right special factor of length n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Weak and strong partial quotients]
Let ω be an  Arnoux-Rauzy word with 𝒮-directive sequence (i_m)_m ≥ 0.
Write 

    i_0 i_1 i_2 ⋯ = j_0^k_0 j_1^k_1 j_2^k_2⋯,

where j_n ∈𝒜, k_n ≥ 1, and j_n ≠ j_n +1 for all n ≥ 0.
The powers k_n are called weak partial quotients .

Let (n_ℓ)_ℓ≥ 0 be the increasing sequence of integers satisfying n_0 = 0,

    {i_n_ℓ, i_n_ℓ+1, …,  i_n_ℓ+1} = 𝒜    {i_n_ℓ, i_n_ℓ+1, …,  i_n_ℓ+1-1}≠𝒜

for all ℓ≥ 0.
The quantity (n_ℓ+1 - n_ℓ) is called strong partial quotient .

sentence:
[C-balance] 
Let C ∈ℕ. 
A pair of words u, v ∈𝒜^* with |u| = |v| is C-balanced if 

    -C ≤ |u|_j - |v|_j ≤ C    j ∈𝒜 .

A word ω∈𝒜^ℕ is C-balanced if all pairs of factors u, v of ω with |u| = |v| are C-balanced.
A word ω∈𝒜^ℕ is said to be finitely balanced if there exists C ∈ℕ such that it is C-balanced.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A finite point-line
incidence structure is called linear space
if each line contains at least two points and any
two distinct points are on exactly one line.
If there are exactly r lines through each point, then the linear space
is called (r,1)-design .

A (v_r,b_k)-configuration is a finite point-line incidence
structure with the following properties:


  * There are v points and b lines.

  * There are r lines through each point and there are
k points on each line.

  * Two distinct lines intersect each other at most once
and two distinct points are connected by at most one line.


If v=b and r=k, then the configuration is called
symmetric (v_k)-configuration .
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A connected and locally finite planar graph G is a planar tessellation , or just tessellation , if it satisfies the following conditions.



  (i) Every edge is contained in exactly two different faces.

  (ii) Every bounded face is a polygon: it is homeomorphic to the closed disk 𝔻, and its boundary is a simple cycle (i.e. a finite path in which the first and the last vertices coincide). The edges of the cycle are called sides of the polygon.

  (iii) The intersection of any two distinct faces are either an empty set, or a vertex, or an edge.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a locally-finite and connected graph. Let 
    P(V):={μ:V→ [0,1]  |  ∑_x∈ Vμ(x)=1, μ(x)>0  x}
 be the space of all probability measures on V with finite supports. 

Given any μ,ν∈ P(V), a transport plan (or, in short, a plan ) from μ to ν is a function π: V× V → [0,1] satisfying 

    μ(x) = ∑_y∈ Vπ(x,y)         ν(y)=∑_x∈ Vπ(x,y).


Furthermore, define ∏(μ,ν) to be the set of all transport plans from μ to ν, and the (transportation) cost of a plan π is given by 
    (π)=∑_x,y∈ V d(x,y)π(x,y).

sentence:
[Combinatorial Cartan-Hadamard]
Let G=(V,E,F) be a tessellation. For a fixed vertex v_0∈ V, define the cut locus of f_0 to be 

    C(v_0) := { v'∈ F: d(v_0,v') ≤ d(v_0,v) v  v' }


If κ(v,f)≤ 0 for every corner (v,f), then G has no cut locus, i.e. C(v_0)=∅ for all v_0∈ V.

sentence:
[The Cheeger constant]
The Cheeger constant of a compact manifold (M^n,g) is defined to be

    h(M):=inf_H_n-1(∂ H)/_n(H)

where the infimum is taken over all compact submanifolds H⊂ M (of the same dimension) such that 0<_n(H)≤1/2_n(M), and ∂ H denotes the smooth boundary of H.

Moreover, in case M is non-compact manifold, the Cheeger constant (cf. Chavel, <cit.>) is defined almost in the same way, except that the condition _n(H)≤1/2_n(M) is removed.

sentence:
[Gradient, divergence and Laplacian]  

Gradient operator : C^∞(M) →𝔛(M) maps a smooth real function f to a smooth vector field f such that its evaluation at any point x∈ M is defined by the inner product: 

    g_x( f(x), w):= w(f)(x)

for every w∈ T_xM. Here w(f) is a differentiation of f in direction of the vector w. 

Divergence operator : 𝔛(M) → C^∞(M) maps a smooth vector field X to a smooth real function X defined at each point x∈ M by

    ( X)(x) := _T_x M (v ↦∇_v X)

where the mapping is considered from the tangent space T_xM onto itself, and ∇ is Levi-Civita connection.

Laplacian operator Δ: C^∞(M) → C^∞(M) is then defined to be the composition: Δ = ∘.

sentence:
[Tessellation]
A connected and locally finite planar graph G is a planar tessellation , or just tessellation , if it satisfies the following conditions.



  (i) Every edge is contained in exactly two different faces.

  (ii) Every bounded face is a polygon: it is homeomorphic to the closed disk 𝔻, and its boundary is a simple cycle (i.e. a finite path in which the first and the last vertices coincide). The edges of the cycle are called sides of the polygon.

  (iii) The intersection of any two distinct faces are either an empty set, or a vertex, or an edge.

sentence:
Let X be a space and C(X) be the function space of X, that is the set of all functions f:X→ℝ, equipped with the addition and scalar multiplication rules: (f+f')(x)=f(x)+f'(x) and (cf)(x)=c· f(x). Assume that the X has Laplacian operator Δ defined on it. Fix a number n∈ℝ^+∪{∞} to be the dimension of X. The curvature at each point x∈ X is defined to be the maximal number K_x such that the inequality


    Γ_2(f)(x) ≥1/n(Δ f(x))^2 +K_xΓ(f)(x)

holds true for all functions f∈ C(X)


Moreover, for a fixed real number K, we say that X satisfies CD(K,n) if K_x≥ K for all x∈ X; in other words,

    Γ_2(f)(x) ≥1/n(Δ f(x))^2 +KΓ(f)(x)

holds for all x∈ X and for all f∈ C(X).

Here the operators Γ and Γ_2 on X are also defined as in the equation (<ref>) and (<ref>).

sentence:
Let X be a space with Laplacian operator Δ.
For t∈ [0,∞), a heat semigroup operator P_t: C(X)→ C(X) is defined by 

    P_t:=e^tΔ
 
for all f∈ C(X).

sentence:
[Transport plan]
Let G=(V,E) be a locally-finite and connected graph. Let 
    P(V):={μ:V→ [0,1]  |  ∑_x∈ Vμ(x)=1, μ(x)>0  x}
 be the space of all probability measures on V with finite supports. 

Given any μ,ν∈ P(V), a transport plan (or, in short, a plan ) from μ to ν is a function π: V× V → [0,1] satisfying 

    μ(x) = ∑_y∈ Vπ(x,y)         ν(y)=∑_x∈ Vπ(x,y).


Furthermore, define ∏(μ,ν) to be the set of all transport plans from μ to ν, and the (transportation) cost of a plan π is given by 
    (π)=∑_x,y∈ V d(x,y)π(x,y).

sentence: A set R of vertices of a graph G is a resolving set if for each pair u,v of distinct vertices, there is a vertex x of R with d(x,u)≠ d(x,v). The smallest size of a resolving set of G is the metric dimension of G.

sentence:
[Reduction of a hexagon] 
Let K be a pseudohex, h a hexagon of K and N a perfect matching of h. We define the 
reduction of h by N as follows.
For each of the three paths P_i, i=1,2,3, consisting of one edge of N and the white edges adjacent 
to this edge we introduce a new white edge e_i between the end-vertices of P_i
whenever P_i is not a cycle of length 2. If P_i is not a cycle of length 2, then 
for each red edge {u,w} attached to an interior vertex 
w of P_i we introduce new red edge {u,w'} where w' is the vertex of e_i of the same bipartition 
class of K as w. If P_i is a cycle of length 2, then for each red edge {u,w} attached to an interior vertex 
w of P_i we introduce a new red edge {u,u̅}.
Finally, we delete the vertices of h.
The paths P_i,  i= 1,2,3, are said to be contracted .

sentence: Let _n denote a random labeled biconnected planar graph with n vertices, and let ω = ω(n) be any function such that lim_n→∞ω(n)=∞. Let >0. Then, _n contains a.a.s. a unique largest core with (1±)cn vertices, where c=0.765… is given explicitely. Moreover, every other core contains at most n^2/3ω(n) vertices, and there are (1±)c_ℓ n cores with ℓ vertices, where 4 ≤ℓ = O(n^2/3) and the c_ℓ are given explicitely.

sentence:
A network in 𝒩(𝒯) is either an edge, whose endvertices are the poles, or is of type S ( series network ), or of type P ( parallel network ), or of type H ( core network ). 

Series networks: 
A network of type S consists of two networks N_1 and N_2, such that the right pole of N_1 is identified with the left pole of N_2. Here, N_1 is restricted to be either an edge, or of type S or H, and N_2∈𝒩(𝒯). 

Parallel networks:
A network of type P consists either of an edge and a non-empty set of networks, 
either of type S or of type H, where 
their right poles (left poles) are identified into a single right pole (left pole), or a set of networks of size at least 2, either of type S or of type H where the identification of the poles is as before.

Core networks: Let 𝒯̅ be the class of networks which are created by taking any graph in , deleting an edge, and then turning its endvertices into poles. A network of type H consists of a network from 𝒯̅, where each edge is replaced by a network whose poles are identified in a unique way with the endvertices of the edges. 

In any of the above cases, we do the necessary relabeling in case there are conflicts, when two or more networks are joined through one of the above operations. 


    < g r a p h i c s >

A core network whose core is K_4.


With the above notation at hand, we can now introduce formally the classes of networks that we are interested in.
 
We say that ( ) is -nice , if the following conditions hold.


  (A) For all y>0, T̅(x,y) is analytic in ℂ or has a unique dominant singularity at ρ_T̅(y) > 0, and admits a local singular expansion of the form 

    T̅(x,y) = ∑_k ≥ 0 t_k(y) (1- xρ_T̅(y))^k/m,

where m∈ℕ, and the t_k(y) are analytic functions. 
Furthermore, there exist δ,  >0 such that T̅(x,y) is analytic in a domain
Δ = Δ (δ, ) = {z  :  |z|< ρ_T̅ (y) + δ,  (z-ρ_T̅(y))> }.
Moreover, the smallest integer k such that t_k(y)≢0 and k/m ∉ℕ satisfies k/m = α. Also, the function ρ_T̅(y) is strictly decreasing and continuously twice differentiable.

  (B) For y in a neighborhood of 1, let ρ_N(y) be the radius of convergence of the egf enumerating ( ) with respect to vertices and edges. Then

    - ρ_N”(1)/ρ_N(1)
    	- ρ_N'(1)/ρ_N(1)
    	+ (ρ_N'(1)/ρ_N(1))^2 ≠ 0.

sentence:
We say that Δ has uniform definability of types over finite sets (abbreviated as UDTFS) in 𝐌 if there are finitely many families 

    ℱ_i=(φ_i(y;y_1,…,y_d))_∈Δ     (i∈ I)
 
of ℒ-formulas (where y_j=y for every j=1,…,d) such that for every finite  set B⊆ M^y
and q∈ S^Δ(B) there are b_1,…,b_d ∈ B and some i∈ I such that ℱ_i(y;b_1,…,b_d)
defines q. We call the family ℱ=(ℱ_i)_i∈ I a uniform definition of Δ(x;B)-types over finite sets in 𝐌 with d parameters. If Δ={φ} is a singleton, we also speak of φ having UDTFS.

A matroid M is an ordered pair (E, ) consisting of a finite set E (called the ground set of M) and a collection  of subsets of E called independent sets, having the following three properties:


  (I1) ∅∈.

  (I3) If I_1 and I_2 are in  and |I_1| < |I_2|, then there is an element e of I_2 - I_1 such that I_1 ∪ e ∈.

A loop e ∈ E is an element that does not belong to any independent set.

sentence:
Let :X× X→ be a map. For a given phylogenetic tree (T,λ) with λ:E→ and
two leaves x and y we denote with ℙ_(x,y) the unique path in T from 
_T(x,y) to y. 
A pair (x,y)∈X× X is explained by a phylogenetic tree (T,λ) on X
whenever, 

	
  * (x,y) = m∈ M iff some edge e on the path ℙ_(x,y) has 
					label λ(e)=m; and 
	
  * (x,y) = ⊗ iff none of the edges e on the path ℙ_(x,y)
				have label λ(e)∈ M. 
 
  
The map  is tree-like if each pair (x,y)∈X× X is explained by (T,λ). 
In this case,  we say  that (T,λ) explains 
and (K_|X|,) is a (generalized) Fitch graph . 

Moreover, a tree (T,λ) is least-resolved for a map , 
if (T,λ) explains  and there is no tree (T',λ')
that explains , where T' is obtained from T by contracting
edges and λ' is an M∪{⊗}-edge-labeling map.

	isomorphic to one of G_1,… G_5 or G_6.

    I(P, ∩γ) = {[ _tF(ξ_0(t),ξ_1(t),ξ_2(t))                    if γ∉,;                         ∞                    if γ∈. ].

sentence:
A line l in the Picard group of del Pezzo surface S_r obtained
by blow-up from a divisor class D in S_r-1 is called an m
-degree line if l =D-me_rwhere e_ris the exceptional
class produced by the blow-up.

sentence: A short circuit of a planar graph G is a circuit C with |E(C)| ≤ 5 such that the two open regions bounded by C contain at least one vertex each of G if |E(C)| ≤ 4 and at least two vertices each if |E(C)| = 5.

sentence: The second neighborhood of a vertex v of a planar triangulation is well-behaved if the subgraph of G induced by vertices at distance i from v is a circuit for i = 1, 2.

sentence: A triangulation is internally 6-connected if it has no short circuit and has minimum degree 5.

sentence: Let K be a configuration and let S be the free completion of K with ring R. Then K is D-reducible if the maximal consistent subset of C^*C is empty, where C^* is the set of all 4-colorings of R and C⊆C^* is the set of colorings of R that extend to S.

sentence: A configuration K appears in a triangulation T if G(K) is spherically homeomorphic to an induced subgraph of T such that the image of every vertex v ∈ V(G(K)) has degree _K(v) in T.

sentence:
Let q be a prime power, V an _q-vector space of finite dimension v and t,k,λ be non-negative integers.
A set D of k-subspaces ( blocks ) of V is called a t-(v,k,λ)_q (subspace) design if each t-subspace of V is contained in exactly λ blocks of D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let D be a t-(v,k,λ)_q subspace design.
For any subspace S of V and i∈{0,…,k}, we define the i-th intersection number of S in D as

    α_i(S) = #{B∈ D |(B∩ S) = i}.

If the set S is clear from the context, we use the abbreviation α_i = α_i(S).
Furthermore, the (k+1)-tuple α(S) = (α_0(S),α_1(S),…,α_k(S)) will be called the intersection vector of S in D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence: A plane partition is a two-dimensional array of positive integers which weakly decrease across rows from left to right and weakly decrease down columns.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let a subset S of the six colors {red, blue, green, orange, yellow, silver} (abbreviated {r,b,g,o,y,s}) be called admissible if all of the following are true:


  * If {r,b}⊆ S then g∈ S 

  * If {o,s}⊆ S then b∈ S 

  * If {s,y}⊆ S then g∈ S 

  * If {r,o}⊆ S then y∈ S

sentence:
Let  be the set of all real-valued functions on the nonnegative integer quadrant ℕ^2.
Let F∈ satisfy 


  * F(n,k) is decreasing in k for each fixed n.

  * F(n,0) = 1 and F(n,k) = 0 whenever k>n.

We say that F is an admissible rescaling .

sentence:
Let X be a finite set. 

A weighted weak semivalue on X is an allocation on X that has the form 

    ψ_i(v) = ∑_S⊆ X p(S) [v(S) - v(S∖{i}]

where p(S) ≥ 0.

A weak semivalue on  X is a weighted weak semivalue for which 
∑_S:i∈ S p(S) = 1 for each i∈ X.

sentence:
A weighted semivalue on X is a weighted weak semivalue for which p(S) depends only on 
|S|, and thus has the form

    ψ_i(v) = ∑_k=0^n f(n,k) ∑_|S|=k, S ⊆ X[v(S) - v(S∖{i}]

where f(n,k) ≥ 0 for all n,k.

A semivalue on X is a weighted semivalue on X that in addition satisfies the normalization 
condition

    ∑_k=1^n n-1k-1 f(n,k) = 1.

sentence:
Given two integers s,t, a subset C⊂ E is said (s,t)-separating
if for any subsets S,T⊂ C with S≤ s, T≤ t, and
S∩ T=∅, one has also (S)∩(T)=∅.

sentence:
A parallelogram polyomino P (see an example in Figure <ref>(a)) is an (edge-)connected set of unit cells in the Cartesian plane, 
that is the interior of a contour defined by two paths, which are composed of (0,1) and (1,0) steps 
and which never meet except at their beginning and end. 
Denoting (k,ℓ) the dimension of the minimal bounding rectangle of P, the semi-perimeter of P is k+ℓ, and the size of P is k+ℓ -1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Baxter slicing (see an example in Figure <ref>(b)) of size n is a parallelogram polyomino P of size n whose interior is divided into n blocks as follows: 
one block is the topmost row (resp. rightmost column) of P – such blocks are called horizontal (resp. vertical ) blocks – 
and the other n-1 blocks form a Baxter slicing of the parallelogram polyomino of size n-1 obtained by deletion of the topmost row (resp. rightmost column) of P.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A path of size n is a sequence of North (N = (0,1)) and East (E=(1,0)) steps, containing n-1 steps in total. 
Given three paths u, m, and d of the same size n, 
all containing the same number of E (and N) steps, 
(u,m,d) is a triple of non-intersecting lattice paths (for short, triple of NILPs) of size n 
when the embeddings of u, m and d in the plane never meet, 
with u (resp. m, resp. d) starting at the point of coordinates (0,2) (resp. (1,1), resp. (2,0)).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (u,m,d) be a triple of NILPs as in Definition <ref>. 

A pair (N_u,N_m) of N steps of u and m is matched 
if there exists i such that N_u (resp. N_m) is the i-th N step of u (resp. m).
Similarly, a pair (E_m,E_d) of E steps of m and d is matched 
if there exists i such that E_m (resp. E_d) is the i-th E step of m (resp. d).

Moreover, for any N step N_u in u (resp. N_m in m), 
we denote by h_u(N_u) (resp. h_m(N_m)) the number of E steps of u (resp. m) that occur before N_u (resp. N_m). 
And for any E step E_d in d, we denote by k_d(E_d) the largest k such that E^k is a factor of d ending in E_d.

sentence:
[Nonstandard concepts]  Let G be a nonstandard additive group, and let A, B be nonstandard finite subsets of G.


  (i) We say that A is small if its cardinality |A| is a standard natural number, and large otherwise.  (Note that A is small if and only if it is (externally) finite.)  We say that A,B have comparable size if |A| ≪ |B| ≪ |A|.

  (ii)  We say that A is somewhat sum-closed if ϕ(A) is (standardly) finite. 

  (iii) We write

    A+B := { a+b: a ∈ A, b ∈ B }
 
for the Minkowski sum of A and B, and say that A has bounded doubling if |A+A| ≪ |A|.  For instance, any coset x+H of a nonstandard finite group H is of bounded doubling.

  (iv) For any standard natural number l, we write lA = A + … + A for the l-fold iterated sumset of A.  (
Although it can be done, we will not need to define lA for unbounded l.)

  (v) We say that A avoids B if |A ∩ B| = o(|B|), and occupies B if it does not avoid B (or equivalently, if |A ∩ B| ≫ |B|).  For instance, if A and B are groups, A avoids B when A ∩ B has (externally) infinite index in B, and A occupies B when A ∩ B has (externally) finite index in B.  See also Figure <ref>.

  (vi)  We say that A and B are commensurate if they occupy each other, and transverse if they avoid each other.  

  (vii) A sequence A_n of sets indexed by standard natural numbers n is said to be an wandering sequence if for every standard natural numbers n,m, we have (A_n+A_m) ∩ (A_n+A_m') = ∅ for all but finitely many m'.  For instance, if x_n+H is a sequence of disjoint cosets of a single nonstandard finite group H, then the x_n+H form an wandering sequence.

  (viii) We say that A has the wandering property if the sequence nA is an wandering sequence, or equivalently that nA ∩ n'A = ∅ whenever n' is sufficiently large depending on n.  For example, a coset x+H of a nonstandard finite group H has the wandering property if and only if x has infinite order in G/H, or equivalently if nx ∉H for any standard n.  As another example, if G = ^* are the nonstandard integers and N is an unbounded natural number, then the nonstandard interval { n ∈^* : N ≤ n < 2N } has the wandering property, but the nonstandard interval { n ∈^* : 1 ≤ n ≤ N} does not.  

All of the above notions are understood to be restricted to nonstandard finite sets; for instance, if we say that A is large, it is understood that A is also nonstandard finite.

sentence:
For any I ⊂{1,…,m+1}, write H_I for the subgroup H_I := ⋂_i ∈ I H_i (this subgroup may be trivial), with the convention H_∅ = G.  If d is a natural number, a subspace[Since it is possible for H_I to equal H_J for distinct I,J, we should strictly speaking define a subspace to be a pair (x+H_I, I) rather than just x+H_I, otherwise concepts such as the codimension of the subspace would be undefined.  However, we shall abuse notation and use x+H_I rather than (x+H_I,I) to denote a subspace.] of G of codimension d to be a coset x+H_I of one of the H_I with |I|=d (note that no such subspaces exist if d>m+1).  If the codimension is one, we call the subspace a hyperplane , that is to say a hyperplane is a coset x+H_i of one of the H_1,…,H_m+1.   A subspace x+H_I is said to be aperiodic if  nx+H_I is occupied by one of the H_1,…,H_m+1 for some natural number n, and periodic otherwise.  Thus for instance G = H_∅ (the unique subspace of codimension 0) is aperiodic for vacuous reasons, and any aperiodic subspace of codimension at least one has the wandering property.  We say that a subspace x+H_I is captured by another subspace y+H_J if x+H_I ⊂ y+H_J and I ⊃ J.

A core is a set of the form C = H'_1 ∪…∪ H'_m+1, where each H'_i is a group containing H_i as a commensurate subgroup.  If C is a core, a C-residual set is a set of the form A \ C' where C' is a core containing C.  A subspace x+H_I is said to be C-involved it has codimension at least one, and there exists a large C-residual set A' that is occupied by x+H_I.

sentence: A q-fan F_q in ℝ^n is the union of q half-hyperplanes centered about a (2n-2)-dimensional affine space. A q-fan is called regular if the angle between successive half-hyperplanes is always 2π/q, in which case the corresponding regions S_0,…, S_q-1 between the half-hyperplanes are called regular q-sectors .

sentence: Regular q-fans F_q^1,…, F_q^r  in ℝ^n are linearly independent ( pairwise orthogonal ) if F_q^1⊥, …, F_q^r⊥ are linearly independent (pairwise orthogonal), where F_q^i⊥ is the linear span of the normal vectors of the half-hyperplanes of F_q^i.

sentence:
Let C be the partially shaded current tree and F the final tree. 

We say a supply node   is well-connected if all edges that are incident to  in 
F exist in the current tree C and are shaded ('nothing left to insert'). Otherwise it is open . 

A demand node  is well-connected if it is not incident to an unshaded edge in C ('nothing to delete'). 
Otherwise it is open .

A shaded edge incident to at least one well-connected node is a well-connected edge .

sentence:
A well-connected component in a partially shaded tree C is a connected subgraph induced by the well-connected edges. Further, 
any node not incident to a well-connected edge forms a component by itself.

sentence:
We say a component of a partially shaded tree C satisfies property  (UNO) 
( unique open node property)  if it contains a unique  open node. 
(UNO) holds in a partially shaded tree C if all its components satisfy (UNO).

sentence:
A supply node  satisfies property (SIN) ( supply node insertion property) in a partially shaded tree C if all edges that are odd with respect 
to  are unshaded edges or (shaded) -edges incident to well-connected demand nodes.

sentence:
For a set of characters Γ⊂G and
	a real number δ > 0, we let
	
    B(Γ,δ) = { x ∈ G  :  |1-γ(x)| 
    		≤δ  ∀γ∈Γ}

	be the Bohr set of frequency set Γ and 
	radius δ.
	We define d=|Γ| to be the dimension of this Bohr set.

sentence:
[Regular Bohr set]
	
	Let C_0 be an absolute constant.
	A Bohr set B is said to be regular for C_0 if
	
    ( 0 < |ρ | < 1C_0 d )   
    		1 - C_0 |ρ| d ≤|B_1 + ρ|/|B|≤ 1 + C_0 |ρ| d
    		         ( 0 < |ρ | < 1C_0 d ).

sentence:
A pair ℳ=(E, 𝒞^*) is called oriented matroid with cocircuits 𝒞^* if 𝒞^* is a system of signed sets with ground set E, satisfying the following axioms: 
=2.5em
 
  (C0) ∅∉𝒞^*
 
  (C1) 𝒞^*=-𝒞^*
 
  (C2) if X,Y∈𝒞^* and X⊆Y then X=± Y
 
  (C3) for all X,Y∈𝒞^* with X≠± Y and e∈ S(X,Y) exists Z∈𝒞^* with Z(e)=0, Z^+⊆ X^+∪ Y^+ and Z^-⊆ X^-∪ Y^-

sentence: Given a graph G representing a position in a game of narrow Dots-and-Boxes/Triangles, let V_BG be the set of all vertices that are incident to an exterior leg, incident to an interior leg, or part of a path joining two vertices that are both incident to legs. Then the graph induced by V_BG and the ground vertex is called the base graph . Any vertices and edges that are not part of the base graph are said to be pendant vertices and pendant edges , respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
A chain of length k≥0 is a collection of k+1 edges in the base graph satisfying one of the following.
 

  
  * Every interior leg is a chain of length zero.

  
  * An exterior leg together with the edges of the path connecting it to the nearest interior leg in the same component comprise a chain, which excludes the interior leg.

  
  * Edges of the path connecting two consecutive interior legs in the same component comprise a chain, again excluding the interior legs.

  
  * If a component has two exterior legs and no interior legs, then all edges of the base graph in that component comprise a chain of length at least two.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a function Wℝ^k→ℝ, a point x∈ℝ^k, and a unit direction vector d∈ℝ^k, the upper Dini derivative of W at x in direction d is defined as
		
    W_+'(x,d) = lim sup_h→ 0^+W(x+hd)-W(x)/h.

		The lower Dini derivative of W at x in direction d is
		
    W_-'(x,d) = lim inf_h→ 0^+W(x+hd)-W(x)/h.

sentence:
A graphon W is locally α-Hölder continuous at (a,a) if there exists some neighborhood U of (a,a) and some constant C>0 such that for all points ,
		
    |W((a,a)+(x,y)) - W(a,a)|<C(x,y)^α,

		where · may be taken to represent any fixed norm on ℝ^2.

sentence:
Let V be a variety in the polynomial ring ℂ[X_1, …,X_n].
	We define the coordinate ring to be the quotient ℂ[V] :=  ℂ[X_1, …,X_n]/ I(V)
	and the field of rational functions
	ℂ(V) to be the field of fractions of ℂ[V].
	Each f̂/ĝ∈ℂ(V) can, 
	for any f ∈f̂ and g ∈ĝ, be considered to be a partially defined function
	
    f/g : V →ℂ,   x ↦ f(x)/g(x),

	and this function is independent of the choice of f,g.
	If C is an algebraic curve then ℂ(C) is also referred to as a function field .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: coordinate ring;field of rational functions;function field

sentence:
For a function field ℂ(C),
	a function ν : ℂ(C) →ℤ∪{∞} is a valuation if 
	
		
  * ν (x) = ∞ if and only if x = 0.
		
		
  * ν (xy) = ν (x) + ν (y).
		
		
  * ν (x + y) ≥min{ν (x) , ν (y) }, with equality if ν (x) ≠ν (y).
		
		
  * ν (x) = 0 if x ∈ℂ∖{0}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A Γ-gain graph is a triple G := (V(G),E(G), Γ), where:
	
		
  * V(G) is a finite set of vertices .
	
		
  * Γ is an additive abelian group with identity 0.
	
		
  * E(G) ⊂ (V(G)^2 ×Γ)/ R is a set of edges ,
		where (a,b,γ) R (c,d,μ) if and only either a=c, b=d and γ = μ,
		or a=d, b = c and γ = -μ.
		We shall assume that there is no edge of the form (v,v , 0).
		We shall, however,  allow E(G) to be an infinite set.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (G,p,L) and (G,p',L') be k-periodic frameworks in 𝕂^d. 
	Then (G,p,L) ∼ (G,p', L') (or (G,p,L) and (G,p', L') are equivalent ) if for all (v,w, γ) ∈ E(G),
	
    p(v) - p(w) - L.γ^2 = p'(v) - p'(w) - L'.γ^2,

	and (p,L) ∼ (p',L') (or (p,L) and (p',L') are congruent ) if (<ref>)
	holds for all v, w ∈ V(G) and γ∈ℤ^k;
	equivalently,
	we may define (p,L) ∼ (p',L') if and only if there exists a linear isometry M ∈ M_d(𝕂) and y ∈𝕂^d
	such that p'(v) = M.p(v) + y for all v ∈ V(G) and L' = ML.
	For any L, L' ∈ M_d × k(𝕂),
	we define to be L and L' orthogonally equivalent (or L ∼ L') if for any γ, μ∈ℤ^k,
	
    (L.γ). (L.μ) = (L'.γ). (L'.μ).
