sentence:
Let (G,p,L) be a k-periodic framework in 𝕂^d.
	A flex of (G,p,L) is a continuous path t ↦ (p_t, L_t), t ∈ [0,1],
	in  𝒱_𝕂(G,p,L).
	If (p_t, L_t) ∈𝒱^f_𝕂(G,p,L) for all t ∈ [0,1] then (p_t, L_t) is a fixed lattice flex .
	If (p_t,L_t) ∼ (p,L) for all t ∈ [0,1] then (p_t,L_t) is trivial .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let (G,p,L) be a k-periodic framework.
	Then we define the following:
	
		
  * (G,p,L) is rigid if all flexes of (G̃,p̃) are trivial, and flexible otherwise.
		
  * (G,p,L) is fixed lattice rigid if all fixed lattice flexes of (G̃,p̃) are trivial,
		and fixed lattice flexible otherwise.

sentence:
Let G be a Γ-gain graph with edge colouring δ: E(G) →{red, blue}.
	We define the following:
	
		
  * G^δ_red := (V(G),{ e ∈ E(G) : δ(e) = red}).
		
		
  * A red component is a connected component of G^δ_red.
		
		
  * A red walk (respectively, red circuit ) is a walk (respectively, circuit) where every edge is red.
		
		
  * An almost red circuit is a circuit with exactly one blue edge.
		
		
  * G^δ_blue, blue components , blue walks ,
		blue circuits , and almost blue circuits are defined analogously. 
		
		
  * We define monochromatic components , monochromatic walks ,
		monochromatic circuits and almost monochromatic circuits to be either red or blue. 

	A colouring δ is a NBAC-colouring ( No Balanced Almost Circuits )
	if it is surjective
	and there are no balanced almost red circuits and no balanced almost blue circuits;
	see Figure <ref> for an example of an NBAC-colouring.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: red component;red walk;red circuit;almost red circuit;blue components;blue walks;blue circuits;almost blue circuits;monochromatic components;monochromatic walks;monochromatic circuits;almost monochromatic circuits;NBAC-colouring;No Balanced Almost Circuits

sentence:
Let G be a ℤ^k-gain graph for some k ∈{1,2},
	with an NBAC-colouring δ. 
	If G^δ_red (respectively, G^δ_blue) is unbalanced,
	G^δ_blue (respectively, G^δ_red) is balanced
	and G has no almost red (respectively, almost blue) circuits,
	then δ is a fixed lattice NBAC-colouring.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let G be a ℤ-gain graph with an NBAC-colouring δ. 	
	If both G^δ_red and G^δ_blue are balanced,
	then δ is a flexible 1-lattice NBAC-colouring.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let G be a ℤ^2-gain graph with an NBAC-colouring δ.
	We define the following:
	
		
  * If both G^δ_red and G^δ_blue are balanced,
		then δ is a type 1 flexible 2-lattice NBAC-colouring.
		
		
  * If there exists α,β∈ℤ^2 
		such that 
		
			
  * either α,β are linearly independent or exactly one of α,β is equal to (0,0),
			
			
  * (G^δ_red) is a non-trivial subgroups of  ℤα or α=(0,0), 
			
			
  * (G^δ_blue) is a non-trivial subgroups of  ℤβ or β=(0,0),
			
			
  * there are no almost red circuits with gain in ℤα, and
			
			
  * there are no almost blue circuits with gain in ℤβ,
		
		then δ is a type 2 flexible 2-lattice NBAC-colouring.
		
		
  * If there exists α∈ℤ^2 ∖{(0,0)} such that
		
			
  * (G^δ_red) and (G^δ_red) are non-trivial subgroups of ℤα, and
			
			
  * there are no almost monochromatic circuits with gain in ℤα, 
		
		then δ is a type 3 flexible 2-lattice NBAC-colouring.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
For any two edges e_1,e_2 of a k-periodic framework (G,p,L) in ℝ^2
	with e_i := (v_i,w_i,γ_i) for each i ∈{1,2},
	we define the angle function of e_1,e_2 to be the map
	
    A_e_1,e_2: 𝒱_𝒞^2(G) →ℂ, 
    		  (p',L') ↦ (p'(v_1)-p'(w_1) - L'.γ_1).(p'(v_2)-p'(w_2)- L'.γ_2).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (G,p,L) be a k-periodic framework in ℝ^2.
	We define a k-periodic framework (G',p',L) in ℝ^2 to be a 
	Hennenberg 1 extension of (G,p,L) at v_1,v_2 by γ_1,γ_2 if
	
    V(G') := V(G) ∪{v_0} ,      E(G') := E(G) ∪{(v_0,v_i,γ_i) : i=1,2}

	and p'(v)=p(v) for all v ∈ V(G).
	If v_1=v_2,
	we define (G',p',L) to be a
	Hennenberg 1 extension of (G,p,L) at v_1 by γ_1,γ_2 (Figure <ref>).

sentence:
Let (p_t,L_t) a flex of a 2-periodic framework (G,p,L) in ℝ^2.
	If there exists linearly independent α,β∈ℤ^2 such that L_t.α^2 and L_t.β^2 are constant
	but (L_t.α).(L_t.β) is not constant,
	then (p_t,L_t) is a scissor flex.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A holomorphic quadratic differential (HQD) on a graph =(V,E) is the data consisting of:
a function q: E →ℝ defined on unoriented edges, i.e. q_uv = q_vu, and 
a mapping z:V →ℂ to the complex plane, satisfying for every interior vertex u

    ∑_v q_uv   =0 
    ∑_v q_uv/z_u -z_v   =0.

sentence:
In the case where open knot type is one of the overcrossing closure , undercrossing closure , or the over-undercrossing closure , open knot type is invariant under the usual Reidemeister moves ( i.e. those which do not interact with the loose ends).

  In the case where open knot type is the min-closure knot type, the min-closure knot type is not invariant under Reidemeister moves. However, we have that any two knotoid diagrams S, S' related by a sequence of Reidemeister moves are not orthogonal in the vector space of knot types; ⟨ [S], [S'] ⟩ > 0.

  By definition, any two knotoid diagrams with the same knotoid type are furthermore related by a sequence of Reidemeister moves.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let S be a knotoid diagram of at least one crossing and a, z its loose flags. Say that a is connected to a crossing v joining flags a,b_1,c_1,d_1, oriented counterclockwise (namely, flag c_1 meets the crossing opposite a). Say that the latter three flags are part of edges e_b = (b_1b_2), e_c = (c_1c_2), and e_d = (d_1d_2).

  Then the contraction Sa of S by flag a is the new knotoid diagram produced by deleting crossing v, edges e_b, e_c, e_d, and flags a, b_1, c_1, d_1 and inserting the edge e = (b_2d_2) joining flags b_2 and d_2. Sa is a new knotoid diagram with one fewer crossing, two fewer edges, and loose flags c_2 and z.

  
    0.45
      [width=0.666]figs/k10_146_open
      
    
    0.45
      [width=0.666]figs/k10_146_open_contracta
      
    
    a knotoid diagram D and its contraction along flag a, D-a.
    The diagram D has knot type [D] = 1/24_1 + 1/20_1,
    while the knot type of the contraction is [D-a] = 0_1.
    
  

  If S has precisely one crossing, then its contraction (by either flag) is the “trivial” knotoid diagram.

  If T is a knotoid diagram with no more crossings than S, then say S contains T as a knotoid diagram , T ≤ S, if S = T or there exists a series of contraction operations on S that produces the knotoid diagram T. If D is a diagram with as many or more crossings than T, then say D contains T (T ≤ D) as a knotoid diagram if there exists an edge e in D so that D∖ e contains T.

plain_text_term: contraction S;contains T as a knotoid diagram;contains T

sentence:
Consider a knotoid diagram S with loose flags a, z. An open knot type of S is an equivalence class of S under some equivalence relation. We only consider open knot types who satisfy analogous characteristics to the MDS method <cit.> of identifying subknots in open space polygons:
  
  
  * The open knot type of a knotoid diagram does not change under small perturbations.
    
  
  * The open knot type of a knotoid diagram which is “almost closed” is the same as that of the “obvious closure”. That is, the type of the knot diagram [D] is equivalent to the type of the knotoid diagram [D ∖ e].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A diagram D (strongly) contains [K] as a subknot if there exists a knotoid diagram S contained in D whose knot type is precisely [S] = [K]. For certain open knot types, we say the diagram D weakly contains a knot type [K] if the inner product ⟨ [D], [K]⟩ is nonzero, or probabilistically contains a knot type [K] if ⟨ [D], [K]⟩≥ 1/2.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: (strongly) contains [K] as a subknot;weakly contains;probabilistically contains

sentence: Let [K] be a knot type and D a diagram (open or closed). D contains [K] as a slipknot if there is a subdiagram U ≤ D where U contains [K] as a subknot but ⟨ [U], 0_1 ⟩ = p > 0. The slipknot is contained weakly if p > 0, probabilistically if p ≥ 1/2, or strongly if p = 1. The knotoid diagram S ≤ U ≤ D which represents the knot type [K] is an ephemeral knot .

sentence: The geodesic distance <cit.> (also called complexity <cit.> or height <cit.>) d(L) of an knotoid diagram L is the minimum number of edges that any path in the surface of the diagram connecting the two legs crosses.

sentence:
Let P be a set of n points contained in [0,1]^2. Define the measure

    d μ^s_P(x)=n^-1· n^d/s·∑_p ∈ Pχ_B^  p_n^-1/s(x)  dx,
 where χ_B^  p_n^-1/s(x) is the characteristic function of the ball of radius n^-1/s centered at p. We say that P is s-adaptable if 


    I_s(μ_P)=∫∫|x-y|^-s dμ^s_P(x) dμ^s_P(y)<∞.

sentence:
Given sets S, B⊆ [n], define the link graph of B generated by S , denoted L_S[B], as follows.
We set V(L_S[B]):=B, and given x,y ∈ B, we have xy ∈ E(L_S[B]) if and only if there is some z ∈ S such that { x,y,z} is a Schur triple, and x,y,z are distinct.
Note that L_S[B] is a simple graph (i.e. it does not contain loops).
If S = { v }, then we use the shorthand L_v[B] := L_{ v }[B].

plain_text_term: link graph of B generated by S

sentence:
Let r,n ∈ℕ and >0. 
Suppose that

    α_i1d_1 +… + α_ird_r + α_ia ≤β_i  for all   i ≤ N(r),

where N(r) is a positive integer depending only on r; and α_ij,β_ij,α_i ∈ℝ for all i ≤ N(r) and j ≤ r.
We say that the set 𝒞 whose members are these inequalities is a family of constraints for A_1,…,A_r .
Further, 𝒞 is (,r)-sufficient if

    max∑_i ∈ [r]d_ilog i   subject to  𝒞  is at most  max{1/2log r, 1/4log(r⌊ r^2/4⌋)} + .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[See <cit.>] 
Let P be a finite poset. Let uni_P denote the uniform probability distribution on P. Let maxchain_P denote the probability distribution where each p ∈ P occurs with probability proportional to the number of maximal chains containing p. Let ddeg P →ℕ denote the down-degree statistic: ddeg(p) is the number of elements of P which p∈ P covers. If μ is a discrete probability distribution on a finite set X and f X →ℝ is some statistic on X, we use the notation 𝔼(μ; f) to denote the expectation of f with respect to μ. Finally, we say that P has the coincidental down-degree expectations (CDE) property if

    𝔼(uni_P; ddeg) = 𝔼(maxchain_P; ddeg).

In this case we also say that P is CDE .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let σ = λ/ν be a connected skew shape of height a and width b. We assume that σ has been translated so that it lies in the rectangle a× b. The main antidiagonal of σ is the line connecting the northeast and southwest corners of the boundary of the rectangle a× b. A corner of σ is a point where two line segments which are part of the boundary of σ meet. We say the corner is outward if no box of σ intersects both of the line segments (except at the corner point). We say that σ is balanced if all its outward corners are exactly on its main antidiagonal.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A permutation w ∈𝔖_n is Grassmannian if it has at most one descent.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that w∈𝔖_n is fully commutative if starting from any reduced word for w we can obtain any other reduced word for w by applying a sequence of commutation relations (i.e., we only need to use the relations (<ref>), not (<ref>)).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let μ be a probability distribution on L. We say that μ is toggle-symmetric if 𝔼(μ;𝒯_p)=0 for all p∈Irr(L).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O

sentence: We say that the semidistributive lattice L is toggle CDE (tCDE) if 𝔼(μ;ddeg)=𝔼(uni_L;ddeg) for every toggle-symmetric distribution μ on L.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let D⊆ℤ^2 be a diagram. Let (i,j)∈ D be a box of D. We say that (i,j) is cross-saturated in D if whenever (i,j')∈ D is a box of D in the same row as (i,j) and (i',j)∈ D is a box of D in the same column as (i,j), we have (i',j')∈ D. If (i,j) is cross-saturated in D, then we define its cross-saturation in D to be the set of all boxes (i',j'), where (i,j')∈ D is a box of D in the same row as (i,j) and (i',j)∈ D is a box of D in the same column as (i,j).

sentence: Let X be a finite combinatorial set, Φ X→ X an invertible operator, and f X →ℝ some statistic. We say that the triple (X,Φ,f) exhibits homomesy if the average of f along every Φ-orbit of X is the same. In this case we also say that f is homomesic with respect to the action of Φ on X, and we say f is c-mesic if the average of f along every Φ-orbit is c∈ℝ.

sentence:
Consider a vertex set V with |V|=n. Let the function μ: V
→ℝ_+ assign a non-negative weight μ(v) to
each vertex v∈ V, while the function d: V →ℕ assign a natural degree d(v). The tuple ⟨μ,
d⟩ is called a generating tuple if ∑_v∈ V
d(v)=2(n-1). Denote with μ:=∑_v∈ Vμ(v) the
total weight of vertex set V.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We will say that in a generating tuple ⟨μ, d⟩
weights are degree-monotone , if for any m, m' ∈ M(μ,d)
from d(m) < d(m') it follows that μ(m) ≤μ(m'), and, also,
μ(w)>0 for any w∈ W(μ,d).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A vertex-weighted directed tree is a connected directed graph
where each vertex except the root has the sole outbound arc,
the root has no outbound arcs, and each vertex has non-negative
weight assigned to it.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For an arbitrary vertex v∈ V(T) of the directed tree T define
its subordinate group g_T(v)⊆ V(T) as the set of
vertices having the directed path to the vertex v in the tree T
(the vertex v itself belongs to g_T(v)) . The
weight f_T(v) of the subordinate group g_T(v) is defined
as the total vertex weight of the group: f_T(v):=∑_u∈ g_T(v)μ_T(u).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: subordinate group;(;);weight f_T(v) of the subordinate group

sentence:
For a directed tree T∈𝒲ℛ(μ,d) with root r define
a vector 𝐟(T):=(f_T(m))_m∈
M(T)\{r}^↑ of subordinate groups'
weights .

sentence: We say that a monomial x^μ is a closed corner if x_i·μ'∈ I ∀ x_i∈ supp(μ). We say that a monomial is a maximal corner if it is a closed corner with maximal support.

sentence:
* Let I be a monomial ideal, its artinian closure Î is the smallest artinian ideal such that the set of minimal generators of I is included in the set of minimal generators of Î. 

  * If I=⟨ m_1,…,m_r⟩ then λ(I):=(m_1,…,m_r) denotes the least common multiple of all the minimal generators of I.

sentence:
We say that a set of indeterminates {x_j_1,…,x_j_k} is a cone of locally free directions of the monomial x^μ with respect to I if τ={j_1,…,j_k}∈Δ^μ_I. The set of cones of locally free directions of x^μ will be denoted (x^μ), and is given by the facets of Δ^μ_I.

We say that a set of indeterminates {x_j_1,…,x_j_k} is a cone of globally free directions of the monomial x^μ∉ I with respect to I if x^μ· x^σ∉ I for all monomials x^σ∈[x_j_1,…,x_j_k]. The set of cones of globally free directions of x^μ will be denoted (x^μ). For x^μ∈ I we state (x^μ):=(x^(μ)).

plain_text_term: cone of locally free directions;cone of globally free directions

sentence:
For each 1≤ s≤ r denote I_s:=⟨ m_1,… m_s⟩, Ĩ_s:=I_s-1∩⟨ m_s⟩=⟨ m_1,s,…,m_s-1,s⟩, where m_i,j denotes (m_i,m_j). Then, for each s we have


    ⋯⟶ H_i+1((I_s))Δ⟶H_i((Ĩ_s)⟶ H_i((I_s-1)⊕(⟨  m_s⟩  ))⟶ H_i((I_s))Δ⟶⋯

and since the Koszul differential respects multidegrees, we also
have a multigraded version of the sequence. The set of these
sequences for each s is called the (recursive)
Mayer-Vietoris sequence of I.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: A simple braid is a positive braid β∈ℳℬ_n which contains a letter x_i at most once.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The simple graph Γ_𝒮ℬ_n is the graph with vertices 𝒮ℬ_n and edges between the simple braids β↔β x_i (i=1,…, n-1). The number of vertices of Γ_𝒮ℬ_n is F_2n-1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph with vertices u and v.


  * We say that G admits perfect state transfer (PST) from u to v if there is some time t>0 such that

    |U(t)_u,v| = 1.


  * We say  G admits pretty good state transfer (PGST) from u to v if, for any ϵ>0, there is a time t>0 such that

    |U(t)_u,v| > 1-ϵ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: perfect state transfer;pretty good state transfer

sentence: Let M be a symmetric matrix. Two indices u, v ∈ V(M) are cospectral if ϕ(M_u) = ϕ(M_v).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence: The indices u,v ∈ V(M) are strongly cospectral if φ(u) = ±φ(v) for every eigenvector φ of M.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An unoriented de Bruijn sequence uB(k,n) is a sequence of characters drawn from an alphabet Σ_k of k symbols that (i) contains as subwords a member from each of the length-n reflections on k symbols, and (ii) is of the shortest length amongst all such sequences satisfying property (i).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For positive integers k,n, an unoriented de Bruijn graph uBg(k,n) contains (k^n+k^⌈ n/2 ⌉)/2 vertices labeled by the equivalence classes [v] of k-ary words of length n-1.  Edges of uBg(k,n) are labeled by distinct equivalence classes of words of length n.  An undirected edge labeled [e] connects the vertices labeled by the equivalence classes of the prefix and suffix of e, respectively.  Thus, there is an (undirected) edge [v] ↔ [w] if v→w or v→w' is a (directed) edge in the de Bruijn graph Bg(k,n).
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An alternating Eulerian path in an unoriented de Bruijn graph is an Eulerian path such that if it enters a vertex on an edge of Type I (II) relative to that vertex, then it leaves that vertex on an edge of Type II (I) relative to that vertex.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a group isomorphism from G to G, such that (y)=χ_y for each y ∈ G. Let S and T be subsets of G. Then S and T form a formally dual pair in G under the isomorphism , if for each y ∈ G,

    |χ_y(S)|^2=|S|^2/|T|ν_T(y).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: For a subset S of a group G, define S to be a primitive subset of G, if S is not contained in a coset of a proper subgroup of G and S is not a union of cosets of a nontrivial subgroup in G. For a formally dual pair S and T in G, it is a primitive formally dual pair, if both S and T are primitive subsets.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let f,g:Ω→ℝ^+. We say that f flows to g
if there exists v:Ω×Ω→ℝ^+ such that:


  * For any A ∈Ω, we have ∑_B v(A,B) = f(A).


  * For any B ∈Ω, we have ∑_A v(A,B) = g(B).


  * If A B, then v(A,B)=0.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:

(ℳ^(l))_l is a embedding family of incidence matrices of CFFs, if X_l ⊆ X_l+1, rows(l) ≤ rows(l+1), and cols(l) ≤ cols(l+1), d(l) ≤ d(l+1) and
		
    ℳ^(l+1)= [ ℳ^(l)     Y;     Z     W ].

sentence: A nested family of incidence matrices of d-CFFs is an embedding family of incidence matrices with fixed d such that each row of Z is one of the rows of ℳ^(l), a row of all zeros, or a row of all ones.

sentence: A monotone family of incidence matrices of d-CFFs is an embedding family of incidence matrices  with fixed d such that Z is a matrix of zeros.

sentence:

(ℳ^(l))_l is a embedding family of incidence matrices of CFFs, if X_l ⊆ X_l+1, rows(l) ≤ rows(l+1), and cols(l) ≤ cols(l+1), d(l) ≤ d(l+1) and
		
    ℳ^(l+1)= [ ℳ^(l)     Y;     Z     W ].

sentence: An orthogonal array OA(v^t;t,k,v) is an v^t × k array with elements from an alphabet of v symbols, such that in any t columns, every t-tuple of points is contained in exactly one row.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Stevens and Mendelsohn<cit.>]
	A packing array , PA(n;t,k,v), is an n× k array with values from  an alphabet with v symbols, such that in any t columns, every t-tuple of points is contained in at most one row.

sentence:
<cit.>
Assume the Generalized Riemann Hypothesis .  Let Γ be a finite abelian group of odd order with a perfect pairing on Γ.  Then there exists a graph G such that K(G) ≅Γ as groups with pairing.
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any set Ω of non-negative integers which contains 0,1 and at least one integer greater than 1, an Ω-k-tree is a connected  k-tree satisfying
that the number of (k+1)-cliques that contain any fixed k-clique belongs to the set Ω.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For any set Ω of non-negative integers which contains 0,1 and at least one integer greater than 1, a (k,Ω)-front coding tree of size n is a tree T consisting of (kn+1) white nodes and n black nodes which satisfies:


  * T is rooted at a white node, every white node has only black nodes as children and every black node has only k white nodes as children.

  * The number of black children of the white root belongs to the set Ω and the number of black children of any other white node belongs to the set {i | i+1∈Ω,i≥ 0}.

  * The white root of T is labeled by a k-subset A of [n+k]={1,2,…,n+k} and the black nodes are labeled by the integers from the set [n+k]-A such that for every white node, the subtrees stemming from its black children are not ordered between themselves.

The labels on the white root and black nodes determine the labels on the rest white nodes. We start from the white root and recursively label other white nodes. For every white node, we label it with a set {r_1,…,r_i-1,r,r_i+1,…,r_k} if the white node is the i-th child (from left to right) of a black node labeled by r and the white parent of this black node is labeled with the set {r_1,…,r_k}.

If the white root of a (k,Ω)-front coding tree has precisely one black child, we call it reduced (k,Ω)-front coding tree.

Let R be a finite ring. A function w R→
is called a homogeneous weight , if w(0)=0 and


  * if Rx=Ry then w(x)=w(y) for all x,y ∈ R;

  * there exists a real number γ≠ 0 such that
∑_y∈ Rx w(y)=γ| Rx | for all x ∈ R∖{0}.

sentence: If F is a Ferrers board, then an F-sequence is a sequence of nonnegative integers assigned to the vertices on the right/up border of F, starting with the vertex at the top left corner.

sentence:
[the 231-conditions]
If F is a Ferrers board and S is an F-sequence, then the 231-conditions for the pair (F,S) are the following three conditions:



  (i)  (monotonicity conditions)  If V_1 and V_2 are vertices on the right/up border and V_1 is either directly to the left of V_2 or directly below V_2 then S(V_1)≤ S(V_2)≤ S(V_1)+1.

  (ii) (0-conditions)  The first and last values of S are 0, and there do not exist consecutive vertices V_1 and V_2 such that S(V_1)=0=S(V_2).

  (iii) (diagonal condition) If V_1 and V_2 are vertices on the right/up border that are at the left and right ends of a diagonal with slope -1 that lies entirely within F, then S(V_1)≤ S(V_2).

sentence:
[the 312-conditions]
With S as in the preceding definition, the 312-conditions for the pair (F,S) are the same as the 231-conditions, except that we reverse the inequalities in the diagonal condition.

sentence:
For an n-core ν, the affine dual equivalence graph
_ν^(n) is the signed, colored graph with vertex set V_ν
given by the set of all starred strong tableaux S^* of shape
ν, with signature function σ(S^*) obtained from the
reading word on the starred letters in S^*, and for each
1<i<ℓ(ν), the set of i-colored edges, E_i, is the set of
all pairs {S^*,_i(S^*)} such that S^*≠_i(S^*).  This definition also extends to skew shapes ν /μ
in the n-core poset.    For S^*∈(ν/μ, n), let [S^*] denote the
connected component of the affine dual equivalence graph
_ν /μ^(n) containing S^*.

Assume that S^* has a cloneable index at j and that
T^*=cl_j(S^*) ∈(β /α ,n).  Define the cloning map on
components

    cl_j:[S^*] ⟶(β /α ,n)
 
by cloning each starred strong tableaux in [S^*] at the column beginning with j.  The
inverse map to cloning, when its defined, will be denoted by 

    sq_j:[T^*] ⟶ [S^*]

and we call it the squashing map .

sentence:
Let S = (∅ = μ^0 ⊂μ^1 ⊂⋯⊂μ^m) be a
  saturated chain in the n-core poset such that the interval
  [μ^i-1,μ^i+1] is not a chain for 0 < i < m. The
  i-interval swap on S, denoted
  _i,i+1(S)=_i+1,i(S), replaces μ^i with the
  unique other n-core at rank i in [μ^i-1,μ^i+1].

sentence:
Let S^*= (S,c^*) be a starred strong tableau of rank m.  Fix
  1<i<m.  Consider the locations of (i-1)^*, i^*,(i+1)^* in
  S^*.  The i-witness , or simply the witness
  when i is fixed, is chosen among {i-1,i,i+1 } as follows.

  
  
  * If c_i-1≠ c_i+1, then c_i-1,c_i,c_i+1 are
    all distinct since p-ribbons and p+1-ribbons cannot have 
    head or tails of the same content by the analysis in Section <ref>. 
    In this case, the witness is the index of
    the median of the set {c_i-1,c_i,c_i+1}.
  
  * If c_i-1=c_i+1, then we have three cases to consider.
    
    
  * If the (i-1)-ribbons and (i+1)-ribbons have the same
      length, then i+1 is the witness .
    
  * If the (i-1)-ribbons and (i+1)-ribbons have different lengths
      and c_i-1>c_i, then the witness is the letter
      indexing the longer ribbons among the (i-1)-ribbons and the
      (i+1)-ribbons.
    
  * If the (i-1)-ribbons and (i+1)-ribbons have different
      lengths and c_i-1<c_i, then the witness is the
      letter indexing the shorter ribbons among the (i-1)-ribbons
      and the (i+1)-ribbons.

sentence:
Let μ⊂ν be m+1-cores such that some (equivalently,
  every) transposition sequence from μ to ν does not touch
  rod d.  Define the flattening map
  
    _d:(ν/μ,m+1) ⟶(ν^(d)/μ^(d),m)



  sending S^*∈(ν/μ,m+1) to the underlying strong
  tableau S^(d) with the stars placed on each i-ribbon in such a
  way as to preserve the depth.

sentence:
For any n-core μ, define μ_(j) to be the unique
partition associated to the abacus obtained by cloning the
column of the n-rod abacus of μ containing positions j,
j+1, …, j+n-1.  Specifically, let β be the binary string
encoding the abacus for μ.  Then μ_(j) is the abacus
associated to the string obtained from β by inserting a copy of
the substring β_j,β _j+1, …, β_j+n-1 into the
abacus for μ between positions j-1 and j.

sentence:
The LLT polynomial of shape λ, denoted
  _λ, is defined by
  
    _λ(X;q)   =  ∑_𝐓∈_d(λ) q^_d(𝐓) -
          a_λ Q_σ(𝐓)(X) ,

  where the sum is over standard d-tuples of shape
  λ, a_λ is the
  normalizing constant for λ, and
  σ(𝐓) is defined analogously to equation
  (<ref>) using shifted contents.

sentence:
Let q+1 be an even integer, {F_1,…,F_t} a set of perfect matching pairwise edge-disjoint of K_q+1 for some t∈{1,…,q} and W=⋃_j=1^tF_j. An edge-coloring ς E(W) →𝒞, for 𝒞={c^1,…,c^t} a set of t colors, will say to be of Type M_t if for every j∈{1,2,…,t} the set { xy∈ E(W) ς(xy) = c^j} is F_j.

Since each color class is a matching, we will say that W is an owner of the set of colors 𝒞.

The probability distribution on S_n resulting from Description 1
will be called as the riffle shuffle distribution and will be
denoted by P_n,a,p.  When
p=(1/a,1/a,...,1/a), the shuffle is said to be
unbiased and the resulting probability measure is denoted by
P_n,a. Otherwise, shuffle is said to be biased.

sentence:
[Function Density Problems]

Let 𝒞 be a set of some functions, and let 𝒞' be a subset of 𝒞.
Let d(·,·) be a distance function for the pairs of functions in 𝒞.
In this setting, we define a Function Density Problem to be a problem of estimating the following quantity:

    r(𝒞,𝒞') := sup{ d(f,𝒞') | f ∈𝒞},

where, for each f ∈𝒞, d(f,𝒞') := inf{ d(f,g) | g ∈𝒞'} is the distance from f to 𝒞'.
(The symbol r' stands for radius”, by an analogy as if 𝒞' is a single central point in the figure 𝒞, in which case the r is the radius of 𝒞 in usual sense.)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Function Density Problems – typical cases]

Let 𝒞 be the set of all functions f  X → Y from a given finite set X to a given finite set Y.
Let 𝒞' ⊂𝒞.
For any f,g ∈𝒞, we define the distance between f and g by

    d_H(f,g) := |{x ∈ X | f(x) ≠ g(x)}| .

In this setting, a Function Density Problem is a problem of estimating the quantity r(𝒞,𝒞') defined by (<ref>) with d(·,·) = d_H(·,·).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[see e.g., <cit.>]

Let G  S → X be an algorithm with finite input set S and finite output set X.
Given parameters T ≥ 0 and ε≥ 0, G is called a (T,ε)-secure pseudorandom generator ( PRG ) if, for any algorithm (called a distinguisher ) D  X →{0,1} with time complexity bounded by T, we have 𝖠𝖽𝗏_D(G) ≤ε where 𝖠𝖽𝗏_D(G) denotes the advantage of D defined by

    𝖠𝖽𝗏_D(G) := | Pr[D(U_X) = 1] - Pr[D(G(U_S)) = 1] | .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]

Let G  S → X be an algorithm with finite input set S and finite output set X.
Given parameters T ≥ 0, ε≥ 0 and an integer n ≥ 2, G is called (T,n,ε)-secure if, for any algorithm (distinguisher) D  X →{0,1,…,n-1} with time complexity bounded by T, we have 𝖠𝖽𝗏_D(G) ≤ε where we put 𝖠𝖽𝗏_D(G) := Δ(D(U_X),D(G(U_S))).
Such an algorithm G is called a PRG that fools non-boolean distinguishers ( nb-PRG , in short).

sentence: Let T be a possibly rooted tree. Then we construct the outline graph of T by replacing all maximal subtrees isomorphic to some C_k, k≥ 0, by a special leaf C_k.  In this process, we attach (d+1-r) leaves C_0 to internal nodes (non-leaves and non-root) of degree r with 2≤ r ≤ d. If T is a rooted tree with a root of degree r (1≤ r≤ d), then we also attach d-r leaves C_0 to it.

sentence:
Given two maintenance strategies g∈ℒ_R(J, G) and f∈ℒ_R(H, J), we construct Left's residual strategy g⊛ f as follows.

Consider a Right move from [ G,H] to [ G^R,H]. We will find a Left's maintenance response, given the candidate morphisms f and g.
      
           Set up the two games [ G, J] and [ J, H], corresponding to the maintenance strategies f and g respectively; see the  columns of Figure <ref>. 
           
           If Left's maintenance response in [G^R,J] is to [G^RL,J], then adapt this maintenance strategy for the game 
           [G^R,H], as [G^RL,H]. 
           
           If Left's maintenance response in [G^R, J] is to [G^R,J^R] then Left considers instead her maintenance response to the Right move in the game [J^R, H]. If this is [J^R,H^R], then her response in [G^R, H] is to [G^R,H^R]. If, instead, the response is to some [J^RL, H], she swivels back to the game [ G^R,J^RL], and finds a response to this Right move, and so on. 
           
           In case [G^R,J^R] is a terminal position, then, because  [J^R, H] is a Right's move in a Left Maintenance Strategy, there must exist a Right move in H^R, and so the play will terminate in [G^R,H^R], with a Left win (recall the Left Maintenance Game is normal-play).
           
           In either case, by continuing this idea, because J is finite and because f and g are maintenance strategies, eventually Left's response shifts to either of the forms [ G^RL,J^α ], with α=RL… L or [ J^α,H^R] with α=RL… R (i.e. α is a finite sequence of alternating moves). In the first case, the response in [ G^R,H] will be to [ G^RL,H] and in the second case it will be to [ G^R,H^R].  Unless this is a terminal position, we may iterate the argument. 
          
The construction of g⊛ f in the case of the Right move [ G,H^L] is analogous.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Consider the Left Provisonal Game  position [G,G]. We define the mimic strategy m∈ℒ_R(G,G) (or copy-cat) as the strategy where Left replies to [G^R,G] and [G,G^L] with [G^R,G^R] and [G^L,G^L] respectively, and repeats this mimic process during the play.

sentence:
[Left's Residual Strategy]

Given two maintenance strategies g∈ℒ_R(J, G) and f∈ℒ_R(H, J), we construct Left's residual strategy g⊛ f as follows.

Consider a Right move from [ G,H] to [ G^R,H]. We will find a Left's maintenance response, given the candidate morphisms f and g.
      
           Set up the two games [ G, J] and [ J, H], corresponding to the maintenance strategies f and g respectively; see the  columns of Figure <ref>. 
           
           If Left's maintenance response in [G^R,J] is to [G^RL,J], then adapt this maintenance strategy for the game 
           [G^R,H], as [G^RL,H]. 
           
           If Left's maintenance response in [G^R, J] is to [G^R,J^R] then Left considers instead her maintenance response to the Right move in the game [J^R, H]. If this is [J^R,H^R], then her response in [G^R, H] is to [G^R,H^R]. If, instead, the response is to some [J^RL, H], she swivels back to the game [ G^R,J^RL], and finds a response to this Right move, and so on. 
           
           In case [G^R,J^R] is a terminal position, then, because  [J^R, H] is a Right's move in a Left Maintenance Strategy, there must exist a Right move in H^R, and so the play will terminate in [G^R,H^R], with a Left win (recall the Left Maintenance Game is normal-play).
           
           In either case, by continuing this idea, because J is finite and because f and g are maintenance strategies, eventually Left's response shifts to either of the forms [ G^RL,J^α ], with α=RL… L or [ J^α,H^R] with α=RL… R (i.e. α is a finite sequence of alternating moves). In the first case, the response in [ G^R,H] will be to [ G^RL,H] and in the second case it will be to [ G^R,H^R].  Unless this is a terminal position, we may iterate the argument. 
          
The construction of g⊛ f in the case of the Right move [ G,H^L] is analogous.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a totally ordered group and let Ω_0={ℓr|ℓ, r ∈}. 
 For n>0, the set Ω_n is the set of all games with finite sets of options in Ω_n-1, 
 including games which are left- and/or right-atomic, and the set of games of rank n is Ω_n∖Ω_n-1. Let Ω = ∪_n≥ 0Ω_n. Then (Ω, ) is  a free space of games.

sentence:
A play in a Left Provisonal Game X_0=[ G, H] is a chain of positions X_0 X_1 ⋯ X_n 
where the `moves ' correspond to alternating Left and Right (or Right and Left) moves, and where n≥ 0.

sentence:
A Left Maintenance Strategy in a given LPG is a play with the following property: consider any stage of the play, where Right is to move; if Right has a move, then Left has a response to this move. 
We write ℒ_R(H, G) for the set of all Left Maintenance Strategies in the game [ G,H], 
assuming that Right starts, and ℒ_L(H,G) for all Left Maintenance Strategies, assuming that Left starts.

sentence:
[Mimic strategy]
Consider the Left Provisonal Game  position [G,G]. We define the mimic strategy m∈ℒ_R(G,G) (or copy-cat) as the strategy where Left replies to [G^R,G] and [G,G^L] with [G^R,G^R] and [G^L,G^L] respectively, and repeats this mimic process during the play.

sentence:
A labeled seed in ℱ is a pair (, B̃) where

  * B̃ is an m × n integer matrix such that the submatrix B consisting of the top n rows and columns of B̃ is skew-symmetrizable (i.e., DB is skew-symmetric for some n × n diagonal matrix D with positive integer diagonal entries).

We call  the extended cluster of the labeled seed, (x_1, …, x_n) the cluster , B̃ the exchange matrix , and the matrix B the principal part of B̃.

We call an arrow i → j in Q^0 acceptable (with respect to the pair (, )) if e_i - e_j
≤ [d_i - d_j]_+.  Also, an arrow i → j is called critical (with respect to (, )) if either

    (d_i, e_i) = (2,1),    (d_j,e_j) = (1,0),

    (d_j, e_j) = (2,1),    (d_i,e_i) = (1,1).

  (2) For each i, j ∈ [1, n] in the same orbit and ℓ∈ [1, 2n], b_ℓ i, b_ℓ j are both nonnegative or both nonpositive.

sentence:
The weak K-Knuth moves are the relations on words given by




  * (a,b, …)  (b,a, …)

  * (…, a,c,b, …)  (… ,c,a,b, …)

  * (… ,b,a,c, …)  (… ,b,c,a, …)

  * (… ,a,b,a, …)  (… ,b,a,b, …)

  * (… ,a,a, …)   (… ,a, …)



for any integers a < b < c, where in these expressions corresponding ellipses denote matching subsequences.
Two words  and $̱ are weak K-Knuth equivalent , denoted$̱, 
if there exists a sequence of weak K-Knuth moves transforming  to $̱.

sentence:
Let w = w_1 … w_n be a word in the alphabet X. We recursively construct a sequence (T_0,U_0), …, (T_n, U_n) = (T,U) of tableaux, where T_i is a shifted Young tableau, and U_i is a standard shifted Young tableau, as follows. Set (T_0, U_0) = (∅, ∅). For i = 1, …, n, insert w_i into T_i-1 in the following manner:

Insert w_i into the first row, bumping out the smallest element a that is strictly greater than w_i (in the order given by the alphabet X').


  * if a is not on the main diagonal, do as follows:


  * if a is unprimed, then insert it in the next row, as explained above;

  * if a is primed, insert it into the next column to the right, bumping out the smallest element that is strictly greater than a;


  * if a is on the main diagonal, then it must be unprimed. Prime it, and insert it into the next column to the right.

The insertion process terminates once a letter is placed at the end of a row or column, bumping no new element. The resulting tableau is T_i.

The shapes of T_i-1 and T_i differ by one box. Add that box to U_i-1, and write i into it to obtain U_i.

We call T the mixed insertion tableau and U the mixed recording tableau , and denote them (w) and (w), respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:

    𝒫_μ𝒫_ν = ∑_λ b^λ_μ, ν .

sentence:
[ Generalized shifted Littlewood-Richardson Rule ]
Let the u_i be partial maps in 𝐘 satisfying the shifted plactic relations (<ref>)–(<ref>). Then for any g, h ∈𝐘, the polynomial G_h/g defined by (<ref>) is a nonnegative integer combination of Schur Q-functions. More specifically, 

    G_h/g(x_1, …, x_m)
    =∑ b_g, λ^h   Q_λ(x_1, …, x_m) ,

where b_g, λ^h
is equal to the number of shifted semistandard Young tableaux T of
shape λ such that u^T g = h.

sentence:
[Mixed insertion]
Let w = w_1 … w_n be a word in the alphabet X. We recursively construct a sequence (T_0,U_0), …, (T_n, U_n) = (T,U) of tableaux, where T_i is a shifted Young tableau, and U_i is a standard shifted Young tableau, as follows. Set (T_0, U_0) = (∅, ∅). For i = 1, …, n, insert w_i into T_i-1 in the following manner:

Insert w_i into the first row, bumping out the smallest element a that is strictly greater than w_i (in the order given by the alphabet X').


  * if a is not on the main diagonal, do as follows:


  * if a is unprimed, then insert it in the next row, as explained above;

  * if a is primed, insert it into the next column to the right, bumping out the smallest element that is strictly greater than a;


  * if a is on the main diagonal, then it must be unprimed. Prime it, and insert it into the next column to the right.

The insertion process terminates once a letter is placed at the end of a row or column, bumping no new element. The resulting tableau is T_i.

The shapes of T_i-1 and T_i differ by one box. Add that box to U_i-1, and write i into it to obtain U_i.

We call T the mixed insertion tableau and U the mixed recording tableau , and denote them (w) and (w), respectively.

sentence:
Two words u and v in the alphabet X are shifted plactic equivalent (denoted u  v) if they have the same mixed insertion tableau. By Theorem <ref>, u and v are shifted plactic equivalent if they can be transformed into each other using the shifted plactic relations (<ref>)–(<ref>).

A shifted plactic class is an equivalence class under the relation . The shifted plactic class containing a word w is denoted by [w]. We can identify a shifted plactic class with the corresponding shifted Young tableau T = (w), and write [T] = [w].

sentence: The shifted plactic monoid 𝐒 = 𝐒(X) is the set of shifted plactic classes with multiplication given by [u][v] = [uv]. (This multiplication is well defined by Theorem <ref>.) Equivalently, the monoid is generated by the symbols in X subject to the relations (<ref>)–(<ref>).

    = ∑_(T) = λ [T].

sentence:
[Noncommutative Schur P-function]
Let u_1, u_2, … be a finite or infinite sequence of elements of some associative algebra 𝒜 over . (We will always assume that these elements satisfy the shifted plactic relations.) For a shifted shape λ, define

    P_λ() = P_λ(u_1, u_2, …) = ∑_T u^T,

where T runs over all shifted Young tableaux, and the monomial u^T is determined by (T), or by any other representative of the shifted plactic class corresponding to T. (In the infinite case, P_λ(𝐮) is an element of the appropriate completion of the algebra 𝒜.)

sentence:
[Partial maps, cf. <cit.>]
Let 𝐘 be a finite or countable set, and let 𝐘
be the vector space formally spanned over  by the elements
of 𝐘. 
A linear map u∈End(𝐘) is called 
a partial map in 𝐘 if the image u(p) of each
element p ∈𝐘 is
either another element of 𝐘 or zero.

sentence:
[cf. <cit.>]
The diagonal box-adding operators u_j act on shifted shapes according to the following rule:

    u_j (λ)=     
    λ∪{box on the j-th diagonal}   if this gives a valid shape; 
    
    0    otherwise.

Here the diagonals are numbered from left to right, starting with j=1 for the main diagonal.

sentence: A standard shifted Young tableau of shape λ = (λ_1, λ_2, …, λ_l) is a special recording tableau if it is standard, and for every i such that 1 ≤ i ≤ l, the entries λ_l + … + λ_i+1+1, λ_l + … + λ_i+1+2, …, λ_l + … +λ_i+1 + λ_i form a connected vee.

sentence: The mixed reading word of a shifted Young tableau T is the word corresponding to the pair (T, U) under the mixed insertion correspondence, where U is the shifted dual reading tableau of the same shape as T. The mixed reading word of T is denoted (T).

sentence: A word w in the alphabet X is a shifted tableau word if there exists a shifted Young tableau T such that w = (T). The shape of a shifted tableau word is given by the shape of the corresponding tableau.

sentence:
A semistandard decomposition tableau (SSDT) is a filling R of a shape λ = (λ_1, …, λ_l) with elements of X, such that:


  * the word u_i formed by reading the i-th row from left to right is a hook word of length λ_i, and

  * u_i is a hook subword of maximum length in u_l u_l-1⋯ u_i, for 1 ≤ i ≤ l-1.


The reading word of R is (R) = u_l u_l-1⋯ u_1. The content of an SSDT is the content of (R).

sentence:
A word of length n is called a permutation if it contains each of the letters 1,2,…, n each exactly once. A shifted Young tableau of content (1,1,…,1) will be called a Haiman tableau . In other words, a Haiman tableau is a standard shifted tableau, possibly with some primed off-diagonal entries.

Let w = w_1 w_2 … w_m be a word. Let (α_1, …, α_m) be the content of w, i.e., α_i letters in w are equal to i. The standardization of w, denoted (w) is the permutation obtained by relabelling the elements labelled i by α_1+⋯ + α_i-1+1, …, α_1 + ⋯ + α_i, from left to right.

The standardization of an SSDT R, denoted (R) is the filling obtained by applying the same procedure used in the standardization of a word, namely, taking the order of the elements from (R).  Note that in general, any filling of a shifted shape with letters in X can be standardized, using this method.

The standardization of a shifted Young tableau T, denoted (T) is the Haiman tableau of the same shape, obtained as follows: Let α = (α_1, …, α_m) be the content of T. For every i, the entries labelled i' or i are relabelled α_1 + … + α_i-1+1, α_1 + … + α_i-1+2, …, α_1 + … + α_i-1 + α_i. One assigns these values in increasing order, starting from the boxes labelled i', from top to bottom, and then moving to the boxes labelled i, from left to right. If the old element in a box was primed, so is the new one. This procedure has been suggested by Haiman <cit.>.

sentence:
A simplicial complex  is called a matroid complex (or just matroid) if one of the following equivalent properties hold:


  1. The augmentation axiom: For any two faces F, G ∈ with |F| < |G| there exists i ∈ G such that F ∪{i}∈.

  2. The exchange property: For any two facets F, G ∈ and for any i ∈ F there exists a j ∈ G such that (F∖{i}) ∪{j}∈.

  3. For any subset W⊂ [n] the restriction |_W is pure.

sentence: Two side-by-side dimers (or, sometimes, their four endpoints) are called a block .   A block is odd if it has a black vertex in the upper left corner; otherwise it is even .

sentence:
An odd-deficient (respectively, even-deficient ) dimer cover is a partial dimer cover such that the set of non-covered vertices is a finite union of odd (respectively, even) blocks.  
Given a dimer cover T,  construct the odd-deficient dimer cover T̃ by deleting all of the odd blocks of T.  Construct the even-deficient dimer cover T̂ by deleting all of the even blocks of T.  Let

    _n    := {π̃ : π∈_n }, 
    _n    := {π̂ : π∈_n }.

sentence:
The sliding map S is a mapping from the set {dimers on the colored square lattice} to itself.  If d is a dimer, then define S(d) to be the other dimer in the odd block containing d.
If T is an odd-deficient partial dimer cover, then define S(T) to be the partial dimer cover {S(d) : d ∈ T}.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let π∈_n.  The following three steps constitute the dimer shuffling algorithm:


  * (Deleting) Delete all of the odd blocks in π to get π̃. 

  * (Sliding) Compute S(π̃), as defined above.

  * (Creating) Now we have a partial dimer cover which is possibly missing some even blocks.  Each block may be filled in with either two horizontal dimers, or two vertical dimers.  Define S(π) to be the formal sum of all of these fillings.

sentence:
A Young diagram is a finite subset of (_≥ 0)^2 which 
satisfies the following closure properties:


  * If (x,y) ∈λ and x>0, then (x-1, y) ∈λ.

  * If (x,y) ∈λ and y>0, then (x, y-1) ∈λ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let λ be a Young diagram. The leg of shape λ is the set 

    L_λ = λ×_≥ 0⊆ (_≥ 0)^3.

A three-dimensional partition asymptotic to λ is a set π satisfying L_λ⊆π⊆ (_≥ 0)^3 satisfying the following properties: 


  * The set π∖ L_λ is finite.

  * If (x,y,z) ∈π and x>0, then (x-1, y, z) ∈π.

  * If (x,y,z) ∈π and y>0, then (x, y-1, z) ∈π.

  * If (x,y,z) ∈π and y>0, then (x, y, z-1) ∈π.

We also define the size of π , written |π|, to be the cardinality of the set π∖ L_λ.

sentence: A super-rigid partition is a triple (π_0, λ, π_∞), where π_0 and π_∞ are three-dimensional partitions asymptotic to λ.

sentence:
[Age-dependent branching process]
We call a branching process age-dependent , if individuals have random life-lengths with distribution function F_ Y with F_ Y(0)=0. At death, an individual produces offspring of random size with probability generating function h(s) and all life-lengths and family sizes are independent of each other. We assume that the process starts at time t=0 with one individual of age 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Explosive age-dependent process]
We say that the branching process (h_ B,F_ Y) is explosive if there is a positive probability that N_t=∞, where N_t denotes the number of individuals alive at some finite time t>0. Otherwise, it is called conservative.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The hopcount H_n(u,v) is the number of edges in the shortest-weight path between u and v.

sentence:
Let Γ be a finite graph with vertex set S. A heap on Γ (or of type Γ) is a finite poset (H,≤), together with a labeling map ϵ:H→Γ, which satisfies the following conditions:



  * For any vertex s, the subposet H_s:=ϵ^-1({s}) is totally ordered, and for any edge {s,t}, the subposet H_{s,t}:=ϵ^-1({s,t}) is totally ordered.

  * The ordering on H is the transitive closure of the relations given by all chains H_s and H_{s,t}, i.e. the smallest partial ordering containing these chains.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Δ be a polyhedral cell complex, and let M be an acyclic matching on the face poset of Δ.
  Let c_i denote the number of critical i-dimensional cells of Δ.
  
  
  (a) The space Δ is homotopy equivalent to a cell complex Δ_c, called the Morse complex of Δ with respect to M , with c_i cells of dimension i for each i≥ 0, plus a single 0-dimensional cell in the case where the empty set is paired in the matching.
  
  (b) There is an indexing of the cells of Δ_c with the critical cells of Δ such that for any two cells σ and τ of Δ_c satisfying (σ)=(τ)+1, the incidence number [τ:σ] in the cellular chain complex for Δ_c is given by
    
    [τ:σ]=∑_cw(c)

    where the sum is taken over all alternating paths c connecting σ with τ, i.e. with all sequences c=(σ,a_1,u(a_1),…,a_t,u(a_t),τ) such that a_1 ≺σ, τ≺ u(a_t), and a_i+1≺ u(a_i) for i=1,…,t-1.
    For such an alternating path, the quantity w(c) is defined by
    
    w(c):=(-1)^t[a_1:σ][τ:u(a_t)]∏_i=1^t[a_i:u(a_i)]∏_i=1^t-1[a_i+1:u(a_i)]   ,

    where the incidence numbers on the right-hand side are taken in the complex Δ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Morse complex of Δ with respect to M

sentence:
A partial matching in a poset P is a partial matching in the underlying graph of the Hasse diagram
  of P, i.e., it is a subset M⊆ P × P such that
  
  
  * (a,b)∈ M implies b ≻ a; i.e. a<b and no c satisifies a<c<b.
  
  * each a∈ P belongs to at most one element in M.
  
  When (a,b) ∈ M, we write a=d(b) and b=u(a).

  * A partial matching on P is called acyclic if there does not exist a cycle
  
    a_1 ≺ u(a_1) ≻ a_2 ≺ u(a_2) ≻⋯≺ u(a_m) ≻ a_1

  with m≥ 2 and all a_i∈ P being distinct.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A and B be finite sets.  
  Let M  be a collection of maps from A to B called homomorphisms.  
  Let P(A,B) be the polyhedral cell complex ∏_i∈ AΔ_B, where Δ_B is the simplex with vertices labeled by elements of B.  
  We record a face of P(A,B) by an |A|-tuple of the form X=(X_i)_i∈ A, with each ∅≠ X_i⊆ B.
  The homomorphism complex _M(A,B) is the subcomplex of P(A,B) consisting of all cells labeled by (W_i)_i∈ A∈ P(A,B) satisfying the following property: if η:A→ B is such that η(i)∈ W_i for all i∈ A, then η∈ M.  
  We call such a (W_i)_i∈ A∈ P(A,B) a multi-homomorphism , and we call A the test object and B the target object for the complex.
  The faces of _M(A,B) are partially ordered by X≤ Y if and only if X_i⊆ Y_i for all i∈ A.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An order-preserving map ϕ from a poset P to itself is a descending closure operator if ϕ^2 = ϕ and ϕ(x) ≤ x for every x ∈ P.
  Similarly, ϕ is an ascending closure operator if ϕ^2 = ϕ and ϕ(x) ≥ x for every x ∈ P.

sentence:
Given a poset P, Δ(P) is the order complex of P, the simplicial complex whose simplices are the chains of P.
  Moreover, if P is the face poset of a polyhedral cell complex X, then (Δ(P)) = Bd  X.

sentence:
Given a k-dimensional cell σ∈(), the word obtained by removing the parentheses from σ but keeping all of the entries in the same order will be called the underlying word of σ .

  of P, i.e., it is a subset M⊆ P × P such that
  
  
  * (a,b)∈ M implies b ≻ a; i.e. a<b and no c satisifies a<c<b.

sentence:
Let A and B be finite sets.  
  Let M  be a collection of maps from A to B called homomorphisms.  
  Let P(A,B) be the polyhedral cell complex ∏_i∈ AΔ_B, where Δ_B is the simplex with vertices labeled by elements of B.  
  We record a face of P(A,B) by an |A|-tuple of the form X=(X_i)_i∈ A, with each ∅≠ X_i⊆ B.
  The homomorphism complex _M(A,B) is the subcomplex of P(A,B) consisting of all cells labeled by (W_i)_i∈ A∈ P(A,B) satisfying the following property: if η:A→ B is such that η(i)∈ W_i for all i∈ A, then η∈ M.  
  We call such a (W_i)_i∈ A∈ P(A,B) a multi-homomorphism , and we call A the test object and B the target object for the complex.
  The faces of _M(A,B) are partially ordered by X≤ Y if and only if X_i⊆ Y_i for all i∈ A.

  The poset homomorphism complex (P,Q) is defined to be _M(P,Q) for this choice of M.

sentence: A pants decomposition P of S is a collection of non-oriented mutually disjoint curves decomposing P into pairs of pants (i.e., into spheres with 3 holes).

sentence:
We will say that a curve c on a surface S is a handle curve if at least one of the connected components of the surface S∖ c is a torus with one hole (a “handle”). 
All other curves will be called non-handle curves.

sentence:
Let M be a positroid on [n] and let S_1, S_2, …, S_t be the ground sets of the connected components of M. Then Π_M={S_1, …, S_t} is a non-crossing partition of [n], called the non-crossing partition of M .

Conversely, if S_1, S_2, …, S_t form a non-crossing partition of [n] and M_1, M_2, …, M_t are connected positroids on S_1, S_2, …, S_t, respectively, then 
M_1 ⊕…⊕ M_t is a positroid.

sentence:
A matroid M is a pair (E, ) consisting of a finite set E and a nonempty collection of subsets =(M) of E, called the bases of M, which satisfy the basis exchange axiom: 


 If B_1, B_2 ∈ and b_1 ∈ B_1 - B_2, then there exists b_2 ∈ B_2 - B_1 such that B_1 -  {b_1}∪{b_2}∈.

sentence:
Let M be a matroid on E and N a matroid on F. The direct sum
of matroids M and N is the matroid M ⊕ N
whose underlying set is
the disjoint union of E and F, and whose bases are the disjoint 
unions of a basis of M with a basis of N.

sentence:
Given a matroid M=(E,), the orthogonal or dual matroid M^*=(E,^*) is the 
matroid on E defined by 
^* = {E - B | B∈}.

sentence:
Given a matroid M=(E,), and a subset S of E, the restriction
of M to S, written M|S, is the matroid on the ground set S whose independent sets 
are all independent sets of M which are contained in S. Equivalently,
the set of bases of M|S is

    (M|S) = {B ∩ S  | B ∈,  and  |B ∩ S|  is maximal among all B ∈}.

sentence:
Given a matroid M=(E,) and a subset T of E, the contraction
of M by T, written M/T, is the matroid on the ground set E - T whose bases
are the following:

    (M/T) = {B - T  | B ∈,  and  |B ∩ T|  is maximal 
    among all B ∈}.

sentence:
Suppose A is a d × n matrix of rank d with real entries such that all its maximal minors are nonnegative. Such a matrix A is called totally nonnegative , 
and the representable matroid M(A) associated to A is called a positroid .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let d ≤ n be positive integers. A Grassmann necklace of type (d,n) is a sequence (I_1, I_2, …, I_n) of d-subsets I_k ∈[n]d such that for any i ∈ [n]

 
  * if i ∈ I_i then I_i+1 = I_i - {i}∪{j} for some j ∈ [n],
 
  * if i ∉ I_i then I_i+1 = I_i,

where I_n+1 = I_1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A decorated permutation of the set [n] is a bijection π : [n] → [n] whose fixed points are colored either “clockwise” 
or “counterclockwise.” 
We denote a clockwise fixed point by π(j) = j and 
a counterclockwise fixed point by π(j) = j.
A weak i-excedance of the decorated permutation π is an element j ∈ [n] such that either j <_i π(j) or 
π(j)=j is a “counterclockwise” fixed point. 
The number of weak i-excedances of π is the same for any i ∈ [n]; we will simply call it the number of weak excedances of π.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Let G be a reduced plabic graph as above
with boundary vertices b_1,…, b_n.  
The trip from b_i is the path 
obtained by starting from b_i and traveling along 
edges of G according to the rule that each time we reach an internal white vertex we turn 
right, and each time we reach an internal black vertex we turn left. 
This trip ends at some boundary vertex b_π(i).  
If the starting and ending points of the trip are the same vertex b_j, 
we set the color of the fixed point π(j)=j to match the orientation of the trip
(clockwise or counterclockwise.)



In this way we associate a decorated permutation 
π_G=(π(1),…,π(n)) to each reduced plabic graph G, which 
is called the 
decorated trip permutation of G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
Given a matroid M=([n],), the (basis) matroid polytope Γ_M of M is the convex hull of the indicator vectors of the bases of M:

    Γ_M := {e_B | B ∈}⊂^n,

where e_B := ∑_i ∈ B e_i, and {e_1, …, e_n} is the standard basis of ^n.

sentence:
A matroid which cannot be written as the direct sum (see Definition <ref>) of two nonempty
matroids is called connected .

sentence:
Let S be a partition [n]=S_1 ⊔⋯⊔ S_t  of [n] into pairwise disjoint non-empty subsets. We say that S is a non-crossing partition if there are no a,b,c,d in cyclic order such that a,c ∈ S_i and b,d ∈ S_j for some i ≠ j. 
Equivalently, place the numbers 1,2,…, n on n vertices around a circle in clockwise order, and then for each S_i, draw a polygon on the corresponding vertices. If no two of these polygons intersect, then S is a non-crossing partition of [n]. 

Let NC_n be the set of non-crossing partitions of [n].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Suppose S_1 and S_2 are disjoint sets. If π_1 is a decorated permutation of S_1 and π_2 is a decorated permutation of S_2, the direct sum π_1 ⊕π_2 is the decorated permutation of the set S_1 ⊔ S_2 such that π|_S_1 = π_1 and π|_S_2 = π_2.

sentence:
<cit.>
A stabilized-interval-free (SIF) permutation π of [n] is a permutation which does not stabilize any proper interval of [n]; that is, π(I) ≠ I for all intervals I ⊊ [n].
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let Π be a non-crossing partition of [n].
Consider nodes 1,1',2,2', …, n,n' in that order around a circle, and draw the partition Π on the labels 1, 2, …, n. The Kreweras complement K(Π) is the coarsest (non-crossing) partition of [n] such that when we regard it as a partition K(Π)' of 1', 2', …, n', the partition Π∪ K(Π)' of 1,1',2,2', …, n,n' is non-crossing.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A weighted non-crossing partition S^w of [n] is a non-crossing partition S of [n], say [n]=S_1 ⊔⋯⊔ S_t, together with a weight vector w=(w_1,…,w_t) ∈ (_≥0)^t of integer 
weights w_1 = w(S_1), …, w_t = w(S_t) with 0 ≤ w_i ≤ |S_i| for i=1, …, t. The weight of the partition S^w is w_1+⋯+w_t.

sentence:

  * ℓ_max(Q) = |Φ_+(Q)|,
		
		where Φ_+(Q) is the set of positive roots of Q.

are defined by (<ref>).

sentence:
Let G be a finite group, 𝒦 be a partition of G into unions of conjugacy classes, and 𝒳 be a set of characters of G. We say that the pair (𝒦,𝒳) is a supercharacter theory of G if


  (SCT1) |𝒳|=|𝒦|,

  (SCT2) the characters χ∈𝒳 are constant on the members of 𝒦, and

  (SCT3) each irreducible character of G is a constituent of exactly one character in 𝒳.

The characters χ∈𝒳 are called supercharacters and the blocks K ∈𝒦 are called superclasses .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let I be a finite set and let 𝒫 be a poset on I. Given a subset S ⊆ I and a nonnesting (𝔽_q,𝒫)-set partition η, define the projection of η from I to S, denoted proj_S^I(η), to be the set of nonnesting (𝔽_q,𝒫|_S)-set partitions ν such that


  * if i a⌢j ∈η and i,j ∈ S, then i a⌢j ∈ν; and

  * if i a⌢j ∈ν, then there exist k,l ∈ I with kb⌢l ∈η and k ≼_𝒫 i ≺_𝒫 j ≼_𝒫 l.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A graph of matrices consists of a triple
=(G,(_v)_v∈ V,(T_e)_e∈ E) in which 


  * G = (V, E) is a directed graph (possibly with
  multiple edges and loops),

  * _v  is a finite dimensional Hilbert space  equal to ^N_v and


  * T_e:_s(e)→_t(e) is a linear operator.
 (This is also known as a representation of a quiver, but we shall not need this terminology.)
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a directed graph (possibly with multiple
edges). We say that G is an input-output graph if
there exists two disjoint non-empty subsets, V_ and
V_, of the set of vertices of G such that the
following properties are satisfied. 

  * G does not contain a directed cycle. (Recall that a cycle
  is a closed path and that a path is directed if all the
  edges are oriented in the same direction.)


  * Each vertex of G lies on a directed path from some vertex
in V_ to some vertex in V_.

  * Every internal vertex has at least one incoming edge and at
least one outgoing edge.

  * Every input vertex has only outgoing edges and every output
vertex has only ingoing edges.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that =(Ĝ,(_v)_v∈V̂,(T̂_e)_e∈Ê) is a modification
of =(G,(_v)_v∈ V,(T_e)_e∈ E), if the
former can be obtained from the latter by finitely many
applications of the following operations:


  * change the direction of the arrow of an edge e and replace
T_e:_s(e)→_t(e) by its transpose
T_e^t:_t(e)→_s(e)

  * split a vertex v into two vertices v and v',
redistribute in some way the incoming and outgoing edges for
v together with their matrices to v and v' and add a
new edge between v and v' with arbitrary direction for
this edge and the identity matrix attached to it; should v
be a two-edge connected component, then we add two edges
between v and v', both with the same orientation, and
both having the identity matrix attached to them
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let ℋ_+ denote the open upper half-plane. A polynomial p ∈[z_1,...,z_n] is said to be stable if either p ≡ 0 or (z_1,...,z_n) ∈ℋ_+^n implies p(z_1,...,z_n) ≠ 0. Additionally, if p ∈[z_1,...,z_n], we say that p is real stable . (Notice that a univariate polynomial is real stable iff it is real-rooted.)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A polynomial p ∈[z_1,...z_n] is said to be multi-affine if it is of degree at most one in each variable.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let p,q ∈[z] be real-rooted polynomials given by p(z) = C_1 ∏_k=1^n (z - λ_k) and q(z) = C_2 ∏_k=1^m (z - γ_k), where n and m differ by at most 1 and m ≤ n. We write q ≪ p, or say q interlaces p, if λ_1 ≥γ_1 ≥λ_2 ≥γ_2 ≥⋯.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence: Let p_1,p_2,...,p_m ∈[z] be real-rooted polynomials. We say that p_1,p_2,...,p_m have a common interlacing , if there exists f ∈[z] such that f ≪ p_k for all k ∈ [m].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A polynomial p ∈[z_1,...,z_n] is said to be same-phase stable if one of the following equivalent conditions is satisfied.

    
  * For every 𝐭∈_+^n, the univariate restriction p(𝐭z) is stable (for =, p(𝐭z) is real-rooted).
    
  * If (z_1) = (z_2) = ⋯ = (z_n), then p(z_1,...,z_n) = 0 implies z_k ∉ℋ_+ for some k (for =, z_k ∈ for all k).

We will primarily make use of condition (i).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Polynomials p_1,...,p_m ∈[z_1,...,z_n] are said to be same-phase compatible if p_k is same-phase stable for all k, and the polynomials {p_k(𝐭z)}_k=1^m have a common interlacing for each 𝐭∈_+^n.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let p,f_0,f_1,...,f_m ∈[z_1,...,z_n] be polynomials, not necessarily multi-affine, such that

    p = f_0 + z_i_1 f_1 + ⋯ + z_i_m f_m.

We call such an expression a proper splitting of p (with respect to {z_i_j}_j) if none of the f_k's depend on any of the z_i_j's. We also say that {z_i_j}_j=1^m splits p.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Given a graph G and vertex v, we define the (labeled) path tree T_v(G) of G with respect to v recursively as follows. If G is a tree, we define T_v(G) = G, and we say that v is the root of T_v(G). We also label the vertices of T_v(G) using the vertices of G. (In the recursive step, we will continue to label using vertices of G.)

For an arbitrary graph G, we first consider the forest which is the disjoint union of the labeled trees T_w(G ∖{v}) for each w ∈ N(v). We then define T_v(G) by appending a vertex (the root) labeled v and connecting it to the roots of each of these trees.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a graph G and vertex v, we define the induced path tree T^∠_v(G) of G with respect to v recursively as follows. If G is a tree, we define T^∠_v(G) = G, and we say that v is the root of T^∠_v(G).

For an arbitrary graph G, we first consider the forest which is the disjoint union of the trees T^∠_w(G ∖ N[v] ∪{w}) for each w ∈ N(v). We then define T^∠_v(G) by appending a vertex corresponding to v (the root) and connecting it to the roots of each of these trees.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a graph G and a clique K, the induced path tree T^∠_K(G) of G with respect to K is defined as follows. Construct a new graph G^* by attaching a new vertex * to G, with the property that {*,u}∈ E(G^*) iff u ∈ K. Then, define T^∠_K(G) := T^∠_{*}(G^*).

sentence:
Given a simplicial graph G and simplicial clique K ≤ G, we define the (simplicial) clique tree T^⊠_K(G) of G with respect to K recursively as follows. If G = K, we define T^⊠_K(G) = G, and we say that K is the “root clique” of T^⊠_K(G).

For an arbitrary graph G, we first consider the “forest of simplicial clique trees” which is the disjoint union of T^⊠_J_u(G ∖ K) for each u ∈ K. (Here, we define J_u := N[u] ∩ G ∖ K.) Note that this is valid, since the previous lemma implies J_u is a simplicial clique for all u ∈ K. We then define T^⊠_K(G) by appending the clique K (the root clique) and connecting each vertex u ∈ K to each vertex of the root clique of T^⊠_J_u(G ∖ K).

sentence:
Let H=(W,E_H) and R=([k],E_R) be graphs and let R'=([k],E_R') be a
  subgraph of R. We say that a vertex partition W=(W_i)_i∈[k] of H is
  -compatible 
  with an integer partition (n_i)_i∈[k] of n
  and with R'⊂ R if the following holds. For
  i∈[k] let S_i be the set of vertices in W_i with neighbours in some
  W_j with ij∉E_R' and i≠ j, set S:=⋃ S_i and
  T_i:=N_H(S)∩ (W_i∖ S). Then for all i,j∈[k] we have that
  
    
  * 
      |W_i|≤ n_i,
    
  * 
      xy∈ E_H for x∈ W_i and y∈ W_j implies ij∈ E_R,
    
  * 
      |S_i|≤ n_i and
      |T_i|≤·min{n_j:i and j are in the same
      component of R'}.
  
  The partition W=(W_i)_i∈[k] of H is -compatible
  with a partition V=(V_i)_i∈[k] of a graph G and with R'⊂ R if 
  W=(W_i)_i∈[k] is -compatible with (|V_i|)_i∈[k] and with
  R'⊂ R.

sentence:
A sequence a_n is k-regular if it can be completely defined by recurrences of the following form:

    a_k^m+r = ∑_i=1^L c_i a_k^m_i+r_i,

where m > m_i, 0≤ r ≤ k^m-1, and 0≤ r_i ≤ k^m_i-1, and the c_i can be any constants.

sentence:
Define the staircase grid B_a as a staircase-like grid with a rows and a columns such that the top row and right column have a boxes, the second-to-top row and second-to-right column have a-1 boxes, and so on. By a box , we mean a unit square. See Figure <ref> for an example.

More specifically, define the staircase encoding of π as the grid B_a combined with a number in each box. For the box in the i^th row from the top and the j^th column from the bottom, fill in the number of elements in π which are strictly between π_k_i and π_k_i-1 as a value and between position k_j and k_j+1 in the order of the permutation (assume π_k_0 = k_a+1 = n+1). For an example, see Figure <ref>.

sentence: A Young diagram is a finite, connected collection of boxes such that there exists a bottom-left most box that we label as (1, 1). Moreover, if the box (k, ℓ) (which is in the k^th column from left and ℓ^th row from bottom) in the Young diagram, then every box (k', ℓ') with 1 ≤ k' ≤ k, 1 ≤ℓ' ≤ℓ is also in the diagram.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A skew Young diagram is a finite collection of boxes such that there exists a Young diagram λ and another Young diagram μ⊂λ with the same bottom-left most box, such that a box is in the skew Young diagram if and only if it is in λ but not in μ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that two sequences (a_1, …, a_k) and (b_1, …, b_k) are order-isomorphic if for any 1 ≤ i,j ≤ k, we have a_i < a_j if and only if b_i < b_j. In this case, we write a_1 ⋯ a_k ∼ b_1 ⋯ b_k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let σ∈ S_k.
	A permutation π∈ S_n contains σ as a classical pattern
	if there exists 1 ≤ i_1 < … < i_k ≤ n such that 
	
    π_i_1π_i_2⋯π_i_k∼σ_1σ_2⋯σ_k.

	Alternatively, if a permutation does not contain σ,
	it is said to avoid σ.
