sentence: For a permutation π = π_1π_2⋯π_n, we define π_i to be a left-to-right minimum if π_j > π_i for all j < i.

sentence:
Define the staircase grid B_a as a staircase-like grid with a rows and a columns such that the top row and right column have a boxes, the second-to-top row and second-to-right column have a-1 boxes, and so on. By a box , we mean a unit square. See Figure <ref> for an example.

More specifically, define the staircase encoding of π as the grid B_a combined with a number in each box. For the box in the i^th row from the top and the j^th column from the bottom, fill in the number of elements in π which are strictly between π_k_i and π_k_i-1 as a value and between position k_j and k_j+1 in the order of the permutation (assume π_k_0 = k_a+1 = n+1). For an example, see Figure <ref>.

sentence:
The downcore graph of a staircase grid of size n (i.e. n rows, n columns) is the undirected graph with the vertex set {(i, j): 1 ≤ i ≤ j ≤ n} where (i, j) refers to the box at the i^th row from top and j^th column from left. An edge exists between (i, j) and (k, ℓ) if
  

	
  * i < k ≤ j < ℓ or
  
  * k < i ≤ℓ < j.


We can alternatively think of this as requiring i<k and j<ℓ or vice versa, and that (i, ℓ) and (k, j) are boxes in the staircase grid.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a 123-avoiding permutation π of length n, define the boundary grid of π as a subset of an (n-1) × (n-1) grid of boxes such that if we label the vertices of the boxes from (1, 1) to (n, n) in a standard Cartesian coordinate way, a box is in the boundary grid if and only if it is above and to the right of at least one left-to-right minimum and below and to the left of at least one right-to-left maximum. See Figure <ref> for an example.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The downcore graph on a skew Young diagram is a graph with the boxes of the diagram as vertices. If (x, y) denotes the box in the x^th column from left and y^th row from bottom (to correspond with the Cartesian coordinates), there is an edge between (i, j) and (k, ℓ) if the following two conditions are met:
  

	
  * i < k, j > ℓ or i > k, j < ℓ
	
  * (i, ℓ), (k, j) are both in the skew Young diagram.


	The second condition is equivalent to the rectangle created with corner boxes (i, j), (i, ℓ), (k, j), and (k, ℓ) being entirely contained within the boundary grid. See Figure <ref> for an example of a downcore graph on a boundary grid.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A set S⊂ is called thick if it contains arbitrarily large intervals, and piecewise syndetic if it is the intersection of a thick set with a syndetic set (cf. Remark <ref>). A set S is called BohrCf. Footnote <ref>. if there exist d∈, α∈^d = ^d/^d, and an open set ∅≠ U⊂^d such that

    ∅≠{n∈ : nα∈ U}⊂ S.

Finally, the intersection of a thick set with a Bohr set is called piecewise Bohr .

sentence:
Let F be a star-shaped set with colored boundary.
Let p be a point in the kernel of F.
The p-extension of the coloring of the boundary 
is the following coloring of F.
For every point x on the boundary of F,
all points on the open segment between p and x get the color of x.
The point p gets an arbitrary color of those used on the boundary.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let 𝖡_1 be the block of π containing 1, and for 1< j ≤ |π|, let 𝖡_j be the block of π containing the smallest number not in 𝖡_1 ∪𝖡_2 ∪⋯∪𝖡_j-1.   
The standard labeling of π  is  (_π | _π'),  where 
_π = (b_1,…, b_k) and _π' = (b_k+1, …,b_2k) in [1,n]^k,  and 

    b_ℓ = j    if  ℓ∈𝖡_j   for  ℓ∈ [1,2k].

sentence:
Let G be a graph and
F be a class of graphs.
We write 

    G Fr,m

if given any r-edge coloring c:E(G)→{0, …, r-1 }   the vertex set of G 
can be partitioned into m monochromatic elements of F.


We write 





    G F, F,…, Fr

if given any r-edge coloring c:E(G)→{0, …, r-1 }   the vertex set of G 
can be partitioned into r monochromatic elements of F
 in distinct colors .


In particular,   GPathr,m holds if 
given any r-edge coloring c of G the vertex set of G 
can be partitioned into m monochromatic paths.

We write ⊏^* instead of ⊏ if we can partition the vertex set apart 
from a finite set .

sentence:
[Polyhedron]
A polyhedron P⊆^n is a set of points that satisfy a finite number of linear inequalities; that is, P={x∈^n: Ax≤ b }, where (A,b) is an m×(n+1) matrix.

sentence:
[Valid Inequality]
An inequality π x ≤π_0 is called valid for polyhedron P⊆^n if it is satisfied by all points of P.

sentence:
[Convex Hull]
The set S is defined as S=P ∩ Z^n where P⊆ ^n. The convex hull of S is denoted as conv(S) and  conv(S)={y ∈^n:y=∑_i=1^kλ_ix^i}, where x^i∈ S and λ_i∈_+ ∀ i, with ∑_i=1^kλ_i=1.

sentence:
Let G be a square geometric graph with linear orders <_1 and <_2 as in Theorem <ref>. Define


    E_i={wz |∃ u,v∈ V(G),  u<_i w<_i v        u<_i z<_i v      u∼ v}.


The completion of <_i, denoted by _i, is (E(G))^c∩ E_i. Indeed _i is the set of the non-edges of G whose ends are in between two adjacent vertices in <_i.

sentence: Let G be a _a,b-graph with bipartition X_a∪ X_b and Y. Assume v∈ X_a∪ X_b and S⊆ X_a∪ X_b. Then v is called rigid-free with respect to S if there is no rigid pair {x_1y_1,x_2y_2} of G with {x_1, x_2}⊆ S and y_1, y_2∈ N_Y(v).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A tiered tree of size n is a pair (T,t) where:


  * T is a labeled tree on [n].

  * t is a surjective mapping from [n] → [k] for some k such that for any edge (i,j) of T with i>j we have t(i) < t(j).

The function t is called the tiering function of the tiered tree (T,t), and the integer k is its number of tiers.

A tiered tree is said to be fully tiered if its number of tiers equals its number of vertices, that is, k=n, or equivalently, if its tiering function is a bijection.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A configuration c ∈G is recurrent on Gs if it satisfies the following three conditions:


  * We have c_s=d_s.

  * The configuration c is stable, that is, c_i < d_i for i ≠ s.

  *  There exists a sequence v_1,…,v_n with v_1=s and {v_1,…,v_n} = [n] such that 

    c^0 = c v_1 c^1 v_2⋯v_n c^n=c.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G=(V,E) be a graph, T a spanning tree of G, and ≺ a total order on the edges E of G. An edge e ∉ T is said to be externally active if it is the maximal edge for ≺ in the unique cycle contained in T ∪{e}. An edge e ∈ T is said to be internally active if it is the maximal edge for ≺ in the unique cocycle contained in T ∖{e}, that is, in the set of edges connecting the two connected components of T ∖{e}. The external, resp. internal, activity of T is its number of externally, resp. internally, active edges, and is denoted by (T), resp. (T).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G = (V,E) be a graph, and suppose we have a mapping Ψ: T ↦≺_T from the set of spanning trees of G to the set of total orders on E. We say that the mapping Ψ is Tutte-descriptive if

    _G(x,y) = ∑_T x^(T) y^(T),

where the sum is over all spanning trees of G, and (T), resp. (T), is the number of internally, resp. externally, active edges for the order ≺_T.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a permutation π∈ and a distinguished vertex s ∈ [n], we say that an ordered set partition P=P_0,…,P_k of [n] is (π,s)-compatible if it satisfies the following three conditions:


  *  P_0 = {s}.

  *  For any j ≥ 0, the elements of P_j appear in increasing order in π (that is, there is no inversion in π between two elements of P_j).

  *  For any j ≥ 1 and i ∈ P_j, there exists i' ∈ P_j-1 such that (i,i') or (i',i) is an inversion of π.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A non-ambiguous binary tree () is a filling of a rectangular Ferrers diagram F where every cell is either empty or dotted such that:


  *  Every row and every column has a dotted cell.

  *  Except for the top left cell, every dotted cell has either a dotted 
cell above it in its column or to its left in its row, but not both.

 The dot in the top left cell (implied by (<ref>) and (<ref>)) is called the root dot, or simply the root .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
A complete multirooted non-ambiguous binary tree (CMNAB) is obtained from , for a permutation π, by adding a further n-1
 dots with the following conditions:


  *  Every added dot has a dotted cell below it in its column and to its right in its row.

  *  The graph obtained as in the case of a  is a tree.

The added dots are called internal dots . The set of  arising from  is denoted , and the tree obtained from M∈ is denoted T(M).

sentence:
Let d_2, δ_2>0. A bipartite graph G with the bipartition V(G)=X Y is called (δ_2, d_2)-regular if for all subsets X'⊆ X and Y'⊆ Y we have

    |e(G[X',Y'])-d_2|X'||Y'||≤δ_2 |X||Y| .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let d_3,δ_3>0.

A 3-graph ℋ=(V,E_H) is called (δ_3,d_3)-regular

with respect to a tripartite graph P=(X  Y  Z,E_P) with V⊇ X∪ Y∪ Z, if for every subgraph Q⊆ P we have

    ||E_H ∩ T(Q)| - d_3|T(Q)|| ≤δ_3|T(P)| .

sentence:
For τ∈Σ (j) and j-1 ≤ k ≤ n define the localization map 
    C^k(X,ℝ)→ C^k-j-1(X_τ,ℝ), ϕ→ϕ_τ ,

where ϕ_τ is defined by ϕ_τ(σ)=ϕ(τσ).

sentence:
An acyclic matching in a simplicial complex K is a set M⊂ K× K of pairs of faces such that 


  * if (σ,τ)∈ M then σ is a codimension 1 face of τ,

  * every face σ belongs to at most one element of M,

  * there is no cycle

    σ_0,τ_0,σ_1,τ_1,σ_2,…,σ_n,τ_n,σ_0

such that (σ_i,τ_i)∈ M, σ_i+1 is a codimension 1 face of τ_i (where σ_n+1=σ_0), all σ_i are distinct and n≥ 1.	

The faces of K which do not belong to any element of M are called critical .
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
Let G be a graph and H a subgraph of G isomorphic to a subdivision of K_3,3.  
Let v_1, v_2, …, v_6 be the degree three vertices of H and for i=1,2,3 and j=4,5,6 let
P_ij be the paths in H between v_i and v_j.  
We then refer to H as a hex or a hex of G , the vertices v_i as the feet of H, 
and the paths P_ij as the segments of H.
A segment is odd if it has an odd number of edges, and even otherwise.
A hex H is odd if every segment of H is odd.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We will refer to the paths P_1', P_2', and P_3' as the replacement paths and the paths 
P_4' and, when appropriate, P_5' as the new paths .  
In the forthcoming arguments we will apply either the induction hypothesis or Lemma <ref>
to various carefully selected paths R_1, R_2, R_3 to obtain replacement paths R_1', R_2', R_3' and new paths R_4' and, when appropriate, R_5'.  
However, we will be able to assume that R_1' = R_1, R_2' = R_2 and R_3' = R_3 which will simplify our notation.  
We will refer to this assumption as assuming that the replacement paths do not change .

sentence: A hex in a graph G is optimal if no hex of G has strictly more odd segments.

sentence:
We say that {u,v} is a spanning pair of G if

[    (C1)]

  * for all x∈ V∖ N[v], we have N[x]⊆ N[u],
(C)

  * for all y∈ V∖ N[u], we have N[y]⊆ N[v].
(C)

sentence:
A linear ordering < of V(G) is said to be an interval ordering
of G if there are no three vertices a,b,c∈ V(G) with a<b<c such that:
[    (i)]

  * ab is a non-edge and ac is an edge, or

  * ab is an inclusion edge, ac is a non-edge, and bc is an edge, or

  * ab is an overlap edge, ac is an edge, and bc is a non-edge, or

  * ab and bc are overlap edges, while ac is an inclusion edge, or

  * ab and bc are inclusion edges, while ac is an overlap edge.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A set X⊆ V is a non-inverting set of G if the following
holds:
[  (V1)]

  * no 2-overlap edge of G has both endpoints in X,
(V)

  * no x,y∈ X are such that there is an xy-walk P⊆ X and a
yx-walk Q⊆ X that avoid each other.
(V)

sentence:
[consistent interval representation]
An interval representation of G is said to be consistent with the
labelling of G if for any two vertices u,v∈ V(G), the interval for u
overlaps the interval for v if and only if uv is an overlap edge.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A consistently edge-labelled graph G is an edge-labelled graph that


has a transitive orientation D_c of its inclusion edges such that for each
(u,v)∈ D_c, N[v]⊆ N[u].

sentence:
Let A and B be two matrices which are not permutation-similar. We say A and B are strongly-cospectral , if for any arbitrary finite order polynomial q() and real c, we have 
    Spec(q(A+cJ)-diag(q(A+cJ))=Spec(q(B+cJ)-diag(q(B+cJ))

We define split spectrum of a graph G as 


    SplitSpec (G)={ Spec(G,v) |  v ∈ V(G) }

sentence:
A graded graph is a triple G = (P, ρ, E) where
P is a discrete set of vertices, ρ : P →ℤ is a
rank function and E is a multi-set of edges (x, y) satisfying
ρ (y) = ρ (x) + 1.

sentence: Let 𝒞 be a class of finite structures. We say that 𝒞 has the extension property for partial automorphisms (or EPPA ), also called the Hrushovski property , if for every A∈𝒞 there is B∈𝒞 such that A is an (induced) substructure of B and for every isomorphism f of substructures of A there is an automorphism g of B such that f⊆ g. We call such B an EPPA-witness for A.

sentence:
Let C be a -structure. A -structure C' is a completion
of C if there exists an injective homomorphism-embedding fC→C' which fixes every symbol of the language. We say that C' is an automorphism-preserving completion of C, if C⊆ C', the inclusion together with the identity from  give a homomorphism-embedding, for every α∈( C) there is β∈( C') such that α⊆β and moreover the map α↦β is a group homomorphism (C)→(C').

sentence:
Let z be a real random variable, and let V={v_1,…,v_n} be a multiset in ^d. For any r>0, we define the small ball probability as


    ρ_r,z(V):=sup_x∈^d(v_1z_1+… v_nz_n ∈ B(x,r)),


where z_1,…, z_n are iid copies of z, and B(x,r) denotes the closed disk of radius r centered at x in ^d.

sentence:
Two sets V,V' of additive groups G,G' (not necessarily
torsion-free) are a Freiman isomorphism of order k (in generalized form) if there is an 
injective map f from V to V' such that f(v_1)+… +f(v_k) = 
f(v_1')+… +f(v_k') in G' if and only if v_1+…+v_k =
v_1'+… +v_k' in G.

sentence:
Let Δ be a simplicial complex, and let u, v be vertices of Δ.  An independent set A of Δ
    is nested if the vertices of A can be linearly ordered so that v ≤ u implies
    _Δ(u) ⊂_Δ(v); such an order is a nesting order of A.  A proper vertex
    k-colouring = C_1  C_k of Δ is nested if every colour class of  is nested.
    The nested chromatic number χ_N(Δ) is the least integer k such that a nested k-colouring of
    Δ exists.

sentence:
(a)
A (basic or full) quasigroup word is reduced if it will not reduce further via the quasigroup identities.
1.5mm
(b)
A (basic or full) parsing tree representing a quasigroup word is reduced if its corresponding quasigroup word is reduced.

sentence: Let s, a and b be positive integers. The auxiliary bivariate m^s(a,b) denotes the number of (a+b)-leaf parsing trees representing reduced quasigroup words in s arguments, with an a-leaf basic parsing tree on the left branch, a b-leaf basic parsing tree on the right branch, and a given (basic or opposite) quasigroup operation at the root vertex.

[<cit.>]
  Let a, b be two weak compositions. Then
  
    _a_b = ∑_c [c | a  b] _c,

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  Given a poset  on [p], a -partition is a map f : →ℕ such that for all i,j∈ we have
  
  
  * if i ≺ j, then f(i) ≤ f(j), and
  
  * if i ≺ j and i > j, then f(i) < f(j).
  
  If ∑_i ∈ f(i) = n, then f is a -partition of n .

sentence: For Ł a linear order on [p], the descent composition of Ł , denoted by (Ł), is formed by removing the edge in the Hasse diagram between i and j whenever a cover i  j is such that i>j, calling the resulting chains C_1,…,C_r taken in ascending order in Ł, and setting (Ł)_s = |C_s|. We have that (Ł) is a strong composition of p.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  For α a strong composition, the fundamental quasisymmetric function F_α is given by
  
    F_α(X) = ∑_(b)  refines α x_1^b_1 x_2^b_2⋯ ,

  where the sum is over weak compositions b whose flattening refines α.

sentence: Given a poset  on [p], and a map ρ : →ℤ, a  (,ρ)-partition is a -partition such that f(i) ≤ρ(i) for all i ∈. We denote by _ρ() the set of all  (,ρ)-partitions.

sentence:
Given a poset  on [p] and a map ρ : →ℤ, the maximal -increasing (,ρ)-partition  is
  
    (i) = min{ρ(x) - δ(i,x) | i ≼ x} .

sentence:
For Ł a linear order on [p] and ρ a restriction map satisfying Ł(i) ≥ 1 for all i ∈Ł, we define two associated weak compositions.
 
 
  * The reduced weak descent composition of (Ł,ρ) , denoted by (Ł,ρ), is formed as follows. Remove edges between descents, i.e. whenever i  j and i>j, and call the resulting chains C_1,…,C_r in ascending order of Ł. For s=1,…,r, set c_s = Ł(min_Ł{ C_s}), and define the part c_s of (Ł,ρ) to be (Ł,ρ)_c_s = |C_s| and set all other parts to 0.
  
  * The weak descent composition of (Ł,ρ) , denoted by (Ł,ρ), is formed as follows. Remove edges between i and j whenever i  j and Ł(i) < Ł(j), and call the resulting chains C'_1,…,C'_ℓ in ascending order of Ł. For s=1,…,ℓ, set c'_s = Ł(min_Ł{ C'_s}), and define the part c'_s of (Ł,ρ) as (Ł,ρ)_c'_s = |C'_s| and set all other parts to 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
  For a weak composition a of length n, the slide polynomial _a is given by
  
    _a(x_1,…,x_n) = ∑_(b)  refines (a) 
     b ⊵ a x_1^b_1⋯ x_n^b_n .

  where the sum is over weak compositions b that dominate a and for which the flattening of b refines the flattening of a.

sentence:
For a poset , a restriction ρ is a -flag if ρ(i)>0 for all i∈[p],  
  
  
  (i) if i  j and i<j, then ρ(i) = ρ(j), and
  
  (ii) if i  j and i > j, then ρ(i) ≤ρ(j).
  
  We call _ρ() the set of flagged (,ρ)-partitions to emphasize that ρ is a -flag.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a poset  on [p] and a restriction ρ, we say that (,ρ) is well-labelled  if
  
  
  (i) if i  j and i<j, then ρ(i) ≥ρ(j), 
  
  (ii) if i  j and i > j, then ρ(i) ≤ρ(j), and
  
  (iii) for all incomparable i,j∈, if i<j, then ρ(i) ≥ρ(j).

sentence:
[<cit.>]
    Let a,b be weak compositions of length n. Let A and B be words defined by A = (2n-1)^a_1⋯ (3)^a_n-1 (1)^a_n and B = (2n)^b_1⋯ (4)^b_n-1 (2)^b_n. Define the shuffle set of a and b , denoted by Sh(a,b), by
  
    Sh(a,b) = { C ∈ A  B |_A(C) ≥ a _B(B) ≥ b },

  where _A(C)_i (respectively _B(C)_i) is the number of letters from A (respectively B) in the ith increasing run of C.

  Define the slide product of a and b , denoted by a  b, to be the formal sum
  
    a  b =  ∑_C ∈Sh(a,b)(bump_(a,b)(C))

  where bump_(a,b)(C) is the unique element of the shuffle set 0^n-ℓ((C)) C such that _A(bump_(a,b)(C)) ≥ a and _B(bump_(a,b)(C)) ≥ b and if D ∈ 0^n-ℓ C satisfies _A(D) ≥ a and _B(D) ≥ b, then (D) ≥(bump_(a,b)(C)).

sentence:
Let d be the number of digits needed for the binary expansion of n.
    Take T ∈. Write every label of T as a d–digit number,
    possibly starting with several zeros. For an edge e ∈ T, let n_e
    be the number of ends of T_e and d_e be the number of digits in the
    binary expansion of n_e. By the k–th digit of a label, we always
    mean the k–th digit from the right. We  say an edge e ∈ T is
    k–sorted if the digits (k+1) to d of all labels of T_e
    are the same and either 

     
    
      
  (a1) all labels of T_e have the same k–th digit as well
      or
       
      
  (a2) all labels of T_e whose k–th digit is 0 appear as
      ends of T_e_l and all labels of T_e whose k–th digit is 1
      appear as ends of  T_e_r.

sentence:
We will say a tree T is ripe if for any edge e ∈ T is
     k–sorted, then each child of e is either (k-1)–pre-sorted or
     (k-1)–sorted. Note that if T is ripe, then any subtree of T is
     ripe. We will say an edge e ∈ T is ripe if T_e is ripe.

Suppose that x ∈ N_k,s. Then we define the group coordinates ψ_(x) to be (x_1,…,x_t), where x_1,…,x_t are the unique
complex numbers such that x = u_1^x_1… u_t^x_t. We define the
algebra coordinates ψ_(x) to be (x^'_1,…,x^'_t), where x^'_1,…,x^'_t are the
unique complex numbers such that x = exp(x^'_1 X_1 + … +
x^'_t X_t).

sentence:
Let G be a graph. The quantity 

    χ^∗(G):=inf{k/d|∃ (k,d) -colouring of G}∈ℝ_+

is called the star chromatic number resp. circular chromatic number of G.

sentence: Let D be a digraph and k ≥ d natural numbers. A circular (k,d)-colouring is a vertex-colouring c:V(D) →{0,...,k-1}≃ℤ_k such that (c(w)-c(u))  mod k ≥ d or c(u)=c(w) for all e=(u,w) ∈ E(D) and each colour class c^-1(i), i ∈ℤ_k induces an acyclic subdigraph of D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let D be a digraph, (k,d) ∈ℕ^2, k ≥ d. An acyclic (k,d)-colouring of D
  is an assignment c:V(D) →ℤ_k of colours to the
  vertices such that for every i ∈ℤ_k, the pre-image of
  the cyclic interval A_i:={i,i+1,...,i+d-1}⊆ℤ_k of colours, c^-1(A_i) ⊆ V(D), induces an
  acyclic subdigraph of D.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let p ∈ℝ, p ≥ 1. For a,b ∈ [0,p), we denote by (a,b)_p the open “interval” (a,b)_p:={y ∈ [0,p)|0<(y-a)  mod p < (b-a)  mod p }. Analogous definitions apply for [a,b]_p,[a,b)_p, (a,b]_p. In each case, we call (b-a)  mod p the length of the respective interval. For each x ∈ S_p, denote by |x|_p:=min{x,p-x} its two-sided distance to 0.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let D be a digraph and p ≥ 1. An acyclic p-colouring
  of D is an assignment c:V(D) → [0,p) ≃ℝ/pℤ of “colours” to the vertices, such that
  for every open interval I=(a,b)_p of length 1 within [0,p)
  ≃ℝ/pℤ, the subdigraph induced by the
  vertices in c^-1(I) is acyclic.  The star dichromatic
    number of D  now is defined as the infimum over the numbers p
  for which D admits an acyclic p-colouring:

    χ⃗^∗(D)=inf{p ≥ 1|∃acyclic p-colouring of D}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[cf. <cit.> and <cit.>] 

  (A) Let G be a graph. Denote by ℐ(G) the collection of independent vertex subsets of G, and for each v ∈ V(D), let ℐ(G,v) ⊆ℐ(G) be the subset containing only those sets including v.  The fractional chromatic number χ_f(G) of D is now defined as the value of the following linear program

    min∑_I ∈ℐ(G)x_I
     subj. to    ∑_I ∈ℐ(G,v)x_I≥ 1,  for all  v ∈ V(G) 
        x ≥ 0.


  (B) 
  Let D be a digraph. Denote by 𝒜(D) the collection of
  vertex subsets of D inducing an acyclic subdigraph, and for each
  v ∈ V(D), let 𝒜(D,v) ⊆𝒜(D) be the
  subset containing only those sets including v.  The
  fractional dichromatic number χ⃗_f(D) of D is now
  defined as the value of 
 
    min∑_A ∈𝒜(D)x_A
      subj. to    ∑_A ∈𝒜(D,v)x_A≥ 1,  for all  v ∈ V(D)     x ≥ 0.

For a graph G, we define χ⃗_f(G):=max_𝒪(G)  orient.χ⃗_f(𝒪(G)) to be its fractional dichromatic number .

* A  clutter is a set family with no members containing each other.

  * A subset of arcs in a digraph is called dijoin if it intersects ever directed cut.

  * A subsets of arcs in a digraph is called feedback arc set if it intersects every directed cycle.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
Let 𝒯 be a plane triangulation, and denote by
v_0,v_1,v_2 the outer vertices in counterclockwise ( ccw )
order around the outer face.
A Schnyder wood  of 𝒯 is an orientation and
labeling, with labels in {0,1,2} of the inner edges of   so as
to satisfy the following conditions:





  * root-face condition: for i∈{0,1,2}, the inner edges incident to the
outer vertex v_i are all ingoing of color i.

  * local
condition for inner vertices: For each inner vertex v, the
edges incident to v in counterclockwise ( ccw ) order are: one
outgoing edge  colored 2,
zero or more incoming edges  colored 1,  one outgoing edge  colored
0, zero or more incoming edges  colored 2, one outgoing edge
 colored 1, and zero or more incoming edges  colored 0, which we write concisely as

    (( 1), 0, ( 2), 1,( 0), 2).

sentence:
A chordal edge is an edge of ∖sin
whose two brins h_1 and h_2 are exterior brins of some
boundary corners b_1 and b_2.
A boundary corner b of sin is free if no exterior edge of b is a
chordal edge.

sentence:
Consider a genus g triangulation  with
n vertices, and having a root-face
f=(v_0, v_1, v_2) (the vertices are ordered according to a
walk along f with the interior of f on the right). Let  be
the set of inner edges of .
A g-Schnyder wood of  (also called genus g Schnyder wood)
is a partition of
  into a set of normal edges  and a set
ℰ^s of
special edges considered as fat, i.e., each special edge is
 doubled into two edges delimiting a face of degree 2, called a special face .
 In addition, each edge, a normal edge or one of the two
edges of a special edge, is directed and has a
label (also called color) in {0,1,2}, so as to satisfy the following conditions:





  * root-face condition:
The outer vertex v_2 is incident to no special edges. All inner edges
incident to v_2 are ingoing of color 2.

Let k≥ 0 be the number of special edges incident to v_0 (each of these
special edges is doubled), and let L=(e_1,f_1,e_2,f_2,…,e_r,f_r)
be the cyclic list of edges and faces incident to v_0 in ccw order (f_i
is the face incident to v_0 between e_i and e_(i+1) mod r).
A sector of v is a maximal interval of L that does not contain
a special face nor the root-face. Note that there are k+1 sectors, which are
disjoint; the one containing the edge {v_0,v_1} is called the root-sector .

Then, all inner edges in the root-sector are ingoing of color 0.
In all the other k sectors, the edges in ccw order are of the form

    ( 1), 0, ( 2), 1,( 0).

The definitions of sectors and conditions are the same for v_1,
except that all edges in the root-sector are ingoing of color 1.


  * local condition for inner vertices: Every
inner vertex v has exactly one outgoing edge e of color 2.
Let k be the number of special edges incident to v (each of these
edges is doubled and delimits a special face), and
let L=(e_1,f_1,e_2,f_2,…,e_r,f_r)
be the cyclic list of edges and faces incident to v in ccw order.
A sector of v is a maximal interval of L that does not contain
a special face nor the edge e. Note that there are k+1 sectors around v,
which are disjoint.

Then, in each sector the edges in ccw order are of the form

    ( 1), 0, ( 2), 1,( 0).



  * Cut-graph condition: The graph T_2 formed by the edges of color 2
is a tree spanning all vertices except v_0 and v_1, and rooted at v_2,
 i.e.,  all
edges of T_2 are directed toward v_2. The embedded
subgraph G_2 formed by T_2 plus the two edges (v_0,v_2) and
(v_1,v_2)
plus the special edges (not considered as doubled here) is a cut-graph of ,
which is called the cut-graph of the Schnyder wood.

(Note that the cut-graph condition forces the number of special edges to be 2g.)
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X be a finite subset of {1,2,…}.
  A partition matrix on X is an upper
  triangular matrix over the powerset of X satisfying the
  following properties:
  
  
  (i) each column and row contain at least one non-empty set;
  
  (ii) the non-empty sets partition X;
  
  (iii) (i)<(j)  i<j,  
  
  where (i) denotes the column in which i is a member. Let
  _n be the collection of all partition matrices on [1,n]={1,…,n}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A permutation π∈ S_n has a descent at position i if π(i) > π(i+1), where i = 1, …, n-1, and the descent set of π, denoted Des(π) is the set of all descents of π. The descent number of π is defined as d(π) := | Des(π) |.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[]
A quasi-order is a pair (Q, ≼) such that Q is a set and
≼ is a transitive reflexive relation on Q.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[]
A set A ⊆ Q is an antichain if x ⊥ y for all x ≠ y
∈ A. A set C ⊆ Q is a chain if x ≼ y or y
≼ x for all x, y ∈ C.

A set I ⊆ Q is an initial interval if y ∈ I whenever y
≼ x for some x ∈ I. The definition of final interval is
symmetric, with x ≼ y for some x ∈ I.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[]
A quasi-order (Q,≼) is linear if Q is a chain.

If ≼ is a quasi-order on Q and ≼_L is a linear quasi-order
on Q, then we say ≼_L is a linear extension of ≼ if
for all x,y ∈ Q, x ≼ y implies x ≼_L y and x ∼_L y
implies x ∼ y.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[]
Let ≼ be a quasi-order on Q. (Q,≼) is wqo if for
every map f: → Q there exist m <_ n such that f(m) ≼ f(n).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[]
An infinite sequence of elements of Q is a function f: A → Q where A
⊆ is infinite.

f is ascending if f(n) ≺ f(m) for all n,m ∈ A with n <_
m. Similarly, f is descending if f(m) ≺ f(n) whenever n,m
∈ A are such that n <_ m.

A well-order is a linear quasi-order with no infinite descending
sequences.

We say that f is a good sequence (with respect to ≼) if
there exist m,n ∈ A such that m <_ n and f(m) ≼ f(n); if this
does not happen we say that f is bad .

sentence:
[]
Let (Q,≼) be a quasi-order:


  * Q is wqo(set) if for every f:ℕ→ Q
    there is an infinite set A such that for all n,m ∈ A, n <_ m
    → f(n) ≼ f(m);

  * Q is wqo(anti) if it has no infinite descending sequences
    and no infinite antichains;

  * Q is wqo(ext) if every linear extension of ≼ is a
    well-order.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[]
If ≼_1 and ≼_2 are quasi-orders on Q_1 and Q_2 we may
assume that Q_1 ∩ Q_2 = ∅ (or replace each Q_i by its
isomorphic copy on Q_i ×{i}). We can define the sum
quasi-order and the disjoint union quasi-order on Q_1 ∪ Q_2
(denoted by Q_1 + Q_2 and by Q_1  Q_2 respectively) by

    x ≼_+ y     (x ∈ Q_1  y ∈ Q_2)  (x,y ∈ Q_1  x ≼_1 y)  (x,y ∈ Q_2  x ≼_2 y);
    
        x ≼_ y     (x,y ∈ Q_1  x ≼_1 y)  (x,y ∈ Q_2  x ≼_2 y).

The product quasi-order on Q_1 × Q_2 is defined by

    (x_1,x_2) ≼_× (y_1,y_2)  x_1 ≼_1 y_1  x_2 ≼_2 y_2.

Moreover if ≼_1 and ≼_2 are quasi-orders on the same set Q
then the intersection quasi-order on Q is defined by

    x ≼_∩ y  x ≼_1 y  x ≼_2 y.

sentence:
[]
A set B ⊆ is a block if:


  * (B) is infinite;

  * ∀ X ∈(B) ∃ s ∈ B  s  X;

  * ∀ s,t ∈ B  s t.

B is a barrier if it satisfies (1), (2) and


  * ∀ s,t ∈ B  s ⊄t.

sentence:
[]
Let (Q, ≼) be a quasi-order, B be a block and f: B → Q. We
say that f is good (with respect to ≼) if there exist s,t
∈ B such that s  t and f(s) ≼ f(t). If f is not good then
we say that it is bad . f is perfect if for every s,t ∈ B
such that s  t we have f(s) ≼ f(t).

sentence:
[]
Let (Q, ≼) be a quasi-order.

  
  * Q is bqo if for every barrier B every f: B → Q is
      good with respect to ≼;
  
  * Q is bqo(block) if for every block B every f: B → Q
      is good with respect to ≼.

sentence:
A quasi-order (Q, ≼) is bqo(set) if for every barrier B
and every f: B → Q there exists a subbarrier B' ⊆ B such that
f restricted to B' is perfect with respect to ≼.

sentence:
[]
Let (Q,≼) be a quasi-order. A transitive binary relation <' on
Q is compatible with ≼ if for every x,y ∈ Q we have that
x <' y implies x ≼ y. We write x ≤' y for x <' y  x = y.
In this situation, if A, A' ∈, f: A → Q, and f': A' → Q we
write f ≤' f' if A ⊆ A' and ∀ n ∈ A  f(n) ≤'
f'(n); we write f <' f' if f ≤' f' and ∃ n ∈ A  f(n) <'
f'(n). f is minimal bad with respect to <' if it is bad with
respect to ≼ and there is no f' <' f which is bad with respect to
≼.

sentence:
[]
Let (Q,≼) be a quasi-order and <' be compatible with ≼ in
the sense of definition <ref>. If B and B' are barriers, f: B
→ Q, and f': B' → Q we write f ≤' f' if (B) ⊆ (B'), and for every s ∈ B there exists s' ∈ B' such that s'
 s and f(s) ≤' f'(s'). We write f <' f' if f ≤' f' and
for some s ∈ B, s' ∈ B' with s'  s we have f(s) <' f'(s').
f is minimal bad with respect to <' if it is bad with respect to
≼ and there is no f' <' f which is bad with respect to ≼.

sentence:
[]
Let (Q,≼) be a quasi-order. I ⊆ Q is an ideal if

  
  * ∀ x,y ∈ Q (x ∈ I  y ≼ x → y ∈
      I);
  
  * ∀ x,y ∈ I ∃ z ∈ I (x ≼ z  y ≼
      z).

sentence:
[]
If ≼ is a quasi-order on X, a sequence (X_n)_n ∈ of
elements of X is good (with respect to ≼) if there
exist m <_ n such that X_m ≼ X_n. If every such sequence is good
we say that ≼ is wqo .

Analogously, a sequence (X_s)_s ∈ B of elements of X indexed by
a barrier B is good (with respect to ≼) if there exist s,t
∈ B such that s  t and X_s ≼ X_t. If every such sequence is
good we say that ≼ is bqo .

sentence: A rotor configuration on D is a function ϱ that assigns to each non-sink vertex v an out-edge with tail v. We call ϱ(v) the rotor at v.

sentence: A chip-and-rotor configuration is a pair (w,ϱ), where ϱ is a rotor configuration, and w∈ V(D). We imagine that a chip is placed on vertex w.

sentence: We call a chip-and-rotor configuration (w,ϱ) recurrent , if starting from (w, ϱ), the rotor-router process eventually leads back to (w, ϱ), and we call it transient otherwise.

We call a labeled bipartite graph G=(V,U,E) without parallel edges and loops an F-fixed realisation of integer sequence S=(a_1,…,a_n),(b_1,…,b_n' ) with a_i,b_i>0 for set F:= F_E ∪ F_N if and only if

A full rook placement is a pair (R,F) where F is a Ferrers board and R is a subset of squares of F (marked by placing a rook in each one of them) such that each row and each column of F contains exactly one rook.

Let _F denote the set of full rook placements on F.

sentence:
[Theorem 1.10.2 in <cit.>]
    Let (X_n)_n≥ 0 be an irreducible Markov chain (every state can reach any other with nonzero probability in an arbitrary number of steps) on a finite set of states S. Then,
    
    (V_i(n)/n→1/m_i as  n→∞) =1  ∀ i ∈ S.


    Where m_i is the expected number steps to go from state i to itself, and V_i(n) is the number of visits to i before n steps .

sentence:
(<cit.>)
If X is a simplicial complex with a coloring f of V(X) we define the pattern of a face to be the multiset of colors on its vertices. If f is a proper coloring, in the sense that no two vertices connected by an edge receive the same color, we define the pattern complex X/f to be the simplicial complex on the set of colors of f so that a subset P of the colors of f is a face of X/f if and only if there is a face of X with P as its pattern.

sentence:
Let T be an exchange of k intervals satisfying the minimality condition.
Given a subinterval I⊂ J, we define the mapping r_I: I→^+={1,2,3,…} by

    r_I(x)=min{n∈^+  T^n(x)∈ I} ,

the so-called return time to I. The prefix of length r_I(x) of the word
u_x coding the orbit of a point x∈ I
is called the I-itinerary of x and denoted R_I(x). The set of all I-itineraries is
denoted by It_I={R_I(x)  x∈ I}.
The mapping T_I:I→ I defined by

    T_I(x) = T^r_I(x)(x)

is said to be the first return map of T to I , or induced map of T on I .

sentence:
Let φ and ψ be morphisms over ^* and let w∈^*
be a word such that wφ(a) = ψ(a)w for every letter
a∈. The morphism φ is said to be a left
conjugate of ψ and ψ is said to be a right
conjugate of φ. We write φ⊲ψ. If
φ is a left or right conjugate of ψ, then we say
φ is conjugate to ψ. If the only left
conjugate of φ is φ itself, then φ is called
the leftmost conjugate of ψ and we write
φ=ψ_L. If the only right conjugate of ψ is ψ
itself, then ψ is called the rightmost conjugate of
φ and we write ψ=φ_R.

sentence:
Let u and v be finite or infinite words over the alphabet {0,1}. We say that u is amicable to
  v, and denote it by u∝ v, if there exists a ternary word w over {A,B,C} such that
  u=σ_01(w) and v=σ_10(w).
  In such case, we set w:=ter(u,v) and say that w is the
  ternarization of u and v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O

sentence:
Let φ,ψ:{0,1}^*→{0,1}^* be two morphisms.
  We say that φ is amicable to ψ, and denote it by
  φ∝ψ, if the three following
  relations hold
  
    φ(0)   ∝ψ(0) ,
    φ(1)   ∝ψ(1) ,
    φ(01)   ∝ψ(10) .

  The morphism η:{A,B,C}^*→{A,B,C}^* given by

    η(A)     :=ter(φ(0),ψ(0)) , 
    η(B)     :=ter(φ(01),ψ(10)) , 
    η(C)     :=ter(φ(1),ψ(1)) ,

is called the ternarization of φ and ψ and denoted by
η:=ter(φ,ψ).

sentence:
Let φ be a substitution over an alphabet . We say that φ belongs to the class P if there exists a palindrome
p such that for every a∈ one has φ(a)=pp_a where p_a is a palindrome.
We say that φ is of class P' if it is conjugate to some morphism in class P.

A factor of P with respect to w is a lattice polytope F⊂ satisfying:


  * w(F) = 0;

  * For every integer h, ≤ h<0, there exists a (possibly empty) lattice polytope G_h⊂ at height h such that

    H_w,h∩P⊆ G_h+(-h)F⊆ w_h(P).

Let P⊂ be a polytope with width vector w∈ M, factor F, and polytopes {G_h}. We define the corresponding combinatorial mutation to be the convex lattice polytope

    _w(P,F;{G_h}):=⋃_h=^-1G_h∪⋃_h = 0^(w_h(P) + hF)⊂.

For brevity we will often refer to a combinatorial mutation simply as a mutation .

sentence:
A σ-Bulgarian solitaire is said to be well-behaved if the following three conditions on σ are satisfied:


  * σ(1)=1,

  * σ(h) is a non-decreasing function,

  * σ̅(h):=h-σ(h) is a non-decreasing function.

sentence:
An ordered partition of the ordered set π is a
  decomposition of π into disjoint ordered subsets π_1,…,π_n
  covering π. Such a decomposition is denoted by
  π_1|π_2|…|π_n.

  Given a permutation σ∈ S_n, the rising partition of
    σ of σ is a sequence of integer sequences, each of
  which is a maximal monotonically increasing subsequence of the
  σ(1),…,σ(n) and the concatenation of all sequences
  form the sequence σ(1),…,σ(n).

  Analogously, we define the falling partition of σ of a
  permutation.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
Let π=π_1|π_2|…|π_k be a partition.  A proper
  subset M of some part π_j in π with j<k is
  admissible with respect to a partition
  μ=μ_1|μ_2|…|μ_r if min
  M>maxπ_j+1 and, supposing that min M occurs in μ_k,
  then π_j+1∩⋃_t=k^r μ_r=∅.

  An M-shift of a partition π with respect to a partition
  μ, with M an admissible subset of π_j with respect to
  μ, is the operation that returns the new partition
  π_1|…|π_j∖ M|π_j+1∪ M|…|π_k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let R be a random geometric graph with parameters N and r, and let Mπ N r^2.
Let W= W(N)  Mr log N, and assume that W^-1 is an integer. Partition the unit square S into W^-1 horizontal 
rectangles of size
W × 1
(the horizontal slabs ),
and also into
W^-1 vertical 
rectangles of size
1× W
(the vertical slabs ).
For a horizontal slab L, a left-to-right crossing is a path 
v_0v_1 … v_k
contained in L
such that 
v_0 has distance ≤ r/5
to the left side of L,
v_k has distance ≤ r/5
to the right side of L,
and the distance between v_i and v_i+1
is ≤ r/2 for each 0≤ i≤ k-1.
A top-to-bottom crossing
is defined similarly for vertical slabs.
It is easy to see that if R has a left-to-right crossing
for each of the 
W^-1 horizontal slabs,
and has a top-to-bottom crossing for each of the
W^-1 vertical slabs,
then the vertices of these crossings
are contained in the same connected component,
which is called a spanning component .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[Spanning component]

Let R be a random geometric graph with parameters N and r, and let Mπ N r^2.
Let W= W(N)  Mr log N, and assume that W^-1 is an integer. Partition the unit square S into W^-1 horizontal 
rectangles of size
W × 1
(the horizontal slabs ),
and also into
W^-1 vertical 
rectangles of size
1× W
(the vertical slabs ).
For a horizontal slab L, a left-to-right crossing is a path 
v_0v_1 … v_k
contained in L
such that 
v_0 has distance ≤ r/5
to the left side of L,
v_k has distance ≤ r/5
to the right side of L,
and the distance between v_i and v_i+1
is ≤ r/2 for each 0≤ i≤ k-1.
A top-to-bottom crossing
is defined similarly for vertical slabs.
It is easy to see that if R has a left-to-right crossing
for each of the 
W^-1 horizontal slabs,
and has a top-to-bottom crossing for each of the
W^-1 vertical slabs,
then the vertices of these crossings
are contained in the same connected component,
which is called a spanning component .

plain_text_term: horizontal slabs;vertical slabs;left-to-right crossing;top-to-bottom crossing;spanning component

sentence:
Let Γ and η be the constants in Theorem <ref>.
We say that a random geometric graph R=RGG(N,r) is nice if


  (i)
R has a spanning component, and

  (ii)
for any two vertices u,v of R
that are connected by a path
and have
d_E(u,v) ≥Γlog N / (rN),
we have
d_R(u,v) ≤η d_E(u,v) /  r.

sentence:
Let τ=τ(n)=n^β and  L=L(n)=n^-η, where 
 η, β∈ (0,1) and
 

    η m <β (1-pA_1).

Say an edge is long if the distance between its endpoints is larger than L, and is short otherwise.
A vertex/edge is old if it was born during one of the rounds 1,2,…,τ, and is new otherwise.

sentence:
The reduced graph G_R=G_R(X,Y') of G(X,Y)  has color classes X and Y'={y'_1,… ,y'_d_k} and x_i is adjacent to the vertices y'_1,… ,y'_d_i, i=1,… ,k. 

We say that G is reduced if G=G_R.

sentence: A bipartite multigraph H with degree sequence d_X=(d_1≤⋯≤ d_k) on the color class X has a sequential coloring for X if there is a proper edge coloring of H such that the edges incident with vertex x_i receive colors {1,… ,d_i} for each i.

sentence:
Let ℒ={E}, a language with one r-ary relation symbol E. Let T be an ℒ-theory that consists of a single sentence of the form 
    ∀ x_1 ⋯ x_r E(x_1,…,x_r) ⋀_i ≠ j x_i ≠ x_j ⋀_π∈ J_T E(x_π(1),…,x_π(r))
 for some subgroup of the group of permutations on r elements, J_T ⊆ S_r. Call such a theory a generalized directed hypergraph theory and any finite model of T is a generalized directed hypergraph (GDH) .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O
plain_text_term: generalized directed hypergraph theory;generalized directed hypergraph (GDH)

sentence: For any GDH G, an edge of G will always refer to an equivalence class of [E_G]_∼.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a GDH G on n elements, denote the number of edges of G by e_T(G) and let the edge density of G be defined as 
    d_T(G) := e_T(G)/r!/m_Tn  r.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given two GDHs G and H and a function ψ: V_H → V_G, we say that ψ is a homomorphism if for all (a_1,…,a_r) ∈ E_H, (ψ(a_1),…,ψ(a_r)) ∈ E_G.

We say that G contains a copy of H if there exists some injective homomorphism, ψ:V_H → V_G. Otherwise, we say that G is H-free. Similarly, we would say that a GDH G is ℱ-free for some family ℱ of GDHs if G is F-free for all F ∈ℱ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a family of GDHs ℱ and a positive integer n, let the nth extremal number , ex_T(n,ℱ), be defined as the maximum number of edges over all ℱ-free GDHs on n elements, 
    ex_T(n,ℱ) := max_ℱ-free  G_n{e_T(G_n) }.
 The Turán density of ℱ is defined as 
    π_T(ℱ) := lim_n →∞ex_T(n,ℱ)/r!/m_Tn  r.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a GDH with V_G = {x_1,…,x_n}, and let t = (t_1,…, t_n) be a tuple of positive integers. Define the t-blowup of G to be the ℒ-structure G(t) where 
    V_G(t) = {x_11,…,x_1t_1,…,x_n1,…,x_nt_n}
 and 
    (x_i_1j_1,…,x_i_rj_r) ∈ E_G(t) (x_i_1,…,x_i_r) ∈ E_G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a GDH on n vertices. For each r-set R ∈V_G  r, let e_R be the number of edges of G in R. Then let the edge polynomial be 
    p_G(x) := ∑_R ∈V_G  r e_R∏_i ∈ R x_i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a GDH on n vertices. Let 
    S^n = {(x_1,…,x_n)|x_i ≥ 0 ∑_i=1^nx_i = 1},
 the standard (n-1)-dimensional simplex. Define the blowup density of G as 
    b_T(G) = m_T max_x ∈ S^n{p_G(x)}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let T' and T be GDH theories such that J_T'⊆ J_T⊆ S_r. For a T-graph F and a T'-graph F' we say that F contains F' if V_F = V_F' and every edge of F' is contained in some edge of F (where the edges are considered under their equivalence class definition as subsets of E_F and E_F'). We say that F is the minimum T-container of F' if F has no edges that do not contain edges of F'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let T be a GDH theory, then α∈ [0,1) is a jump for T if there exists a c >0 such that for any ϵ > 0 and any positive integer l, there exists a positive integer n_0(α, ϵ, l) such that any GDH G on n ≥ n_0 elements that has at least (α + ϵ) r!/m_Tn  r edges contains a subGDH on l elements with at least (α + c) r!/m_Tl  r edges.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let α∈ [0,1). Call α a demonstrated nonjump for a GDH theory T if there exists an infinite sequence of GDHs, {G_n}, such that b_T(G_n) > α for each G_n in the sequence and for any positive integer l there exists a positive integer n_0 such that whenever n ≥ n_0 then any subGDH H ⊆ G_n on l or fewer vertices has blowup density b_T(H) ≤α.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let d≥ 2.  A graph H is called d-heavy if the indiscrete cellule (H) has maximum dimension (not necessarily uniquely) among all cellules of (H).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let  be a simple graph, let v ∈, and let e={ u,v}∈. 
The open star of v , denoted (v), is the union of {v } and the set { f ∈| f  v }.  Similarly, the open edge-star of e , denoted (e) or ({u,v}), is the union of the sets  { u }, { v }, and  { f ∈| f  u,v }.

Given two open stars (v_1) and (v_2), a star isomorphism is a bijection φ: (v_1) →(v_2) such that φ(v_1)=v_2. 

Given two open edge-stars ({u_1,v_1}) and ({u_2,v_2}), an edge-star isomorphism  is a bijection φ: ({u_1,v_1}) →({u_2,v_2}) such that


  (i) φ(∩({u_1,v_1}))=∩({u_2,v_2}), that is, the vertices u_1,v_1 are mapped (in some order) to the vertices u_2,v_2.

  (ii) φ is incidence-preserving, that is, f ∈∩({u_1,v_1}) is incident to u_1 if and only if φ(f) is incident to φ(u_1) and 
f ∈∩({u_1,v_1}) is incident to v_1 if and only if φ(f) is incident to φ(v_1). In particular, φ({ u_1,v_1 }) = { u_2,v_2 }.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: open star of v;open edge-star of e

sentence:
Let  be a simple graph, and let G ≤(). Then  is called 


  (i)  G-star-transitive if for all v_1,v_2∈ and for all star isomorphisms φ: (v_1) →(v_2), there exists an automorphism ψ∈ G
such that ψ(v_1)=φ(v_1) and for all f ∈∩(v_1) we have ψ(f)=φ(f); and 

  (ii)  G-st(edge)-transitive if for all {u_1,v_1}, {u_2,v_2}∈ and edge-star isomorphisms  φ: ({u_1,v_1}) →({u_2,v_2}),
there exists an automorphism ψ∈ G
such that ψ(u_1)=φ(u_1),  ψ(v_1)=φ(v_1), and for all f ∈∩({u_1,v_1}) we have ψ(f)=φ(f).

If G =() then we simply say that  is star-transitive or st(edge)-transitive, respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let R = (T,r,u) and R' = (T',r',u') be rooted grounded tree-like  polycubes such that u' is a free direction of R. The graft union of R and R', whenever it exists, is the rooted grounded tree-like  polycube

    R  R' = (_3[V ∪τ(V')],r,u),

where V, V' are the sets of vertices of T, T' respectively and τ is the translation with respect to the vector r'r - u'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let T = (V,E) be a tree-like  polycube and r,r' two adjacent vertices of T. Let V_r and V_r' be the set of vertices of T defined by

  
  * r ∈ V_r, r' ∈ V_r',
  
  * the subgraphs of T induced by V_r and V_r' are precisely the two connected components obtained from T by removing the edge {r,r'}.


Then the rooted tree-like  polycube B = (T[V_r ∪{r'}], r, rr') is called a branch of T and the rooted tree-like  polycube B^c = (T[V_r'∪{r}], r', r'r) is called the co-branch of B in T. When neither r nor r' are leaves of T, then we say that B and B^c are proper branches of T.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Graft union]
Let R = (T,r,u) and R' = (T',r',u') be rooted grounded tree-like  polycubes such that u' is a free direction of R. The graft union of R and R', whenever it exists, is the rooted grounded tree-like  polycube

    R  R' = (_3[V ∪τ(V')],r,u),

where V, V' are the sets of vertices of T, T' respectively and τ is the translation with respect to the vector r'r - u'.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Branch]
Let T = (V,E) be a tree-like  polycube and r,r' two adjacent vertices of T. Let V_r and V_r' be the set of vertices of T defined by

  
  * r ∈ V_r, r' ∈ V_r',
  
  * the subgraphs of T induced by V_r and V_r' are precisely the two connected components obtained from T by removing the edge {r,r'}.


Then the rooted tree-like  polycube B = (T[V_r ∪{r'}], r, rr') is called a branch of T and the rooted tree-like  polycube B^c = (T[V_r'∪{r}], r', r'r) is called the co-branch of B in T. When neither r nor r' are leaves of T, then we say that B and B^c are proper branches of T.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence: Let R, R' be two rooted tree-like  polycubes having the same direction. We say that R is substitutable by R' if, for any tree-like  polycube T containing the branch  R, R^c  R' is well-defined.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let R be a rooted tree-like polycube. We say that R is abundant if one of the following two conditions is satisfied:

  
  * R contains exactly two cells,
  
  * There does not exist another abundant rooted tree-like polycube R', such that R is substitutable by R', n(R') < n(R) and

    n_1(R) - n_1(R') ≤Δℓ_(n(R) - n(R'))


Otherwise, we say that R is sparse .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[Saturated tree-like polyforms and polycubes]
A fully leafed tree-like polyform or polycube T is called saturated when n_1(T) ≥L(n(T)).
We denote by SAT_i(n) the set of saturated tree-like polyforms of size n up to an isometry of the corresponding lattice.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[4-cross and 4-tree polycubes]
A tree-like polycube of 5 coplanar cells with exactly one inner cell of degree 4 is called a 4-cross .
Moreover, for any integer k≥ 0, a tree-like polycube is called a 4-tree when it is the graft union of k 4-crosses.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let N be a k-nilpotent group, T be a subgroup of N and M be the left coset space of T in N. The factor map g:N→ M is defined by g(t)=tN. A map ϕ from a group A to M is called a degree k nil-morphism if there is a group B, surjective homomorphism f:B→ A and polynomial map ϕ':B→ N of degree (at most) k such that the next diagram is commutative.


    
        B [r]^ϕ' [d]_f     N [d]^g 

        A [r]_ϕ           M 

Let N=N_0⊃ N_1⊃…⊃ N_k={1} be the upper central series of N. In most applications we will also assume that ϕ':B→ N/N_i is a polynomial of degree i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let A be an abelian group with a shift invariant probability measure μ. Let F={f_S | S⊆ [k]} be a collection of 2^k functions in L_∞(A,μ). We define the k-th order convolution _k(F) as the k variable function

    _k(F)(t_1,t_2,…,t_k)=∫_x ∏_S⊆ [k]f_S(x+∑_i∈ St_i).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The group G(M) is a topological space with respect to the weakest topology in which the functions f^σ-f_2 are all continuous for every f∈ M.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The topology on W_0 is given by the week operator topology on Ξ(W_0).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence: The image of the co-homology class describing the extension of N under the map α^* will be called the the interpretation of the nil-pattern under the homomorphism T→ T_2. By abusing the notation we denote the interpretation of N under the map α by α^*(N). As we will see later α induces a map from C(α^*(N)) to C(N) so its acts in the reverse way between the cores.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that a nil-pattern N_2 belongs to the class of N if it is an interpretation on N over some homomorphism.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A suitable word is called initial if every vertex labeled as 2 is placed between two 0's and every vertex labeled as 1 is preceded or followed (but not both) by 0
and it is called final if it has no vertex labeled as 3.

The initial vector X^1 is a column vector of size k such that for every suitable word p∈{1,2,… , k}, the p^th entry of the vector is

    X^1(p)=
    {[     number of zeros of word p                             …     if  p  is an initial word;                             ∞                             … if  p  is not an initial word ].
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that word p can follow word q if they satisfy all the properties described above.

The transition matrix is the square matrix A of size k such that, for every pair p, q∈{1,2,… , k}, the entry A_pq in row p and column q is defined as follows:

    A_pq=
    {[         number of zeros of word p                                 …     if word  p  can follow word q;                                  ;                                 ∞                                 … if word  p  can not follow word q ].
word_labels: O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: word p can follow word q;transition matrix

sentence: Let G be a graph. Let P be a (u,v)-path of length l in G. We say that P is geodesic with respect to G if all (u,v)-paths in G have length at least l.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a graph, and let H ⊆ G. We say that H is geodesically closed with respect to G if for any u,v ∈ V(H), every geodesic (u,v)-path in G is a subgraph of H.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that a cyclic order of integers in the form (a, a+1, …, a+m-1, a+m, a+m-1, …, a+1) is called a sawtooth order .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let G be an infinite graph. We say that G has polynomial growth if there exists a polynomial f such that for any vertex v ∈ G, the number of vertices at distance exactly d from v is at most f(d).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let S be a scattered 𝔽_q-linear set of (2k-1,q^n) of rank kn, where n, k≥ 2. We say that S is of pseudoregulus type if

    
  * there exist m=q^nk-1/q^n-1 pairwise disjoint lines of (2k-1, q^n), say s_1, s_2, … , s_m, such that
    
    |  S∩  s_i|=q^n-1/q-1  ∀ i=1,…,m,

    
  * there exist exactly two (k-1)-dimensional subspaces T_1 and T_2 of (2k-1,q^n) disjoint from S such that T_j∩ s_i ≠∅ for each i = 1,…, m and j = 1, 2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: A 0-point in H_∞ is a point P∉ D such that P is contained in at least one (q-1)-secant to D.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An arc  in (S,M) is a curve in S such that 


  (a) the endpoints are in M,

  (b)  does not cross itself,

  (c) the relative interior of  is disjoint from M and
  from the boundary of S,

  (d)  does not cut out a monogon or a digon.

sentence:
A step set ⊂^2 is a finite set of vectors 

    { (x_1,y_1), (x_2,y_2), …, (x_m,y_m)}.

An n-step lattice path or walk is a sequence of vectors v = (v_1,v_2,…,v_n), such that v_j is in . 
Geometrically, it may be interpreted as 
a sequence of points =(0,1,…,n), where i∈^2, 0 = (0,0) (or another starting point),
and i-i-1 = v_i for i=1,2,…,n.
The elements of  are called steps . 
The length || of a lattice path is its number n of steps.

sentence:
A permutation p∈_ℓ is called a Baxter permutation ,
  if there is no four-tuple of indices a<b<c<d∈ [ℓ] such that
  
  
  * c=b+1, and
  
  * the subpermutation p_a,p_b,p_c,p_d is order-isomorphic to 2413 or to 3142.
  
  In the terminology of Babson and Steingrímsson <cit.>,
  Baxter permutations are exactly the permutations avoiding simultaneously the 
  two patterns 2-41-3 and 3-14-2.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: By a reflection faithful representation  of (W,𝒮) we mean a faithful, finite dimensional representation V of W such that for each w∈ W, the subspace V^w is an hyperplane of V if and only if w∈𝒯.

sentence: Let n and k be positive integers such that  2 ≤ 2k <n. Then the generalised Petersen graph P_n,k is defined to have the vertex set V(P_n,k) = {u_i, v_i | i∈[n]}, and edge set [4] E(P_n,k) = {u_iu_i+1, v_iv_i+k,u_iv_i | i∈[n]}, where [n]={0,1,...,n-1} and the subscripts are read modulo n.

sentence:
For A,B∈,
	
		
  (i) We say that A is closed or strong in B and in notations we write B, if  A⊆ B and for any C⊆ B with A⊊ C we have that δ(C)>δ(A).
		
  (ii)  We say that A is weakly closed or weakly strong in B and in notations we write A≤ B, if  A⊆ B and for any C⊆ B with A⊆ C we have that δ(C)≥δ(A).
		
  (iii) For M∈ and A⊆_ω M we say that A is closed in M, denoted by A≤^*M, if for any B⊆_ω M with A⊆ B we have that A≤^*B. We may define A≤ M in a similar way.
		
  (iv) If A,B⊆ D∈, then the relative predimension of B over A in D is defined as δ(B/A):=δ(AB)-δ(A).

sentence:
For A,B∈,


  (i) (A,B) is called a minimal pair , denoted by B, if  A⊆ B and A is closed in any proper substructure of B containing A but is not closed in B. If δ(B/A)=0, we call (A,B) a 0-minimal pair.

  (ii) B is called an intrinsic extension of A, denoted by B, if A⊆ B and no proper substructure of B that contains A is closed in B. If δ(B/A)=0, we call B a 0-intrinsic extension of A.

  (iii) For N⊆ M∈ the closure of N in M is defined as the following

    ^*_M(N)=⋃{E M|E for some  A N}.


The corresponding notations for weak closedness (<Ref>) are denoted respectively by A≰_minB, A≤_B and _M(N).

sentence:
Suppose that A, B⊆_ωM∈. 


  (i) The dimension of A in M is defined as 

    _M(A):=inf{δ(C)|A⊆ C⊆_ω M}.


  (ii) The relative dimension of B over A (with respect to M) is defined as

    _M(B/A):=_M(AB)-_M(A).


  (iii) If N is an arbitrary substructure of M, then the relative dimension of A over N is defined as the following

    _M(A/N):=inf{_M(A/B)|B⊆_ω N}.

sentence:
Suppose that M_0, M_1, M_2∈ with M_1∩ M_2 = M_0. The structure M is called the free join or free amalgam of M_1 and M_2 over M_0, denoted by M_1M_0M_2, if the universe of M is M_1∪ M_2 and the following holds 

    R^M = R^M_1∪ R^M_2.

sentence:
Suppose that G is a graph and A is a subset of G.
 
 
  (i) We say that two elements b_1, b_2∈ G are  connected over A if they are connected by a path disjoint from A.
 
  (ii) If a∈ G, the component of a over A in G, denoted by C_G(a/A), is the set of all b∈ G\ A connected with a over A.

sentence:
Suppose that b̅ is a finite tuple and A and C are subsets of 𝕄_α.
   
   
  (i)  We say that b̅ is d-independent of A over C and, in notations, we write []b̅CA, if the following hold
   
   
  (a)  (b̅/C)=(b̅/AC)
   
  (b) (b̅C)∩(AC)=(C).
   
   		
   
  (ii) We say that B is d-independent of A over C, in notations []BCA, if every finite subset of B is d-independent of A over C.

sentence: Let A be a binary (n× n')-matrix in Ω_k for fixed row and column sums k. Let R be the set of all permutations ρ: (1, …, n) → (1, …, n) such that the row sums ∑_j=1^n' A_ρ(i)j = r_i for all i and let S be the set of all permutations σ: {1, …, n'} → {1, …, n'} such that the column sums ∑_i=1^n A_iσ(j) = c_j. We define a preprocessing step which randomly selects a ρ∈ R and σ∈ S to form the matrix B_ij = A_ρ(i)σ(j). This preprocessing step can be implemented by choosing a random order for sets of rows with equal row sum and a random order for sets of columns with equal column sum in O(n+n') <cit.>.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let G be a (directed) graph with n nodes and adjacency matrix A. Let P be a partition of the nodes with equal degree (equal in- and out-degree in case of directed graphs). Let R be the set of all permutations ρ: {1, …, n} → {1, …, n} which respect the partition P, i.e. nodes are permuted within each partition separately. We define the following preprocessing step: randomly select a permutation ρ∈ R and apply it to the nodes of G, then return the resulting adjacency matrix.

sentence:
The writhe of a graph G with n vertices and ℓ looped vertices
is w(G)=n-2ℓ.

sentence:
If G is a graph and v∈ V(G) then the local complement
G^v is the graph obtained from G by toggling edges involving only
neighbors of v. That is, if w≠ v is adjacent to v then w is looped
in G^v if and only if it is not looped in G; and if v≠ x≠ y≠
v and x, y are both neighbors of v then x, y are adjacent in
G^v if and only if they are not adjacent in G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a doubly marked graph with two adjacent vertices
v≠ w. Then the graph ((G_cru^v)_cru^w)_cru^v is the
marked pivot of G with respect to v and w, denoted G_cru
^vw.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A marked-graph Reidemeister move on a marked graph
G is performed by first applying marked local complementations, then
applying one of the marked-graph Reidemeister moves defined above, and then
applying marked local complementations.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G be a graph with V(G)={v_1, ..., v_n}.
The Boolean adjacency matrix of G is the n× n matrix
𝒜(G) with entries in GF(2) defined by: if i≠ j then
𝒜(G)_ij=1 if and only if v_i is adjacent to v_j, and
𝒜(G)_ii=1 if and only if v_i is looped.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The marked-graph bracket polynomial of a marked graph
G with ϕ free loops and V(G)={v_1, ..., v_n} is

    G]=d^ϕ·∑_T⊆ V(G)A^n-| T|B^| T|d^ν(𝒜(G)_T),

where ν(𝒜(G)_T) is the GF(2)-nullity of 𝒜(G)_T.

sentence:
The reduced marked-graph bracket polynomial ⟨
G⟩ is the image of the three-variable marked-graph bracket under
the evaluations B↦ A^-1 and d↦-A^-2-A^2.

sentence:
<cit.> A labeled graph G is a simple graph each of whose vertices
is labeled by a pair (a, α)∈{0, 1}×{+, -}.
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.> A graph-link is an equivalence class of labeled graphs under
the equivalence relation generated by the following operations.

Ω_g1. Adjoin or remove an isolated vertex with label (0, ±).

Ω_g2. Adjoin or remove a pair of non-adjacent (resp. adjacent)
vertices that are labeled (0, ±α) (resp. (1, ±α)) and
have the same adjacencies with other vertices.

Ω_g3. Suppose G has three distinct vertices v, w, x labeled
(0, -), such that the only neighbors of x are v and w, which are not
neighbors of each other. Then change the labels of v and w to (0, +),
make x adjacent to every vertex that is adjacent to precisely one of v,
w, and remove the edges connecting x to v and w. (The inverse of this
operation is also an Ω_g3 move.)

Ω_g4. Suppose G has two adjacent vertices v and w labeled (0, α) and (0, β). Replace G with ((G^v)^w)^v and then
change the labels of v and w to (0, -β) and (0, -α)
respectively. (The inverse is also an Ω_g4 move.)

Ω_g4^'. Suppose G has a vertex v with label (1,
α). Replace G with G^v, change the label of v to (1,
-α), and change the label of each neighbor of v by changing the first
coordinate and leaving the second coordinate the same. (The inverse is also an
Ω_g4^' move.)
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let F and H be doubly marked, weighted graphs whose
intersection consists of a single unlooped, unmarked vertex a with weights
α(a)=A and β(a)=B. The composition G=F∗ H is
constructed as follows.

(a) The elements of V(G)=(V(F)∪ V(H))-{a} inherit their loops, marks
and weights from F and H.

(b) E(G)=E(F-a)∪ E(H-a)∪{{v,w}|{v,a}∈ E(F) and {a,w}∈
E(H)}.

(c) The number of free loops of G is ϕ(G)=ϕ(F)+ϕ(H).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a k-uniform hypergraph H=(V,E) and a labeling ϕ of V by ℕ, an infinite increasing path in H is an infinite path with vertex set {v_j: j≥ 1} and edges e_0,…, e_i, …, where 


  (1) each e_i={v_(k-1)i+1, v_(k-1)i+2, …, v_(k-1)i+k} for i≥ 0,

  (2) all v_j-s are distinct, and

  (3) ϕ(v_j)< ϕ(v_j+1) for j≥ 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(1) The infinite (k-1)-branching tree is the unique k-uniform hypergraph so that each pair of vertices is connected by a unique path and so that all vertices have degree 2, except the root vertex, which has degree 1. See figure <ref>.

  (2) In a rooted infinite (k-1)-branching tree, t(v) will denote the number of edges on the path from vertex v to the root.

  (3) Given a k-uniform hypergraph H=(V,E) and a labeling ϕ of V by ℕ, an infinite increasing (k-1)- branching tree in H is an infinite (k-1)-branching tree so that for any x,y∈ V with t(x) < t(y), ϕ(x) < ϕ(y).
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: infinite (k-1)-branching tree is the unique k-uniform;infinite increasing (k-1)- branching

sentence: Given a k-uniform hypergraph H=(V,E) and a labeling ϕ of E by ℕ, an infinite increasing path in H is an infinite  path e_1, …, e_i, … such that {ϕ(e_i)}_i=1^∞ is increasing.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(1) In a rooted infinite (k-1)-branching tree, let t(e) be the number of edges on the path from edge e to the root.  E.g. t(e)=1 for the edge e that contains the root.

  (2) Given a labeling ϕ of E by ℕ, an infinite increasing (k-1)-branching tree in H is an infinite (k-1)-branching tree so that for any e_1, e_2 ∈ E with t(e_1) < t(e_2), ϕ(e_1) < ϕ(e_2).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: We say that a countable graph G has a property FIN if for any labeling of vertices of G with ℕ and any k∈ℕ there exists an increasing path of length k, but there exists of labeling of G with no infinite increasing path.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a countable graph G=(V,E) and a labeling ϕ of V by ℤ, an infinite increasing two-sided path in G is an infinite path {v_i: -∞ < i < ∞}, with ϕ(v_i) < ϕ(v_i+1) for all i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Given a directed graph D=(V,E) and a labeling ϕ of V by ℤ, we say D contains an infinite two-sided directed path if there exists an infinite directed path {v_i}_-∞^∞ in D with ϕ(v_i) < ϕ(v_i+1) for all i.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let G=(V,E) be a k-uniform hypergraph. For a labeling ϕ of V by ℕ we say that infinite path e_0, …, e_i,… is skip-increasing if there exist vertices v_0, v_1, v_2, … so that for every i≥ 0, ϕ(v_i) < ϕ(v_i+1) and  {v_i, v_i+1}⊂ e_i.


Let ℓ≤ k and G=(V,E) be a k-uniform hypergraph. For a labeling ϕ of V with ℕ we say that infinite path e_0, …, e_i,…, such that e_i={v_i(k-1)+1, … ,v_i(k-1)+k} is (k-ℓ)-skip increasing in ϕ if for each e_i there is a subsequence u_1, … u_ℓ of a sequence v_i(k-1)+1, … ,v_i(k-1)+k with u_1=v_i(k-1), u_ℓ=v_i(k-1)+k such that ϕ(u_1) < ϕ(u_2)<⋯<ϕ(u_ℓ).

sentence:

Let (W,S) be a Coxeter group. Then for any u ≤ v in W,
the order complex Δ(u,v) of the 
interval (u,v) is PL-homeomorphic to a sphere 𝕊^ℓ(u,v)-2.
In particular, the Bruhat order is thin , that is,
every rank 2 interval is a diamond .  In other words,
whenever u ≤ v with ℓ(v)-ℓ(u)=2, 
there are precisely two elements
z_(1), z_(2) such that u < z_(i) < v.

hull of the n! points obtained by permuting the coordinates
of the vector (1,2,…,n).

sentence:
Let u,v ∈ S_n such that u ≤ v in (strong) Bruhat
order.  We identify each permutation z∈ S_n with
the corresponding vector (z(1),…, z(n)) ∈^n.
Then the Bruhat interval polytope
𝖰_u,v is defined as the convex hull of all
vectors (z(1),…,z(n)) for z such that u ≤ z ≤ v.

    v_i > v_k,    u_i < u_k.
