sentence:
A pattern of length n is an equivalence class of sequences x_1 x_2 ⋯ x_n of distinct integers. Two such sequences x_1 x_2 ⋯ x_n, y_1 y_2 ⋯ y_n are in the same equivalence class (“have the same pattern”) if 

    x_i > x_j  y_i > y_j  for all i, j such that  1≤ i,j ≤ n.

 Denote by _n the set of patterns of length n.

sentence: Let P be a graded poset. A matching M of the Hasse diagram of P is a special matching if for all x , y ∈ P such that x ⋖ y, we have M(x) = y or M(x) ≤ M(y).

sentence:
The Gelfand-Serganova stratification 
(or thin cell stratification ) of G/P is the simultaneous
refinement of all the Schubert cell decompositions described above.
The (nonempty) strata in this decomposition are called Gelfand-Serganova
strata or thin cells .
In other words,  we choose for each Borel 
subgroup C a Schubert cell associated with C.  The intersection
of all chosen cells, if it is nonempy, is called a Gelfand-Serganova 
stratum or a thin cell.

sentence:
A combinatorial (v_k) configuration is an incidence structure  = (,,), where ⊆×, ∩ = ∅ and || = || = v. The elements of  are called points , the elements of  are called lines and the relation  is called the incidence relation. Furthermore, each line is incident with k points, each point is incident with k lines and two distinct points are incident with at most one common line, i.e.,

    { (p_1, b_1), (p_2, b_1), (p_1, b_2), (p_2, b_2) }⊆, p_1 ≠ p_2  b_1 = b_2.

sentence:
A configuration  is splittable if there exists an independent set of vertices Σ in the Grünbaum graph
(L())^2 such that L() - Σ, i.e., the graph obtained by removing the set of vertices Σ from the Levi graph L(), is disconnected.
In this case the set Σ is called a splitting set of elements .  A configuration that is not splittable is called unsplittable .

A connected graph G is splittable if there exists an independent set Σ in G^2 such
that G - Σ is disconnected.

sentence:
*The ℓ-insertion procedure.
Let T be an element of _n,ℓ. 
The ℓ-special box of T is defined as


  * the right-most box of the ℓ-th row, if the (ℓ+1)-st row is strictly smaller;

  * the right-most dotted box at the bottom of a column, otherwise.

Given an integer m in {1,…,n}, we associate to it an edge e_m of the South-East border of T
by labeling these edges from South-West to North-East.
Note that we exclude the (vertical) edges e_n+1,…,e_n+ℓ at the right of the first ℓ rows of T.
As in the insertion procedure of <cit.>, if e_m is a horizontal (resp. vertical) edge of the border of T,
we add a row (resp. column) to T below (resp. to the right of) e_m,
composed of empty boxes except for one dotted box: the one below (resp. to the right of) e_m.
Next, if the dotted box added is to the left of the ℓ-special box of T, we add a ribbon
(a connected  set of empty boxes without any 2× 2 square) adjacent simultaneously to the ℓ-special box of T
and to the dotted box added.

where the sum is over all proper colourings κ of G.

sentence:
Let Γ_1,Γ_2 be finite groups.  If there exists a graph G with |V(G)| ≥ 3 and vertex v ∈ V(G) so that
		(G) ≅Γ_1 and (G-v) ≅Γ_2, then Γ_1 ( vertex ) deletes to Γ_2,
		denoted Γ_1→Γ_2.
	Similarly, the group Γ_1 edge deletes to Γ_2 if there exists a graph G and edge e ∈ E(G) so that
		(G) ≅Γ_1 and (G-e) ≅Γ_2.
	If a specific graph G and subobject x give (G) ≅Γ_1 and (G-x) ≅Γ_2, the deletion relation
		may be presented as Γ_1 G-x⟶Γ_2.

A sequence i∈𝒫^'(α -1) is called a minimal prime sequence realizing (n,k;α) if:


  * i is a minimal element in 𝒫^'(α -1), and

We call  the hypercube product of ^' and ^''.

Let  be a hypercube graph indexed by Q_h.
We say that  is square commutative if it satisfies two conditions:


  * Upward square commutativity: Given indices ,' and ” in Q_h such that →'→”, and vertices v∈ U_, v'∈ U_', and v_1”,…, v_n”∈ U_” such that v→ v'→ v_i” for i=1,…,n, there exist distinct vertices v_1',…,v_n'∈ U_'_c such that v→ v_i'→ v_i” for i=1,…,n.

  * Downward square commutativity: Given indices ,' and ” in Q_h such that →'→”, and vertices v_1,…,v_n∈ U_, v'∈ U_', and v”∈ U_” such that v_i→ v'→ v” for i=1,…,n, there exist distinct vertices v_1',…,v_n'∈ U_'_c such that v_i→ v_i'→ v” for i=1,…,n.

[Channels of directed graphs]
Given a directed graph =(V,E) and two sets of vertices X,Y⊆ V, the channel (X,Y) between X and Y is the subgraph of  induced by the set of vertices that lie on a path from X to Y (including endpoints).

  Let  be a hypercube graph indexed by Q_h.

  * Downward square commutativity: Given indices ,' and ” in Q_h such that →'→”, and vertices v_1,…,v_n∈ U_, v'∈ U_', and v”∈ U_” such that v_i→ v'→ v” for i=1,…,n, there exist distinct vertices v_1',…,v_n'∈ U_'_c such that v_i→ v_i'→ v” for i=1,…,n.

sentence:
A tree decomposition of a graph G=(V,E) is 
    a pair (T,ℬ={B_x}_x∈ V(T)) 
    where T is a tree and for all x∈ V(T), B_x⊆ V which are called bags , 	
    satisfying the following three conditions:


  (T1) V=⋃_x∈ V(T)B_x.

  (T2) For every edge uv of G, there exists a vertex x of T such that u, v∈ B_x.

  (T3) For every vertex v in G, the bags containing v induce a subtree in T.

	The width of a tree decomposition (T,ℬ) is max{B_x-1:x∈ V(T)}. 
	The treewidth of G, denoted by (G), is the minimum width of all tree decompositions of G. 
	A path decomposition of a graph G is a tree decomposition (T,ℬ) where T is a path. 
	The pathwidth of G, denoted by (G), is the minimum width of all path decompositions of G.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Bodlaender and Kloks <cit.>]

The class of trees of cycles is the class of graphs recursively defined as follows.

	
  * Each cycle is a tree of cycles.
	
  * For each tree of cycles G and each cycle C, the graph obtained from G and C by taking the disjoint union and identifying an edge and its end vertices in G with an edge and its end vertices in C, is a tree of cycles.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Bodlaender and de Fluiter <cit.>]

A path of cycles is a tree of cycles G for which the following holds.

	
  * Each chordless cycle of G has at most two edge separators.
	
  * If an edge e ∈ E is contained in m ≥ 3 chordless cycles of G, then at least m - 2 of these cycles are simplicial triangles.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Bodlaender and de Fluiter <cit.>]

Let G be a path of cycles. Let C = (C_1,…,C_p) be a sequence
of chordless cycles such that each chordless cycle in G appears exactly once in the sequence of cycles, and for 1≤ i≤ p-1, C_i shares exactly one edge e_i with C_i+1. 
Let E = (e_1,…,e_p-1) be the corresponding set of
common edges. The pair (C,E) is called a cycle path model for G.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
A chain tree of cycles is a tree of cycles G=(V,E) for which the following holds.


  * If an edge e ∈ E is contained in m ≥ 3 chordless cycles of G, then at least m - 2 of these cycles are simplicial triangles.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A tree of two-boundaried cycles is a tree of cycles G for which the following holds. 


  * Each chordless cycle of G has at most two edge separators.

sentence:
The class of mamba trees is the class of graphs recursively defined as follows.

	
  * Each mamba is a mamba tree.
	
  * For each mamba tree G and each mamba M, the graph obtained from a disjoint union of G and M by identifying a vertex of G with a head vertex of M is a mamba tree.

sentence:
[<cit.>]
An arrow presentation consists of a set of circles, each with a collection of disjoint, labelled arrows on them. Each label appears on
precisely two arrows.

sentence:
Let w∈^n be a weight vector.
  Given a polynomial f∈ K[x], say f=∑_α∈^n c_α· x^α, we define its initial form with respect to w to be
  
    _w(f)=∑_w·α+ν(c_α)  minimalc_α· p^-ν(c_α)· x^α∈𝔎[x].

  Additionally, we define the evaluation of the tropical polynomial of f at w to be the minimum occurring weighted valued degree:
  
    (f)(w):=min{w·α+ν(c_α)| c_α≠ 0 }.

  Given an ideal I K[x], we define its initial ideal with respect to w to be
  
    _w(I)=⟨_w(f)| f∈ I⟩𝔎[x].

  The tropical variety of I is given by
  
    (I) :=    {w∈^n|_w(I)  monomial free}.

  For elements f∈ K[x] and finite subsets F⊆ K[x], we abbreviate (f):=(⟨ f⟩) and (F):=(⟨ F⟩) respectively.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A set of polynomials F={f_1,…,f_n}⊆ K[x] is called a triangular set , if for each i=1,…,n we have
  
    f_i∈ K[x_1,…,x_i]∖ K[x_1,…,x_i-1].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a univariate polynomial f∈ K[x_k], say f=∑_i=0^d c_i x_k^i with c_i∈ K, c_0c_d ≠ 0, the Newton polygon (or extended Newton polyhedron ) is defined to be
  
    Δ(f):= ({(i,ν(c_i))| i=0,…,d}∪{(0,∞)}).

  Similarly, for a multivariate polynomial f∈ K[x_1,…,x_k], say f=∑_i=0^d f_i· x_k^i with f_i∈ K[x_1,…,x_k-1] and a weight w∈^k-1, we define the expected Newton polygon of f at w to be
  
    Δ_w(f):=({(i,(f_i)(w))| i=0,…,d}∪{(0,∞)}).

  And we say f has a unique Newton polygon at w, if for all vertices (i,(f_i)(w)) ∈Δ_w(f) the initial form _w(f_i) is a monomial. We write Λ(f) or Λ_w(f) for the set of all negative slopes of Δ(f) or Δ_w(f) respectively.

plain_text_term: Newton polygon;extended Newton polyhedron;expected Newton polygon;unique Newton polygon

sentence: We say a triangular set F={f_1,…,f_n} admits series of unique Newton polygons , if for all weights w=(w_1,…,w_k-1)∈ K^k-1 with w_i ∈Λ_(w_1,…,w_i-1)(f_i) for i=1,…,k-1 the polynomial f_k has a unique Newton polygon at (w_1,…,w_k-1).

sentence:
Let I K[x] be an ideal. The homogeneity space of I is given by
  
    C_0(I):={w∈^n|_w(I)=I }.

  It can be read off any reduced Gröbner basis and is trivially included in (I), provided (I) is non-empty. We call a point p∈(I) non-trivial , if p∉ C_0(I).

sentence: Given a set of forbidden patterns B and prefix p, then v⃗ is a gap vector for prefix p with respect to B if, for all n, nBpw=∅ for any w such that g⃗(n,w)≥v⃗.  In this case we say that w satisfies the gap vector criterion for v⃗.

sentence:
The set of indices R is reversibly deletable for p with respect to B if the map 

    d_R: nBpw→n-|R|Bd_R(p)d_R(w)

is a bijection for all words w failing the gap vector criterion for every gap vector of p with respect to B (d_R is a bijection for all w such that nBpw≠∅).

sentence:
Let B be a set of vincular patterns.  An enumeration scheme for B is a set E of triples (p, G, R), where p is a permutation (, the prefix pattern), G is a basis of gap vectors for p with respect to B, and R is a reversibly deletable set for p with respect to B.  Furthermore, E must satisfy the following criteria:


 
  * (ϵ, ∅, ∅)∈ E.
 
  * For each (p, G, R) ∈ E,
  
   
  * If R=∅ and 0⃗∉ G, then there exists a triple (p', G', R') ∈ E for each child p' of p.
   
  * If R≠∅, then there exists a triple (p̂, Ĝ, R̂)∈ E for p̂=d_R(p).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let f: ⋃_n≥ 0n→ℤ be a permutation statistic.  For a permutation π  let the R-deletion difference , denoted δ^f_R(π), be f(π) - f(d_R(π)).  

For nonnegative integer m, a permutation statistic f is enumeration-scheme-compatible (or “ES-compatible”) with margin m if for any positive integer t and any R⊆ [t], the R-deletion differences δ^f_R (π) = δ^f_R (π') whenever π and π' are two permutations of length n≥ t+m such that π_1 …π_t+m = π'_1 …π'_t+m.  We denote this constant value Δ^f_R(w,n) where w=π_1 …π_t+m.

sentence: For nonnegative integer c, an enumeration scheme E has clearance c if for each (p, G, R)∈ E, either R = ∅, 0⃗∈ G, or |p| - max R ≥ c.

sentence:
Let ϵ > 0.  Given a graph G and two nonempty disjoint vertex sets A, B ⊂ V, we say that the pair (A, B) is ϵ-regular if for every X ⊂ A and Y ⊂ B satisfying

    |X| > ϵ |A|    and    |Y| > ϵ |B|

we have

    |d(X, Y) - d(A, B)| < ϵ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let ϵ, >̣ 0.  Given a graph G and two nonempty disjoint vertex sets A, B ⊂ V, we say that the pair (A,B) is (ϵ, )̣-super-regular if for every X ⊂ A and Y ⊂ B satisfying

    |X| > ϵ |A|    and    |Y| > ϵ |B|,

we have

    e(X, Y) > |̣X| |Y|,

and furthermore d_B(a) > |̣B| for all a ∈ A and d_A(b) > |̣A| for all b ∈ B.

sentence:
Let A and B be two linearly ordered sets of equal size.
We say that a quasi configuration is obtained from 
  A and B in a crossing way if the first element 
  of A is paired with the last element of B, and so on, 
  until finally the last element of A is paired to the first 
  element of B.

sentence:
Let M={D_1,D_2,… , D_m } be a disk system. We say M is a Vietoris-Rips system if D_i∩ D_j ≠∅ for each pair i,j∈{1,2,…, m}. 
Moreover, if the disk system M has the nonempty intersection property ⋂_D_i ∈ M D_i ≠∅, then M is called a Čech system.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let m≥ 2 be an integer. An m-constellation on 𝒮_g 
is a map on 𝒮_g, together  with a colouring of its faces in black and white
such that:


  (i)
only faces of different colours are adjacent.

  (ii)
black faces have degree m, and white faces have a degree which is a 
multiple of m.

  (iii)
every vertex can be given a label in {1,…,m} such that around every black face, 
the labels of the vertices read in clockwise order are exaclty 1,…,m.

A map that satisfies conditions (i) and (ii) is called a
m-hypermap.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
(see Figure <ref>)
A white split-edge is an edge that links a white
unlabelled vertex to a pair formed by two flags, each one lying on one side of the edge, as in
Figure <ref>. Each flag is labelled by integer. If those labels are
l_1 and l_2, in clockwise order around the unlabelled vertex, the quantity
l_2-l_1+1 is called the type of the split-edge. The same definition
holds for black split-edges , but in this case the type is defined as
l_1-l_2-1.

A white elementary star is a star formed by a central white unlabelled
vertex, which is connected to a certain number of labelled vertices, and to a
certain number of white split edges, and that satisfies the property iii-w of Definition <ref>. Elementary stars are considered up to
translation of the labels. 

The same definition holds for black elementary stars, up to replacing “white”
by “black” and property iii-w by property iii-b.
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that a split-edge is special if its type is not equal to m. A
star is special if it contains at least one split-edge, and
standard otherwise.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
(see Figure <ref>)
A cell of type 0 is a standard elementary white star of degree multiple
of m, which carries two distinguished labelled vertices: 
the in one and the out one.

 The increment of a cell of
type 0 is the difference l_-l_ of the labels of its out and in vertices. Its size is its number of 
split-edges, and its total degree is its degree as an elementary star
(i.e. the degree of the central vertex).

A chain of type 0 is a finite sequence of cells type 0. Its
size and increment are defined additively from the size and increment of the
cells it contains. Its in vertex (resp out vertex) is the in
vertex of its first cell (resp. out vertex of its last cell).
word_labels: O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: cell of type 0;in;out;increment;size;total degree;chain of type 0;in;out

sentence:
(see Figure <ref>)
Let τ∈ 1,m-1.
A cell of type τ is a pair
(𝔰_1,𝔰_2) where:

- 𝔰_1 is an elementary white star, with exactly two
special split-edges: the in one, of type τ, and the out
one, of type m-τ.

- 𝔰_2 is an elementary black star, with exactly two
special split-edges: the in one, of type m-τ, and the out
one, of type τ.

 On pictures, we identify the two split-edges of type m-τ, as in
Figure <ref>. 
The in split-edge of the cell is the in
split-edge of 𝔰_1, and its out split-edge is the out
split-edge of 𝔰_2 ; the corresponding labels l_ and
l_ are defined with the convention of Figure <ref>. The
increment of the cell is the difference l_ - l_.

A chain of type τ is a finite sequence 𝔠 of cells of type
τ. On pictures, we glue the flags of the out split-edge of a cell with the
flags of the in split-edge of the following cell, as in Figure <ref>. The
increment of the chain is the sum of the increment of the cells it
contains. We let |𝔠| denote the total number of labelled vertices
appearing in 𝔠. We also let ⟨𝔠⟩ be the
total number of black vertices appearing in 𝔠 plus its total
number of split-edges of type m (equivalently, ⟨𝔠⟩ is the total number of black vertices of 𝔠 if
one links each split-edge of type m to a new univalent black vertex).

sentence:
A scheme of genus g is a rooted map 𝔰 of genus g, which
has only one face, and whose all vertices have degree ≥ 3. The set of schemes of genus
g is denoted 𝒮_g.

sentence:
We say that the quadruple 

    (𝔰,τ,F,𝔞)=
    (
    𝔰,
    (τ(e))_e∈ E(𝔰),
    (F(v))_v∈ V(𝔰),
    (𝔞_1(e),𝔞_2(e))_e∈ E(𝔰))
 is the
decorated scheme of 𝔱.

sentence:
We say that the quintuple (𝔰,τ,F,𝔞,λ) is the
full scheme of 𝔱.

sentence:
A dominant pair of genus g is a pair (𝔰,λ), where
𝔰 is a rooted scheme of genus g with 6g-3 edges and 4g-2
vertices of degree 3, and λ is bijection:
V(𝔰)→ 0, 4g-3. 

The set of all dominant pairs of genus g is denoted 𝒫_g.

sentence:
A linear [n,n-r]_q code has covering radius R and is denoted as an [n,n-r]_qR code if any of the following equivalent properties holds:

  (i) The value R
 is the least integer such that the space _q^ n is covered by
the spheres of radius R centered at the codewords.

(ii)
Every column of _q^ r is equal to a linear combination of at most R columns
of a parity check matrix of the code, and R is the smallest value with
this property.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.>
The length function ℓ_q(r,R) is the smallest
length of a q-ary linear code of codimension r and covering radius R.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.>
  A linear covering code is called locally optimal
if one cannot remove any column from its parity check matrix without an increase in covering radius.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
<cit.>, <cit.>, <cit.> Let 0≤ℓ≤ R. An [n,n-r]_qR code  is called an (R,ℓ)-object and is denoted by [n,n-r]_qR,ℓ code if any of the following equivalent conditions holds:

(i) The space _q^ n is covered by the spherical (R,ℓ)-capsules centered at the codewords.

(ii) Every column of the space _q^ r (including
the zero column) is equal to a linear combination with nonzero
coefficients of at least ℓ and at most R distinct columns of
a parity-check matrix of the code.

(iii) Every coset of the code (including the code itself) contains a weight w word of the space _q^ n such that ℓ≤ w≤ R.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: An [n,n-r]_qR,R code is called surface-covering code of radius R.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence: A   ρ-saturating set in (N,q)  is minimal if it does not contain a smaller ρ-saturating   set in (N,q).
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let S be a ρ-saturating set in (N,q).
A point A∈ S is ρ-essential if S∖{A} is no longer a ρ-saturating set. A point A∈ S is ρ-essential for a set _ρ(A)⊂(N,q) if all points of  _ρ(A) are not ρ-covered by S∖{A}. We denote by _ρ(A) a set such that _ρ(A)⊆_ρ(A)⊂(N,q).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X be a smooth projective surface. We say that X has the bounded negativity property if there exists an integer b(X) such that for every reduced curve C ⊂ X one has the bound

    C^2≥ -b(X).
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let X be a smooth minimal complex projective surfaces of general type. The number

    c_1^2(X)/c_2(X)∈ [1/5, 3]

is called the Chern slope of X .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Star of the skeleton T at v ∈ V (T) is defined as the subtree of T consisting of the hyperedges of T incident to v. The vertex v is called the center of this star.
word_labels: B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let us define a graph G(T ) consisting of all the pairs covered by the hyperedges of the skeleton T. For a vertex v ∈ V (T ) and a vertex pair {x, y} such that xy ∈ E(G(T)), we say {x, y}  is opposite to v if x and y are at equal distance from v in G(T). This equal distance is also called the distance between v and the opposite pair {x, y}.
	
	Note that every hyperedge of T contains exactly one pair opposite to v.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a linear path {p_0q_0p_1, p_1q_1p_2, p_2q_2p_3, …, p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1, p_k-1q_k-1p_k} of length k in H and a skeleton containing it, the set of hyperedges of this skeleton which contain p_1 (respectively p_k-1) except p_1q_1p_2 (respectively except p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1) is called as a windmill at p_1 (respectively p_k-1) and the size of this set is called the size of the windmill. In other words, windmill at p_1 is a star at p_1 minus the hyperedge p_1q_1p_2 (and similarly, windmill at p_k-1 is a star at p_k-1 minus the hyperedge p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1).

So there are two windmills corresponding to a linear path of length k and a skeleton containing it. The windmill of smaller size among the two is referred as the smaller windmill. If they are of same size, then either one can be considered as the smaller windmill. 

Note that as we assumed k ≥ 3, the two windmills do not have any hyperedges in common.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O

sentence:
A linear tree is a hypergraph obtained from a vertex by repeatedly adding hyperedges that intersect the previous hypergraph in exactly one vertex. 
	

	
	 A linear path 𝒫 of length k ≥ 0 is an alternating sequence v_1,h_1,v_2,h_2,...,h_k, v_k+1 of distinct vertices and distinct hyperedges such that h_i ∩ h_i+1 = {v_i+1} for each i ∈{1,2,…,k-1}, v_1 ∈ h_1, v_k+1∈ h_k and h_i ∩ h_j= ∅ if j-i≥ 2. The vertex set V(𝒫) of 𝒫 is ∪^k_i=1 h_i or {v_1} if k = 0.
	 
	  We say that 𝒫 is a linear path between/joining v_1 and v_k+1 or in general, between vertex sets A and B if v_1 ∈ A, v_k+1∈ B, h_i ∩ A = ∅ for 2 ≤ i ≤ k and h_i ∩ B = ∅ for 1 ≤ i ≤ k-1. Typically A and B are (vertex sets of) hyperedges or one element sets.
	
	A linear cycle of length k ≥ 3 is an alternating sequence v_1,h_1,v_2,h_2,...,v_k, h_k of distinct vertices and distinct hyperedges such that h_i ∩ h_i+1 = {v_i+1} for each i ∈{1,2,…,k-1}, h_1 ∩ h_k = {v_1} and h_i ∩ h_j= ∅ if 1 < j-i < k-1.
	
	A skeleton T in H is a linear subtree of H which cannot be extended to a larger linear subtree by adding a hyperedge e of H for which e ∩ V(T) = 1.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a vertex v ∈ V(H) and a hyperedge abc ∈ E(H) such that v ∉{a,b,c}, we say that v is “strongly associated" to abc if at least two of the three edges vab, vbc, vca are in E(H) . We say that v is “weakly associated" to abc if exactly one of the three edges vab, vbc, vca is in E(H). We say that v is associated to abc if it is either strongly or weakly associated.
	
	The set of pairs {{x,y}⊂{a,b,c}| vxy ∈ E(H) } is called the “support" of v in abc, denoted s_abc(v) and these hyperedges vxy are called  “supporting" hyperedges of v in abc.

sentence: Let h_1 =abc, h_2 =bde where h_1, h_2 ∈ E(T). If there is no hyperedge h ∈ H such that h ∩ (h_1 ∪ h_2) = 2, then the set of vertices {a,b,c,d,e} is called a special block of T.

sentence:
[star]
	
	Star of the skeleton T at v ∈ V (T) is defined as the subtree of T consisting of the hyperedges of T incident to v. The vertex v is called the center of this star.

sentence:
[opposite pair]
	
	Let us define a graph G(T ) consisting of all the pairs covered by the hyperedges of the skeleton T. For a vertex v ∈ V (T ) and a vertex pair {x, y} such that xy ∈ E(G(T)), we say {x, y}  is opposite to v if x and y are at equal distance from v in G(T). This equal distance is also called the distance between v and the opposite pair {x, y}.
	
	Note that every hyperedge of T contains exactly one pair opposite to v.

sentence:

Given a linear path {p_0q_0p_1, p_1q_1p_2, p_2q_2p_3, …, p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1, p_k-1q_k-1p_k} of length k in H and a skeleton containing it, the set of hyperedges of this skeleton which contain p_1 (respectively p_k-1) except p_1q_1p_2 (respectively except p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1) is called as a windmill at p_1 (respectively p_k-1) and the size of this set is called the size of the windmill. In other words, windmill at p_1 is a star at p_1 minus the hyperedge p_1q_1p_2 (and similarly, windmill at p_k-1 is a star at p_k-1 minus the hyperedge p_k-2q_k-2p_k-1).

So there are two windmills corresponding to a linear path of length k and a skeleton containing it. The windmill of smaller size among the two is referred as the smaller windmill. If they are of same size, then either one can be considered as the smaller windmill. 

Note that as we assumed k ≥ 3, the two windmills do not have any hyperedges in common.

sentence:
Let χ∈^n and ϵ∈{ -, + }. We say that χ is a weighted
intriguing set if χ∈⟨ j ⟩⊥ V^ϵ. If χ is a 0-1-vector,
then we say that χ is an intriguing set . We call a weighted intriguing set χ in
⟨ j ⟩⊥ V_- a weighted ovoid . We call a weighted intriguing set χ in
⟨ j ⟩⊥ V_+ a weighted tight set . We say that a collection of intriguing
sets have the same type if they are either all weighted ovoids, or if they are all weighted
tight sets.

sentence:
[Crystal operators on fillings]
Let F ∈(λ/μ) and define the crystal biword W̃,
with entry ([ j; c ]) appearing in W̃
if and only if there is a box with value j in column c.
The entries in W̃ are then sorted decreasingly, primarily on the bottom row entry ,
see <ref>. 
Note that this is map to W̃ is invertible if λ/μ is fixed.
We then define _i(F), and _i(F) as the result when applying 
e_i and f_i, respectively, on the first row of W̃.

For the subset of coinversion-free fillings F with (F)=0, 
these operators are essentially a generalization of the raising– and lowering 
operators defined on semistandard Young tableaux.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[As in <cit.>]
Let  be a k-tuple of skew Young diagrams. Given such a tuple, we let 
() = (^1) ×(^2)×…×(^k)
where (λ/μ) is the set of skew semistandard Young tableaux of shape λ/μ.
Given T = (T^1,T^2,…,T^k) ∈(),
let ^T ^T^1…^T^k where ^T^i
is the same monomial weight of T^i as for Schur polynomials.
Given a cell u = (r,c) (row, column) in a skew diagram, the content 
is defined as c(u) c-r. 

Entries T^i(u) > T^j(v) in a tuple form an inversion if and only if

    i<j and c(u) = c(v),   or  i>j and c(u) = c(v)-1.

The LLT polynomial associated with the k-tuple  is given by

    _(;q) = ∑_T ∈()  q^(T)^T

where (T) is the total number of inversions appearing in T.
One can show that _(;q) is a symmetric function, see <cit.> or 
<cit.> for short proofs.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

  or v=1 we call it trivial .

sentence:
[Theorem 1.5.1, <cit.>] 
Let G=(V,E) be a graph with at least two vertices. Then the maximal strong submodules ( m.s.s. ) of G form a partition of V and exactly one of the following conditions hold:

	
  Parallel case G is not connected. Then its m.s.s. are its connected components.
	
  Serial case G is not connected. Then the m.s.s. of G are the connected components of G.
	
  Prime case Both G and G are connected. Then there is a subset U⊂ V such that
		
			
  * #U > 3,
			
  * G_U is a maximal prime subgraph of G,
			
  * and every m.s.s. M of G has # M∩ U = 1.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[<cit.>]
	
	
  * A set M ⊂ V is called a module of G if for m_1,m_2 ∈ M and v ∈ V∖ M it holds that vm_1 ∈ G if and only if vm_2 ∈ G.
	
  * A module M is called strong if for every other module N either M∩ N = ∅, M⊂ N or N ⊂ M holds.

sentence:
[<cit.>]

	
  * A π-block is an interval I⊂ [n] such that its image π(I) is again an interval. 
	
  * A π-block is called strong if for every other π-block J either I∩ J = ∅, I⊂ J or J ⊂ I holds.

sentence: We call an inv-decomposition π = τ_1 τ_2 multiplicative if π = τ_1 τ_2 or π = τ_2 τ_1 (multiplication as permutations).

sentence:
[(Gluing of hypertrees)]
Let ℋ=(V,ℰ) be an S(2,l,n)
 Steiner system (i.e., every pair of points is contained in exactly one edge and m=|ℰ|=n2/l2).
Let k≥ 3, and suppose that for each E_i∈ℰ, a k-uniform hypergraph ℱ_i=(E_i, ℰ_i) is given.


  * If for all i=1,2,…, m |ℰ_i| = αl2, then |⋃_i=1^m ℰ_i| = αn2.

  * If for all i=1,2,…, m ℱ_i is an edge-minimal hypertree, then 
ℱ=(V,⋃_i=1^m ℰ_i) is also an edge-minimal hypertree.

In this case, the edge-minimal hypertree ℱ is called the gluing of the edge-minimal hypertrees {ℱ_i: E_i∈ℰ} along the Steiner system ℋ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:

    q=∑_i=1^k∑_j=1^ℓq_ijδ _( x_i,y_j)

in the product space X× X such that

    ∑_i=1^kq_ij=n_j and ∑_j=1^ℓq_ij=m_i

for each i and j. Denote Plan( 𝐚,𝐛) as
the space of all transport plans from 𝐚 to 𝐛.

sentence:
Let k be a positive integer, let G be a finite set and let
S⊂ G^k. The pair (S,G) is said to be a system of configurations of degree k.

sentence:
[System of configurations]
Let k be a positive integer, let G be a finite set and let
S⊂ G^k. The pair (S,G) is said to be a system of configurations of degree k.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O

sentence:
[Varnavides property, V-property]
The system of configurations (S,G) of degree k is said to fulfill
the Varnavides property , or V-property, if for every ε>0 there exist a
γ=γ(ε,k)
such
that, for any X⊂ G with |X|≥ε |G|,

    |X^k∩ S|≥γ |S|.

A sequence of systems {(S_i,G_i)}_i≥ 1 of degree k
is said to satisfy the V-property if γ is the same function for each member of the family and only depends on ε.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A sequence {(S_i,G_i)}_i≥ 1  of configuration systems of degree k  is said to be normal with function γ if

	
  *  The G_i's are finite and growing in size with i.

	
  *  lim_i→∞|G_i|/|S_i|=0 and lim_i→∞|G_i|^k/|S_i|=∞.

	
  *  lim_i→∞|S_i^(k)|/|S_i|=1.
	
  *  Each  (S_i,G_i) satisfies the V–property with a function γ=γ_<ref>(δ ) universal for all the systems in the sequence.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let (S,G) be a system of configurations of degree k.
We say that a set X ⊆ G is the (δ,S)-stable if, for  every subset X' ⊂ X with  |X'| ≥δ |X|, we have  X'^k ∩ S ≠∅.
We also say that X  is (δ,S)_k–stable if in addition X'^k ∩ S^(k)≠∅.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[Concentration for configuration systems]
Let 𝒢={(S_i,G_i)}_i≥ 1 be a sequence of configuration systems with n_i=|G_i|, and let 0≤ p≤ 1 (which may depend on n_i).
We say that  𝒢 is concentrated for p if,
for every ε,ε'>0, there exist an n_0=n_0(ε,ε',k) such that

    ℙ(| |π_U(S_i^(k))∩ [G_i]_p^|U||  - p^|U||π_U(S_i^(k))| |≥ε p^|U||π_U(S_i^(k))|)≤ε',

for each n_i≥ n_0 and each U⊂ [1,k] with |U|≥ 2.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
[ρ-k-uniformity]
	Given ρ>0,
	the system (S,G) is said to be ρ-k-uniform (or ρ-uniform if k is clear from the context) if, for each U⊂ [1,k] with |U|≥ 2, and for each (x_1,…,x_|U|)∈π_U(S^(k)), then
	
    |π^-1_U((x_1,…,x_|U|))∩ S^(k)|≥ρmax_(y_1,…,y_|U|)∈π_U(S^(k)){|π^-1_U((y_1,…,y_|U|))∩ S^(k)|}.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A crystal graph of some crystal ℬ is a directed, edge colored (with colors i ∈ I) graph with vertices in ℬ satisfying the following:


  * all monochromatic directed paths have finite length,

  * for every vertex x ∈ℬ and i ∈ I, there is at most one edge z  x, and dually, at most one edge x  y. Here, we say that z=e_i(x) and y=f_i(x).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
We say that an edge colored directed graph, X, is A-regular if the axioms (S1)-(S6) and (S5')-(S6') are satsified:


  (S1) All monochromatic paths in X have finite length.

  (S2) For any vertex x ∈ X, there is at most one incoming edge, z  x, colored i and at most one outgoing edge, x  y colored i. Here, we say that z = e_i(x) and y = f_i(x), where e_i and f_i are crystal operators .

We can define the i-string through x to be:

    f_i^-d(x) →⋯→ f_i^-1(x) → x → f_i(x) →⋯→ f_i^r(x).
 
We can then define the i-rise of x to be ε_i(x) := r and the i-depth of x to be δ_i(x) := -d. To measure the effect of the crystal operators e_i and f_i on the j-rise and j-depth of each vertex, we define the difference operators Δ_i to be:

    Δ_iδ_j(x) = δ_j(e_i(x)) - δ_j(x),   Δ_iε_j(x) = ε_j(e_i(x)) - ε_j(x),

whenever e_i(x) is defined, and

    ∇_iδ_j(x) = δ_j(x) - δ_j(f_i(x)),   ∇_iε_j(x) = ε_j(x) - ε_j(f_i(x)),

whenever f_i(x) is defined.


  (S3) For a fixed x ∈ X and i,j ∈ I such that e_i(x) is defined, we require Δ_iδ_j(x) + Δ_iε_j(x) = a_ij,

  (S4) For a fixed x ∈ X and i,j ∈ I such that e_i(x) is defined, we require Δ_iδ_j(x) ≤ 0 and Δ_iε_j(x) ≤ 0.

  (S5) For a fixed x ∈ X such that e_i(x) and e_j(x) are both defined, we require that Δ_iδ_j(x) = 0 implies e_ie_j(x) = e_je_i(x) and ∇_jε_i(y) = 0 where y = e_ie_j(x) = e_je_i(x).

  (S6) For a fixed x ∈ X such that e_i(x) and e_j(x) are both defined, we require that Δ_iδ_j(x) = Δ_jδ_i(x) = -1 implies e_ie_j^2e_i(x) = e_je_i^2e_j(x) and ∇_iε_j(y) = ∇_jε_i(y) = -1 where y = e_ie_j^2e_i(x) = e_je_i^2e_j(x).  


Dually, we have the additional two requirements for X to be A-regular ,


  (S5') ∇_iε_j(x) = 0 implies f_if_j(x) = f_jf_i(x) and Δ_jδ_i(y) = 0 where y = f_if_j(x) = f_jf_i(x).

  (S6') ∇_iε_j(x) = ∇_jε_i(x) = -1 implies f_if_j^2f_i(x) = f_jf_i^2f_j(x) and Δ_iδ_j(y) = Δ_jδ_i(y) where y = f_if_j^2f_i(x) = f_jf_i^2f_j(x).

sentence: If we have an x such that (S5') holds, then we say there is a degree two Stembridge relation upward from x, namely f_if_j(x) = f_jf_i(x). Similarly, if we have an x such that (S6') holds, we say there is a degree four Stembridge relation upward from x, namely f_if_j^2f_i(x) = f_jf_i^2f_j(x). Dually, if we have an x such that (S5) holds, then we say there is a degree two Stembridge relation downward from x. Similarly, if we have an x such that (S6) holds, we say there is a degree four Stembridge relation downward from x.

plain_text_term: degree two Stembridge relation;degree four Stembridge relation

sentence:
If we have x ∈ℬ such that 
    f_if_j^3f_i(x) = f_jf_if_jf_if_j(x) = f_j^2f_i^2f_j(x),
 then we say there is a degree five Sternberg relation upward from x. Similarly, if we have x ∈ℬ such that 
    f_if_j^3f_i^2f_j(x) = f_if_j^2f_if_jf_if_j(x) = f_jf_i^2f_j^3f_i(x) = f_jf_if_jf_if_j^2f_i(x),
 then we say that there is a degree seven Sternberg relation upward from x. Dually, when these relations occur involving the e_i's, we say we have a degree five or degree seven Sternberg relation downward from x.

plain_text_term: degree five Sternberg relation;degree seven Sternberg relation

sentence:
A discrete Morse function on a simplicial complex Δ is a function f: Δ→ such that for each d-dimensional simplex, α^(d)∈Δ,


  * | {β^(d+1)⊇α | f(β) ≤ f(α) } | ≤ 1,

  * | {γ^(d-1)⊆α | f(γ) ≥ f(α) }| ≤ 1.

sentence: A simplex α is called a critical cell if | {β^(d+1)⊇α | f(β) ≤ f(α) } | = 0 and | {γ^(d-1)⊆α | f(γ) ≥ f(α) }| = 0. Equivalently, a simplex α is called a critical cell if it is left unmatched by the matching on the face poset.

sentence: Let ℬ be the crystal of a highest weight representation of finite classical Cartan type. Let [u,v] ⊆ℬ. If ℬ is of simply laced type and all relations among crystal operators within [u,v] are implied by Stembridge relations, then we say that [u,v] is a Stembridge only interval . If ℬ is of doubly laced type and all relations among crystal operators are implied by Stembridge or Sternberg relations, then we say that [u,v] is a Stembridge and Sternberg only interval .

plain_text_term: Stembridge only interval;Stembridge and Sternberg only interval

sentence: We define a saturated chain C to be greedily maximal if given any x along C where the edge created by applying f_i to x along C is the start of a minimal skipped interval involving the crystal operators f_i and f_j, we have that f_j is the maximal operator for f_i at x.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let ℬ be the crystal of a highest weight representation of type D_n. Let [u,v] ⊆ℬ be a Stembridge only interval. Let x be a vertex on a fully covered saturated chain C from u to v. We say that x is an (n,n-2)-special vertex if there is an n-edge upward from x along C which is the start of a minimal skipped interval for the interval system of C and the number of times f_n needs to be applied along C from f_n(x) to v is nonzero.

sentence:
Given a pair (A,B) of subets of _N, define the closure of
A (relative to B) to be A+B and the interior to be {x:x+B⊂ A}.
Denote these by A^+ and A^-, respectively.
Define the boundary of A to be A^+∖ A^- and denote it 
by ∂ A.

sentence:
Let B be a Bohr set and let q be a quadratic form on
B. Let B' be a Bohr set such that 2B'-2B'⊂ B
and let P be a subset of B'. 
The rank of the local quadratic phase function
h(x)=B(x)ω^q(x) relative to P is log(1/α),
where α is the quantity

    |_a,a',b,b'∈ Pω^q(a+b-a'-b')-q(a-a')-q(b-b')|

If Q is a generalized quadratic average with base (B,q), then we define
the rank of Q relative to P to be the rank of 
the local quadratic phase function B(x)ω^q(x) relative
to P.

sentence: For nonempty subsets L and R of a group G, a two-sided group digraph 2S(G;L,R) has vertex set G and a directed arc (g,h) from g to h if and only if h=l^-1gr for some l∈ L and r∈ R.

sentence: Let S be a nonempty subset of a group G. A word in S of (finite) length n>0 is a string s_1s_2 ⋯ s_n where s_1,s_2, …, s_n ∈ S.  In general, we denote a word in S of length n by w_S,n and write 𝒲(S) for the set containing all finite length words in S.

sentence: If g and h are vertices in a digraph, then g is strongly connected to h if there exists a directed path from g to h and a directed path from h to g. A digraph is strongly connected if every pair of vertices is strongly connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: In a digraph, a vertex g is weakly connected to vertex h if there is a path g_0, g_1, ⋯, g_n such that g=g_0, h=g_n, and  either (g_i-1, g_i) or (g_i, g_i-1) is an arc of the digraph.  A digraph is weakly connected if each pair of its vertices is weakly connected.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The minimum weak connection length in G relative to (L,R) is the minimum length k of a word purely in L, L^-1, R, or R^-1 that is weakly connected to e, and is infinite if there is no such minimum. 
Algebraically this is equivalent to the minimum length of a word w purely in L, L^-1, R, or R^-1 such that e=W_L̅,m,awW_R̅,a,m for some a,m ∈ℕ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: minimum weak connection length in G relative to (L,R)

sentence:
Assuming that 𝒲(L) and 𝒲(R) are subgroups of G, the minimum strong connection length in G relative to (L,R) is the minimum length k of a word purely in L, L^-1, R, or R^-1 that is strongly connected to e, and is infinite if there is no such minimum. 
Algebraically this is equivalent to the minimum length of a word v purely in L, L^-1, R, or R^-1 such that e=w_L^-1,nvw_R,n for some n ∈ℕ.

plain_text_term: minimum strong connection length in G relative to (L,R)

sentence:
The minimum weak connection length in ⟨ L ⟩ s ⟨ R ⟩ is the minimum length k_s of a word w purely in L or L^-1 such that ws ∼ s in 2S(G;L,R), or the minimum length k_s of a word w purely in R or R^-1 such that sw ∼ s in 2S(G;L,R).  Take k_s to be infinite if there is no such minimum. 
Algebraically this is equivalent to the minimum length of a word w purely in L or L^-1 such that s=W_L̅,m,awsW_R̅,a,m for some a, m ∈ℕ, or the minimum length of a word w purely in R or R^-1 such that s=W_L̅,m,aswW_R̅,a,m for some a, m ∈ℕ.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: minimum weak connection length in ⟨ L ⟩ s ⟨ R ⟩

sentence:
Assuming that 𝒲(L) and 𝒲(R) are subgroups of G, the minimum strong connection length in ⟨ L ⟩ s ⟨ R ⟩ is the minimum length k_s of a word w purely in L or L^-1 such that ws is strongly connected to s in 2S(G;L,R), or the minimum length k_s of a word w purely in R or R^-1 such that sw is strongly connected to s in the two-sided group digraph 2S(G;L,R).  Take k_s to be infinite if there is no such minimum. 
Algebraically this is equivalent to the minimum length of a word v purely in L or L^-1 such that s=w_L^-1,nvsw_R,n for some n ∈ℕ, or the minimum length of a word v purely in R or R^-1 such that s=w_L^-1,nsvw_R,n for some n ∈ℕ.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A symplectic link pattern (slp for short) of size k is a symplectic oriented link pattern, such that every arrow is oriented from right to left and every loop is oriented counterclockwise. 
In the same way, the natural notion of orthogonal link pattern (orlp for short)
 enhanced symplectic and enhanced orthogonal link pattern is obtained.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A symplectic oriented link pattern (solp for short) of size l consists of a  set of l vertices 1,2,⋯ l together with a collection of oriented arrows between these vertices and a collection of oriented arrows with dots between these vertices, such that


  (B) every vertex is touched by at most one arrow;

  (SpOr) there are no loops of arrows without dots (that is, no arrows without dots from a vertex to itself).

We denote by _l the set of solps of size l.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An orthogonal oriented link pattern (oolp for short) of size l consists of a  set of l 
 vertices 1,2,⋯ l together with a collection of oriented arrows between these vertices and a collection of oriented arrows with dots between these vertices, such that


  (B) every vertex is touched by at most one arrow;

  (SpOr) there are no loops of arrows without dots (that is, no arrows without dots from a vertex to itself).

  (Or) there are no loops of arrows with dots (that is, no arrows with dots from a vertex to itself).

We denote by _l the set of oolps of size l.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An enhanced symplectic oriented link pattern (esolp. for short) of size k of type (b_1,...,b_k) consists of a  set of k vertices 1,2,⋯,k together with a collection of oriented arrows between different vertices, unoriented loops and oriented arrows with dots between arbitrary vertices. 

Denote by x_i  the number of sources of arrows, by y_i the number of targets of arrows, by z_i the number of unoriented loops and by l_i the number of loops with dots at vertex i.
Then the following condition defines an esolp of such kind:


  (Sp) x_i+y_i+z_i-l_i≤ b_i holds for  each vertex i.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An enhanced orthogonal oriented link pattern (esolp. for short) of size k of type (b_1,...,b_k) consists of a  set of k vertices 1,2,⋯,k together with a collection of oriented arrows and oriented arrows with dots between these vertices. 

Denote by x_i  the number of sources of arrows, by y_i the number of targets of arrows and by z_i the number of unoriented loops at vertex i.
Then the following condition defines an eoolp of such kind:


  (SO) x_i+y_i+2z_i≤ b_i holds for  each vertex i.

A symplectic link pattern (slp for short) of size k is a symplectic oriented link pattern, such that every arrow is oriented from right to left and every loop is oriented counterclockwise. 
In the same way, the natural notion of orthogonal link pattern (orlp for short)
 enhanced symplectic and enhanced orthogonal link pattern is obtained.

sentence: Let h∈. The Fock space representation _h of the Heisenberg algebra is, by definition, the representation induced from a 1-dimensional representation T_h of the subalgebra ⊗ℂ[t]⊕ℂK⊂, where K acts by 1, and h'⊗ p(t) acts by the scalar (h,h')p(0). The basis element of the distinguished copy of T_h inside the induced representation is called the vacuum vector of the Fock space and is denoted by v_h.

sentence:
We call a monomial
 
    e_h,𝐩,𝐢=v_h e_p_1[i_1]… e_p_s[i_s]

admissible , if the following conditions are satisfied:

 
  * i_1≤-(h,f_p_1);
 
  * i_m+1≤ i_m+1 for all m=1,…,s-1;
 
  * if i_m+1=i_m+1, then p_m≤ p_m+1.

Clearly, 
 
    v_h e_p_1[-(h,f_1)]e_p_2[i_2]… e_p_s[i_s]=v_h+f_1 e_p_2[i_2]… e_p_s[i_s],

and in this case we think of these monomials as of the same monomial. Throughout this paper we mean by an admissible monomial the class of pairwise equal admissible monomials; we hope it will not lead to a confusion.

sentence:

  * run-complete if for any multiset  of decreasing sequences, 
we have ()⊆ or ()∩=∅, i.e., 
if  contains a word in () then  contains every words in ();


  * reverse-complete if the reverse word ẘ is in  whenever w ∈.

sentence:
Given two words w and w' in , w is said to be below w'
 if every letter in w is smaller than every letter in w'. The partial order ≪
on  is defined as follows:  

    w ≪ w' w=w' or w is below w'.

Two words w and w' are said to be comparable if  w≪ w' or w≫ w', 
otherwise they are incomparable .

sentence: Let r>2 and m = (m_1, …, m_n) ∈ (Z_r)^n for some n∈. Then we let rm be the matrix satisfying that rmij is the number of directed paths in rm from the 0-vertex of the ith subgraph to the 0-vertex of the jth subgraph that does not pass through the 0-vertex of any other subgraph. We call a path that satisfies these criteria legal .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence: Let r>2 and m = (m_1, …, m_n) ∈ (Z_r)^n for some n∈. Then we let rm be the matrix satisfying that rm⟨ i, j⟩ is the number of directed paths on rm from the 0-vertex of the ith subgraph to the 0-vertex of the jth subgraph which do not exclusively visit 0-vertices and which do not visit the 0-vertex of any other subgraph except if all the following vertices of the path are 0-vertices. We will call a path that satisfies these criteria legal .

sentence: An m-leaf parent is an internal vertex, v, of an m-ary tree such that v has exactly m children, all of which are leaves.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence: Let S be a set of words on the alphabet {1, …, m}, such that no word is a prefix of another word in S. Namely, S is an arbitrary set of words describing an m-ary tree.  We write A(m) for the set of all such sets S.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O

sentence: If x∈ V and y,z∼ x, we say that y and z are linked if there is a vertex w≠ x so that y∼ w∼ z.  We write y≈ z if y and z are linked and y≉z if not.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let u,w be two neighbors of x.  The linkage of u and w is calculated by summing over all vertices z≠ x for which u∼ z∼ w: 
    l(u,w) = ∑_z 1/|{y: x∼ y∼ z}|
word_labels: O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For a non-negative integer s, a drawing D of K_n is s-bishellable if there exist sequences a_0,a_1,…,a_s and b_s,b_s-1,…,b_1,b_0, each sequence consisting of distinct vertices of K_n, so that, with respect to a reference face F:

	
  * for each i=0,1,2,…,s, the vertex a_i is incident with the face of D-{a_0,a_1,…,a_i-1} that contains F;
	
  * for each i=0,1,2,…,s, the vertex b_i is incident with the face of D-{b_0,b_1,…,b_i-1} that contains F; and
	
  * for each i=0,1,…,s, the set {a_0,a_1,… a_i}∩{b_s-i,b_s-i-1,…,b_0} = ∅.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A code C≤_RR^n is said to be modular if there exists
  r∈ such that for all points gR of (R^k_R) either
  α_C(gR)=0 or
  α_C(gR)=rgR^×. The number r is
  called the index of C.
word_labels: O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O

sentence:
The right linear code C'≤ R^b_1_R generated by the columns of
  M_1 is called the dual of the two-weight code C .

sentence:
For a rank d matroid M with ground set E={1,…,m} 
 the realization space of M over ℂ is  
 the set ℛ_ℂ(M) of matrices A∈ M_d,m(ℂ) 
 that satisfy the following condition: 
 
  
  * A realizes M over ℂ.
 
We endow ℛ_ℂ(M) with the subspace topology 
of M_d,m(ℂ).

sentence:
For a rank d matroid M with ground set E={1,…,m} and 
 {1,…,d} as basis, the reduced realization space of M 
over ℂ is the set ℛ_ℂ^R(M) of matrices 
A∈ M_d,m(ℂ) that satisfy the following 
 conditions:

 
  
  *  A realizes M over ℂ, that is, A belongs to 
                   ℛ_ℂ(M);
  
  *  A is of the form (I_d|Ã.), 
                   where I_d is the d × d identity matrix;
  
  *  The entries of Ã that are in the normal frame 
                   𝒫_Ã equal 1. 
 

 We endow ℛ_ℂ^R(M) with the subspace topology 
of M_d,m(ℂ).

sentence:
[Realization space]
 For a rank d matroid M with ground set E={1,…,m} 
 the realization space of M over ℂ is

sentence:
[Isotopic arrangements]
 A smooth one-parameter family of arrangements 𝒜_t 
 is an isotopy if for any t_1 and t_2 the 
 arrangements 𝒜_t_1 and 𝒜_t_2 have the same 
 combinatorial type.
 In this case we say that 𝒜_t_1 and 𝒜_t_2 are 
isotopic .
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O

sentence:
[Milnor fiber and fibration]
 Given linear forms α_i∈(ℂ^d)^∗ with 
H_i=α_i, the polynomial Q_𝒜 = 
∏_i=1^mα_i is homogeneous of degree m and can be considered as 
a map 


    Q_𝒜:M(𝒜)⟶ℂ^∗


that is the projection of a fiber bundle called the Milnor fibration of 
the arrangement (see <cit.>). The Milnor fiber is then the 
fiber F_𝒜=Q_𝒜^-1(1).

 {1,…,d} as basis, the reduced realization space of M 
over ℂ is the set ℛ_ℂ^R(M) of matrices 
A∈ M_d,m(ℂ) that satisfy the following

                   ℛ_ℂ(M);
  
  *  A is of the form (I_d|Ã.),

  *  The entries of Ã that are in the normal frame 
                   𝒫_Ã equal 1. 
 

 We endow ℛ_ℂ^R(M) with the subspace topology 
of M_d,m(ℂ).

sentence:
For a rank d matroid M with ground set E={1,…,m} and {1,…,d} as basis the reduced variety
 of M over ℂ is the quasi-projective variety X_M defined by
 
    X_M={(
            z_1,…,z_s_M)
           ∈𝔸_ℂ^s_M|
            [ (G_M^j_1|⋯|G_M^j_d)≠0                    if         {j_1,…,j_d}∈𝔅; (G_M^j_1|⋯|G_M^j_d)=0                    if         {j_1,…,j_d}∉𝔅;                       ].
           }

where G_M^j is the j-th column of G_M and 𝔅 denotes the set of bases of M.

We now define the tropical volume of A as the expression

    A  :=  |⊕_σ∈(d)∑ a_i,σ(i) - ⊕_τ∈((d)-σ_opt)∑ a_i,τ(i)|  ,

where σ_opt is an optimal solution of the first optimization in the above.

sentence:
Let A∈^d× m.
The upper and lower dequantized tropical volumes of A are defined by

    ^+ A:= sup{| = A}  and  ^- A:= inf{| = A},

respectively.

sentence:
An RN graph (X,R,N,≤) consists of a linear order ≤ on X and two acyclic
relations R, N ⊆ X× X which are 

 
  *  disjoint (i.e., R∩ N = ∅) and
 
  *  compatible with ≤ (i.e., both R⊆ ≤ and N⊆ ≤).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For two RN graphs A and B an embedding from A to B is an injective map 
f X(A)→ X(B) such that 


  ∙ (x,y) ∈ R(A)  (f(x),f(y)) ∈ R(B),

  ∙ (x,y) ∈ N(A)  (f(x),f(y)) ∈ N(B),

  ∙ and x ≤_A y   f(x)≤_B f(y).
word_labels: O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A bad quasicycle of length j≥ 2 in an RN graph (X,R,N,≤) consists 
of j vertices x=x_1,x_2, …, x_j = y with (x_i,x_i+1)∈ R for i=1,2,…, j-1 
and (x,y)∈ N.
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
For an integer ℓ≥ 2 the RN graph (X,R,N,≤) is called an ℓ-RN graph 
if it does not contain a bad quasicycle of length j for any j∈ [2, ℓ].
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
An ordered A-partite RN graph E is an RN graph with 
a distinguished partition X(E) = X_1(E) … X_p(E)
of its vertex set satisfying


  *  
(x, y)∈ R(E)∩(X_i(E)× X_j(E))    ⟹    (v_i, v_j)∈ R(A),

  *  
(x, y)∈ N(E)∩(X_i(E)× X_j(E))    ⟹    (v_i, v_j)∈ N(A),

  *  and X_1(E) <_E X_2(E) <_E … <_E  X_p(E).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
A closure operator  , τ:2^E→2^E, is a map
satisfying the closure axioms:

C1: X⊆τ(X)

C2: X⊆ Y⇒τ(X)⊆τ(Y)

C3: τ(τ(X))=τ(X).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The set system (E,ℱ) is a closure space if it satisfies
the following properties

(1) ∅∈ℱ, E∈ℱ

(2) X,Y∈ℱ implies X∩ Y∈ℱ.
word_labels: O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
The operator ex:ℱ→2^E satisfies the heritage
property ifX⊆ Y implies ex(Y)∩ X⊆ ex(X)
for all X,Y∈ℱ.
word_labels: O O O O O B-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Given a graph G and a positive integer k,
a set D⊆ V(G) is called a k-step dominating set of G,
if every vertex in G is at a distance at most k from D, i.e. V(G)=D∪(∪_i=1^kN^i(D)).
Further, if G[D] is connected,
we call D a connected k-step dominating set of G.
The connected k-step domination number γ_c^k(G) is the number of
vertices in a minimum connected k-step dominating set of G.
When k=1, we may omit the qualifier “1-step" in the above
names and the superscript 1 in the notation.
word_labels: O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O

sentence:
Let C⊂ be a cone of singularity type 1/r(1,a-1). Let ℓ and w be as above, and write w =n ℓ + ρ with 0 ≤ρ < ℓ. The residue of C is given by

    C:={[ 1/ρℓ(1,ρ a/w - 1)           if ρ 0,;                 ∅           if ρ=0. ].

The singularity content of C is the pair C := (n, C).

sentence:
Let Σ be a complete fan in  with two-dimensional cones C_1,…,C_m, numbered cyclically, with C_i=(n_i,C_i). The singularity content of the corresponding toric surface X_Σ is

    X_Σ:=(n,),

where n:=∑_i=0^m n_i and  is the cyclically ordered list {C_1,…,C_m}, with the empty residues C_i=∅ omitted. We call  the residual basket of X_Σ.

sentence:
For 1≤ j <n, 1≤ k≤ n and m≥ 0, we have the blue formula
	
    h_j^⊥^qC_n,k^(m)    = ∑_s=0^min(j,k-1)q^j-s2mj-s_qs+ms_q q^s·^qC_n-j,k-s^(s+m)
        +∑_s=0^min(j,k-1)q^j-s2mj-s_qs+m-1s-1_q∑_r=0^s+m-1 q^r(^qC_n-j,k-s^(r)+ ^qC_n-j,k-s+1^(r))
        + χ(j≥ k) q^j-k2mj-k_q k+m-1k-1_q  ∑_r=0^k+m-1 q^r·^qC_n-j,1^(r),

	and the red formula
	
    h_j^⊥^qC_n,k^(m)    = ∑_s=0^min(j,k-1)q^j-s2mj-s_qs+ms_q ·^qC_n-j,k-s^(s+m)
        +∑_s=0^min(j,k-1)q^j-s2mj-s_qs+m-1s-1_qq^k-s∑_r=0^s+m-1 q^r(^qC_n-j,k-s^(r)+ ^qC_n-j,k-s+1^(r)) 
        + χ(j≥ k) q^j-k2mj-k_q k+m-1k-1_q  ∑_r=0^k+m-1 q^r·^qC_n-j,1^(r).

	Moreover, replacing q by t everywhere these formulae still hold.

sentence: A Dyck path of size n is a lattice path going from (0,0) to (n,n), using only north and east unit steps and staying weakly above the line x=y (also called the main diagonal ). The set of Dyck paths of size n will be denoted by 𝖣(n). A partially labelled Dyck path is a Dyck path whose vertical steps are labelled with (not necessarily distinct) non-negative integers such that the labels appearing in each column are strictly increasing from bottom to top, and 0 does not appear in the first column. The set of partially labelled Dyck paths with m zero labels and n nonzero labels is denoted by (m,n).
word_labels: O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O B-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM I-MATH_TERM O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O O
plain_text_term: Dyck path;main diagonal;partially labelled Dyck path

sentence:
We define for each D∈(m,n) a monomial in the variables x_1,x_2,…: we set 
    x^P ∏_i=1^n+m x_l_i(P)
 where l_i(D) is the label of the i-th vertical step of D (the first being at the bottom), where we conventionally set x_0 = 1. The fact that x_0 does not appear in the monomial explains the word partially .

sentence: Let D be a (partially labelled) Dyck path of size n+m. We define its area word to be the string of integers a(D) = a_1(D) ⋯ a_n+m(D) where a_i(D) is the number of whole squares in the i-th row (counting from the bottom) between the path and the main diagonal.
